From CurtisE at CurtisE.net  Sat Jun  1 01:22:10 2002
From: CurtisE at CurtisE.net (CurtisE)
Date: Sat, 1 Jun 2002 01:22:10 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Serial console with grub
In-Reply-To: <200206010458.g514wFi28990@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <GJELJBAKILGBFNJHBMKGOEECCEAA.CurtisE@CurtisE.net>

>Okay, I was raised on windows and missed out on all this cool oldtimey
stuff.
>What do you do with this? How does the remote part work, is it connected by
a
>serial cable to another PC? Is this meant to replace a NIC?

Um, no it's not intended to replace the NIC.

Here's a nice example of it's usefulness I did in a previous life (old
timer) while administering a bunch of UNIX servers.

I connected the serial console port of each server to a terminal server,
which is accessible via a remote access server (dial-in, reverse telnet).
Then when my pager goes nuts while I'm at the beach (or a ball game or
whatever) because one of the servers crashed and needs a manual fsck or
something else requiring console access, I connect my PDA to my cell phone
or an analog line, dial in and fix the problem with minimal disruption to
the activity at hand.

Of course, you could also hang a modem directly on the serial port, but then
you would have to dial in even when you're in the office, or swap the modem
our for a VT100 terminal.

Either way, copious security measures are in order when hanging your servers
off of the public telephone network...

CurtisE
Unemployed SIG member :(




From linux at maneuveringspeed.com  Sat Jun  1 03:42:18 2002
From: linux at maneuveringspeed.com (Greg Long)
Date: Sat, 1 Jun 2002 03:42:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] NEW TOPIC:  Hibernate in Linux (Specifically Redhat 7.3)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205312244080.17685-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <002101c20959$00a64070$6401a8c0@endeavor>

No, actually I'm talking about a full suspend-to-disk "Hibernate":

As much as I can join the ranks and diss Windows XP (and there are MANY,
many, reasons to do so, I'm sure we can all agree there)....one very
nice feature is a full hibernate to disk followed by a power off - the
batteries are not drained at all.  When the OS is powered back up, it
resumes where it left off.  This works very well - I only find I have
issues with media playback.  Lengthy DivX threads, etc. will keep going.


This is also nice when I want to leave everything as-is and then reboot
to RedHat 7.3 (dual boot).  Because GRUB is pulled up first, I can
select RH7.3, play around, then shutdown and reboot come back to GRUB,
where I then Select Windows XP and whammo - Windows resumes.

The laptop is a IBM A30 - P3 1ghz, though my fiance's p2-300 does it
well too.

Clearly, anyone who has ever lived as a dual-booting road warrior can
see the advantage of this ;)  I can shut my box down, pack it, travel to
my next appointment (class, in my case) and whammo - I'm back where I
left off.

It's also plain to see that if someone doesn't need to close all apps in
order to do this in Linux and boot to Win, it would be a lot easier to
use it more as a client.  As a result, I never really get around to
using Linux as a client as much as I'd like to.

I didn't mean to turn this into a pitch for developers to start a
project implement this, but I think the advantages for those who who see
Linux as a "movement" or a "cause" are obvious - breaking down barriers
to usage.  At home, I mostly use VNCserver to access my server box.
This works well, though it's a server, and not generally used as a
workstation - plus I don't like the idea of working as root too much for
obvious reasons (one of the inherrent limitations of vncserver).

Greg Long
http://www.maneuveringspeed.com/


-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Shannon C. Dealy
Sent: Friday, May 31, 2002 10:57 PM
To: PLUG
Subject: Re: [PLUG] NEW TOPIC: Hibernate in Linux (Specifically Redhat
7.3)


On Fri, 31 May 2002, Greg Long wrote:

> Anyone successfully get this to work? A number of us like to dual boot

> our laptops, and it would be that much easier to spend more time in 
> Linux (I use Linux mostly as a server, not as a client as much as I'd 
> like to now that available software is getting better and better)
>
> But to the point:  Does this need to be a kernel mod that needs to be 
> recompiled, and how does Gnome/KDE do upon resume?

I assume by "hibernate" that you mean "suspend" where the computer keeps
everything in ram but shuts down the screen, hard drive, CPU, etc., so
you can quickly power-up and pickup where you left off.  I have done
this successfully on my old laptop, but haven't used the feature with
the latest upgrades or gnome (I don't use this laptop much these days).
As far as what you need, it requires APM (advanced power management) be
compiled into the kernel or a kernel module.  There are also some
options to look at which are specific to some poorly behaved laptops
when you select the APM option.  Aside from the kernel option(s), you
need the program "apmd" which provides the interface to the power
management system and does things like reset the Linux time when the
system powers back up and other power management related stuff.  This
setup worked fine for me using fvwm and ice window managers (never tried
Gnome or KDE).

I'm working from memory of an older configuration, so there may be some
differences with the latest stuff, perhaps someone else on the list has
done this more recently.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sat Jun  1 06:26:17 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat, 1 Jun 2002 06:26:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Serial console with grub
In-Reply-To: <200206010458.g514wFi28990@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206010551100.4272-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On Fri, 31 May 2002, Carla Schroder wrote:

> Okay, I was raised on windows and missed out on all this cool
> oldtimey stuff.  What do you do with this? How does the remote part
> work, is it connected by a serial cable to another PC? Is this meant
> to replace a NIC?

Hmm. Where to start...? :-)

Many computers sit in special server rooms or remote locations and run
headless -- without a direct keyboard, monitor, and mouse connection
-- and don't run GUI software on the console. They're plain
command-line interface machines.

Console output isn't sent to a monitor, and input isn't received from
a keyboard; it's all done via a serial port. Sometimes that serial 
port is a modem into which you can dial, but most often these days the 
other end of the serial connection is what's known as a terminal 
server: a computer or appliance with a ton of serial ports.

Obviously, most administration on a server like this is done via 
ethernet. But what happens when you want to replumb the network 
interface, install a new kernel, or go into single-user mode? At that 
point, the ethernet interface will fail you.

So you log into the terminal server (not to be confused with the 
Windows product of the same name) and ask for a console session to the 
host in question. Then you can do any task that would typically 
require a direct keyboard/monitor connection.

Some x86 BIOS implementations even allow you to redirect BIOS-level
output to a serial port, or you can fake it with a product like PC 
Weasel (www.realweasel.com). That way, you can even configure your 
Adaptec card or re-do BIOS settings without being anywhere near the 
computer. I understand that Itanium-class machines have this 
capability natively.

Of course, Intel is a Johnny-come-lately to the server party. Suns, 
Alphas, and other architectures have been fully administerable via 
serial consoles for decades.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

> Okay, I was raised on windows and missed out on all this cool oldtimey stuff. 
> What do you do with this? How does the remote part work, is it connected by a 
> serial cable to another PC? Is this meant to replace a NIC?


This provides remote managment.  Combined with a terminal server you can get 
direct console access from anywhere on your network.  

Also if you have a rack of 1U units replacing all the KVM cables with serial
cables eases the physical management of the boxes.  Small gain, but useful.

From rddunlap at osdl.org  Sat Jun  1 09:37:03 2002
From: rddunlap at osdl.org (Randy.Dunlap)
Date: Sat, 1 Jun 2002 09:37:03 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] NEW TOPIC:  Hibernate in Linux (Specifically Redhat 7.3)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206010748360.6759-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33L2.0206010933320.19413-100000@dragon.pdx.osdl.net>

On Sat, 1 Jun 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:

| On Sat, 1 Jun 2002, Greg Long wrote:
|
| > No, actually I'm talking about a full suspend-to-disk "Hibernate":
|
| I believe this is being addressed in the latest development kernels.
| Check the changelog for more details.

Yes, it's being modified heavily in 2.5.x.
It's currently a combo of ACPI and "software suspend" patches.
These have made a lot of progress in recent months, but are
still very much "development level" patches.
If you want to try them out, that's fine, of course;
just backup your important stuff first.
And you should provide feedback to the acpi-devel
mailing list (see acpi.sf.net).
Just don't expect it to be perfect yet.
There are lots of interrupt routing issues and lots
of buggy ACPI byte-code issues (in BIOS).
Power button doesn't work for some people, does for others, e.g.

-- 
~Randy




From mikeraz at patch.com  Sat Jun  1 06:53:36 2002
From: mikeraz at patch.com (mikeraz at patch.com)
Date: Sat, 1 Jun 2002 06:53:36 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] quickie iptables log scan scripts
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205221015190.28925-100000@billings.heinlein.net>; from heinlein@attbi.com on Wed, May 22, 2002 at 10:29:00AM -0700
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205221015190.28925-100000@billings.heinlein.net>
Message-ID: <20020601065336.B20546@patch.com>

On Wed, May 22, 2002 at 10:29:00AM -0700, Paul Heinlein typed:
> With all the reports of that SQL Server script the kiddiez are using 
> these days -- and the continued Code Red scans that hit my box -- I'd 
> thought I'd whip up a couple little tools to give me some stats.
> [snip]

Another iptables tip:

Consider adding two chains to your installation called log-accept and log-deny
like:

    iptables -N log-accept
    iptables -A log-accept -j LOG --log-prefix "FIREWALL-ID-ACCEPT: " --log-level 6
    iptables -A log-accept -j ACCEPT
    iptables -N log-deny
    iptables -A log-deny -j LOG --log-prefix "FIREWALL-ID-DENY: " --log-level 6
    iptables -A log-deny -j DROP

Followup with replacing all '-j ACCEPT' and '-j DENY' with '-j log-accept' and 
'-j log-deny'

Then  `grep ACCEPT: | <one of Paul's scripts | other usefule script>` and check 
for unexpected traffic from a misplaced or misformed rule.  Or `grep DENY | ...` 
to search for traffic inadvertently being dropped.

In a business setting this will also allow you to quickly and authoritatively 
determine if someone's Internet problem is firewall related.  Not that anyone
every blames the network for a machine configuration error or other problem. :)

From mikeraz at patch.com  Sat Jun  1 06:58:36 2002

Subject: [PLUG] cheap UPSes
Message-ID: <20020601065836.C20546@patch.com>

Office Depot has an APC 500VA model for $50 which also
has a $15 rebate.  3 battery backed outlets, phone line
protection, and serial port w/cable for monitoring.

When you check out they print you a "rebate receipt"
to mail in for the cash.

This only provides about 10 minutes of backup time.

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sat Jun  1 18:27:14 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sat, 1 Jun 2002 18:27:14 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] cheap UPSes
In-Reply-To: <20020601065836.C20546@patch.com>
References: <20020601065836.C20546@patch.com>
Message-ID: <200206011827.14962.aschlemm@attbi.com>

It's nice that APC includes the signaling cable with the 500VA units 
now. I purchased one of these units a few years back and I had to make 
my own cable since APC wanted something like $40.00 for a signaling 
cable. I built two signaling cables with $0.99 worth of parts from a 
second-hand electronic parts store using the Linux UPS HOWTO. I also 
rolled my own monitoring software using the example "backupsd" 
monitoring daemon from the HOWTO as well. 

I did purchase a SmartUPS 700 last year for a system and it included 
both the cable and a PowerChute software CD that had a version for 
Linux among other supported operating systems.

Tony

From bhoran at hexdev.com  Sat Jun  1 18:55:23 2002
From: bhoran at hexdev.com (Brian Horan)
Date: Sat, 1 Jun 2002 21:55:23 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] perl for dummies
In-Reply-To: <64521.12.224.130.116.1022979471.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>
References: <64521.12.224.130.116.1022979471.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>
Message-ID: <E17EKGC-00010s-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Any of R. Schwartz's books would help a great deal....Learning Perl got me 
going a few years ago....If you're looking for specific things, a search on 
sourceforge.net for projects will give you a bunch of code to learn from.

Are you trying anything in particular? or just getting a base level of 
knowledge of perl down?

Also check out CPAN (Comprehensive Perl Archive Network) cpan.org.  They have 
countless perl modules and a few scripts....

for CGI stuff, a good learning resource may be Matt's Script archive 
worldwidemart.com/scripts/  I wouldn't necessarily use the exact scripts from 
the site (personal conviction) but they may offer insight into any CGI stuff 
you may want to do....also....If Perl is correctly installed on your system, 
you should have a handy-dandy little program called 'perldoc' which is like a 
'man' system for Perl...say you wanted to learn about the IO::Socket module:
simply type perldoc IO::Socket.....(usually works as 'man IO::Socket' too but 
that wouldn't be a very Perl-ish way of doing things.  It also depends on 
your $MANPATH)

If I can help with any specific items....let me know...

Hope this helps
-Brian

something that will massacre Germans, and he turns into Thomas *Fscking*
Edison."  --Neal Stephenson, Cryptonomicon





From lemming at attbi.com  Sat Jun  1 21:29:49 2002

Brian Horan wrote:
> 
> for CGI stuff, a good learning resource may be Matt's Script archive 
> worldwidemart.com/scripts/  I wouldn't necessarily use the exact scripts from 
> the site (personal conviction) but they may offer insight into any CGI stuff 
> you may want to do....also...

Matt's Script Archive is a good resource for those who want to find out 
what not to do.  Most of them are rather buggy and full of security 
holes.  http://www.perlmonks.org has good pointers with CGI and other stuff.

http://www.easystreet.com/~ovid/cgi_course is a good beginning for CGI.

-Mark

From m at netpro.to  Sat Jun  1 21:47:18 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Sat, 1 Jun 2002 21:47:18 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] winbind default domain?
In-Reply-To: <20020531165552.A14193@patch.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206012145110.25317-100000@lukem.com>

I believe so, although I haven't tested it yet (I plan on trying the same
thing when I get back to work on Monday).

Add this line to your smb.conf:
add user script = /usr/sbin/useradd -s /bin/false %u


On Fri, 31 May 2002 mikeraz at patch.com wrote:

> The docs don't say so, but is it possible to configure winbindd to
> use a default domain?  And create the user's home directory on the fly?

From lynnming at yahoo.com  Sat Jun  1 22:04:13 2002
From: lynnming at yahoo.com (Lynn Yuan)
Date: Sat, 1 Jun 2002 22:04:13 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] printer repair 
In-Reply-To: <200206010142.g511ggt21866@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <20020602050413.8450.qmail@web10906.mail.yahoo.com>

If the effort is worth it, you may want to try a
chemical rubber restorer called Fedron.  It expands
the rubber for a better grip.  Our copier repair guy
use to use it on our old copier rollers and it did
wonders (at least for a while).

Last resort, if you are ready to give up and toss the
printer - 

read somewhere about cleaning the rollers with WD40
and supposedly gave the rollers more grip

or

very lightly sanding the rollers with sand paper to
give the rollers better grip.

Lynn


--- Galen Seitz <galens at seitzassoc.com> wrote:
> 
> Thanks to everyone for their suggestions.  I went to
> www.fixyourownprinter.com
> and asked for help.  From the response I received,
> it sounds like I need a new
> pickup assembly.  Alas, parts for my printer are no
> longer available.  I
> gave it my best shot cleaning the rollers with some
> Teac rubber cleaner.
> It didn't help.  I may try calling The Printer Place
> tomorrow, but I suspect
> that I'll be shopping for a new printer.
> 
> From what I could tell, www.fixyourownprinter.com is
> a very useful site.  If
> you are having printer problems, it is definitely
> worth checking out.
> 
> thanks again,
> galen

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Sat Jun  1 22:30:21 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Sat, 01 Jun 2002 22:30:21 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] printer repair 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Sat, 01 Jun 2002 22:04:13 PDT."
             <20020602050413.8450.qmail@web10906.mail.yahoo.com> 
Message-ID: <200206020530.g525ULt27443@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

lynnming at yahoo.com said:
> very lightly sanding the rollers with sand paper to give the rollers
> better grip. 

Showing my stubborn streak, I decided to give it one more try today.  I
figured out how to pull the entire pickup assembly out of the printer.
I then removed the 'D'-shaped rubber bands.  I sanded them with 220 grit
and then cleaned them with rubber conditioner.  When I reinstalled the
bands, I rotated them 180 degrees.  I figured the rotation might help
by putting rubber that wasn't quite as worn up at the initial pickup point.
After reassembling the printer, I was able to print a 40 page document
without problems.  No doubt it will fail again in the future, but at 
least I've kept it out of the waste stream for a little while longer.

galen

You misunderstand. I'll break it down for you.

Facts:

1. He did not say that he wants to learn Perl.

2. He did not say that Perl is a requirement.

3. He did not say that he is aware of alternatives.

4. He did say that he finds Perl difficult.

5. Python is often a viable alternative to Perl.

6. The web site for Python is http://www.python.org/

Opinions:

1. Python is easier to learn than Perl.

2. Short, informative posts are best.

Get it?

> not python, php, smalltalk, ada, or mindf*ck, et. al.

Careful with that language. ;)

From dcf at aracnet.com  Sun Jun  2 08:36:13 2002
From: dcf at aracnet.com (David Fleck)
Date: Sun, 2 Jun 2002 08:36:13 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] perl for dummies
In-Reply-To: <64521.12.224.130.116.1022979471.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206020821380.25138-100000@linux.sourballs.org>

On Sat, 1 Jun 2002, Dave Poirier wrote:
> Just kinda feeling overwhelmed with Perl at this point and wondering if
> anyone would care to share, sites or books they found helpful.  Any
> suggestions would be appreciated. Thanks much in advance.Dave

In my own experience, the following have been the most helpful:
the llama book
the camel book
the perl manpages
The Perl Cookbook (forget what animal is on that one)
looking at the structure of modules on CPAN
www.perlmonks.org
comp.lang.perl.* newsgroups

these are arranged in more-or-less chronological order; that is, I started
with the llama book, then moved on to the camel book, etc.  I think I'm
pretty familiar with the language now, and 90% of the time I'll use the
man pages for reference.

What is it you're trying to do?  Pick up a new language, maintain someone
else's existing code, fix a specific problem?  What other languages are
you familiar with?


--
 David Fleck
 dcf at aracnet.com




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun Jun  2 09:04:35 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun, 2 Jun 2002 09:04:35 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] RPM questions
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206020900360.23525-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  I've installed several libraries from tarballs because these libraries are
required by packages I've installed. Because the libraries were not
installed from a package, the rpm database is unaware of their existence and
reports that they are missing when I try to install a different application
that requires them. Is there a way to make the package database aware that
these libraries are installed?

  Seems to me that the only difference between the Update and Freshen
options is that the former will install a package if it's not already
present. Are there any other differences?

Thanks,

Rich




From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Sun Jun  2 13:40:27 2002
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Sun, 2 Jun 2002 13:40:27 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] RPM questions
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206020900360.23525-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206021328020.16727-100000@antares.mpcu.com>

On Sun, 2 Jun 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I've installed several libraries from tarballs because these libraries are
> required by packages I've installed. Because the libraries were not
> installed from a package, the rpm database is unaware of their existence and
> reports that they are missing when I try to install a different application
> that requires them. Is there a way to make the package database aware that
> these libraries are installed?

Only if they are installed via rpm.  For packages that are reluctant to 
install due to dependency issues, check out the 'force' and 'nodeps' 
options with rpm.  Alternatively to the 'compile tarball' route,  use some 
non-official rpm choices.

		www.freshrpms.net
		www.bero.org
		www.rpmfind.net
		
And www.freshmeat.net houses a significant number of software projects any 
more, many with links to pre-built rpm packages.  Then, of course, there 
is always getting down and dirty with generating your own rpms.  
www.rpm.org is a place to start.

> 
>   Seems to me that the only difference between the Update and Freshen
> options is that the former will install a package if it's not already
> present. Are there any other differences?
> 

That's my understanding also.




From ed at alcpress.com  Sun Jun  2 14:46:11 2002
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: 02 Jun 2002 14:46:11 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Maximum file sizes
Message-ID: <1023054372.29843.3.camel@red>

I'd like to confirm a few things that I think are true:

1. The maximum file and volume sizes are the same for both
ext2 and ext3.

2. The 2 GB file size limit is a library limitation - not a limitation
of the file system or the kernel.

Ed

(With apologies to Dr. Seuss...to the meter of "Green Eggs and Ham") 
 
Linux can. Linux can. Use Linux . 
 
That Linux can! That Linux can! I do not like that Linux can!  
 
Do you like the open sourcing plan?  
 
I do not like that Linux can. I do not like the open sourcing plan.  
 
Would you like to free source share?  
 
I would not like to free source share. I would not like it anywhere. I 
do not like the open sourcing plan. I do not like that Linux can.  
 
Would you like it very stable? Would you like it to enable?  
 
I do not like it very stable. I do not like it to enable. I do not 
like to free source share. I do not like it anywhere. I do not like 
the open sourcing plan. I do not like that Linux can.  
 
Would you use it in a X-Box? Would you use it if it rocks?  
 
Not on an X-box. Not if it rocks. Not if it's very stable. Not to 
enable. I would not let them free source share. I would not let them 
anywhere. I would not allow the open sourcing plan. I do not like that 
Linux can.  
 
Would you? Could you? In your biz? Use it! Use it! Here it is.  
 
I would not, could not, in our biz.  
 
You may like it. You will see. You may like it if it's free!  
 
I would not, could not if it's free. Not in our biz! It should never 
be! I do not like it on the X-box. I do not like it that it rocks. I 
do not like it amongst our biz. I do not like it that it is. I do not 
like the free source share. I do not like that anywhere. I do not like 
that Linux can. I do not like you Linux man!  
 
Service! Service! Service! Service! Could you, would you, as a 
service?  
 
Not as a service! Not if it's free! Not in my biz! Man! Let not it be! 
I would not, could not, on a X-box. I could not, would not, if it 
rocks. I will not use it if its stable. I will not use it even to 
enable. I will not let them free source share. I will not let them 
anywhere. I do not like the open sourcing plan. I do not like that 
Linux can.  
 
Say! If in copyleft? Always free copyleft! Would you, could you, 
copyleft?  
 
I would not, could not, in copyleft.  
 
Would you, could you, why so nervous?  
 
I would not, could not, I'm NOT nervous. Not as copyleft. Not as a 
service. Not in my biz. Not if it's free. I do not like that it can, 
you see. Not if it's stable. Not on an X-box. Not to enable. Not if it 
rocks. I will not let them free source share. I do not like it 
anywhere!  
 
You do not like the open sourcing plan?  
 
I do not like that Linux can.  
 
Could you, would you use what we wrote?  
 
I would not, could not, use what you wrote!  
 
Would you, could you, to avoid your bloat?  
 
I could not, would not, avoid bloat. I will not, will not, use what 
you wrote. I will not compete with them as a service. I will not 
because it makes us nervous. Not in our biz! Not if it's free! Not if 
it is! You let me be! I do not like it on the X-Box. I do not like it 
that it rocks. I will not use it if it's stable. I do not like that it 
does enable. I do not like the free source share. I do not like it 
ANYWHERE! I do not like the open sourcing plan! I do not like that 
Linux can.  
 
You do not like it. So you say. Try it! Try it! And you may. Try it 
and you may, I say.  
 
Man! If you will let me be, I will try it. You will see.  
 
(...) 
 
Say! I like the open sourcing plan! I do! I like that Linux can! And I 
would use it because it's stable. And I could use it to enable!  And I 
could charge for providing a service. And I could copyleft without 
being nervous. And in my biz. And still source free. For you can still 
charge for a service fee!  So I will use it on the networked X-box. 
And I will promote it because it rocks. And I will use it because it's 
stable. And I will use it to enable. And I will use it here and there. 
Say! I can use it ANYWHERE! I do so like the open sourcing plan! Thank 
you! Thank you, Linux man!  
 
(From a post on Slashdot, of all things, by "NZheretic" 
 
~D.A. Stone 



From mikeraz at patch.com  Sun Jun  2 15:25:47 2002
From: mikeraz at patch.com (mikeraz at patch.com)
Date: Sun, 2 Jun 2002 15:25:47 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] perl for dummies
In-Reply-To: <64521.12.224.130.116.1022979471.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>; from dave_poirier@parkrose.k12.or.us on Sat, Jun 01, 2002 at 05:57:51PM -0700
References: <64521.12.224.130.116.1022979471.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>
Message-ID: <20020602152547.A572@patch.com>

On Sat, Jun 01, 2002 at 05:57:51PM -0700, Dave Poirier typed:
> Just kinda feeling overwhelmed with Perl at this point and wondering if
> anyone would care to share, sites or books they found helpful.  Any
> suggestions would be appreciated. Thanks much in advance.Dave

The Llama book - Learning Perl - commit a weekend to doing the whole book.  
Do every single exercise.  EVERY single one.  That was the foundation that
my Perl is built on.  

Check the PLUG archives for Paul Heinlein scripts.  Unlike what you'll find 
on CPAN they are small enough for you to grok the entire thing and learn from it.

Compare Matt's scripts (suggested elsewhere) with NMS (Not Matt's Scripts) both
sets have good levels of comments and the contrast of doing the same task as
implemented by two different programmers is more helpful than figuring out
what one person did.  

Magazine columns - because they tend to be very focused and explain the how of 
what they do.  Randal Schwartz posted a link to his stuff.

Port anything you have from a different language.  DOS batch files, Paul 
Heinlein's sh scripts, the AWK thing you wrote a year ago.  Porting something
you've done in a different language is very instructive and narrows the problem
set to just figuring out how to implement a solution in the new language.

http://www.perlmonks.org


-- 
    Michael Rasmussen  aka  mikeraz
   Be appropriate && Follow your curiosity

   "They that give up essential liberty to obtain
   temporary safety, deserve neither liberty nor safety."
				-- Benjamin Franklin 	

   and the fortune cookie says:
FORTRAN is the language of Powerful Computers.
		-- Steven Feiner

From rddunlap at osdl.org  Sun Jun  2 16:06:40 2002
From: rddunlap at osdl.org (Randy.Dunlap)
Date: Sun, 2 Jun 2002 16:06:40 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] NEW TOPIC:  Hibernate in Linux (Specifically Redhat 7.3)
In-Reply-To: <1023001330.1508.6622.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33L2.0206021604480.30695-100000@dragon.pdx.osdl.net>

On 2 Jun 2002, Brent Rieck wrote:

| On Sat, 2002-06-01 at 07:49, Matt Alexander wrote:
| > On Sat, 1 Jun 2002, Greg Long wrote:
| > > No, actually I'm talking about a full suspend-to-disk "Hibernate":
| > I believe this is being addressed in the latest development kernels.
| > Check the changelog for more details.
| > ~M
|
| For what it's worth, as far as I can tell "hibernate" works well for me
| on my 2.4.18-6mdk kernel on my Sony Z505, it even picks up the
| Fn-hibernate keypress.  As I use it *ALL* the time, is there some
| drawback to what mandrake is doing vs. the latest/greatest dev kernel?

Hibernate using APM or ACPI?
APM often works if the BIOS isn't buggy.
But new notebooks (Toshiba, Fujitsu, Sony, Compaq, et al) use
ACPI only -- no APM provided.
Same is true about some newer desktop motherboards.
And development of ACPI sleep modes is still work-in-progress.

-- 
~Randy

Brian Horan
bhoran at hexdev.com



From heinlein at attbi.com  Sun Jun  2 18:13:49 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sun, 2 Jun 2002 18:13:49 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] RPM questions
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206021548360.23525-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206021805460.4272-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On Sun, 2 Jun 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> I have been using '--nodeps' once I check that the required libs are
> present. I just wondered if there's a way of making the rpm db aware
> of a non-rpm-installed library. You confirmed that the answer is,
> "no".

That's really not true. What you do is write a dummy package that
contains no files, just a bunch of Provides: lines. That's what I did
on my Solaris box to let rpm know what libraries came installed with
the system.

First, you create the .spec file. It'd look something like this:

#
# this is a virtual rpm; it doesn't contain any files, just a list
# of Provides taken from the base solaris os. See the very bottom
# of this .spec for the actual package info...
#

Summary: Manually installed libraries
Name: handbuilt
Version: 1.0
Release: 1
Copyright: GPL
Group: System Environment/Base
Packager: Rich Shepard <>
# these are just examples. season to taste
Provides: lib450.so.1
Provides: libC.so.3
Provides: libC.so.5
Provides: libCrun.so.1
Provides: libCstd.so.1
Provides: libFS.so
Provides: libFS.so.5
Provides: libICE.so
Provides: libICE.so.6

%description
This is a virtual RPM package.  It contains no actual files.  It uses
the `Provides' token from RPM 3.x and later to list many of the shared
libraries I've installed by hand on my system.

%prep
# nothing to do

%build
# nothing to do

%install
# nothing to do

%clean
# nothing to do

%files
# nothing here

#
# eof
#


Then "build" the rpm: "rpm -bb /path/to/foo.spec" -- and install it. 
>From that point forward, rpm is aware of the libraries you've listed 
in the various Provides: lines. Note that you don't need to provide a 
full path to the library, just its basename.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

contrasting NMS work with MSA work is one path to seeing it.

would do differently.  Then review the NMS version for more ideas and insight.

Considering that Matt says "don't use my stuff" and "here are links to the NMS
replacements for my stuff" you get plenty of advice about what path to follow.

--- Galen Seitz <galens at seitzassoc.com> wrote:

> > very lightly sanding the rollers with sand paper
> to give the rollers
> > better grip. 
> 
> Showing my stubborn streak, I decided to give it one
> more try today.  I
> figured out how to pull the entire pickup assembly
> out of the printer.
> I then removed the 'D'-shaped rubber bands.  I
> sanded them with 220 grit
> and then cleaned them with rubber conditioner.  When
> I reinstalled the
> bands, I rotated them 180 degrees.  I figured the
> rotation might help
> by putting rubber that wasn't quite as worn up at
> the initial pickup point.
> After reassembling the printer, I was able to print
> a 40 page document
> without problems.  No doubt it will fail again in
> the future, but at 
> least I've kept it out of the waste stream for a
> little while longer.

From aapuch at attbi.com  Sun Jun  2 23:11:45 2002
From: aapuch at attbi.com (Andrew Puch)
Date: 02 Jun 2002 23:11:45 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] web filtering
In-Reply-To: <E4ZTSMGWGFZU75EANMLKFBF0USWV8.3cfafbbd@miked>
References: <E4ZTSMGWGFZU75EANMLKFBF0USWV8.3cfafbbd@miked>
Message-ID: <1023084705.30047.87.camel@brain>

On Sun, 2002-06-02 at 22:16, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> I've got a potential customer with semi-public winboxen.  It's difficult for me 
> to imagine, but people check out porn on the PCs. Anybody, including the staff 
> and minors.
> 
> Does anybody have experience with content filters? I could easily put a proxy 
> server on the LAN and handle it that way.


What I would do is run squid, 

here is the info you will need, 
http://www.squid-cache.org/Doc/FAQ/FAQ-10.html#ss10.4
http://list.cineca.it/cgi-bin/wa?S2=squid&q=porn+&s=&f=&a=&b=

You can set squid to block via regex /porn/ and host base.

By far squid is your best bet. 

I run squid for my home pc, since I had a dialup, way better speed :) 

cache of dns, web, images, 

You might want to set the porn log to dev null, if you want to skip out
of being the porn police, and getting people fired due to their porn.

To run squid, you need to make sure that there is only squid to the out
side world on your firewall. 

Else the porn seekers, will turn off the proxy settings, and go right to
the INTERNET.   

If you are talking about library, where the regex of /breast/ cancer
would cause issues, then I would have 2 squid caches running.

port 8080: Minor 0-18. with filtering. 
port 9090: No filtering. 

Then have the logon switch the settings in IE/ Netscape what ever. 


Your millage may vary. 

Good luck :) 





From eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us  Sun Jun  2 22:39:28 2002
From: eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us (Eric Harrison)
Date: Sun, 2 Jun 2002 22:39:28 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] web filtering
In-Reply-To: <E4ZTSMGWGFZU75EANMLKFBF0USWV8.3cfafbbd@miked>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206022224490.31812-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Sun, 2 Jun 2002, Mike De La Mater wrote:

>I've got a potential customer with semi-public winboxen.  It's difficult for me 
>to imagine, but people check out porn on the PCs. Anybody, including the staff 
>and minors.
>
>Does anybody have experience with content filters? I could easily put a proxy 
>server on the LAN and handle it that way.

Filtering is one of my other pet projects, which should come as no shock
considering the number of teenagers I have on my network ;-)

There are two excellent GPL web filters available, squidGuard
(www.squidguard.org) and Dan's Guardian (www.dansguardian.org). Both are
designed to work with the squid cache server that ships with all major
versions of Linux.

I've just started playing around with the latest version of Dan's Guardian,
it has a number of interesting features such as "stateful" inspection of
webpages (i.e. you can filter based on the content within a web page).

I've had squidGuard in heavy production use now for over a year. We're
providing filtering services for over 250,000 students in Oregon and
possibly as high as a million or more nationally/globally. 

SquidGuard is just as effective as the commercial software we used to use,
but it has a much lower "false positive" rate - it blocks fewer sites that
should not be blocked. One we got it tuned to our tastes, our users were
much happier with squidGuard.

The squid FAQ has a section on setting transparent proxying, so that all
web requests are automagically forced through the filter:

	http://www.squid-cache.org/Doc/FAQ/FAQ-17.html

-Eric




From CurtisE at CurtisE.net  Sun Jun  2 23:40:59 2002
From: CurtisE at CurtisE.net (CurtisE)
Date: Sun, 2 Jun 2002 23:40:59 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] web filtering
In-Reply-To: <E4ZTSMGWGFZU75EANMLKFBF0USWV8.3cfafbbd@miked>
Message-ID: <GJELJBAKILGBFNJHBMKGCEEKCEAA.CurtisE@CurtisE.net>

>Does anybody have experience with content filters? I could easily put a
proxy
>server on the LAN and handle it that way.

I've used Little Brother, the software formally known as Big Brother.  I
think it was since bought by Surf Control and they now call it Super Scout
or something.

Anyway, it worked fairly well.  It didn't catch everything it was supposed
to, but I think that's to be expected with this sort of product.  Porn sites
come and go so quickly that it's pretty hard to completely filter them
unless you go the route of only allowing certain sites.  It does provide
some very good information about who went (or tried to go) where.  You hang
it off of a hub between the users and the internet border router.  It
watches the traffic and logs (and optionally filters) all conversations.  I
liked that it's not actually in the data stream (traffic doesn't have to go
through it to get to the internet), so it's not a potential point of
failure.  You could configure a custom page to be returned to the browser
requesting an inappropriate page.  You can run on a number of platforms
including on a proxy server, on a Checkpoint FW-1, or stand alone on Windoz,
Solaris and Linux.

My only real beef with it was that it's database seemed to crash all the
time.  Of course I had it on a VERY busy link and pretty much ignored the
box until I wanted to run a report which was not very often.  The database
would get very big very fast and when I went to run a report, it would kind
of puke on itself.  Paying the box a little more attention may have gone a
long way towards resolving the db issue.  It just wasn't a high priority at
the time.  The company only used it for an excuse to fire someone when they
wanted to get rid of them for other reasons, but feared legal repercussions.
Or if my boss wanted some good blackmail material. ;)

I've heard of another product that somehow includes a "percentage of skin
tone colors" in it's filters.  I can't recall the name, but it might be
worth checking into if you don't want ANY porn getting through, but don't
want to otherwise restrict which sites users can visit.

CurtisE





From dealy at deatech.com  Mon Jun  3 00:45:17 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Mon, 3 Jun 2002 00:45:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Maximum file sizes
In-Reply-To: <1023054372.29843.3.camel@red>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206021511240.27079-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On 2 Jun 2002, Ed Sawicki wrote:

> I'd like to confirm a few things that I think are true:
>
> 1. The maximum file and volume sizes are the same for both
> ext2 and ext3.

Don't know about this one, I've never used ext3.

> 2. The 2 GB file size limit is a library limitation - not a limitation
> of the file system or the kernel.

It's been a while since I went through this stuff, but I believe that it
is a limitation (on 32 bit systems) of all pre-2.4 kernels, and requires
that libraries and many command line tools be updated as well.  In other
words, to use >2GB files, you need to be running a 2.4+ kernel, and
up-to-date libraries and command set.  When I first upgraded to the 2.4
kernel, the system would only sort-of handle 2GB+ file sizes because I
was using an old version of most of the system software with a 2.4
kernel (some programs had to be updated for the 2.4 kernel, but the rest
wasn't).  With this setup, some programs couldn't handle it, others could,
depending on if I was running an updated and/or relinked version of the
command.  I can't remember specifically, but I think I had problems with
cp, tar, and a few other commands.

Of course I could be senile, it's been over a year since I had any
problems with 2+ gig. files, so the details are a little vague in my
memory.

   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Mon Jun  3 09:54:20 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Mon, 03 Jun 2002 09:54:20 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] floppyfw, port forwarding 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Mon, 03 Jun 2002 09:08:30 PDT."
             <200206031600.g53G0Qe03068@smtp.easystreet.com> 
Message-ID: <200206031654.g53GsKt04716@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> I'm trying our floppyfw and the ip masquerading part seems to work fine.  
> However, I tried to direct ouside port 80 to an inside server and that didn't 
>  work. Any ideas?
> 

Here's what I use.  I restrict access to my web server to a list of know
IP's.  If you want to allow anyone in, set EXTERNAL_HTTP_CLIENT to
ANYWHERE.

galen


ANYWHERE="any/0"
UNPRIVPORTS="1024:65535"

    # ------------------------------------------------------------------
    # HTTP server (80)
    # ----------------
    #
    for i in $EXTERNAL_HTTP_CLIENT
    do
        echo "Allowing inbound www from $i"
        ipchains -A input -i $OUTSIDE_DEV -p tcp \
             -s $i $UNPRIVPORTS \
             -d $OUTSIDE_IP www  -j ACCEPT

        ipchains -A output -i $OUTSIDE_DEV -p tcp ! -y \
             -s $OUTSIDE_IP www \
             -d $i $UNPRIVPORTS  -j ACCEPT
    done


    if [ $INTERNAL_HTTP_IP ]; then
        echo "Forwarding inbound www to $INTERNAL_HTTP_IP"
        # forward inbound www connections to the internal www server
        ipmasqadm portfw -a -P tcp -L $OUTSIDE_IP www -R $INTERNAL_HTTP_IP www
    fi

than the one I give.  Thanks, Paul.




From alex at daniloff.com  Mon Jun  3 09:19:35 2002

From craighead.scot at vectorscm.com  Mon Jun  3 10:40:46 2002
From: craighead.scot at vectorscm.com (Craighead, Scot D)
Date: Mon, 3 Jun 2002 10:40:46 -0700 
Subject: [PLUG] RPM questionsz
Message-ID: <51C603B9AB4696408D7273AA133734AC1EA9E5@ljcms002.prod.vectorscm.com>

>Uuuummmm.  What Rich said.  99 times out of a 100 there is a better answer 
>than the one I give.  Thanks, Paul.

I found something else that may be helpful.  http://freshrpms.net/ has a lot
of packages in rpm format for different redhat versions that are hard to
find in rpms.  Personally, I have had very little luck compiling sources.
It takes a very long time to compile these and most of the time the build
fails and you have to try to determine what else is needed.

From montagne at boora.com  Mon Jun  3 11:12:23 2002
From: montagne at boora.com (Michael Montagne)
Date: Mon, 3 Jun 2002 11:12:23 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] LinNeighborhood
Message-ID: <20020603181222.GA25711@boora.com>

I use this cool little program called LinNeighborhood to map drives from
my NT network using smbmount.  This weekend we changed our passwords and I forgot to
unmount the drive.  I get an input/output error using LinNeighborhood.
The directory can not be removed either.  I did find an smbmount process
running and killed that but I'm stuck.  How can I force this to be
gone?

-- 
Michael Montagne
montagne at boora.com
http://www.boora.com



From richard.langis at sun.com  Mon Jun  3 11:22:00 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis Jr.)
Date: Mon, 03 Jun 2002 11:22:00 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] LinNeighborhood
References: <20020603181222.GA25711@boora.com>
Message-ID: <3CFBB3C8.2000704@sun.com>

Open an xterm window, su to root, and type:

umount -fv /path/to/mounted/share

At the very least that *should* give you some more info (-v option) as 
to what's going wrong.

-R

Michael Montagne wrote:

> I use this cool little program called LinNeighborhood to map drives from
> my NT network using smbmount.  This weekend we changed our passwords and I forgot to

> The directory can not be removed either.  I did find an smbmount process
> running and killed that but I'm stuck.  How can I force this to be
> gone?

From mike at linuxlink.com  Mon Jun  3 12:22:25 2002

Subject: [PLUG] ftp problem.
Message-ID: <20020603152225.3fe1eb3c.mike@linuxlink.com>

I have a server that must get to an ftp site.  It cannot.  I can get
there from most anywhere else. Perhaps it is an iptables problem, but I
hnow of two seperate networks that cannot get there.  I know nothing
about the second sites firewall setup.  Access from my dialup account
with virtually the same firewall and I get in like this:

t at riecilla mike]# ftp polar.wwb.noaa.gov
Connected to polar.wwb.noaa.gov.
220-
220-
220-**WARNING**WARNING**WARNING**WARNING**WARNING**WARNING*
220-
220-YOU HAVE ACCESSED A UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT COMPUTER.
220-USE OF THIS COMPUTER WITHOUT AUTHORIZATION OR FOR
220-PURPOSES FOR WHICH AUTHORIZATION HAS NOT BEEN EXTENDED
220-IS A VIOLATION OF FEDERAL LAW AND CAN BE PUNISHED WITH
220-FINES OR IMPRISONMENT (PUBLIC LAW 99-474).  REPORT
220-SUSPECTED VIOLATIONS TO THE SYSTEM SECURITY OFFICER.

220-
220 polar.ncep.noaa.gov FTP server (Version wu-2.6.1(1) Fri Nov 30
13:36:43 EST 2001) ready. Name (polar.wwb.noaa.gov:mike): anonymous
331 Guest login ok, send your complete e-mail address as password.
Password:
230 Guest login ok, access restrictions apply.
Remote system type is UNIX.
Using binary mode to transfer files.
ftp> 


When I try from the server I get this:

[mike at neptune mike]$ ftp polar.wwb.noaa.gov
Connected to polar.wwb.noaa.gov (140.90.192.168).
421 Service not available, remote server has closed connection
ftp> 

What might I be doing wrong?  Or what could cause this situation.

Thanks ahead.

have something going here too.

Michael H. Collins 		Admiral, Penguinista Navy

From richard.langis at sun.com  Mon Jun  3 12:25:35 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis Jr.)
Date: Mon, 03 Jun 2002 12:25:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] LinNeighborhood
References: <20020603181222.GA25711@boora.com> <3CFBB3C8.2000704@sun.com> <20020603190140.GB25711@boora.com>
Message-ID: <3CFBC2AF.2080305@sun.com>

Make absolutely certain that there is NOTHING in that directory before 
you rmdir.  Also check to see if it's actually unmounted by using 
'mount' (no arguments) and looking for the sharepoint.

If everything looks okay, then yeah, go ahead.  However, leaving the 
directory won't do you any harm.  And the link is only established via 
smbmount.  The directory is made only as a point on which the mount 
command hangs the remote filestructure to.

-R

Michael Montagne wrote:

> Hey that seemed to work...no errors.  The directory remains.  Can I
> safely rmdir? You see, this is the office fileserver and I'd like to not
> have Linux be responsible for deleteing it.  If I run rmdir on this
> directory, it just removes the link correct?





From lemming at attbi.com  Mon Jun  3 12:36:35 2002
From: lemming at attbi.com (lemming at attbi.com)
Date: Mon, 03 Jun 2002 19:36:35 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] LinNeighborhood
Message-ID: <20020603193636.NTKU20219.sccrmhc03.attbi.com@rwcrwbc58>

Mr. X wrote:
> Make absolutely certain that there is NOTHING
> in that directory before you rmdir.  Also
> check to see if it's actually unmounted by
> using 'mount' (no arguments) and looking for
> the sharepoint.

Not a bad idea to check, but 'rmdir' will only remove 
empty directories in anycase. It's fairly safe.
For the reckless, use 'rm -rf'

-Mark



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jun  3 12:50:06 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 3 Jun 2002 12:50:06 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] floppyfw, port forwarding
In-Reply-To: <200206031600.g53G0Qe03068@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206031249340.3238-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 3 Jun 2002, Bill Spears wrote:

> I'm trying our floppyfw and the ip masquerading part seems to work fine.  
> However, I tried to direct ouside port 80 to an inside server and that didn't 
>  work. Any ideas?

Bill,

  I have this line in firewalls.ini:

/bin/ipchains -A input -p TCP -d ${OUTSIDE_IP} 80 -j DENY       #web (http)

  You'll want to make it ACCEPT on the end.

Rich




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jun  3 12:53:21 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 3 Jun 2002 12:53:21 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Recommended DB datafile =?iso-8859-1?q?size=3F?=
In-Reply-To: <200206031619.g53GJZd02887@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206031251100.3238-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 3 Jun 2002, Alex Daniloff wrote:

> What is better for DB performance to have one big datafile for example
> 20GB or a couple of smaller ones at 2GB?

Alex,

  How about a definite "maybe"?

  If the tables are related, I strongly recommend normalizing the data and
putting the appropriate chunks in separate, but related tables. OTOH, if
it's all one, big flat file the answer probably depends on your disk speed
and filesystem structure. And, I wouldn't know in that case.

Rich




From bspears at easystreet.com  Mon Jun  3 13:25:53 2002
From: bspears at easystreet.com (Bill Spears)
Date: Mon, 3 Jun 2002 13:25:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] floppyfw, port forwarding
In-Reply-To: <200206031600.g53G0Qe03068@smtp.easystreet.com>
References: <200206031600.g53G0Qe03068@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <200206032017.g53KHmb12177@smtp.easystreet.com>

Let me clarify, I have these two lines, in firewall.ini, which I uncommented:
ipchains -A input -p TCP ${OUTSIDE_IP}  80 -j ACCEPT
ipmasqadm portfw -a -P tcp -L  ${OUTSIDE_IP}  80 -R 10.0.1.17 80

Later I have the line
ipchains -A input -p TCP -y ${OUTSIDE_IP}  -j DENY
which I assume doesn't cause trouble because it comes after the others

I'm pretty sure it's not something on the web server,  because it works 
fine with a Windows firewall.

On Monday 03 June 2002 09:08 am, you wrote:
> I'm trying our floppyfw and the ip masquerading part seems to work fine.
> However, I tried to direct ouside port 80 to an inside server and that
> didn't work. Any ideas?

> 220-PURPOSES FOR WHICH AUTHORIZATION HAS NOT BEEN EXTENDED

> What might I be doing wrong?  Or what could cause this situation.
I'm not sure about the cause, but have you tried accessing the site with
a different client?  I had a problem with access from outside, the
customer was using CuteFTP, and my ftp server would refuse the
connection, but I had the costumer use the url

ftp://username at ftp.infotects.com

in a browser (not mentioning names), and it connected without errors
(this was not an anonymous login though).

I know this is probably describing more of a winblowz issue, but it may
be worth trying a different client, just for the information that might
give you.

Good Luck

Derek Loree

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Mon Jun  3 14:11:40 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 03 Jun 2002 14:11:40 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ftp problem.
In-Reply-To: <1023138492.12236.219.camel@dereklinux>
References: <20020603152225.3fe1eb3c.mike@linuxlink.com> 
	<1023138492.12236.219.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <1023138704.30109.2.camel@pookie>

Derek;

On neptune, what is your shell? Perhaps your shell is not listed on the
remote servers' /etc/shells file. This will cause the remote server to
close the connection immediately.

Try switching shells for this user and try the server again.


-Cooper

From alex at daniloff.com  Mon Jun  3 13:15:27 2002
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)
Date: Mon, 03 Jun 2002 13:15:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Recommended DB datafile =?iso-8859-1?q?size=3F?=
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206031251100.3238-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200206032015.g53KFRF03182@gate.daniloff.com>

Richard,
In older databases it used to be one data file for the each table.
BerkleyDB, Gemini, ISAM, MyISAM and so on.
Modern DB datafiles have nothing to do with database structure and
tables.All databases and tables data is stored in datafile.
Oracle, PostgreSQL, InnoDB and so on. 
You can see datafile as a DB virtual filesystem. 
My question is related to DB optimization. 
What is better to have a couple of datafiles (virtual DB FS's) on the
same physical partition or just a one big datafile on the same
partition?

Thank you in advance for any thoughts and ideas.
Alex
  


 
-------------------
> On Mon, 3 Jun 2002, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> 
> > What is better for DB performance to have one big datafile for
example
> > 20GB or a couple of smaller ones at 2GB?
> 
> Alex,
> 
>   How about a definite "maybe"?
> 
>   If the tables are related, I strongly recommend normalizing the
data and
> putting the appropriate chunks in separate, but related tables.
OTOH, if
> it's all one, big flat file the answer probably depends on your disk
speed
> and filesystem structure. And, I wouldn't know in that case.
> 
> Rich
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
> 



From russj at dimstar.net  Mon Jun  3 14:24:46 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Mon, 03 Jun 2002 14:24:46 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ftp problem.
In-Reply-To: <20020603152225.3fe1eb3c.mike@linuxlink.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020603142032.020e1df0@localhost>

I agree with John's diagnosis. This definitely looks like the remote is 
refusing you, not a problem on your end.

If another ftp client doesn't resolve the issue (ncftp is a good one), then 
you might check to make sure both machines are resolving the host name to 
the proper IP. I notice in the first (working) example, no IP is given in 
the welcome. In the second, it gives it's IP.

Lastly, a note to the system administrator might be in order, if no other 
resolution presents itself.

At 03:22 PM 6/3/2002 -0400, you wrote:
>[mike at neptune mike]$ ftp polar.wwb.noaa.gov
>Connected to polar.wwb.noaa.gov (140.90.192.168).
>421 Service not available, remote server has closed connection
>ftp>

Russ Johnson
http://www.dimstar.net


A man with a watch knows what time it is. A man with two watches is never sure.





From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jun  3 14:35:34 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 3 Jun 2002 14:35:34 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Recommended DB datafile =?iso-8859-1?q?size=3F?=
In-Reply-To: <200206032015.g53KFRF03182@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206031431150.4775-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 3 Jun 2002, Alex Daniloff wrote:

> Modern DB datafiles have nothing to do with database structure and
> tables. All databases and tables data is stored in datafile.
> Oracle, PostgreSQL, InnoDB and so on.

  Well, not to belabor the point, but (at least in postgres) one uses the
'create table' command for each table in a normalized database. They are
stored on disk as separate files, too. Used to be by name now it's by
number. Shrug.

> You can see datafile as a DB virtual filesystem. 
> My question is related to DB optimization. 
> What is better to have a couple of datafiles (virtual DB FS's) on the
> same physical partition or just a one big datafile on the same
> partition?

  If all your tables (relations) are stored in a single, large disk file my
gut tells me that you're better off keeping that file in a single
filesystem. Unless you know how the tables are stored (which ones in which
files) and how frequently the two separate files will be accessed for an
operation, one file would be the way to go.

  I may not really understand your situation, Alex. In that case, please
excuse my impractical answers.

Rich




From derek at infotects.com  Mon Jun  3 17:32:04 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 03 Jun 2002 17:32:04 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Serial console with grub
In-Reply-To: <200206010458.g514wFi28990@smtp.easystreet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205311754580.4272-100000@billings.heinlein.net>
	 <200206010458.g514wFi28990@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <1023150725.12236.236.camel@dereklinux>

On Fri, 2002-05-31 at 22:07, Carla Schroder wrote:
> On Friday 31 May 2002 06:00 pm, you wrote:
> > I finally got the time to experiment with having a grub-loaded kernel
> > use a serial port as its main console (very handy for remote
> > administration!). What follows is part of the documentation I prepared
> > on the subject for work...
> >
> > --Paul Heinlein <heinlein at cse.ogi.edu>
> 
> <cool stuff snipped>
> 
> Okay, I was raised on windows and missed out on all this cool oldtimey stuff. 
> What do you do with this? How does the remote part work, is it connected by a 
> serial cable to another PC? Is this meant to replace a NIC?

I like to use a serial port for a console on my lrp boxes.  It makes
them more like appliances.  Then I use a null modem to connect to an
interanl server, and minicom to emulate the terminal connection to the
router/firewall.  I've even had the lrp box reload the network from an
outside connection, and the connection was not dropped!  (Try that with
a Cisco!!)

Derek

Date: Mon, 3 Jun 2002 19:00:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] THE PRESIDENT'S CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE PROTECTION BOARD
Message-ID: <20020604020056.6A8F82EF21@einstein.seansdomain.org>

From: Alan Paller, Director of Research, SANS

Deadline for reservations: Noon (CDT) Wednesday (reservation details at the 
end of the note.)

You may have heard about the White House Town Halls being run in Portalnd 
and three other cities to help Dick Clarke (the cyber security advisor to 
President Bush) and his staff draft the national strategy for securing 
cyber space. 

It is a chance to meet both Dick Clarke himself and Howard Schmidt who used 
to be head of security at Microsoft and now is Deputy Director of The 
President's Critical Infrastructure Protection Board. The chief security 
architect for Intel and the main virus watcher for McAfee and a few other 
folks will also be there.

And there's time and opportunity for lots of audience input. 

We just got a call telling us we could invite SANS alumni and readers to the

one in Portland on Thursday, so I am sending you this note.  Here are the 
details if you want to come.

(A hint. To get heard, line up near one of the two microphones very early. 
Don't wait until they say "Now it is time to take questions.")

Alan

Alan Paller
Director of Research
The SANS Institute 
paller at sans.org

====================

You are invited:

THE PRESIDENT'S CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE PROTECTION BOARD
THE WHITE HOUSE
PORTLAND TOWN HALL MEETING
 
7-9 PM, JUNE 6, 2002
VANPORT AUDITORIUM, Smith Center
PORTLAND STATE UNIVERSITY

The purpose of this town hall is to raise awareness on cybersecurity, 
educate people about the Administration's cybersecurity initiatives, and 
provide a vehicle for interested parties to provide input to the 
Administration's National Strategy to Secure Cyberspace.

Panel members will include:
Mr. Richard Clarke, Special Advisor to the President on Cyberspace Security
Howard Schmidt, Vice Chairman, President's Critical Infrastructure 
Protection Board
Other local dignitaries/Cybersecurity experts


Please RSVP by Wednesday, June 5, at noon to
Y. Sherry Sheng at sherry.sheng at state.or.us or 
503-986-0109, 

There are only 300 seats available.

From trnutt at aracnet.com  Mon Jun  3 23:14:36 2002
From: trnutt at aracnet.com (trnutt)
Date: Mon, 3 Jun 2002 23:14:36 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] floppyfw, port forwarding
References: <200206031600.g53G0Qe03068@smtp.easystreet.com> <007301c20b2d$2098e4c0$0f00a8c0@bsod.club> <200206032018.g53KItb13632@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <002d01c20b8f$1a211600$0f00a8c0@bsod.club>

I was trying to run Roger Wilco on a Winbox and couldn't get it to work when
I opened the port for it.

I had put a password in -the fill in the blank spot- when I configed
Floppyfw. After I added the password to the Roger Wilco parameters on the
Winbox, no problem.

I can only assume that it is on by default, and that the client mmachine
behind your firewall needs to pass it on to floppyfw.

hope this a help, but I'm only passing on my experience with opening a port.

cheers,

t

Subject: [PLUG] non-buffered I/O in Linux?
Message-ID: <02060322180600.04342@gate>

Hello Linux folkz,
Does somebody know if Linux kernel allows to perform non-buffered I/O on raw 
disk partitions?
In documentation on InnoDB tables it said:
By using a raw disk you can on some Unixes perform unbuffered I/O.
I assume that it should improve DB performance.
Thank you in advance for any thoughts or sources of information.
Alex

From aapuch at attbi.com  Tue Jun  4 00:06:30 2002
From: aapuch at attbi.com (Andrew Puch)
Date: 04 Jun 2002 00:06:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] non-buffered I/O in Linux?
In-Reply-To: <02060322180600.04342@gate>
References: <02060322180600.04342@gate>
Message-ID: <1023174391.7535.46.camel@brain>

On Mon, 2002-06-03 at 22:18, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> Hello Linux folkz,
> Does somebody know if Linux kernel allows to perform non-buffered I/O on raw 
> disk partitions?
> In documentation on InnoDB tables it said:
> By using a raw disk you can on some Unixes perform unbuffered I/O.
> I assume that it should improve DB performance.
maybe, sun has run bench marks of both. 

See sun solars performance, red 911 car book. 

In some cases, sun found that data base improved with the normal file
system tweaked for database.  

A normal file system is a hell of a lot easier to deal with, I would
only go to raw partitions if I did not have to deal with the PAIN of
back ups. Or had a happy oracle tool, to grab the raw data. 

I have talk to many a oracle dba, and they have said the same. 


Do you have big DLT tape drive. 

It is far far easier to loose all of your data with raw partions. 

The free databases are no oracle / db2 as far as tool chain to back up
your data.

You are looking at, database shut down, dump the raw partitions. 

Wait a long time, hours , etc. 

> Thank you in advance for any thoughts or sources of information.
> Alex

 SGI was the 1st do this work 

here are a few links, 

POSIX Asynchronous I/O 
http://oss.sgi.com/projects/kaio/

Raw IO 
http://oss.sgi.com/projects/rawio/news.html


This is what you want. 

http://tldp.org/HOWTO/IO-Perf-HOWTO/x159.html
http://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/kiobuf-io-devel
http://www.itworld.com/nl/lnx_tip/10122001/




From mike at microsharp.com  Tue Jun  4 00:56:59 2002
From: mike at microsharp.com (Mike Culbertson)
Date: Tue, 4 Jun 2002 00:56:59 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ftp problem.
References: <20020603152225.3fe1eb3c.mike@linuxlink.com>
Message-ID: <002901c20b9d$67a85010$6e00a8c0@mikeistan>

Sounds like a firewall issue. Try opening ftp without connecting and
specifying passive mode (then active mode if that doesn't work) to see if
the ftp server is just not making it back through a firewall.

ie:

Mike at MIKEISTAN ~
$ ftp
ftp> passive
Passive mode on.
ftp> open www.mikeistan.com
Connected to www.mikeistan.com.
220 ProFTPD 1.2.5rc1 Server (Iron Maiden) [www.imaiden.info]
Name (www.mikeistan.com:Mike):

Mike Culbertson
mike at culbertson.info

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Jun  4 06:20:04 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 4 Jun 2002 06:20:04 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] non-buffered I/O in Linux?
In-Reply-To: <02060322180600.04342@gate>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206040609570.6760-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 3 Jun 2002, Alex Daniloff wrote:

> Does somebody know if Linux kernel allows to perform non-buffered
> I/O on raw disk partitions? In documentation on InnoDB tables it
> said: By using a raw disk you can on some Unixes perform unbuffered
> I/O. I assume that it should improve DB performance. Thank you in
> advance for any thoughts or sources of information. Alex

This article might interest you:

  http://www.linuxjournal.com/article.php?sid=5841

Among the interesting quotes:

    For database creation, loading and indexing, Figure 3 shows that 
    the ext3 filesystem wins hands down and that RAW devices come in
    next to last place.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jun  4 07:41:32 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 4 Jun 2002 07:41:32 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] A mail list management question
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206040737130.7569-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I don't know if this annoyance is specific to majordomo or is common to
all MLM software. But, I'd sure like to know how to handle the problem.

  Majordomo tries to be very helpful by looking for words within the body of
the message that appear to be administrative requests sent to the list
rather than to the MLM. A nice feature, except ... when I try to send a
message to the list telling subscribers how they can have others subscribe
(or unsubscribe), any mention of the words "subscribe" or "unsubcribe"
(quoted or not) causes majordomo to send the message to me (as list owner)
rather than resending it to the list. A major PITA!

  Does anyone know how to use these two words within a message so that it
can be sent out as a regular e-mail?

TIA,

Rich

Pay special attention to the `idle' number. Higher is better. 99.5 per
cent, for example, is very good.

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Tue Jun  4 08:25:11 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 04 Jun 2002 08:25:11 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] killing a process that doesn't want to die
In-Reply-To: <WSL85VRPKZV7562LKTOXFFFIB.3cfcd954@miked>
References: <WSL85VRPKZV7562LKTOXFFFIB.3cfcd954@miked>
Message-ID: <1023204311.32500.16.camel@pookie>

On Tue, 2002-06-04 at 08:14, Mike De La Mater wrote:

> That's not doing it either...

Okay. Let's deploy the ``big guns.'' In your message you indicate that
it is a ``Samba mount'' that is causing df -h to hang. I can see that.
``df is trying to go out all the mount points but is not getting a good
connection from the remote host for some reason. This can also happen if
an NFS share is down.

First, change your current directory to / and unmount the samba share as
root:

  # umount /name/of/samba/mount/directory

If the umount reports the filesystem busy, you will have to unmount it
forcibly. The ``cleanest'' way to do this is to analyze the processes
using that mount, determine what they are doing, and kill them
appropriately. Second, one will inspect the mount's semaphores to make
sure it is not inappropriately using shared memory.

If you just want to unmount it, do the following. This will kill the
processes using the mount ``the hard way.''

  # fuser -km /name/of/samba/mount/directory

Now unmount the filesystem with the umount command above.

At this point I would recommend diagnosing why the remote share went
bad. Can you ping the server? Can you run `smbclient' against it?

Remount the Samba file system.


-Cooper





From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Tue Jun  4 08:27:43 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 04 Jun 2002 08:27:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] killing a process that doesn't want to die

-Cooper

has nothing to do with floppyfw, but with something about the network, which 
I don't know how to debug.  Thanks to all who helped.

> Let me clarify, I have these two lines, in firewall.ini, which I
> uncommented: ipchains -A input -p TCP ${OUTSIDE_IP}  80 -j ACCEPT

>
> Later I have the line
> ipchains -A input -p TCP -y ${OUTSIDE_IP}  -j DENY
> which I assume doesn't cause trouble because it comes after the others

> fine with a Windows firewall.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jun  4 08:33:55 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 4 Jun 2002 08:33:55 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] killing a process that doesn't want to die
In-Reply-To: <1YNMWTBAFEJRN97FAA6B076RL32W3.3cfcd6f1@miked>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206040832280.7569-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 4 Jun 2002, Mike De La Mater wrote:

> Maybe I need a luck charm, then. The process has gone 'DR', maybe it's no longer 
> loading the system, right?

Mike,

  The way I interpret the man page,
   PROCESS STATE CODES
       D   uninterruptible sleep (usually IO)
       R   runnable (on run queue)

something is holding that process open. Is anything actively mounted via
samba, or is there an application working across that mount?

  I've now reached the limit of my knowledge.

Rich




From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Tue Jun  4 09:04:45 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 04 Jun 2002 09:04:45 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] killing a process that doesn't want to die
In-Reply-To: <SR2X1WFC1XQO74WUA0E012ZT1TE952.3cfcdea9@miked>
References: <SR2X1WFC1XQO74WUA0E012ZT1TE952.3cfcdea9@miked>
Message-ID: <1023206685.32484.28.camel@pookie>

Mike;

Based on this information I cannot fathom why `top' is showing only one
process. If you connecting remotely with a Windows box it is likely the
telnet client is not updating the screen information correctly.

I can see a few processes here that are causing a problem. Assuming the
processes are still the same, perform the following:

  # kill -9 22391

Also, I note that you have several smb daemons running. Restart them as
root:

  # /etc/init.d/smb restart


-Cooper

following:

  # ps -eo pid,ppid,command

Mike

On Tuesday 04 June 2002 09:04 am, you wrote:
> Mike;
>
> Based on this information I cannot fathom why `top' is showing only one
> process. If you connecting remotely with a Windows box it is likely the
> telnet client is not updating the screen information correctly.
>
> I can see a few processes here that are causing a problem. Assuming the
> processes are still the same, perform the following:
>
>   # kill -9 22391
>
> Also, I note that you have several smb daemons running. Restart them as
> root:
>
>   # /etc/init.d/smb restart
>
>

From dealy at deatech.com  Tue Jun  4 09:46:22 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Tue, 4 Jun 2002 09:46:22 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] A mail list management question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206040737130.7569-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206040936110.1156-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Tue, 4 Jun 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

[snip]
>   Majordomo tries to be very helpful by looking for words within the body of
> the message that appear to be administrative requests sent to the list
> rather than to the MLM. A nice feature, except ... when I try to send a
> message to the list telling subscribers how they can have others subscribe
> (or unsubscribe), any mention of the words "subscribe" or "unsubcribe"
> (quoted or not) causes majordomo to send the message to me (as list owner)
> rather than resending it to the list. A major PITA!
>
>   Does anyone know how to use these two words within a message so that it
> can be sent out as a regular e-mail?

There are two ways to deal with this:

   1 - There should be a script file named "approve" in the bin directory
       wherever you installed majordomo.  You need to copy this to the
       system you read your email on, and when you receive the bounce
       message you can pipe the message through the approve command in
       order to get it delivered through majordomo.  NOTE: you first have
       to setup a file in your home directory with the password(s) for any
       lists you adminster for this to work.

   2 - You can embed a string which includes the list administrators
       password into the message before you send it in the first place.
       The positioning and format can be figured out from reading the
       script for the "approve" command.

I only use the first of these two methods, let the message bounce then
pipe it through "approve", otherwise it would be real easy to accidentally
send the list administrators password to the whole list.  To setup the
password file for #1, I believe the comments at the begining of "approve"
tell you everything you need to know.

NOTE: Some for mail programs such as pine, piping the message to approve
is trivial from within the mail program, for others it might be a real
pain: export the message to an external file, then in a separate window
pipe the message through the approve command.


Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

to the motherboard.  Sorry, I don't know the techical terms for them.

I recall looking for these at Norvac years ago and coming up empty.

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Tue Jun  4 10:46:45 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Tue, 04 Jun 2002 10:46:45 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] local (or non-local) connector supplies 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "04 Jun 2002 10:26:17 PDT."
             <868z5vklae.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> 
Message-ID: <200206041746.g54Hkjt19243@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> 
> I am looking for a source of various motherboard-type connectors that
> I can use to wire up fans or LEDs (i.e., the female part to match to
> motherboard's male parts).  Either one of those three pin fan headers
> or the kind that you usually use to connect up the case switches/LEDs
> to the motherboard.  Sorry, I don't know the techical terms for them.
> 
> I recall looking for these at Norvac years ago and coming up empty.
> 

I believe a mate to the fan connector is the DigiKey part number WM2001.
Go to www.digikey.com and search for WM2001.  Note that you would also need
the contacts, part number WM2200.  To do it right, you would also need
a crimp tool for the contacts, but you can  get by with just a pair of
needle nose and a soldering iron.

I may have some extras lying around.  How many do you need?

galen

Subject: [PLUG] NIS/SMB Apache Authentication
Message-ID: <20020604225510.GA23171@subtend.net>

I'm trying to get select areas of a website to authenticate against NIS.

I installed the perl module Apache::AuthenNIS and tried the correct
syntax in an .htaccess file, but I keep getting this error message:

[Tue Jun  4 15:14:40 2002] [error] Can't locate object method
"get_basic_auth_pw" via package "Apache" at
/usr/lib/perl5/site_perl/5.6.0/Apache/AuthenNIS.pm line 11.


So, I tried switching gears and authenticating to a NT domain controller
using Apache:AuthenSmb.  Same error:

[Tue Jun  4 15:38:15 2002] [error] Can't locate object method
"get_basic_auth_pw" via package "Apache" at
/usr/lib/perl5/site_perl/5.6.0/Apache/AuthenSmb.pm line 12.


What is this get_basic_auth_pw and how can I get it kick started?  I
have a feeling I'm missing some basic package that alternative authen
modules require.

Apache and mod_perl were installed using RPM's.  The authen modules were
installed using the CPAN shell (perl -MCPAN -e shell).

From craighead.scot at vectorscm.com  Tue Jun  4 16:24:28 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Strange Problem with CD Burner
Message-ID: <51C603B9AB4696408D7273AA133734AC1EAA0B@ljcms002.prod.vectorscm.com>

I recently installed grip to rip CD tracks into mp3's.  I then found that in
order to make that work, I had to install an encoder.  I found an rpm for
lame and installed it.  Now that works, but now when I try to go the other
way and burn an audio CD, it fails when the first track is in the middle of
recording.  Also, a CD player pops up and tries to play the first track.  I
ran setup and found a service called rawdevice is now running.  I notice
that if grip is running, it knows when an audio CD has been placed in the
drive and after a few seconds it has the name of the CD and all the song
titles.  Did grip add this service?  And is this interfering with writing
CD's?

> Any gcc gurus out there? I'm going around in circles on targeting specific 
> CPUs. For example, optimize for k6 or i686 instead of i386. Is this a 

gcc -march=i686

in the gcc info file it's under "Invoking GCC",
"Submodel options", "i386 Options".
--
