From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jun  4 19:18:57 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 4 Jun 2002 19:18:57 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] code optimization with gcc
In-Reply-To: <200206050023.g550NFs25020@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206041917460.10054-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 4 Jun 2002, Carla Schroder wrote:

> Any gcc gurus out there? I'm going around in circles on targeting specific 
> CPUs. For example, optimize for k6 or i686 instead of i386. Is this a 
> compiler option? make/config option? Do you need to wade through manufacturer 
> specs and tailor your code itself?

  From info gcc:

              i386 Options
              -m486 -mno-486 -msoft-float -mno-fp-ret-in-387
Could probably do -m686, too.

  Most of the time there's a configure option that's accessed by specifying
--target=ix86.

HTH,

Rich




From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Jun  4 20:39:17 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 4 Jun 2002 20:39:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] code optimization with gcc
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206041917460.10054-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206042034480.18906-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On Tue, 4 Jun 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> On Tue, 4 Jun 2002, Carla Schroder wrote:
> 
> > Any gcc gurus out there? I'm going around in circles on targeting
> > specific CPUs. For example, optimize for k6 or i686 instead of
> > i386. Is this a compiler option? make/config option? Do you need
> > to wade through manufacturer specs and tailor your code itself?
> 
>   From info gcc:
> 
>               i386 Options
>               -m486 -mno-486 -msoft-float -mno-fp-ret-in-387
> Could probably do -m686, too.
> 
>   Most of the time there's a configure option that's accessed by
> specifying --target=ix86.

Ah, here's the rub. The optimization switches have changed slightly
between gcc 2.x and 3.x (the uniquely Red Hat 2.96 release is a 3.x in
disguise).

The -m486 option has been retired. The new way of doing things is, as 
Felix mentioned, -march=<whatever> or, to a lesser extent, 
-mcpu=<whatever>.

I haven't really looked to see what changes the recently released gcc 
3.1 introduced.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>





From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue Jun  4 21:10:37 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 04 Jun 2002 21:10:37 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] local (or non-local) connector supplies
In-Reply-To: <200206041746.g54Hkjt19243@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
References: <200206041746.g54Hkjt19243@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <86hekigybm.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Galen" == Galen Seitz <galens at seitzassoc.com> writes:

Russell> I am looking for a source of various motherboard-type
Russell> connectors [...]

Galen> I believe a mate to the fan connector is the DigiKey part
Galen> number WM2001.  Go to www.digikey.com and search for WM2001.
Galen> Note that you would also need the contacts, part number WM2200.
Galen> To do it right, you would also need a crimp tool for the
Galen> contacts, but you can get by with just a pair of needle nose
Galen> and a soldering iron.

Galen> I may have some extras lying around.  How many do you need?

Hmm.  I guess my question was a little abstract.  I was remembering an
earlier problem (I wanted to build an external bank of LEDs).  Anyway,
the digikey.com was a good reference, which I appreciate.  

However, I guess my immediate problem is actually a different one: to
power a big 5-inch fan off of a 5V supply.  I had cobbled something
together years ago on a Pentium 133 box (it had a 4 gig SCSI drive
that ran hot) that I powered off on the the standard 4-pin drive power
connectors, but (I thought, cleverly) was also switchable using the
case turbo switch to select 5V or 12V (it is marked a 12V 5W fan).
Turned out it was noisy at 12V and did a fine job at 5V, so I left it
there about 99.9% of the time.

So, I guess my immediate need is to crimp on a 4-pin power connector
(the load side, with the male pins) to the two wires coming from the
fan.  I only need one "kit": two pins and a plastic terminal housing
for each botch job + 1! :-)


--

                         extremely unusual.' ''

From kens at cad2cam.com  Tue Jun  4 21:34:52 2002
From: kens at cad2cam.com (Kenneth G. Stephens)
Date: Tue, 4 Jun 2002 21:34:52 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] NIS/SMB Apache Authentication
In-Reply-To: <20020604225510.GA23171@subtend.net>
Message-ID: <NMEPJGMCLGBMCOCPJFHKCEDBDJAA.kens@cad2cam.com>

Kris,

My first cut is below, but after rereading you email, mod_perl does not seem
to be loading.  Check you http.conf file and make sure you can see the
libperl.so module in your /etc/httpd/modules (really /usr/lib/apache)
directory.

My first cut______________________________________

The password is available only through the Perl API with the help of the
get_basic_auth_pw() method. http://perl.apache.org/guide/security.html

The method can be found in the Mod Snake API
http://modsnake.sourceforge.net/mod_snake/doc/mod_snake_api/request-api.html

Example of its call is: http://www.perldoc.com/cpan/Apache.html

$r->get_basic_auth_pw
If the current request is protected by Basic authentication, this method
will return 0, otherwise -1. The second return value will be the decoded
password sent by the client.

   ($ret, $sent_pw) = $r->get_basic_auth_pw;

In fact this is where you can download the mod_perl module.


Ken

From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Tue Jun  4 21:45:51 2002
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Tue, 4 Jun 2002 21:45:51 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Strange Problem with CD Burner
In-Reply-To: <51C603B9AB4696408D7273AA133734AC1EAA0B@ljcms002.prod.vectorscm.com>
References: <51C603B9AB4696408D7273AA133734AC1EAA0B@ljcms002.prod.vectorscm.com>
Message-ID: <64655.12.231.181.15.1023252351.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>

---snip---

>  I ran setup and found a service called rawdevice
> is now running.  I notice that if grip is running, it knows when an
> audio CD has been placed in the drive and after a few seconds it has
> the name of the CD and all the song titles.  Did grip add this service?
>  And is this interfering with writing CD's?

If you want to know if this is grip's doing and you are using rpms, you
could do something like
  rpm -q --whatprovides /etc/rc.d/init.d/rawdevices

It appears to belong to the initscripts rpm, rather than grip. Grip
doesn't look like it enables any services or does anything else nefarious
just from installing the rpm. Do this to check for yourself:
  rpm -ql grip

>From /etc/rc.d/init.d/rawdevices:

# rawdevices       This shell script assignes rawdevices to block devices
#
# chkconfig: 345 56 44
# description: This scripts assignes raw devices to block devices \
#              (such as hard drive partitions). This is for the use \
#              of applications such as Oracle. You can set up the \
#              raw device to block device mapping by editing \
#              the file /etc/sysconfig/rawdevices.

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District

From AthlonRobNF at cs.com  Tue Jun  4 22:42:25 2002
From: AthlonRobNF at cs.com (AthlonRob)
Date: Tue, 4 Jun 2002 22:42:25 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] code optimization with gcc
In-Reply-To: <200206050023.g550NFs25020@smtp.easystreet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206041643570.10054-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <200206050023.g550NFs25020@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <200206042242.29681.AthlonRobNF@CS.com>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

On Tuesday 04 June 2002 05:32 pm, Carla Schroder wrote:
> Any gcc gurus out there? I'm going around in circles on targeting specific
> CPUs. For example, optimize for k6 or i686 instead of i386. Is this a
> compiler option? make/config option? Do you need to wade through
> manufacturer specs and tailor your code itself?

It just so happens this has been an ongoing topic in AOLS 
(alt.os.linux.slackware)  :-)

http://hints.linuxfromscratch.org/hints/optimization.txt
http://hints.linuxfromscratch.org/hints/old/optimization2.txt

Those have some good info in 'em.  I see other folks answered your question 
pretty well, though.

One thing to be wary of... a K6 is *not* i686... it's but i586.  Pentium Pros 
through Pentium IVs, Celerons, I *think* VIA C3s (ick!), and AMD Athlons and 
Durons are all i686 compatable, but have specific optimizations available if 
you're using GCC 3.x.  Many distros are still with GCC 2.95.x, though, as it 
is still the official kernel compiler.

Hope this helps!  :-)

The new guy,
Rob

>>>>> "Galen" == Galen Seitz <galens at seitzassoc.com> writes:

Russell> So, I guess my immediate need is to crimp on a 4-pin power
Russell> connector (the load side, with the male pins) to the two

Galen> suggest buying a 4 wire drive power extension cable and
Galen> chopping off the unneeded end.

I had been resisting that option because I wasn't thinking of a
reliable way to "seal" the splice and I didn't want a hot 5V wire
bouncing around inside the box with electrical tape or something
gradually softening and falling off.  This caused me to latch on to
the connector kit option.  However, I now realize that I just need
some heat shrink tubing (which I do have somewhere) and a dab of
solder, and I _will_ have a reliable way to "seal" the splice.

Hey, I never claimed to be much of a hardware guy. :-)

now.

##########
I have a couple .sh scripts that if I run out my shell (bash) runs fine,
but if I put on the cron (crontab) it loses its env vars (like

I actually call ". /etc/profile" to load them)

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Jun  5 08:10:44 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 5 Jun 2002 08:10:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Shell questions
In-Reply-To: <20020605104324.1a473255.mike@linuxlink.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206050805130.18906-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On Wed, 5 Jun 2002, Michael H.Collins wrote:

> ##########
> I have a couple .sh scripts that if I run out my shell (bash) runs
> fine, but if I put on the cron (crontab) it loses its env vars (like
> $SOMETHING), even calling su root -c myscript.sh on the crontab
> 
> What should I do to make sure my .sh scripts has the env vars? (on
> bash I actually call ". /etc/profile" to load them)
> ##########

Things to try:

1. Make sure the shebang line calls bash explicitly (i.e.,
   #!/bin/bash rather than #!/bin/sh)

2. Add --login to the shebang line: #!/bin/bash --login

3. Specify an rcfile: #!/bin/bash --rcfile $HOME/.profile

Pointing your colleague at the INVOCATION section of the bash(1) man 
page might be worthwhile.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>





From wallywharton at attbi.com  Wed Jun  5 08:16:53 2002
From: wallywharton at attbi.com (Wally Wharton)
Date: Wed, 5 Jun 2002 08:16:53 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Shell questions
In-Reply-To: <20020605104324.1a473255.mike@linuxlink.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206050811260.30123-100000@dhcp-73-190.attbi.com>

On Wed, 5 Jun 2002, Michael H.Collins wrote:

: I have a couple .sh scripts that if I run out my shell (bash) runs fine,
: but if I put on the cron (crontab) it loses its env vars (like
: $SOMETHING), even calling su root -c myscript.sh on the crontab
:
: What should I do to make sure my .sh scripts has the env vars? (on bash
: I actually call ". /etc/profile" to load them)
:

cron jobs run from a /bin/sh shell (unless otherwise declared with a #!
line) and a minimal environment.  `man cron' for the details.  The way to
fix the script is to either source the user's profile within the cron
script, or explicitly set the desired environment at the top of the script.

Wally





From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jun  5 08:01:25 2002

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jun  5 08:05:47 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 5 Jun 2002 08:05:47 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Shell questions
In-Reply-To: <20020605104324.1a473255.mike@linuxlink.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206050804560.1185-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 5 Jun 2002, Michael H.Collins wrote:

> I have a couple .sh scripts that if I run out my shell (bash) runs fine,
> but if I put on the cron (crontab) it loses its env vars (like
> $SOMETHING), even calling su root -c myscript.sh on the crontab 

  Who's crontab is running? If it's root, then I suggest exporting the same
env vars from root's .bash_profile as from yours.

Rich




From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Wed Jun  5 08:19:26 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 05 Jun 2002 08:19:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Shell questions
In-Reply-To: <20020605104324.1a473255.mike@linuxlink.com>
References: <20020605104324.1a473255.mike@linuxlink.com>
Message-ID: <1023290370.1837.8.camel@pookie>

On Wed, 2002-06-05 at 07:43, Michael H.Collins wrote:

<snip>
> ##########
> I have a couple .sh scripts that if I run out my shell (bash) runs fine,
> but if I put on the cron (crontab) it loses its env vars (like
> $SOMETHING), even calling su root -c myscript.sh on the crontab 

Guess what! Your environment variables aren't getting exported from the
shell process that is running your cron task!

For example, let's say you have `foo=/temp_file' in your script and you
call it from cron like so (the times are for illustration only, I don't
have cron's man page in front of me)

0 0 0 5 6 /usr/local/bin/my_cron_script

Under this scenario, cron reads your cron script and *forks another
process to run it!*

Change the cron line to this (note the period):

0 0 0 5 6 . /usr/local/bin/my_cron_script

This exports the variables it read in the parent process to the child
processes that will actually run your command.


-Cooper

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Wed Jun  5 09:30:16 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Wed, 05 Jun 2002 09:30:16 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] base64 decoding 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Wed, 05 Jun 2002 08:56:25 PDT."
             <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206050855360.1230-100000@appl-ecosys.com> 
Message-ID: <200206051630.g55GUGt27865@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> On Wed, 5 Jun 2002, Galen Seitz wrote:
> 
> > mimencode
>  
>   Thanks, Galen. Freshmeat and rpmfind don't have it (the latter comes up
> with metamail). Can you please suggest a source?
> 

metamail should be on your rh 6.2 install disk.

bash$ rpm -qif /usr/bin/mimencode 
Name        : metamail                     Relocations: (not relocateable)
Version     : 2.7                               Vendor: Red Hat, Inc.
Release     : 23                            Build Date: Mon 07 Feb 2000 07:11:45 AM PST
Install date: Tue 30 May 2000 01:10:57 PM PDT      Build Host: porky.devel.redhat.com
Group       : Applications/Internet         Source RPM: metamail-2.7-23.src.rpm
Size        : 296239                           License: Distributable
Packager    : Red Hat, Inc. <http://bugzilla.redhat.com/bugzilla>
Summary     : A program for handling multimedia mail using the mailcap file.
Description :
Metamail is a system for handling multimedia mail, using the mailcap
file.  Metamail reads the mailcap file, which tells Metamail what
helper program to call in order to handle a particular type of
non-text mail.  Note that metamail can also add multimedia support to
certain non-mail programs.

Metamail should be installed if you need to add multimedia support to
mail programs and some other programs, using the mailcap file.

From john at johntelford.com  Wed Jun  5 10:22:35 2002
From: john at johntelford.com (John Telford)
Date: Wed, 5 Jun 2002 10:22:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] bls-0.4
Message-ID: <FHEFJJAAILAPHOCOAGDGKEKPEGAA.john@johntelford.com>

Hello

The base Linux system (bls) distribution V0.4 is available on
http://bls.sf.net .

This base Linux system (bls) distribution is a tar ball image of a
configured, functional, running Linux system that's ready to load-and-go
onto a bare-metal box. Once loaded, configuring your networking
environment is about all that needs to be done.

Use bls as is or as a base for building Linux systems. The bls
distribution is network centric. Add or remove rpm packages to fit your
needs. Download the config file and compile a kernel the way you want
it.

Creating new Linux systems starts with downloading the bls tar ball
image and then installing it onto bare- metal boxes using tomsrtbt.

Selecting a set of runtime kernel parameters determines if the bls
distribution becomes a workstation, server, firewall, or router.

Systems built using the bls distribution may be run using a regular
console, a serial console, or totally headless. A Linux laptop running
minicom makes an excellent serial console for plugging into headless
routers and other Linux appliances created using bls.

Speaking of laptops, the bls distribution has the right stuff for
building Linux laptops from bare metal.

A ready to run Linux system is ready for use in about 10 minutes.

The base for bls distribution is the Red Hat 7.3 distribution:

Base Linux System release 4 - Mon Jun  3 14:04:00 PDT 2002
Red Hat Linux release 7.3 (Valhalla)
Kernel 2.4.18-4custom-bls-i486-4 on an i586

I hope you enjoy using the bls distribution as much as I enjoy producing
it.

Thanks ...John
-----
John Telford
JohnTelford.com LLC - (503)292-6865 - Fax(503)292-3094
13508 NW Springville Road - Portland, Oregon 97229-1613
john at johntelford.com - www.johntelford.com

From keith at ahapala.net  Wed Jun  5 11:04:53 2002

From steve at wirex.net  Wed Jun  5 11:38:33 2002
From: steve at wirex.net (Steve Beattie)
Date: Wed, 5 Jun 2002 11:38:33 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] base64 decoding
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206050759160.1185-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206050759160.1185-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20020605183832.GA17664@wirex.net>

On Wed, Jun 05, 2002 at 08:01:25AM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Accoring to 'aporpos', there are no tools on my system to decode base64
> encoded docs. It is (was?) a winWord .doc that someone tried attaching to a
> message to a mailing list. But, it was too big and bounced to me.
> 
>   Other than raising the size limit of messages, is there something I can
> use to rescue this message?

As another option, uudeview works well and can be found on freshmeat.

Also, openssl will decode base64 files as well:

	openssl enc -d -base64 < file.base64 > file.out

This is what I've doing for all the klez virii I've been getting. Alas,
nobody's sent me any interesting documents (no I *don't* need any more
web pages about irc eggdrops).

-- 
Steve Beattie                               Don't trust programmers? 
<steve at wirex.net>                         Complete StackGuard distro at
http://NxNW.org/~steve/                            immunix.org
http://www.personaltelco.net -- overthrowing QWest, one block at a time.

files it needs.

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Wed Jun  5 12:17:24 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Wed, 05 Jun 2002 12:17:24 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] conditional redirect in shell script
Message-ID: <200206051917.g55JHOt28502@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

I want to conditionally redirect stdout to /dev/null in a shell script.
However, it appears that redirection occurs before variable expansion, 
which means my approach won't work.  What is the correct way to do this?

Here's what I currently have, but it doesn't work.  '> /dev/null' ends up
being passed to gs as an argument.

gsredirect='> /dev/null'

set -- $args
for i
do
    case "$i"
    in
	-v)
	    gsredirect=''; shift;;
	-o)
	    outfile=$2; shift; shift;;
	--)
	    shift; break;;
    esac
done

# Merge postscript files into temporary file.
/usr/bin/gs -dNOPAUSE -sDEVICE=pswrite -dBATCH -sOutputFile=$tmpfile $* 
$gsredirect || {
    echo Ghostscript merge of postscript files failed. 1>&2
    myexit
}


thanks,
galen





From galens at seitzassoc.com  Wed Jun  5 12:31:15 2002

galens at seitzassoc.com said:
> I want to conditionally redirect stdout to /dev/null in a shell
> script. However, it appears that redirection occurs before variable
> expansion,  which means my approach won't work.  What is the correct
> way to do this? 

Nevermind, I found the answer.  eval is my friend.

galen





From sandy at herring.org  Wed Jun  5 12:38:55 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Wed, 5 Jun 2002 12:38:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] conditional redirect in shell script

Ah... just when I was going to suggest doing something like...

    exec 3>&1 > /dev/null

to set up the redirect of stdout to /dev/null, and resetting it via...

    exec >&3 3>&-

Sandy

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Jun  5 12:39:36 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 5 Jun 2002 12:39:36 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] conditional redirect in shell script
In-Reply-To: <200206051917.g55JHOt28502@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206051235300.18906-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On Wed, 5 Jun 2002, Galen Seitz wrote:

> I want to conditionally redirect stdout to /dev/null in a shell
> script. However, it appears that redirection occurs before variable
> expansion, which means my approach won't work.  What is the correct
> way to do this?

You've got to eval it. Take a small example script:

#!/bin/bash
redir='> tmp.txt'
echo 'hello' $redir

Running that will produce unwanted output:

  hello > tmp.txt

Adding an eval statement makes things right:

#!/bin/bash
redir='> tmp.txt'
eval echo 'hello' $redir

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>





From srau at rauhaus.org  Wed Jun  5 12:54:53 2002
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Wed, 5 Jun 2002 12:54:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] CVS question
Message-ID: <20020605195453.GA29481@rauhaus.org>

We use rancid (http://www.shrubbery.net/rancid/) to track configuration
changes to all our Cisco gear.

It saves all configs to a CVS repository via a cron job and mails any
diffs to our network engineering group.

Today, I needed to find out when a particular change was made to a
config. I'm pretty much CVS ignorant, is there a way to easily find out
in which revision a particular change first appeared?

Since the device in question didn't have a huge number of revisions, I
just did a bunch of "cvs co -r 1.x device-config" and grep'd for the
line until I narrowed it down to the revision in which it first
appeared, but I'd bet someone in plug-land knows the right way to do it.

Thanks,
--Stafford

cvs annotate device-config | less

  Thanks, Steve.

  I once tried saving the audio and video attacments of the Klez virus to
disk, but I couldn't. Glad to see something so Microsoft-specific not
written by Microsoft.

:-)

Rich




From smathews at pcez.com  Wed Jun  5 14:13:05 2002
From: smathews at pcez.com (Stuart Mathews)
Date: Wed, 05 Jun 2002 14:13:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Trying to ID a spammer...
Message-ID: <3CFE7EE1.AECC9C5F@pcez.com>

I've been told that trying to identify spammers is a waste of
time.  Since losing my job at IBM, I have the time and wanted to
see what I could find about "inbox.org," who wants me to
refinance my house.

The spam is from rachel at inbox.org.  I suppose if you're going to
use phony names, "Rachel" is as good as any.  The offer is to
refi my house, has the usual opt-out info, and a disclaimer.

The disclaimer pronounces their right to spam me because they are
in compliance with some proposed legislation, but that if I am
not having any luck getting off their list I can contact the
"Abuse Control Center" in Canoga Park, CA.

The Center must have relocated, because a google search for the
phone# for the opt-out turned up something indicating the
so-called Abuse Control Center was in Irvine.

Trying to learn about inbox.org I ran;

$ whois "inbox.org"@whois.crsnic.net     ......which returned the
registrant as Anthony DiPierro, in Brewster, NY.

I ran a google search on DiPierro, found discussion threads he
contributed to a couple of years ago relating to C vs Perl stuff,
Free BSD vs Microsoft, and his email (anthony at inbox.org).
DiPierro at inbox.org appears to exist.  Looks like he registered
inbox.org through tucows.

I ran nslookup on inbox.org and found a matching IP address
(161.58.166.119), which I can ping.

But what now?  Is it possible that some spammer has cracked into
Anthony's machine and is using it as a base for their own
nefarious purposes, or is likly that Anthony is just a good old
New Jersey type trying to make a living by freeloading off the
Internet?


Stuart Mathews




From bhoran at hexdev.com  Wed Jun  5 14:54:28 2002
From: bhoran at hexdev.com (Brian Horan)
Date: Wed, 5 Jun 2002 17:54:28 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] Trying to ID a spammer...
In-Reply-To: <3CFE7EE1.AECC9C5F@pcez.com>
References: <3CFE7EE1.AECC9C5F@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <E17FiP4-0002ef-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

well, you could email Anthony...hopefully he knows what his mail server is 
being used for...or you could see if his server is an open relay....for 
example:
it doesn't look like an open relay.....here's a transcript:

bhoran at Darkstar(~) % socket inbox.org 25
220 upstartinternet.com ESMTP Sendmail 8.11.6 ready at Wed, 5 Jun 2002 
17:29:48 -0400 (EDT)
HELO dingleberry.com
250 upstartinternet.com Hello adsl-156-XXX-XXX-XX.bct.bellsouth.net 
[66.156.212.74], pleased to meet you
MAIL From: bob at aol.com
250 2.1.0 bob at aol.com... Sender ok
RCPT To: cow at hexdev.com
550 5.7.1 cow at hexdev.com... SMTP relay denied, authenticate via POP/IMAP first
QUIT
221 2.0.0 upstartinternet.com closing connection

so if the full headers show it came from inbox.org (not just the From: 
part).....the sender has an account with inbox....

It looks like anyone can signup with an @inbox.org account for $5/year.
There's even a link on the www.inbox.org site to report SPAM from @inbox

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jun  5 14:35:21 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 5 Jun 2002 14:35:21 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Trying to ID a spammer...
In-Reply-To: <3CFE7EE1.AECC9C5F@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206051430410.1785-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 5 Jun 2002, Stuart Mathews wrote:

> I've been told that trying to identify spammers is a waste of time.  Since
> losing my job at IBM, I have the time and wanted to see what I could find
> about "inbox.org," who wants me to refinance my house.

Stuart,

  Takes only a few minutes at most. 

> I ran nslookup on inbox.org and found a matching IP address
> (161.58.166.119), which I can ping.
> 
> But what now?

  Do you still have that spam message?

[rshepard at salmo ~]$ whois 161.58.166.119 at whois.arin.net
[whois.arin.net]
Verio, Inc. (NET-VRIO-161-058)
   8005 South Chester Street
   Englewood, CO 80112
   US

   Netname: VRIO-161-058
   Netblock: 161.58.0.0 - 161.58.255.255
   Maintainer: VRIO

   Coordinator:
      Verio, Inc.  (VIA4-ORG-ARIN)  vipar at verio.net
      303.645.1900

   Domain System inverse mapping provided by:

   NS0.VERIO.NET                129.250.15.61
   NS1.VERIO.NET                204.91.99.140
   NS2.VERIO.NET                129.250.31.190

   ********************************************
   Reassignment information for this block is
   available at rwhois.verio.net port 4321
   ********************************************

   Record last updated on 26-Sep-2001.
   Database last updated on  4-Jun-2002 20:01:16 EDT.

  Now you know the ISP of the sender. Forward the spam -- with full headers
turned on -- to abuse at verio.net. My usual comment is:

  "Please take the appropriate actions to prevent this spammer from sending
more UCE via your servers.

Thank you,"

  Works very well.

  Ignore the "we're not spamming because some proposed legislation says what
we're doing is OK as long as we tell you how to opt out." That's nonsense.
The legislation died before it went to committee. Treat it as spam and
you'll find the ISPs are extremely helpful.

Rich

From neil at pacifier.com  Wed Jun  5 15:00:23 2002
From: neil at pacifier.com (Neil Anuskiewicz)
Date: Wed, 5 Jun 2002 15:00:23 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Trying to ID a spammer...
In-Reply-To: <3CFE7EE1.AECC9C5F@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0206051448270.27554-100000@shell.pacifier.com>

On Wed, 5 Jun 2002, Stuart Mathews wrote:

> I've been told that trying to identify spammers is a waste of
> time.  Since losing my job at IBM, I have the time and wanted to
> see what I could find about "inbox.org," who wants me to
> refinance my house.
>
> The spam is from rachel at inbox.org.  I suppose if you're going to
> use phony names, "Rachel" is as good as any.  The offer is to
> refi my house, has the usual opt-out info, and a disclaimer.

Send the email -- with full headers -- to abuse at inbox.com. You can hope
that company has a use policy that forbids spam.

Setup either a free account which gives you spam reporting privaleges or a
paying account ($30/year) which gives you preferred reporting, an email
account, and I believe a few other benefits. See http://spamcop.net/

You can setup an account just provding your email address and then you can
forward spam to a certain email address at spamcop -- with full headers --
and it will analyze the spam and determine the various abuse/postmaster
addresses to send it to.

If you wanted to devote your energy to the battle against spam, then
consider getting an account there and then sending every piece of spam you
get to spamcop.

Another good resource for anti-spam info is http://www.stopspam.org/

I have an idea for what I think would be an amusing science fiction story.
Perhaps you could be the super hero in it? :-)

In this story, this guy decides to devote his life to fighting spam. He is
kind of a cross between Case and Clint Eastwood. That is, he jacks in and
attacks the systems of spammers.


-- 
Neil Anuskiewicz
neil at pacifier.com




From smathews at pcez.com  Wed Jun  5 15:02:06 2002
From: smathews at pcez.com (Stuart Mathews)
Date: Wed, 05 Jun 2002 15:02:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Trying to ID a spammer...
References: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0206051448270.27554-100000@shell.pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <3CFE8A5E.A3449E9@pcez.com>

I wonder how often spammers send their stuff to skilled crackers, and then
pay the price. Surely even crackers get unwanted email from time to time.  To
crack into a spammer's box, wouldn't you have to, along the way, crack into
at least one ISP as well, to find files and logs and such leading back to the
spammer?  That would be impossibly difficult I would think.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jun  5 15:22:36 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 5 Jun 2002 15:22:36 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux /Windows virus appears (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206051521350.1785-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I read both web pages but didn't see just how a Red Hat box would be
infected.

  Any comments?

Rich

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Rich, FYI:

SANS reports:
 --3 June 2002  Simile is Cross-Platform Virus
The Simile virus infects Portable Executable (PE) and ELF files on both
Windows and Linux operating systems.  The virus does not carry a malicious
payload, although infected files could display messages on certain dates.
http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2002/06/03/1022982662974.html
http://www.symantec.com/avcenter/venc/data/linux.simile.html

I guess Linux is becoming a target now too!

-- 
- Bill Thoen

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jun  5 15:32:20 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 5 Jun 2002 15:32:20 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Trying to ID a spammer...
In-Reply-To: <3CFE837E.1D447506@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206051528290.1785-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 5 Jun 2002, Stuart Mathews wrote:

> I suppose I could open a hotmail account and email him.  Just the name of his
> organization, INBOX, sounds like a spam outfit. We'll see.

  There are several individuals and companies (as well as willing ISPs) that
distribute spam for a price. They also don't take 'no' for an answer, even
when reported to their ISP.

  Now that I have postfix running here as our primary MX, I'm developing
lists of spammers: IP addresses and domain names. It's very satisfying to
peruse the maillog and see some of these turned back to the sender.

  One address, in Italy, sent over 500 spam messages a day to a user here;
they were all bounced back to the sender. This went on for several days
before they got tired and quit.

Rich

Is Linux pretty much immune from devastating virusus  by virtue of
the fact that it can do only so much damage in user space? Well, I guess
immune is too strong a word but highly resistant would be apprpriat?

If so this is an excellent selling point for Linux. That is, run Linux
throughout your company and worry much less about virii. In fact, sleep
well. :-)

"Ovid" on http://www.perlmonks.org/
Someone asked me how to count to 10 in Perl:
push at A,$_ for reverse q.e...q.n.;for(@A){$_=unpack(q|c|,$_);@a=split//;
shift at a;shift at a if $a[$[]eq$[;$_=join q||, at a};print $_,$/for reverse @A

From flee at aracnet.com  Wed Jun  5 17:55:48 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)
Date: Wed, 05 Jun 2002 17:55:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] gcc games
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206050709470.13557-100000@appl-ecosys.com> on Wed, 05 Jun 2002 07:12:55 PDT.
Message-ID: <200206060055.g560tm210128@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com>:
>   To follow up on Carla's question of yesterday, here's an observation. I'm
> rebuilding the src.rpm for lyx-1.2.0 (released last Wednesday) and I see the
> following two compiler directives scroll by: "-march=i386 -mcpu=i686". So,
> there's apparently a difference betwixt the two.

-mcpu=i686 tells gcc to do instruction scheduling and
similar optimizations based on the assumption that the
target is an i686 chip.  If you run the resulting executable
on an i386, it may be a little slower than if you compiled
with -mcpu=i386, but it will still run.

-march=i686 tells gcc it can use machine instructions that
are only available on i686 chips, so the resulting
executable may not run on an i386 at all.

specifying -march also implies the corresponding -mcpu flag,
so "-march=i386 -mcpu=i686" means to use only i386
instructions, probably for maximum compatibility, but
optimize it for i686 chips, on the assumption that most
people out there have an i686.
--
[ sometimes there's a black car in the sun ]

From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Wed Jun  5 18:52:21 2002
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Wed, 5 Jun 2002 18:52:21 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] logging input via /dev/ttyS0
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0205311754580.4272-100000@billings.heinlein.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206051822280.18022-100000@antares.mpcu.com>

I've been researching this for a little bit now and still don't have an 
answer yet.  I have an older phone switch that has a DB-25 connect 
originally designed for a serial printer.  From my reading of the manual 
for the phone switch (KSU), this service is called "SMDR" and all it did 
was record the transactions the KSU went thru in the course of answering 
phone calls.

Rather than using a serial printer, I'd like to capture the output via a 
serial connection to a linux host.  I know I can use a terminal program 
such as minicom or kermit.  But I'd like to know if the input to 
/dev/ttyS0 can be logged directly thru the use of a pipe to a service such 
as syslogd?

Thanks for any input PLUGgers can provide.

From alan at clueserver.org  Wed Jun  5 19:08:24 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: 05 Jun 2002 19:08:24 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Mail and Windows XP
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206050936440.28134-100000@skua.ahapala.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206050936440.28134-100000@skua.ahapala.net>
Message-ID: <1023329305.8215.2.camel@summanulla.clueserver.org>

On Wed, 2002-06-05 at 09:56, Keith Nasman wrote:
> 
> I have only corresponded with two people that have machines running
> Windows XP. In both instances they have not received my mail as I sent it.  
> The first instance the recipient received a totally blank reply from me
> (after I wrote quite a few paragraphs) which was written in Evolution. The
> second instance happened this morning in attaching a .doc (from
> OpenOffice1.0) in pine. I then attached the file again and cc'd myself at 
> work and I received the attachment fine but the XP user didn't see any 
> attachment.
> 
> Has anyone seen such things happen to them? Are there settings in XP's 
> Outlook that disable/turn off attachments?

This might not be Outlook or Evolution's fault.

Are you using Postfix? There is a bug that is fixed in the latest
version that causes attachments sent from 8-bit capable MTAs to 7-bit
MTAs to go haywire.

If you are using Postfix, you might want to see if that is the problem.

I would also look at the maillogs to see if there are any other
interesting weirdneses.

Subject: [PLUG] Distribution upgrade, one package at a time.
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206052049580.15545-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  As I sit here waiting for gcc-2.95-110 to recompile, it occurs to me that
over the past several weeks I've rebuilt quite a few RH 7.3 src.rpms on my
6.2 system and used them to freshen the installed packages. "So", I says to
me, "how do I get a list of all the latest packages to compare with with I
have installed here?"

  If I go to ftp.redhat.com/pub/redhat/linux/7.3/en/os/i386/SRPMS/, I can
get a list of all packages there, but I don't know how to redirect that list
to a file on my local system.

  Is it reasonable to finish the upgrade by rebuilding the packages I've yet
to upgrade, then install the latest 2.4.x kernel (which, I presume, includes
glibc-2.2) and have the equivalent of the most recent 7.3 system? My
understanding of up2date and the other RH upgrade tools is that they get the
.rpm rather than the src.rpm. So, should I upgrade the kernel first, then
just use the 7.3 rpms? Finally, how does one change the flag within the
system to indicate that the distribution is, for example, 7.3 and no longer
6.2 or 6.1 as 'salmo' reports.

  I don't have a set of 7.3 disks or ISOs so I'm thinking of doing the
upgrade piece-meal as I have time. A few packages each evening.

Thanks,

Rich

From linux at maneuveringspeed.com  Wed Jun  5 21:36:02 2002
From: linux at maneuveringspeed.com (Greg Long)
Date: Wed, 5 Jun 2002 21:36:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Trying to ID a spammer...
In-Reply-To: <20020606032330.C05332F4FF@einstein.seansdomain.org>

Some say therein lies the bigger issue - the cost of spam.  Although
each spam mail itself is small volume, en masse it accounts for a
sizeable chunk of bandwidth (which costs money). The time spent by
admins such as Sean costs money.  Notwithstanding, we all have family
and friends who are gullible enough to fall for spam-scam and lose money
- whether their trying to lose weight around their thighs or increase
the weight of their genetalia, etc.

My guess is that in the end we'll find that as strong legal penalties as
can feasibly be enacted for spammers and virus authors alike will help,
what else will it take that is constitutionally alowable?

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Jun  6 07:08:52 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 6 Jun 2002 07:08:52 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Another rebuild error
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206051925570.12384-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206060700070.8930-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 5 Jun 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> Never mind. Errors in the .spec file. When I look at the directory
> structure, I see that the info/ and man/ directores are up one
> level. That is, under /usr/ and not under /usr/share/.

Right. Documentation is all doing under /usr/share these days. Red Hat 
made the switch in a couple stages from 6.2 to 7.1.

It seem to me the 'right' way to build portable .spec files is to use 
the _infodir and _mandir variables for info and man pages

  %files
  %{_prefix}/bin/foo
  %doc %{_infodir}/foo*.info.gz
  %doc %{_mandir}/man1/foo.gz

rather than storing them relative to _prefix

  %files
  %{_prefix}/bin/foo
  %doc %{_prefix}/share/info/foo*.info.gz
  %doc %{_prefix}/share/man/man1/foo.gz

The same is true when running configure:

  CFLAGS="%{optflags}" \
  ./configure \
    --prefix=%{_prefix} \
    --infodir=%{_infodir} \
    --mandir=%{_mandir}

That way, it doesn't matter if you build for 5.x, 6.x, or 7.x -- all 
the documentation goes to the right spot.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Jun  6 07:13:49 2002

option. That way I was able to  remotely connect to the screen process
and interact with the console, or just tail the log file.

From mike at planetpeterson.com  Tue Jun  4 08:27:43 2002
From: mike at planetpeterson.com (mike peterson)
Date: Tue, 04 Jun 2002 08:27:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Bytes_in_buffer may be zero on return.
Message-ID: <E17FGDn-0005Fe-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Resync_to_restart (j_decompress_ptr cinfo, int desired)
	This routine is called only when the decompressor has failed to find
	a restart (RSTn) marker where one is expected.  Its mission is to
	find a suitable point for resuming decompression.  For most
	applications, we recommend that you just use the default resync
	procedure, jpeg_resync_to_restart().

Subject: [PLUG] Dual-OS virus story
Message-ID: <51C603B9AB4696408D7273AA133734AC1EAA1B@ljcms002.prod.vectorscm.com>

>I'd say the chances approach 0. Microsoft is not that stupid. The height
>of hubris yes but completely stupid and self-destructive no.

I've had this conspiracy theory for a long time that many virii are written
by employees of companies that sell anti-virus software.  I would never
write a virus or anything else destructive, but if I worked at such a
company, it would occur to me that if someone came out with a really bad
virus and we immediately had the cure, it would be good for me and my
company.  Certainly, most people would be morally opposed to this, but
surely some would not be.

From JMILLER at ci.albany.or.us  Thu Jun  6 10:17:06 2002
From: JMILLER at ci.albany.or.us (Miller, Jeremy)
Date: Thu, 6 Jun 2002 10:17:06 -0700 
Subject: [PLUG] Dual Boot Partitioning Suggestions Please
Message-ID: <51AE6EA505FCD111AB5600805F653ACB010AA16C@EXCHANGE>

> So my questions are:
> 
> 1) How many partitions and what size for each?

Hmmm.  If it's just for trying stuff out, I'd do this with 10Gb:

1.  Wipe it totally clean.
2.  Create 1 partition for Win98.  (I'd guess 2GB, but that depends on how
much room you'll need there.)
3.  Format that partition (fat32 I guess... the installation will do it) and
install Win98.

Then you can get to work on the real system. :)

Take the remaining space (8 GB in this case) and divy it up... there's so
many ways to do it (separate /boot, /var, /usr/local, etc) but just for your
own laptop and messing around with I'd do:


swap 		based on mem.... I'd do 128MB or so
/		3GB
/home		the remainder (almost 5GB)


At this point you'd have a total of 4 simple partitions, all of which can be
"primary".  (Avoiding the whole logical partitions thing.)  You'd tell the
install to put your bootloader in the MBR, and it will be able to load
everything.  You should't really have to worry about the location of your
/boot anymore, either.


If you want a separate /var (not a terrible idea... apt will use a lot of
space in there just by itself) make /home a little smaller.  If you don't,
just pay attention to your disk usage, clean the apt-cache and logs once in
a while and don't let your root fill up. :)

Basically give yourself plenty of room for lots of programs and goodies,
plus a big enough storage spot (/home) that you never delete.  (Survives
from one linux install to the next.  So when you try out slack or gentoo,
your stuff stays with you... just wipe out root and install the new system
there.)  


> 2) What order to install, i.e. Win98 first or Debian first?


Win98 first, so it doesn't whine and complain about things it doesn't
understand.  (Or blow out your MBR... which it probably will.  Easier to
install grub or lilo and dual boot after it is already there anyway.)


> 3) I have a broadband connection. Is it practical to do an 
> installation
>    over the net, or should I download images and burn CD's? I 
> have a CD
>    burner on my other RH machine.

Downloading would be no sweat.  In fact, I'd recommend it.  (Debian,
Progeny, Libranet, and so forth all did fine for me over cable.)  To get
started, you'd need either boot disks or a boot CD.  The official ones would
start you out on Potato (debian 2.2 aka stable) which is a tad dated.  The
"testing" branch is pretty up to date, and seems stable enough for anything
short of serious server duty.  There are "network installation boot CD's"
for the testing branch and they've worked good for me.  (Less hassle than
floppies for me.)

Find them here:

http://www.debian.org/CD/netinst/ 


Also, at one point in the installation you'll get to choose between certain
default configurations, or to go custom.  DO NOT CHOOSE CUSTOM.  It will put
you in dselect, which would be absolutely horrid if you don't know how to
use it.  Especially in comparison to the way "custom" installations in
Mandrake and RedHat work.  (Including the console installations.)  It'd be
easier to drop things you don't want and add things you didn't get by using
apt after you are done.  For now, at least.


Other tips:

The list of locations apt looks for installing/upgrading stuff is in
/etc/apt/sources.list.  Some lines might be commented out (security updates
in particular) by default.  Uncomment them.  (This will probably make more
sense to you once you actually see the file.)

Want something?  Run "apt-get update" to freshen up the lists.  "apt-get
install foo" to install foo.  "apt-get remove foo" to get rid of it.
"apt-get upgrade" to upgrade all of your programs to their latest
versions/patches.  There's lots more, but that is good to start.


Good luck!


Jeremy


> Thanks in advance.
> 
> -- 
> Regards,
> 
> Dick Steffens
> "Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
> http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/

From bdhruva at gmx.net  Thu Jun  6 10:22:51 2002
From: bdhruva at gmx.net (Dhruva B. Reddy)
Date: Thu, 6 Jun 2002 11:22:51 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Dual Boot Partitioning Suggestions Please
In-Reply-To: <3CFF8C3A.45380FD4@attbi.com>
References: <3CFF8C3A.45380FD4@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20020606172251.GA1588@dr.mobizinc.com>

On Thu, Jun 06, 2002 at 09:22:18AM -0700, quoth Richard Steffens:
> I'm getting ready to take the Debian plunge. I have a 10GB drive for my
> Thinkpad 390x (450 Mhz Celeron w/ 96MB RAM) on which I currently have
> Red Hat 7.1 as installed from a set of K12LTSP CDs. I want to set up the
> drive to dual boot Linux and Win98. My intention is to use this as a
> learning experience. I've followed the discussions about RH vs Debian vs
> Mandrake vs etc., and since I have successfully installed RH on 2
> machines, I'd like to give Debian a try so I can determine for myself
> which I like better.
> 
> So my questions are:
> 
> 1) How many partitions and what size for each?

Ho ho!  You will never get a definitive answer on this.  It really
depends on exactly what you will do with the machine.  If I was going to
use a setup like yours as a workstation, here is what I might do:

	/boot:  8MB (I've caught flack for allocating so little space
	before, but with a little maintenance, it serves me well.)
	/var:   2.4GB
	/usr:   3.5GB
	/home:  3.0GB
	/tmp:   300MB
	/:	600MB
	(swap):	240MB

	Total:  ~10GB

But this is *only* my opinion!  It is loosely based on what I do with my
workstations (development and general use).

> 
> 2) What order to install, i.e. Win98 first or Debian first?

It will be easier to install Win98 first--it overwrites the MBR whether
you like it or not.  Then you can install Linux and tell your boot
loader to boot both Windows and Linux.

Check this out:

http://tldp.org/HOWTO/mini/Linux+DOS+Win95+OS2.html

> 
> 3) I have a broadband connection. Is it practical to do an installation
>    over the net, or should I download images and burn CD's? I have a CD
>    burner on my other RH machine.

It is very practical to do this!  What I do is get a minimal
installation working (less than an hour's download at 720kbps), then
install other packages as I need them.  This way I install only what I
need. 

> 
> Thanks in advance.
> 
> -- 
> Regards,
> 
> Dick Steffens



From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Jun  6 10:26:28 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 06 Jun 2002 10:26:28 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Dual Boot Partitioning Suggestions Please
In-Reply-To: <3CFF8C3A.45380FD4@attbi.com>
References: <3CFF8C3A.45380FD4@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <867klc1fp7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Richard" == Richard Steffens <rsteff at attbi.com> writes:

Richard> So my questions are:

Richard> 1) How many partitions and what size for each?

Tastes vary, but on a notebook I am inclined to just plop everything
in one:

  /dev/hda1 (windows crap, size as small as is comfortable)
  /dev/hda2 (swap partition, twice your memory size is a reasonable choice)
  /dev/hda3 (GNU/Linux, the rest)

Richard> 2) What order to install, i.e. Win98 first or Debian first?

I've always installed (or it was already installed) windows first.

Richard> 3) I have a broadband connection. Is it practical to do an
Richard> installation over the net, or should I download images and
Richard> burn CD's? I have a CD burner on my other RH machine.

I just did this on a new box and here's what I did.  I got a "net
install" image, around 30 meg, and burned it to a CD.  Then I can boot
off of that CD and load the necessary bootstrapping, then connected to
the debian archive and did the rest from the network.  That way, you
are only sucking down what you are actually going to use.  If you
can't boot from a CD-ROM, then you can download and copy floppy images
(the number can vary, depending on your needs)

Also, I've been switching all my machines over to grub.  I've found it
is more reliable and in a pinch I can boot off of a grub floppy and
still load kernel images off of the hard disk.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``The two chiefs turned to each other.        
seniorr at aracnet.com      Bellison uncorked a flood of horrible       
                         profanity, which, translated meant, `This is
                         extremely unusual.' ''

From alex at daniloff.com  Thu Jun  6 09:46:37 2002
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)
Date: Thu, 06 Jun 2002 09:46:37 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PLUG resume database project
Message-ID: <200206061646.g56GkbM07628@gate.daniloff.com>

Hello Linux folkz,
One of our PLUGers David and me started to work on PLUG resume
database project for unemployed folkz.

So far we have set up replicated MySQL database to store your resumes.
Pretty soon we are going to start developing resume search and output
interfaces. 

But there are still some questions regarding DB configuration.
Please see the description below and asked questions.
Thank you in advance for any thoughts or sources of information.

If somebody would like to participate in this project please call me
at: 
503-547-2204 during normal business hours. We'll plug you in.  

Data safety and redundancy problem is solved by replicating one
database on another (master - slave relationship).
The server simultaneously runs two MySQL databases on different RAID0 
partitions. 
Both databases provide output (select queries) to the users and client
API 
programs through the load balancing interface. 
But user input (insert and update queries) can be done only on master 
database. That propagates them to slave database with adjustable delay
time 
between slave-master reconnection. In case of one RAID0 failure,
remaining 
database becomes the master and continue to handle load until failed
RAID0 
drive is replaced and array is rebuilt. 
This approach eliminates nessesity in tape drive and periodical backup

procedures.

There are still some questions remain: 
What is better to use for data storage DB datafile on top of existing 
filesystem or raw device partition?  
InnoDB ACID compliant tables in MySQL can use both approaches.
But in case with raw device partition InnoDB can perform unbuffered
IO.
As it said on their web site http://www.innodb.com - using raw device 
partition should improve performance on some UNIXes. 
But what is about Linux?
If it's not true for Linux what filesystem is the best to home InnoDB 
datafile?
Does DB performs better when it has smaller or bigger DB datafile or
raw 
partition? 
What is more practical to assign one big e.g. 10GB datafile / raw
partition 
for DB or start with smaller 100M datafile / raw partition and add
additional 
datafile / raw partition when the first one becomes full?

If you have a better idea for safe data storage, 
integrity and operation, please let us know.

Alex





From lemming at attbi.com  Thu Jun  6 10:56:22 2002
From: lemming at attbi.com (lemming at attbi.com)
Date: Thu, 06 Jun 2002 17:56:22 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] Dual-OS virus story
Message-ID: <20020606175623.ILFB1024.sccrmhc01.attbi.com@rwcrwbc58>

> On Thu, 6 Jun 2002, Craighead, Scot D wrote:
>> I've had this conspiracy theory for a long time
>> that many virii are written by employees of
>> companies that sell anti-virus software.  I would
>> never write a virus or anything else destructive,
>> but if I worked at such a company, it would occur
>> to me that if someone came out with a really bad
>> virus and we immediately had the cure, it would
>> be good for me and my company.  Certainly, most
>> people would be morally opposed to this, but
>> surely some would not be.
>>
> I think I first heard this theory in 1998 when
> Melissa hit and all three major virus companies
> had updated pattern files within 4.5 hours 
> (TrendMicro won with a 3-hour response). 

As a former AV employee, I can tell you there's no need 
for the AV companies to do so.  Most virus authors are 
writing viruses as some sort of recognition and send 
their viruses to the AV companies.  And plenty of script 
kiddies are out there using the virus kits available.
And if an AV company was found to fund a virus author, 
that would mean near instant death.  With the wild 
claims of how much money a virus can cost a company that 
gets infected and then being able to sue a company 
responsible, figure it out.
The Dual OS was probably a proof of concept from someone.
Melissa had a fix quickly since it wasn't a very subtle 
virus and easy to detect.

-Mark

From dealy at deatech.com  Thu Jun  6 11:21:15 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Thu, 6 Jun 2002 11:21:15 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Dual Boot Partitioning Suggestions Please
In-Reply-To: <20020606172251.GA1588@dr.mobizinc.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206061052540.10439-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Thu, 6 Jun 2002, Dhruva B. Reddy wrote:

[snip]
> > 1) How many partitions and what size for each?
>
> Ho ho!  You will never get a definitive answer on this.  It really
> depends on exactly what you will do with the machine.  If I was going to
> use a setup like yours as a workstation, here is what I might do:
>
> 	/boot:  8MB (I've caught flack for allocating so little space
> 	before, but with a little maintenance, it serves me well.)
[snip]

This is way to small for a 2.4 kernel on Debian, Debian uses an initrd
file system during boot, and the kernel packages place the initrd file in
this directory, so between the kernel, map file, and initrd image, it uses
over five megabytes, which means you wouldn't have any room for installing
a new kernel.  In addition, the initrd file sizes vary considerably
depending on the processor architecture the package is built for.
If you want to have room for at least three kernels and not have to worry
about repartitioning in the near future, I would go with at least 30 Meg,
I currently configure all my new systems with 50 Meg for /boot (yeah I
know it seems ridiculous, but I sometimes keep more than half a dozen
kernels installed when I am doing development).

dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

> audio CD, it fails when the first track is in the middle of recording.

burning from mp3, wav, or headerless pcm files?

> I ran setup and found a service called rawdevice is now running.

Is rawdevice the thing that is loading the generic scsi and scsi emulation
modules and allowing users write access to the CD drive?

That's just a guess off the top of my head.  I know diddly about Red
Hat.  Commercial software isn't my thing.

> placed in the drive and after a few seconds it has the name of the CD
> and all the song titles.

This is a simple cddb (likely freedb) lookup.  It's a single subprocess of
grip that is launched as soon as the CD id data is read.

> Did grip add this service?

As was made clear before, grip likely added no services.

> And is this interfering with writing CD's?

Not enough information.

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Thu Jun  6 13:01:55 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Thu, 6 Jun 2002 13:01:55 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Dual-OS virus story
In-Reply-To: <51C603B9AB4696408D7273AA133734AC1EAA21@ljcms002.prod.vectorscm.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206061251330.14217-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Thu, 6 Jun 2002, Craighead, Scot D wrote:

> Thanks, that's reassuring.  I guess I just can't understand the motivation
> that these people have to write destructive code.  I can understand the
> juvinile delinquent script kiddies, but it doesn't seem like they would have
> the skills or the deligence to write something this complex.  Personally, if
> I was going to spend that much time and effort on writing code, I would want
> to write something that would make me some money.  I don't think it would
> look good on a resume to say that you were the main developer on the Melissa
> Virus project...
>
My guess about virus writers is that they don't have access to real
programing tools, like a compiler or decent scripting langauges (name
your poison here). The first big wave of viruses was back in the late
1980s & early 90s when most computer users were limited to what came
installed with DOS: debug & assembler. It was far easier to write
a virus than, say, a word processor, so a lot of viruses were created
as learning exercises. And many fell into the hands of malicious folks.

Now that the Internet has made good quality compilers available for
the cost of a lengthy download, most would-be virus writers have moved
on to more interesting -- & rewarding -- projects. And it shows in that
where once there were hundreds of infective or boot viruses, now there
are only a few dozen VB viruses. In response to Scot's comment, there
are certain circles where saying you wrote the Melissa virus indeed
earns you cred; but these are very small circles, & aren't very supportive.

Geoff




From craighead.scot at vectorscm.com  Thu Jun  6 13:38:29 2002
From: craighead.scot at vectorscm.com (Craighead, Scot D)
Date: Thu, 6 Jun 2002 13:38:29 -0700 
Subject: [PLUG] Strange Problem with CD Burner
Message-ID: <51C603B9AB4696408D7273AA133734AC1EAA27@ljcms002.prod.vectorscm.com>

Sorry if I didn't provide enought information.  I'll try to fill in.

>Exactly what process are you following to burn an audio CD?  And are you
>burning from mp3, wav, or headerless pcm files?

I am using a front end program called gtoaster.  I use mp3 files.  I believe
that gtoaster uses mpg123 to convert the files to wav and then uses cdrecord
to actually burn them.  I have an IDE Sony burner.  It is 8X but I usually
burn at 4X because I have made far fewer coasters that way.  I am using SCSI
emulation with ide-scsi and sg kernel modules as described in the CD Burning
Howto.

>Is rawdevice the thing that is loading the generic scsi and scsi emulation
>modules and allowing users write access to the CD drive?
>
>That's just a guess off the top of my head.  I know diddly about Red
>Hat.  Commercial software isn't my thing.

I think the whole rawdevices thing was a red herring.  I haven't installed
much lately and I checked my services to see what was running and found
that.  I don't know why that was being loaded, but I removed it and had no
change.  I suspected that because I am wondering how grip can tell that a CD
has been placed in the drive as soon as it closes.

>This is a simple cddb (likely freedb) lookup.  It's a single subprocess of
>grip that is launched as soon as the CD id data is read.
>
>> Did grip add this service?

>Not enough information.

Sorry, I'll try to do better.  Could it just be a bad mp3?  The mp3's were
encoded with lame and I can play them on a windows PC with mmplayer.  I have
made many audio CD's in the past, but this is the first time I have tried
with mp3's that I ripped myself.  I will try to make an audio CD with other
mp3's just to test this theory.  (I know I should have tried this already,
but I'm thick-headed!)  The only change I have made to my system was to
install grip and lame, so I thought that was related to my problem.

From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Jun  6 13:52:08 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 06 Jun 2002 13:52:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Dual-OS virus story
In-Reply-To: <51C603B9AB4696408D7273AA133734AC1EAA1B@ljcms002.prod.vecto
 rscm.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020606134424.02114858@localhost>

As well as, this is grounds for immediate termination at every virus 
detection company that I've had dealings with. I've worked for one 
(Symantec) and had close dealings with folks from another (McAfee). I've 
also worked cursorily with a couple others.

I admit it's an interesting theory, and possible, but for most folks, 
highly unlikely.

As for the response time... How fast can a kernel fix come out for linux? I 
think the record is just a couple of hours. Once the notification of a 
virus hits the media, figure the things been out for AT LEAST 8 hours. More 
likely, 24. By that time, the virus detection companies probably already 
have at least one sample. I know for a fact that Symantec and McAfee employ 
a team of developers that tear apart virii and figure them out. It doesn't 
take long, and once you've done a few, you get quick at it.

At 09:40 AM 6/6/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>Certainly, most people would be morally opposed to this, but
>surely some would not be.

Russ Johnson
http://www.dimstar.net


Artificial intelligence is no match for natural stupidity

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Thu Jun  6 14:00:27 2002
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Thu, 6 Jun 2002 14:00:27 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Cable modem problems.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0201300715300.24105-100000@quidditch.measurecast.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0206061354570.27100-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

On Wed, 30 Jan 2002, Paul Heinlein wrote:
>    So all I did was 'chmod a-x /sbin/pump', since dhcpcd works just fine
>    with ATT's server setup.
Just uninstall pump RPM.

> 4. Finally, I dropped a little script into /etc/cron.hourly/:
dhcpcd can also run scripts wheit it acquires, renews, or releases the
interface. Also, ifup can run local scripts, on Redhat /sbin/ifup-local,
after it configures the interface. You can reinitialize your firwall from
there. As far as ip address, you can use dhcpcd's info file or parse output
of ifconfig (which has an advantage that it works for all devices, static,
dhcp, or pump).

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Thu Jun  6 14:36:59 2002
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Thu, 6 Jun 2002 14:36:59 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Dual Boot Partitioning Suggestions Please
In-Reply-To: <3CFF8C3A.45380FD4@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20020606213659.4215.qmail@web9605.mail.yahoo.com>

--- Richard Steffens <rsteff at attbi.com> wrote:
> I'm getting ready to take the Debian plunge. I have
> a 10GB drive for my
> Thinkpad 390x (450 Mhz Celeron w/ 96MB RAM) on which
> I currently have
> Red Hat 7.1 as installed from a set of K12LTSP CDs.
> I want to set up the
> drive to dual boot Linux and Win98.
 So my questions are:
> 
> 1) How many partitions and what size for each?
> 
> 2) What order to install, i.e. Win98 first or Debian
> first?

Probably 5 GB for each OS. Win98 should be installed
first, since it always overwrites the MBR. Linux
requires at least a root and swap partition; all
distributions I know set up the swap partition
automatically. (Whether it would be worthwhile to
further subdivide the Linux installation on a *laptop*
may be an arguable matter.)
> 
> 3) I have a broadband connection. Is it practical to
> do an installation
>    over the net, or should I download images and
> burn CD's? I have a CD
>    burner on my other RH machine.
> 
Unless the network installation is fully automatic, it
would be better to burn CD's. If you ever need to
reinstall, the CD's would be advantageous.

I've tried Win4Lin lately and like it. On a laptop, if
this were an issue with me, I'd seriously consider
installing Linux alone and then running Windows in a
virtual console. (If you have any hardware that is
supported only by Windows, such as a scanner or
digital camera without Linux support, you need a
native Windows partition on at least one computer.)

=====
Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jun  6 15:38:34 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu, 6 Jun 2002 15:38:34 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Dual Boot Partitioning Suggestions Please
In-Reply-To: <20020606213659.4215.qmail@web9605.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206061534170.22554-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 6 Jun 2002, Robert Kopp wrote:
> Linux requires at least a root and swap partition; all distributions I
> know set up the swap partition automatically.

Dunno whether Dick's ever installed Debian or not, but the install utility
asks if you'd like to partition a disk and if you'd like to make and
activate a swap partition.  It's "automatic" insofar as you don't need to
run mkswap yourself, but it's an optional part of the installation
procedure.

> Unless the network installation is fully automatic, it would be better
> to burn CD's. If you ever need to reinstall, the CD's would be
> advantageous.

The network installation IS, in fact, fully automatic.  I've never burned
a Debian CD and wouldn't unless I was building a computer without a
network connection at all (and what's really the point of that?).

> I've tried Win4Lin lately and like it. On a laptop, if this were an
> issue with me, I'd seriously consider installing Linux alone and then
> running Windows in a virtual console.

Well, he didn't say WHY he wanted the Windows partition.  We're probably
better off not poking our noses into Dick's business too much.  I mean, if
he was really explicit as to why he thought he needed Windows, we could
probably find a way around it entirely.

J.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Jun  6 17:34:17 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 6 Jun 2002 17:34:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] ghostscript package upgrade
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206061730050.14083-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I received a bugzilla notice from Red Hat that ghostscript had a security
hole patched. So, I ftp'd the 6.2 upgrade packages that included a bunch of
VFlib stuff.

  Trying to freshen the installed ghostscript I learned that it needed the
VFlib packages and those, it turns out, need xtt-fonts, too. A bit of
checking revealed that the xtt-fonts and VFlib are all for Japanese Kanji
fonts. Because I can't read Japanese -- regardless of font -- I don't need
this support, but it appears that's not an option.

  Has anyone else run into this? When the RH ftp server is less busy I'll
see about grabbing a copy of -6.52 from the 7.3 updates and rebuild that.
Maybe then I can exclude CJK support.

Rich

From m at netpro.to  Thu Jun  6 17:52:19 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Thu, 6 Jun 2002 17:52:19 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] shell scripting problem
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206061747010.17170-100000@lukem.com>

I have about 200 names in /etc/group that I want to remove.  They're all
under a generic "users" group.  I have a file that contains the names that I
want to remove, and I'm looking for a wizbangwowzerz *nix way to read in
all those names and delete them from the group file.  I'll also need to
delete the comma after each name.

I'm thinking something along these lines...

for name in `cat namefile`;do sed s/$name,// group;done

Obviously this won't work, but that's sort of where I'm thinking now...
pull each name and the following comma out of the group file and then
somehow magically rewrite the group file when I'm done.

Any suggestions?
Thanks,
~M




From sandy at herring.org  Thu Jun  6 18:04:05 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Thu, 6 Jun 2002 18:04:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Moving users
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206061744510.7466-100000@zulu.launi.com>; from launi@zaramyth.net on Thu, Jun 06, 2002 at 05:47:07PM -0700
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206061744510.7466-100000@zulu.launi.com>
Message-ID: <20020606180405.D29673@kippered.herring.org>

On Thu, 06 Jun 2002, launi wrote: 
> I want to rebuild one of my servers.  I host email on it and want to move 
> the user accounts and directories onto another server.  Isd there a HowTo 
> that lists the steps to do this using TAR?

No HOWTO on this AFAIK, Lonnie (aside from `man tar' :). You'll want to keep
the same uids and gids when you create the users on the new box so that the
file permissions on the home dirs and mail spool will be correct. And then,
there's ftp space, too. Would it be possible to back up the old server and
restore it to the new one, using one of the many backup utilities
available...

    http://freshmeat.net/browse/137/?topic_id=137

Sandy

From aapuch at attbi.com  Thu Jun  6 18:12:15 2002
From: aapuch at attbi.com (Andrew Puch)
Date: 06 Jun 2002 18:12:15 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Moving users
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206061744510.7466-100000@zulu.launi.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206061744510.7466-100000@zulu.launi.com>
Message-ID: <1023412335.9179.37.camel@brain>

On Thu, 2002-06-06 at 17:47, launi wrote:
> I want to rebuild one of my servers.  I host email on it and want to move 
> the user accounts and directories onto another server.  Isd there a HowTo 
> that lists the steps to do this using TAR?



this should do the trick, from the Book of TOR, chaper 19.17  
cd /home
tar cf = . | cat | (cd /mnt/root/home; tar xbf xbf 1 -)
cd /var/spool/mail
tar cf = . | cat | (cd /mnt/root/var/spool/mail; tar xbf xbf 1 -)

grab these files the /etc/
password, shadow* , group 

let yea files flow, 






From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Thu Jun  6 18:22:31 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 06 Jun 2002 18:22:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] shell scripting problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206061747010.17170-100000@lukem.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206061747010.17170-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <1023412976.1837.460.camel@pookie>

On Thu, 2002-06-06 at 17:52, Matt Alexander wrote:

 
> I have about 200 names in /etc/group that I want to remove.  They're all
> under a generic "users" group.

#***********Cut Here***************************
#!/bin/bash

input_file=your_name_list
passwd_file=/etc/passwd
shadow_file=/etc/shadow
temp_passwd_file=/tmp/passwd
temp_shadow_file=/tmp/shadow

cat $input_file | while read name
do
  sed /$name/d $passwd_file > $tmp_passwd_file
  sed /$name/d $shadow_file > $tmp_shadow_file
done

#**********End Script***************************

Make the script above executable.

Check out the password and shadow files in the /tmp directory to see
that the results were satisfactory.

MAKE SURE YOU DELETE THE TEMP FILES AFTER YOU ARE FINISHED AND BE
*CERTAIN* THE PERMISSIONS ON THE PERMANENT PASSWORD AND SHADOW FILES ARE
CORRECT!
 

-Cooper

  I have a file that contains the names that I
> want to remove, and I'm looking for a wizbangwowzerz *nix way to read in
> all those names and delete them from the group file.  I'll also need to
> delete the comma after each name.
> 
> I'm thinking something along these lines...
> 
> for name in `cat namefile`;do sed s/$name,// group;done
> 
> Obviously this won't work, but that's sort of where I'm thinking now...
> pull each name and the following comma out of the group file and then
> somehow magically rewrite the group file when I'm done.
> 
> Any suggestions?

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jun  6 19:10:12 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu, 6 Jun 2002 19:10:12 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] shell scripting problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206061835230.17170-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206061906520.23732-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 6 Jun 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:
> This works for me:
> for name in `cat namelist`;do sed /$name/d group > newgroup;done

I can't imagine how it does.

I mean, you're removing one name from the original group file each time
and writing out a new newgroup file for each name you remove.

So if your group file contained:
amy
bill
charlie
david

And namelist contained:
bill
david

for name in `cat namelist`; sed /$name/d group > newgroup; done

would yield a newgroup that read:
amy
charlie
david

after one iteration and after the second iteration:
amy
bill
charlie

You're better off copying group to group.old before you begin and adding a
`mv newgroup group` before the loop exits.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org




From jason at vancleve.com  Thu Jun  6 19:14:09 2002
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Thu, 6 Jun 2002 19:14:09 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] shell scripting problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206061835230.17170-100000@lukem.com>
References: <1023413304.1838.472.camel@pookie>
	<Pine.GSO.4.33.0206061835230.17170-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <20020606191409.056c623c.jason@vancleve.com>

On Thu, 6 Jun 2002 18:36:24 -0700 (PDT)
Matt Alexander <m at netpro.to> wrote:

> for name in `cat namelist`;do sed /$name/d group > newgroup;done

Hmm, wouldn't that overwrite newgroup each time through the loop?  What about this:

cp group group-temp1
cat namelist | while read name
do
  sed /$name/d group-temp1 > group-temp2
  mv -f group-temp2 group-temp1
done
mv -f group-temp1 group

Okay, I'm a novice, so feel free to rip that up. . . .

--Jason



From dcf at aracnet.com  Thu Jun  6 19:25:31 2002
From: dcf at aracnet.com (David Fleck)
Date: Thu, 6 Jun 2002 19:25:31 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] shell scripting problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206061747010.17170-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206061921390.31565-100000@linux.sourballs.org>

On Thu, 6 Jun 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:

> I have about 200 names in /etc/group that I want to remove.  They're all
> under a generic "users" group.  I have a file that contains the names that I
> want to remove, and I'm looking for a wizbangwowzerz *nix way to read in
> all those names and delete them from the group file.  I'll also need to
> delete the comma after each name.

How about:

#!/bin/sh

namefile=$1

infile="/etc/group"
temp1="temp1"
temp2="output"

cp ${infile} ${temp1}

while read user;
do
	sed -e "s/${user},//" -e "s/[^^]${user}//" ${temp1} > ${temp2}
	cp ${temp2} ${temp1}
done < $namefile

sed -e "s/,$//" ${temp1} > ${temp2}
rm ${temp1}

exit 0


the script would be given an argument representing the names list file,
and would put the output into 'output'; e.g., 'script.sh namelist'.

--
 David Fleck
 dcf at aracnet.com

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Jun  6 20:43:19 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 6 Jun 2002 20:43:19 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] logs not rotating
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206061934270.14501-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206061934270.14501-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200206062043.19693.aschlemm@attbi.com>

It's all going to depend what sort of logrotate configuration you have 
for your mail log. Most of the time I think things are configured to 
rotate a file once it exceeds it's maximum allowed size. If the file 
size isn't exceeded then it wouldn't be rotated. There is a "daily" 
directive that you can specify in the logrotate configuration for your 
mail log to cause the file to be rotated on a daily basis.

Tony
