From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Fri Jun  7 00:31:39 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 07 Jun 2002 00:31:39 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] shell scripting problem
In-Reply-To: <1023412976.1837.460.camel@pookie>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206061747010.17170-100000@lukem.com> 
	<1023412976.1837.460.camel@pookie>
Message-ID: <1023435102.1839.944.camel@pookie>

> On Thu, 2002-06-06 at 17:52, Matt Alexander wrote:
> 
>  
> > I have about 200 names in /etc/group that I want to remove.  They're all
> > under a generic "users" group.
> 
Here's your script. Change the variables accordingly:

#************************Cut Here******************************
#!/bin/bash

group_file=/tmp/group
output_file=/tmp/group.out
name_file=/tmp/names

cat $name_file | while read name
do
  sed -e s/:$name// -e s/,$name// -e s/,$name,/,/ -e /$name/d
$group_file > $output_file
done

#*********************End Script******************************


-Cooper




From flee at aracnet.com  Fri Jun  7 00:42:43 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)
Date: Fri, 07 Jun 2002 00:42:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] shell scripting problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206061747010.17170-100000@lukem.com> on Thu, 06 Jun 2002 17:52:19 PDT.
Message-ID: <200206070742.g577gi613702@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

Matt Alexander <m at netpro.to>:
> I'm thinking something along these lines...
> for name in `cat namefile`;do sed s/$name,// group;done

For things like this, my approach is to turn namefile
into a sed script and then apply that script.  Something
like this:

    for name in `cat namefile`; do
        echo "s/,$name,/,/"
        echo "s/:$name,/:/"
        echo "s/,$name\$//"
    done > sedscript

    sed -f sedscript group > newgroup

If you're feeling brave, you can write that so it doesn't
need any temporary files at all.
--
[ sometimes dogs sing ]



From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Jun  7 00:57:55 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2002 00:57:55 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] shell scripting problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206062313280.1016-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206070055450.25793-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 6 Jun 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:
> On Thu, 6 Jun 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > On Thu, 6 Jun 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > > On Thu, 6 Jun 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > > > This works for me:
> > > > for name in `cat namelist`;do sed /$name/d group > newgroup;done
> > > I can't imagine how it does.
> > > I mean, you're removing one name from the original group file each time
> > > and writing out a new newgroup file for each name you remove.
> > I agree, it doesn't make sense, but it does work.  Anyone care to explain
> > why?
> Uhh...  OK, it doesn't work.  Well, it sort of works.  What the heck is
> going on?

Oh, man... be VERY careful with pattern matches.

Look at this:

> Here's a test namelist:
[snip]
> m

You have a name that's just "m".  And so your sed pattern is just
"m".  Not ^m:, just m.

So you lose all these:

> Here's the group file:
> bin:x:1:root,bin,daemon
> daemon:x:2:root,bin,daemon
> sys:x:3:root,bin,adm
> adm:x:4:root,adm,daemon
> lp:x:7:daemon,lp
> mem:x:8:
> kmem:x:9:
> mail:x:12:mail
> man:x:15:
> utmp:x:22:
> rpm:x:37:
> m:x:500:

because they've all got m in them, somewhere (usually in the word
"daemon").

> Here's the newgroup file:
> root:x:0:root
> tty:x:5:
> disk:x:6:root
> wheel:x:10:root
> dip:x:40:
> lock:x:54:
> nobody:x:99:
> users:x:100:
> slocate:x:21:
> floppy:x:19:
> vcsa:x:69:
> xfs:x:43:

See?

J.

Subject: [PLUG] logs not rotating

On Thu, 6 Jun 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:

> It's all going to depend what sort of logrotate configuration you have 
> for your mail log. Most of the time I think things are configured to 
> rotate a file once it exceeds it's maximum allowed size. If the file 
> size isn't exceeded then it wouldn't be rotated. There is a "daily" 
> directive that you can specify in the logrotate configuration for your 
> mail log to cause the file to be rotated on a daily basis.
 
Tony,

  I had both weekly and a maximum size specified; just changed it to daily
for maillog. But, ... *all* my logs have been growing since 2/17/02, none
have apparently rotated even though in /etc/logrotate.d/ each is directed to
rotate weekly.

  This is why I'm trying to better understand what's going on. The proper
directives are there but they're not being followed. For example, yesterday
afternoon, I changed the /etc/logrotate.d/maillog from 'weekly' to 'daily'.
This morning's log still summarizes everything since I initiated postfix.
Something's not right.

Thanks,

Rich

From dbridges at austin.rr.com  Fri Jun  7 07:10:50 2002
From: dbridges at austin.rr.com (David Bridges)
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2002 09:10:50 -0500 (CDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Dual Boot Partitioning Suggestions Please
In-Reply-To: <20020607130703.GC1588@dr.mobizinc.com>
References: <20020607130703.GC1588@dr.mobizinc.com>
Message-ID: <35162.192.168.2.1.1023459050.squirrel@dnbridge.dyndns.org>

>> Debian, I would not do for a laptop.
>
> I also have to wonder why not.  I have been happily using Debian
> unstable on my laptop for two years.  They even have a mailing list
> specifically for laptops.  See
> http://www.debian.org/MailingLists/subscribe.

Debian unstable has been working like a charm on my Dell Latitude CPXj for a
very long time.  Everything works great even when plugged in the docking
station.

>>
>> If you are going the debian route, I would go for the testing.
>>
>> Does Debian, do journaling file system , by default ??
>
> No.  Does testing or unstable even come with a 2.4 kernel?

I agree that testing would be the best branch to try out for the first time
user.  You can get the 2.4 kernel and ext2, ext3, or reiserfs if you use the
bf2.4 boot floppies that can be found at the following url.
http://http.us.debian.org/dists/testing/main/disks-i386/current/images-1.44/bf2.4/
It is just my opinion but here is the advise that I usually give people
trying to install debian for the first time.  In the installer it is
probably best to accept the defaults for most things except for partitioning
(actually there aren't any defaults here you have to do it yourself).  To
get a fully functioning system with X say yes tasksel and select X window
system (something like that anyways), games (if you like them), C/C++
programming stuff.  Say no when asked if you want to run deselect.  The
install can be accomplished pretty quickly with a broadband connection,
probably an hour or less.






From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Jun  7 07:30:39 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2002 07:30:39 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] shell scripting problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206061747010.17170-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206070709100.31555-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On Thu, 6 Jun 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:

> I have about 200 names in /etc/group that I want to remove.  
> They're all under a generic "users" group.  I have a file that
> contains the names that I want to remove, and I'm looking for a
> wizbangwowzerz *nix way to read in all those names and delete them
> from the group file.  I'll also need to delete the comma after each
> name.

[Yeah, Mike, I'm being predictable... :-)]

I'd use perl, just because sed doesn't seem to me as clean about
differentiating words from substrings.

#!/usr/bin/perl -w

use strict;

my $tmpoutput = '/tmp/group';
my @goners = ();

open( GONERS, "< /list/of/oldusers.txt" ) or die $!;
while (<GONERS>) {
  chomp;
  push @goners, $_;
}
close( GONERS ) or die $!;

open( TMPOUT, "> $tmpoutput" ) or die $!;

open( GROUP, "< /etc/group" );
while ( <GROUP> ) {
  foreach my $user ( @goners ) {
    # don't delete whole groups, only users
    next if /^$user:/;
    s/\b$user,?\b//;
  }
  s/,$//;
  print TMPOUT $_;
}
close( GROUP ) or die $!;

close( TMPOUT ) or die $!;

exit;

#
# eof
#

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jun  7 07:26:51 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2002 07:26:51 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: *****SPAM***** [PLUG] ADV: Direct Email Blaster, email addresses
 extractor,maillist verify, maillist manager ...........
In-Reply-To: <20020607060505.D2358@kippered.herring.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206070723050.19531-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 7 Jun 2002, Sandy Herring wrote:

> heh. Gotta love spamassassin. This got flagged, even though I've got PLUG
> whitelisted! This luser needs to be unsubbed...

> > SPAM: Hit! (3.2 points)  From an address @btamail.net.cn

  Over the past couple of days I've received several spam that were routed
through this domain. Unfortunately, they were also routed through aracnet's
mail server so my postfix filters didn't catch them. Do you want the domain
names of the originating spammers?

  This one got through because it was addressed to the list. But, I did some
searching last evening and traced the IP address block to a company that has
sub-IP address blocks rented to domains that appear suspiciously like spam
factories. I put every /24 address in /etc/postfix/badip so we'll see what
happens.

Rich




From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Fri Jun  7 07:40:29 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 07 Jun 2002 07:40:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] RE: shell scripting problem
Message-ID: <1023460833.1837.1376.camel@pookie>

> On Thu, 2002-06-06 at 17:52, Matt Alexander wrote:
> 
>  
> > I have about 200 names in /etc/group that I want to remove.  They're
all
> > under a generic "users" group.
> 
Here's your script. Change the variables accordingly:

#************************Cut Here******************************
#!/bin/bash

group_file=/tmp/group
output_file=/tmp/group.out
name_file=/tmp/names

cat $name_file | while read name
do
  sed -e s/:$name// -e s/,$name// -e s/,$name,/,/ -e /$name/d
$group_file > $output_file
done

#*********************End Script******************************


-Cooper

From neil at pacifier.com  Fri Jun  7 07:57:40 2002
From: neil at pacifier.com (Neil)
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2002 07:57:40 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] plug list and spam
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206070751060.21824-100000@localhost.localdomain>

I talked with Karl Hegbloom, who currently admins the PLUG list, and he 
tells me that you can post to the PLUG list without being subscribed. The 
reason is that he setup a news gateway, whereby people can participate in 
the PLUG list via NNTP. In order to do this he had to set things up so 
that people can post to the list from outside of the list.

As for dealing with spam, Karl tells me that he wants a volunteer who has 
experience working with spamassasin to set it up for PLUG.

Any volunteers please email karl at microsharp.com


-- 
Neil Anuskiewicz
neil at pacifier.com

From neil at pacifier.com  Fri Jun  7 08:25:15 2002
From: neil at pacifier.com (Neil)
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2002 08:25:15 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: *****SPAM***** [PLUG] ADV: [snip blah blah blah]
In-Reply-To: <3D00CEA8.6060109@sun.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206070821420.1604-100000@localhost.localdomain>

On Fri, 7 Jun 2002, Richard Langis Jr. wrote:

> The problem is that they don't need to BE subbed to post to the list...
> 
> I tested this last week by posting to the list from home, where I'm not 
> subscribed.  This needs to be fixed so we stop getting spammed.

I asked this very question of Karl Hegbloom, the list admin, and he told 
me it is because he recently setup a news gateway. That is, you can read 
and post to the list via. NNTP. Karl wants to use spamassassin to deal 
with spam.

I would like to know if anyone out there is actually using the PLUG list 
using a news reader? I bet almost everyone does this through email. If 
that is the case, I see no reason to continue the news gateway and hence 
no reason to continue allowing non-subscribers to post to this list.

Of course, I could be wrong and everyone and his brother might be 
accessing this through NNTP now. But to me it is one of those if it ain't 
broke why fix it? If an email list is working well, why add news access 
when many are not likely to use it?


-- 
Neil Anuskiewicz
neil at pacifier.com

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]On Behalf Of Neil
Sent: Friday, June 07, 2002 7:58 AM
To: Plug
Subject: [PLUG] plug list and spam



I talked with Karl Hegbloom, who currently admins the PLUG list, and he
tells me that you can post to the PLUG list without being subscribed. The
reason is that he setup a news gateway, whereby people can participate in
the PLUG list via NNTP. In order to do this he had to set things up so
that people can post to the list from outside of the list.

As for dealing with spam, Karl tells me that he wants a volunteer who has
experience working with spamassasin to set it up for PLUG.

Any volunteers please email karl at microsharp.com


--
Neil Anuskiewicz
neil at pacifier.com

From srau at rauhaus.org  Fri Jun  7 08:41:28 2002
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2002 08:41:28 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Moving users
In-Reply-To: <1023412335.9179.37.camel@brain>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206061744510.7466-100000@zulu.launi.com> <1023412335.9179.37.camel@brain>
Message-ID: <20020607154128.GA12274@rauhaus.org>

* Andrew Puch <aapuch at attbi.com> [020606 18:02]:
> On Thu, 2002-06-06 at 17:47, launi wrote:
> > I want to rebuild one of my servers.  I host email on it and want to move 
> > the user accounts and directories onto another server.  Isd there a HowTo 
> > that lists the steps to do this using TAR?
> 
> 
> 
> this should do the trick, from the Book of TOR, chaper 19.17  
> cd /home
> tar cf = . | cat | (cd /mnt/root/home; tar xbf xbf 1 -)
> cd /var/spool/mail
> tar cf = . | cat | (cd /mnt/root/var/spool/mail; tar xbf xbf 1 -)

I'm not familiar with the "=" notation, but there's no need for the cat,
and this example only works if you're moving it to a local file system
or to one that's been NFS (or AFS or samba or whatever) mounted.

To move directories to a new host, you could do something like the
following:

cd /home
tar -cf - usera userb userc useretc | (ssh newhost "cd /home; tar -xvf -")

If you are using GNUtar at both ends, there are a bazillion options that
make this even nicer - the "-C directory" option will tar or untar
relative to "directory", so you could eliminate that "cd /home;" above.

Be sure the same user accounts and uids exist on the new machine before
you do this.

--Stafford

From sandy at herring.org  Fri Jun  7 09:36:44 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2002 09:36:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] logs not rotating
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206070835310.19865-100000@appl-ecosys.com>; from rshepard@appl-ecosys.com on Fri, Jun 07, 2002 at 08:44:49AM -0700
References: <1023462438.12454.7.camel@sneaker.got-roots.com> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206070835310.19865-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20020607093644.D2790@kippered.herring.org>

On Fri, 07 Jun 2002, Rich Shepard wrote: 
> On 7 Jun 2002, Doug Davis wrote:
> 
> > there should be a line in /etc/cron.daily that says logrotate, This will
> > get run when the run-parts  daily script runs. 
> 
>   I'm confused, Doug. /etc/cron.daily/ is a directory (as are the other
> /etc/cron.*/). It contains:
> cron.daily:
> 1postfix*        dailyscript*  makewhatis.cron*  tetex.cron*   tmpwatch*
> check-packages*  logrotate*    slocate.cron*     tetex.cron.rpmorig*

cron.daily ought to be a directory (at least on RH installs). What you have
there appears correct. Since `logrotate' is executable, it should be
triggered by run-parts (see /usr/bin/run-parts). What's in `logrotate'?
Hopefully...


[bigfish at kippered bigfish]$ cat /etc/cron.daily/logrotate
#!/bin/sh

/usr/sbin/logrotate /etc/logrotate.conf


>   The run-parts daily script. /etc/cron.daily/dailyscript, has nothing about
> logrotate in it.
> 
>   What do other RH installations have to rotate logs?
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> Rich

It shouldn't. The `run-parts' script runs any executable in the directory
given as an arg to the script. You can run it manually...

   /usr/bin/run-parts /etc/cron.daily

...or if you want to test just `logrotate', copy it to it's own directory
and pass that to `run-parts' as an arg. You can stick an `echo "I was here"'
before and after the `/usr/sbin/logrotate' to confirm that `run-parts' is
executing `logrotate'. If it is, then the problem is either with
`logrotate', or more likely, with what you've got in the .conf file.

Sandy
--

From dealy at deatech.com  Fri Jun  7 09:51:30 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2002 09:51:30 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] logs not rotating
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206070835310.19865-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206070944040.13932-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Fri, 7 Jun 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> On 7 Jun 2002, Doug Davis wrote:
>
> > there should be a line in /etc/cron.daily that says logrotate, This will
> > get run when the run-parts  daily script runs.
>
>   I'm confused, Doug. /etc/cron.daily/ is a directory (as are the other
> /etc/cron.*/). It contains:
> cron.daily:
> 1postfix*        dailyscript*  makewhatis.cron*  tetex.cron*   tmpwatch*
> check-packages*  logrotate*    slocate.cron*     tetex.cron.rpmorig*
>
>   The run-parts daily script. /etc/cron.daily/dailyscript, has nothing about
> logrotate in it.

I think you're not understanding the mechanism of the /etc/cron.daily
(or .weekly, .monthly).  /etc/crontab has a line for each of these
directories that says "run-parts . . . /etc/cron.xxxxx"  each time this
command is run, all of the scripts in the corresponding directory are
executed.  Since you list a "logrotate" file in /etc/cron.daily, you
should look at the contents of that file to see what it is doing, or
possibly even manually execute the file to see if it will successfully
rotate your log files.

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

From keith at ahapala.net  Fri Jun  7 10:38:06 2002
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2002 10:38:06 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Printing images with GIMP
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206070957400.20603-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206071035080.4522-100000@skua.ahapala.net>

On Fri, 7 Jun 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I want to place several digital photographs, with captions, on a printed
> page for inclusion with a report. Has anyone used the GIMP for this? Or, is
> there other linux software that will do it?
> 
>   Up to now, I've fired up vmware and used my ol' vector GIS software to do
> this. I'd like to find a linux way to get the same results.
> 

Rich,

If you have the ImageMagick rpm installed you can use the convert command 
to annotate your pictures. Then just place them in your report document, 
or a blank page. This is probably not the easiest way to do it but I have 
found it a useful tool to remember. It can do all sorts of cool things 
with images.

Keith




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jun  7 10:37:24 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2002 10:37:24 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] logs not rotating
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206070944040.13932-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206071031500.20603-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 7 Jun 2002, Shannon C. Dealy wrote:

> I think you're not understanding the mechanism of the /etc/cron.daily
> (or .weekly, .monthly).

> Since you list a "logrotate" file in /etc/cron.daily, you should look at
> the contents of that file to see what it is doing, or possibly even
> manually execute the file to see if it will successfully rotate your log
> files.

Shannon,

  Very astute: I don't understand all that's going on here. :-)

  Your second suggestion may have identified the problem. I didn't see
anything wrong with the file (of course, as I don't know what I should
expect to see). So, I tried running it. Aha!

  The maillog script defines /var/log/maillog. There was another entry in
the syslog script that defined that file, too, and contained only a
post-rotate instruction. So, I moved that to the maillog script and removed
it from the syslog script. Then I learned that logrotate was trying to run
both named and named.rpmorig. Another log file name repeat. So, I've cleaned
that all up and logrotate ran manually.

  I'll know tomorrow morning if that was the problem. If so, there were no
error or warning messages to me to indictate any problem existed. Logrotate
just didn't run, I suppose.

  Thank you all very much. A follow up will be posted tomorrow.

Rich

From deanm at sharplabs.com  Fri Jun  7 11:20:10 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Fri,  7 Jun 2002 11:20:10 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] logs not rotating
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206070835310.19865-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
	(message from Rich Shepard on Fri, 7 Jun 2002 08:44:49 -0700 (PDT))
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206070835310.19865-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20020607182010.B15B710E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>


 :: > there should be a line in /etc/cron.daily that says logrotate, This will
 :: > get run when the run-parts  daily script runs. 
 :: 
 ::   I'm confused, Doug. /etc/cron.daily/ is a directory (as are the other
 :: /etc/cron.*/). It contains:
 :: cron.daily:
 :: 1postfix*        dailyscript*  makewhatis.cron*  tetex.cron*   tmpwatch*
 :: check-packages*  logrotate*    slocate.cron*     tetex.cron.rpmorig*
 :: 
 ::   The run-parts daily script. /etc/cron.daily/dailyscript, has nothing about
 :: logrotate in it.
 :: 
 ::   What do other RH installations have to rotate logs?
 :: 
 :: Thanks,
 :: 
 :: Rich

Richard,

Have a look again at /etc/crontab.  There you will see that
cron fires up `run-parts' on each of cron.{daily,weekly,monthly,...}
at the appropriate time.  It's run-parts that does the important work
of running each of the scripts in the cron.{...} diretories.

Now edit $(which run-parts) and you will  see how it works.

Dean

From m at netpro.to  Fri Jun  7 11:52:19 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2002 11:52:19 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] 1,500,000 records for MySQL?
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206071143540.18911-100000@lukem.com>

We currently have a system that is VERY EXPENSIVE (about $30k every other
year for licensing) that keeps a database of over a million scanned images
on an optical jukebox that are used for legal purposes by our company,
etc.  We'd like to explore using a home-grown solution to save money.  So
I've been asked to research this possibility.  There are about 1,500,000
images currently saved and there's a MS SQL 6.5 database that has info on
each image, such as an ID number, date, name, etc., and then a proprietary
Windows-only client program that accesses the database.

So here's my initial thought...  A web-based front-end that accesses a
MySQL database with the images stored on a large disk array.  I would like
a web-based front-end because about 30% of our company runs Linux on their
desktops, and they'll need access from time to time as well.  I'm leaning
towards MySQL simply because I'm the most familiar with it, but I'm not
sure how well it would handle 1.5 million records.  Has anyone had
experience with MySQL databases this large?  If MySQL is not the best
choice, then I'll gladly use whatever will do the best job.

Thank you for any feedback you might have.
~M




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Jun  7 12:20:53 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2002 12:20:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] logs not rotating
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206070443280.19488-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206070443280.19488-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200206071220.53125.aschlemm@attbi.com>

The other thing to try is running the logrotate command manually with 
debug and verbose messaging enabled. I looked at my (non-RedHat) system 
and it has a little script called "logrotate" in /etc/cron.daily with 
the following command:

#!/bin/sh

/usr/sbin/logrotate /etc/logrotate.conf

Make sure that your system's logrotate.conf file has an "include" 
directive that includes the /etc/logrotate.d directory. Should be 
something like:

include /etc/logrotate.d

In looking at the man page for "logrotate" a command of:

logrotate -dv /etc/logrotate.conf

will run "logrotate" in debug/verbose mode. I'm not sure if the file 
locations on my system are identical to a RedHat system but your setup 
sounds similar from reading your messages.

Tony

On Friday 07 June 2002 04:46 am, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Thu, 6 Jun 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> > It's all going to depend what sort of logrotate configuration you
> > have for your mail log. Most of the time I think things are
> > configured to rotate a file once it exceeds it's maximum allowed
> > size. If the file size isn't exceeded then it wouldn't be rotated.
> > There is a "daily" directive that you can specify in the logrotate
> > configuration for your mail log to cause the file to be rotated on
> > a daily basis.
>
> Tony,
>
>   I had both weekly and a maximum size specified; just changed it to
> daily for maillog. But, ... *all* my logs have been growing since
> 2/17/02, none have apparently rotated even though in
> /etc/logrotate.d/ each is directed to rotate weekly.
>
>   This is why I'm trying to better understand what's going on. The
> proper directives are there but they're not being followed. For
> example, yesterday afternoon, I changed the /etc/logrotate.d/maillog
> from 'weekly' to 'daily'. This morning's log still summarizes
> everything since I initiated postfix. Something's not right.
>
> Thanks,
>
> Rich

From dealy at deatech.com  Fri Jun  7 12:31:36 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2002 12:31:36 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] 1,500,000 records for MySQL?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206071143540.18911-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206071224070.14316-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Fri, 7 Jun 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:

[snip]
> So here's my initial thought...  A web-based front-end that accesses a
> MySQL database with the images stored on a large disk array.  I would like
> a web-based front-end because about 30% of our company runs Linux on their
> desktops, and they'll need access from time to time as well.  I'm leaning
> towards MySQL simply because I'm the most familiar with it, but I'm not
> sure how well it would handle 1.5 million records.  Has anyone had
> experience with MySQL databases this large?  If MySQL is not the best
> choice, then I'll gladly use whatever will do the best job.
>
> Thank you for any feedback you might have.
[snip]

I don't want to get into holy war here, but based on everything I've read
about the implementation of MySQL, while it does fine for many things, it
still lacks full SQL support, and it has some holes in it's implementation
that will allow it to mess up your database while performing transactions.
Given the above, and the fact that PostgreSQL does provide a full SQL
implementation (which will probably make it easier to migrate to from
your old system) and correct handling for transactions, PostgreSQL is the
only free DB that I would use for commercial work.


Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.

                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers

   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

You're joking, right?

I'm sure it's "somewhere" but I learned it the "hard way".  My logging
stopped working once (on a Solaris box) so I just started poking
around.  After seventeen or eighteen hours I had learned all about
syslog, log rotation, and a whole raft of other things which
eventually came in handy.

Search out every problem to it's foundation and refuse to apply
chewing-gum and bailing-wire solutions (unless there is simply no
other way) and you will learn a great deal.

Unfortunately my advice will cost you many hundreds of hours, will
mean that you can forget about taking family vacations, and will probably
lead to bankruptcy :-)

Dean

Well you might want to look at my post to the plug, in evolution I type
postgres, come back with all the treads. So spiffy. 

Our mail list should have a search !!!
https://lists.pdxlinux.org/pipermail/plug/2002-May/003334.html


IMHO MySQL, is not the greatest database. 

It does not pass Mr Dodd ACID Test, only if you build with InnoDB.

Look into postgres, in some cases it was faster then MySql. 

MySQL has the habbit of not gracefully failing.

here read these links. 

http://www.phpbuilder.com/columns/tim20000705.php3

MySQL VS Postgres by the TOR dude. 
http://www.webtechniques.com/archives/2001/09/jepson/



What I think it boils down to is MySQL rocks to snarf web logs, where
each item new entry into table.  Where MySQL is MS Access light. 80/20
rule, Where MySQL team only made fast what occurs 80% of the time, threw
out the rest. 

WOW  UNION is implemented in MySQL 4.0.0.
Wait , dev tree is only on 4.0.1. 

Postgres Rocks where you have many people playing with the same dataset
issuing updates. AKA 80 clients hitting the same row issuing updates.
Think of postgres as oracleGPL for the people. 


XFS. 

IMHO is the best journaling file system for linux. 

It has been design from the ground up to be a true journaling file
system. 

EXT3 is a hack, to ext2 to add journaling. 

JFS is not the JFS on AIX. 

It is from the source tree of Stale OS/2 JFS. So the development is not
the to the same level as the enterprise level as IBM AIX. 

http://oss.sgi.com/projects/xfs/features.html

2^63 = 9 x 1018 = 9 exabytes.  or 9000 Terabytes I think :) 
That is alot of MP3. 

POSIX Access Control Lists (ACLs)

The Linux XFS filesystem supports the ACL semantics and interfaces
described in the draft POSIX 1003.1e standard.

Maximum File Size

For Linux 2.4, the maximum accessible file offset is 16TB on 4K page
size and 64TB on 16K page size. As Linux moves to 64 bit on block
devices layer, file size limit will increase to 9 million terabytes (or
the system drive limits).



Hardware 

I would buy a new MPX Athlon with a dual 2, load up the ram. 

Buy a few Promise ATA 133 cards. 

For Best performance, no chaining the ide. aka 1 drive per each ide
cable.  

Loadup the ide, there is a new Wester Digital Driver with 2 or 4 megs of
cache. I think. 

Also I would do a nice raid 5. 

The hardware above is what I priced out for myself. 

was around 2,000 for 1/4 Terabyte. 


Also you want to see if the LVM, stuff works now. Aka not buggy. 





From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jun  7 12:43:48 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2002 12:43:48 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] phone number regex
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206071232540.21034-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I've been spinning my wheels here trying to create a semantically-correct
regex for emacs. T'ain't workin' properly.

  The file is a comma-and-quote delimited text file dumped from my
addressbook in jpilot. I want to strip out all telephone numbers which are
in the format "xxx-xxx-xxxx" by searching for them and replacing them with
nothing.

  Do I need to wrap the number range and hypen in the begin-group and
end-group symbols?

  I've tried what seemed to be reasonable ways of describing a telepone
number and not a building address, but have not achieved nirvana. I know
that the same results can be achieved with bash, ksh, perl, python, ruby,
scheme, guile. slang and .... I'd prefer to learn how to form the expression
properly in emacs.

Thanks,

Rich

From bhoran at hexdev.com  Fri Jun  7 13:27:52 2002
From: bhoran at hexdev.com (Brian Horan)
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2002 16:27:52 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] phone number regex
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206071232540.21034-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206071232540.21034-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <E17GPyx-00014y-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

how 'bout:

/\d{3}-\d{3}-\d{4}/

or if you're missing the area code:
/\d{0,3}-\d{3}-\d{4}/

On Friday 07 June 2002 03:43 pm, you wrote:
>   I've been spinning my wheels here trying to create a semantically-correct
> regex for emacs. T'ain't workin' properly.

From flee at aracnet.com  Fri Jun  7 14:15:25 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)
Date: Fri, 07 Jun 2002 14:15:25 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] phone number regex
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206071232540.21034-100000@appl-ecosys.com> on Fri, 07 Jun 2002 12:43:48 PDT.
Message-ID: <200206072115.g57LFRc15972@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com>:
>   The file is a comma-and-quote delimited text file dumped from my
> addressbook in jpilot. I want to strip out all telephone numbers which are
> in the format "xxx-xxx-xxxx" by searching for them and replacing them with
> nothing.

[0-9][0-9][0-9]-[0-9][0-9][0-9]-[0-9][0-9][0-9][0-9]

There isn't a simpler regexp in emacs that will match that
exactly.  (This is emacs 20.7; I haven't looked at what
changes emacs 21 introduced yet.)
--
[ sometimes these boots are made for booting ]



From alex at daniloff.com  Fri Jun  7 13:29:08 2002
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)
Date: Fri, 07 Jun 2002 13:29:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] 1,500,000 records for =?iso-8859-1?q?MySQL=3F?=
In-Reply-To: <1023478737.22114.118.camel@brain>
Message-ID: <200206072029.g57KT8N09746@gate.daniloff.com>

Hello,
We are using MySQL as a full blown production database in our company
for over two years. 
It has on average over 16,000,000 data rows per table and consists of
83 tables.
So far we have never experienced any problems with it. 
Recently we upgraded it to MySQL 4.0 Max to take a full advantage of
InnoDB tables which are ACID compliant and have foreign keys. 
The only one point we can't agree upon what to use for datafiles raw
partition or exsisting file system. 
 
Lets cut this crap off:
> 
> Well you might want to look at my post to the plug, in evolution I
type
> postgres, come back with all the treads. So spiffy. 
> 
> Our mail list should have a search !!!
> https://lists.pdxlinux.org/pipermail/plug/2002-May/003334.html
> 
> IMHO MySQL, is not the greatest database. 
> 

Nether your beloved PostgreSQL. 
When we tested it in our environment it was awfully slow, although,
reach in features most of which won't be used in normal operations
and can be easily substituted within API. 

> It does not pass Mr Dodd ACID Test, only if you build with InnoDB.

So what? Use MySQL with ACID compliant InnoDB tables. 

http://www.innodb.com/

It's always better to have a choice what table type (ISAM, MyISAM,
Gemini, BDB, InnoDB) use for your specific tasks,
than just stick with default table provided with PostgreSQL.
 
> Look into postgres, in some cases it was faster then MySql. 

It has never been proven to be a true.
 
> MySQL has the habbit of not gracefully failing.

It's a rubbish.
Rather vice versa. PostgreSQL was failing in our test when it was
managed by persistently running FCGI API's emulating over 200
sumultaneous users.
MySQL was rock solid in the same test conditions. 

> 
> here read these links. 
> 
> http://www.phpbuilder.com/columns/tim20000705.php3
> 
> MySQL VS Postgres by the TOR dude. 
> http://www.webtechniques.com/archives/2001/09/jepson/

Look at the dates of these publications first.
If somebody posted something on Internet it doesn't mean that
informtion is correct nether these tests were done correctly.
 
 
> What I think it boils down to is MySQL rocks to snarf web logs,
where
> each item new entry into table.  Where MySQL is MS Access light.
80/20
> rule, Where MySQL team only made fast what occurs 80% of the time,
threw
> out the rest.

Well, it's your personal opinion which doesn't nesseserely constitutes
the truth.
 
> 
> WOW  UNION is implemented in MySQL 4.0.0.
> Wait , dev tree is only on 4.0.1. 
> 
> Postgres Rocks where you have many people playing with the same
dataset
> issuing updates. AKA 80 clients hitting the same row issuing
updates.

PostgreSQL is not totally SQL compliant ether.

> Think of postgres as oracleGPL for the people. 

Very suggestive!

> 
> 
> XFS. 
> 
> IMHO is the best journaling file system for linux. 
> 

What's about ReiserFS?

> 
> Hardware 
> 
> I would buy a new MPX Athlon with a dual 2, load up the ram. 
> 
> Buy a few Promise ATA 133 cards.

What about HPT370 Sidebus Raid controller? 
Very inexpensivce and fast.
 

> Loadup the ide, there is a new Wester Digital Driver with 2 or 4
megs of
> cache. I think. 

Don't go with WD they are crap. 
As a rule after three years WD fails unexpectably.
We had five of such occasions and we've lost a lot of data. 
Use IBM or Maxtor HD's but not WD,
especially for RAID applications.

> 
> Also I would do a nice raid 5. 
> 

Reliable but very sloooow on average about 4 MB/sec transfer rate on
the system with four ATA 100 HD's.

RAID0+1 configuration is good and reliable. About 33MB/sec 
Even better to use replication master slave on two independent RAID0
arrays on the same server. About 70MB/sec per RAID0 array.
This feature is natively supported in MySQL.

Alex

Subject: [PLUG] Linux Networking course!
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206071559310.1610-100000@localhost.localdomain>

I am happy to report that Accelerated Learning Center is going to be 
offering a Linux Networking course this July. I am definately going to 
sign up for this course. Ed Sawicki, the instructor, tells me that he 
needs at least 6 people to sign up for the course to go forward. For that 
reason he wants to schedule the course on the most convenient days 
possible. This course will be taught by Ed Sawicki, an experienced 
instructor who has worked in the computer industry since the early 1970s.

Here is the curriculum of the course: 
http://alcpress.com/training/courses/linuxnetworking.htm

ALC is offering this course at $320, which is significantly less than the 
$595 for which they usually offer it.

The course will either be three weekdays or three Saturdays.

1. Are there people on this list who would sign up for this course? 

2. If you are interested would you rather attend three weekdays or three 
Saturdays during July?

I will report back to ALC what I learn. I hope some other people join me 
in signing up for this course so it can go forward.


------


In addition, Ed Sawicki is also teaching a Linux OS course at PCC. This 
course will cover the basics of the Linux OS and Linux System 
Administration:

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Fri Jun  7 11:59:16 2002
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: 07 Jun 2002 11:59:16 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Getting Redhat Install to do LBA?
Message-ID: <1023476356.7826.275.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

So I added a 20G drive to my sony vaio F540.

It had a 6G drive in there.

When I run Redhat 7.3 installer it only sees the CHS drive size of 8G
(1027 Cyl, not 1024 BTW).

I cannot seem to convince Redhat's boot process to look at the LBA data.

Oddly, the Vaio is the first Bios that listed the CHS (Cyl Head Sector)
differently then the LBA.

I tried

linux linear
linux lba
linux lba32
linux ide=lba
linux ide=lba32

Any ideas?  I have never had to care about LBA/CHS before......


--

From jeff at jhenshaw.com  Fri Jun  7 11:06:04 2002
From: jeff at jhenshaw.com (J Henshaw)
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2002 18:06:04 -0000
Subject: [PLUG] 1,500,000 records for MySQL?
References: <200206072029.g57KT8N09746@gate.daniloff.com> <200206071441.55452.AthlonRobNF@CS.com>
Message-ID: <02c801c20e4d$fdb05e60$0400a8c0@oem2k>

That won't scale.
That's been proven to be O(N^2) and we need a solution that's O(NlogN).
There are, of course, various export limitations on that technology.
The syntax is idiosyncratic.
Trying to build a team behind that technology would be a staffing nightmare.
That can't be generalized to a cross-platform build.
Unfortunately, the license would contaminate our product.
If we go with that idea, we're going to have Don Marti camped out in the
front lobby with 300 angry software jihad supporters.
Our support infrastructure simply can't handle the volume that change would
involve.
I had one of the interns try that approach for another project, and it
scrambled the CEO's hard drive. So I think it's going to be a hard sell.
Yes, well, that's just not the way things work in the real world.
I like your idea. Why don't you write up a white paper and we'll review it
at the next staff meeting?
Unfortunately, we're an all-FORTH shop. Otherwise, it's a nice idea.
I think you need to stop taking this so personally. We need to think about
what's best for the project, not about our own little pet theories.
Oh, I played with that approach back as an undergrad. Got a D, too.
I was reading about that on BugTraq yesterday.
Yes, I believe that's the approach Windows NT is taking.
That's totally inefficient on modern hardware.
Well, yes, but it really reduces to the knapsack problem in that case. Do
you have some kind of heuristic, or are we dealing with an NP-complete case?
Have you LOOKED at the number of I/O requests that will create?
We can't afford the transaction overhead.
Yeah, or we could all just plink away on Amigas or something.
What? I don't speak your crazy moon-language.
Hmm. Didn't they just go bankrupt? It's OK, I guess -- there's some German
company who's picked up the existing service contracts.
No, no, no. We're really working on an N-TIER architecture, here.
No, no, no. It's fairly important that the database be in THIRD NORMAL FORM.
No, that would break object encapsulation.
I don't think that's altogether clear. Please write it up in UML for me.
I think there's a problem with your drive geometry.
Can you generate some USE CASES that would justify the change?
How is that going to impact the schedule?
RAM is cheap and all, but...
It would probably be best if we deferred that until version 2.0.
I like it, but it is too point-oh for my tastes.
If you make this change, I will fork the code.
Yes, well, unfortunately the economy is going away from anything remotely
like that. Our investors would kill us.
Jakob Nielsen wrote an interesting hit piece on that.
Yes, yes, we've all read DJB's RFCs on the subject.
This is all covered in Knuth, and we don't have time to go over it again.
This one is in the FAQ:
http://www.linuxmafia.com/~rick/faq/#your_dumb_technology
I don't have time for this extropian nonsense.
Well, I guess we could start the QA cycles again from square one. That would
require a press release, though.
You used to program in Pascal, didn't you?
Why don't we make a generalized solution including both options, and let the
administrator decide with a config-file setting?

From pkbarnett at email.msn.com  Fri Jun  7 18:46:59 2002
From: pkbarnett at email.msn.com (pkbarnett)
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2002 18:46:59 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] 1,500,000 records for MySQL?
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206071143540.18911-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <00d601c20e8e$62154060$6e51a1d8@mycomputer>

As a database administrator for a rather large company, I can understand the
concern about the licensing costs.  It is an ongoing battle with management.
They want it cheap, reliable and recoverable.  As the old saw goes, you can
have two out of three.

We too have legal documents.  We do NOT have the option of losing even one
record.  Never, never, never lose a record.  That rules out cheap.  We run
Oracle and SQL Server in various releases.  Moving to a shareware/freeware
database simply would not be allowed.

That said, other places I have worked would have let me do literally
anything I wanted.  However, decisions like this would have been a 'You bet
your job' decision.  As a computer professional my first obligation is to
protect the data of my company.  If MySql allows this to happen and saves
$30K go for it.  If there is even the remotest doubt that you could
completely recover (as in tested under all possible scenarios before going
production), then pay the $30K and pass the blame to the vendor if an
unrecoverable disaster occurs.

Management pays me good money, sends me to at least one conference a year
and a couple of classes without complaint because things just work all the
time every time.  It doesn't hurt to remind them once in awhile that some
new feature I learned saved them a bundle.

If you can't have proven reliability and recoverability - skip the move to
something new.

Pete

----- Original Message -----
From: "Matt Alexander" <m at netpro.to>
To: <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>
Sent: Friday, June 07, 2002 11:52 AM
Subject: [PLUG] 1,500,000 records for MySQL?


> We currently have a system that is VERY EXPENSIVE (about $30k every other
> year for licensing) that keeps a database of over a million scanned images
> on an optical jukebox that are used for legal purposes by our company,
> etc.  We'd like to explore using a home-grown solution to save money.  So
> I've been asked to research this possibility.  There are about 1,500,000
> images currently saved and there's a MS SQL 6.5 database that has info on
> each image, such as an ID number, date, name, etc., and then a proprietary
> Windows-only client program that accesses the database.
>
> So here's my initial thought...  A web-based front-end that accesses a
> MySQL database with the images stored on a large disk array.  I would like
> a web-based front-end because about 30% of our company runs Linux on their
> desktops, and they'll need access from time to time as well.  I'm leaning
> towards MySQL simply because I'm the most familiar with it, but I'm not
> sure how well it would handle 1.5 million records.  Has anyone had
> experience with MySQL databases this large?  If MySQL is not the best
> choice, then I'll gladly use whatever will do the best job.
>
> Thank you for any feedback you might have.
> ~M

I answered Alex question last month, here is the recap. 

 ReiserFS if memory severed rocked at itty bity files. 

Have you looked at the # of patches that come out for ReiserFS ?? 
http://www.namesys.com/download.html

These types of messages do not give me warm fuzzy, when it comes to my
data. 
----------------------------------------------------------
CAUTION
WARNING
1. Don't use linux kernel 2.4.16 or earlier for reiserfs operations, as
many of those releases contain critical bugs, some of the most serious
of which are not in reiserfs but affect reiserfs. 2.4.16, 2.4.9, and
2.4.3 are especially bad. The SuSE release of 2.4.16 is ok, it contains
some needed patches. 2.4.18 is the latest release at the time of
writing, and it said to be solid and reliable.
2. For linux kernel 2.5.6 or 2.5.7 you need an additional patch that
will allow the use of reiserfs: 01-revert_broken_alviro_cleanup.diff
----------------------------------------------------------


Here are some bonie runs , with ext2,ext3 jfs, xfs. 
 
http://oss.software.ibm.com/pipermail/jfs-discussion/2001-October/000687.html

http://www.nobell.org/~gjm/linux/ide-raid/

RAID + LVM + Journaled File System + Oracle + TPC-C and AS3AP SQL
benchmarks. 
http://www.linuxjournal.com/article.php?sid=5841

http://www.linuxjournal.com/modules/NS-articles/style/5841f3.jpg
Table 1. AS3AP Transaction Benchmark Results
Create Load Create Total Trans/ Avg
Database Tables Indexes Time Second Time
ext2 345 289 474 1,108 254 0.205
ext3 230 127 221 578 252 0.208
Reiser 371 291 1,029 1,691 250 0.210
IBM JFS 350 282 462 1,094 253 0.207
RAW 396 290 442 1,128 196 0.369
 
http://www.linuxjournal.com/modules/NS-articles/style/5841f4.jpg

Table 2. TPC-C Transaction Benchmark Results
Create Load Create Total Trans/ Avg
Database Tables Indexes Time Second Time
ext2 348 295 234 877 2.758 0.016
ext3 228 158 122 508 2.753 0.019
Reiser 378 297 537 1,212 2.757 0.028
IBM JFS 351 277 231 859 2.757 0.025
RAW 396 290 225 911 2.748 0.073
RAW X 2 396 240 263 899 2.753 0.050

So Alex, if you look at lj bechmark for Riserfs it comes in dead last
for TPC-C and AS3AP. 

EXT3 Kicked it ass, I just wished there was an xfs part of the
benchmark. 

EXT3 beat out raw file system too. 

Is this benchmark, use able for you ?? 

It is oracle, yes , but it does stress out a RDMS, so these should show
some light on other RDMS other then oracle, when it comes to file system
performance. 

EXT3 even beat out raw file system.

From ed at alcpress.com  Fri Jun  7 18:46:07 2002
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: 07 Jun 2002 18:46:07 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Ethereal problems
Message-ID: <1023500768.2947.15.camel@red>

For those of you that use Ethereal for troubleshooting network
protocols, be aware that it will sometimes decode the wrong
protocol. For example, the last time I started one of my DNS
servers (BIND8 on an old Red Hat 6.X box)) it chose an ephemeral
port of 1745 to use when sending recursive queries to other DNS
servers. Ethereal interprets these packets as the "MSproxy"
protocol instead of the DNS protocol.

These UDP packets use 1745 for the source port and 53 as the
destination port. It seems that Ethereal looks at the source
port first and if it finds a port relating to a protocol it
knows how to decode, it goes with that regardless of what the
destination port is. This is clearly the wrong thing to do
because 1745 is only a registered port but 53 is a well-known
port. A well-known port (1-1023) should always trump a registered
port (1024 an up). This is far more likely to be correct than the
reverse. 

Ed - 11101101

> > uh, I believe that's 11101101 as in 0xED - only one ED :)
> >
> > Sandy
> > --
>
> ASCII code for ED would be 45 44 in Hex.
>
> Numbers aren't  letters....

From sandy at herring.org  Fri Jun  7 21:02:35 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2002 21:02:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Red Hat Certified Engineer (RHCE certification)
In-Reply-To: <000601c20e9b$a07e0b90$7501a8c0@endeavor>; from greg@maneuveringspeed.com on Fri, Jun 07, 2002 at 08:21:41PM -0700
References: <000601c20e9b$a07e0b90$7501a8c0@endeavor>
Message-ID: <20020607210235.A10223@kippered.herring.org>

I got my RHCE last November (RH7.2). My employer paid for the one week
course and exam - otherwise I wouldn't have it. The training did help to
fill in a few holes, but it's mainly a refresher - don't expect to be able
to pass the exam if you have little prior experience with linux (Red Hat in
particular). It's more a validation of what you know than a learning
experience.

I think it was time well spent - and has helped me on the job. But I don't
know how much value it would have in terms of landing a new job. My employer
saw value in sending me and 5 of my cow-orkers in terms of marketing and
sales being able to hype the number of engineers that are certified (we're
all certifiable ;-).

Sandy


On Fri, 07 Jun 2002, Greg Long wrote: 
> I am considering the RHCE training and certification, has anyone out
> there obtained the RHCE, and if so, has the training and/or piece of
> paper helped them?  I know this isn't the best time to ask, in the midst
> of recession and layoffs, however with Linux starting to gain more
> mainstream use and acceptability thought it might merit consideration.
> 
> 
> 
> Greg Long

From kevinh at ados.com  Sat Jun  8 10:27:38 2002
From: kevinh at ados.com (Kevin Hammack)
Date: Sat, 8 Jun 2002 10:27:38 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Printing images with GIMP
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206070957400.20603-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206070957400.20603-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20020608102738.370b0760.kevinh@ados.com>

On Fri, 7 Jun 2002 09:59:53 -0700 (PDT)
Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> wrote:

I haven't personally, but I know it can be done because one of my
coworkers is into digital photography and has incredible printouts using
"gimp-print":  

gimp-print.sourceforge.net

He also got some special paper at pro photo that wasn't too expensive. 
The advantage of doing this with gimp is you can match the color and
gamma of the screen with your printout, so that even if you enhance the
image it will look right when printed.  The results are not
distinguishable from photographs (not by the layperson at least).  

You could easily paste your image onto a slightly larger canvas in gimp,
and use the outer white area to render whatever text and caption you
wanted.  

>   I want to place several digital photographs, with captions, on a
>   printed page for inclusion with a report. Has anyone used the GIMP
>   for this? Or, is there other linux software that will do it?
> 
>   Up to now, I've fired up vmware and used my ol' vector GIS software
>   to do this. I'd like to find a linux way to get the same results.
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> Rich
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From bjh at avalongroup.net  Sat Jun  8 11:32:31 2002
From: bjh at avalongroup.net (Brian Hoag)
Date: Sat, 8 Jun 2002 11:32:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Red Hat Certified Engineer (RHCE certification)
In-Reply-To: <20020607210235.A10223@kippered.herring.org>
Message-ID: <FNECLAAKFMEIJKOOGKKJAEHECBAA.bjh@avalongroup.net>

My previous employer went to NC and got his certification right after it was
released.  He was the first RHCE in Oregon. He did it mainly as a marketing
tool for the company.  According to him, you better have a pretty good
understanding of RedHat if you want to pass.  If you can find a company that
is looking for RHCE's, it is definately worth it.  But the MCSE overload has
soured the industry on certifications as a whole.

Brian Hoag
Vice President of Service
Group Avalon Technology Services, Inc.

From deanm at sharplabs.com  Sat Jun  8 12:24:54 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Sat,  8 Jun 2002 12:24:54 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Urgent help with `rsh'
Message-ID: <20020608192454.4054510E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>

Sorry for the "urgent" but, well, it's urgent.

I need to use `rsh' as root to accomplish a task.

Aside: please --- no lectures on the security risks involved; I'm fully
                  aware of these.  To put your minds at rest: the task is
                  to be performed in a completely
                  closed env. and after it's done rsh will be removed
                  from the system.  

I've installed `in.rshd' on a mandrake 8.2 system (hostname == `medulla')
I need to do a sequence of root --> root remote command executions
like (as root on pons):

      rsh medulla cmd_1
      rsh medulla cmd_2 ...

In which data will flow between the machines.

I have put  a `.rhosts' file in the root dir. of medulla and
a lone `rsh medulla' gets me a root prompt so I know that the
basic communications ports are all working.

But when I do `rsh medulla cmd'  I get either:

"permission denied"  or "Connection refused" as elaborated below.

Here is my current /etc/xinetd.d/rsh file on medulla:

     # default: off
     # description: The rshd server is the server for the rcmd(3) routine and, \
     #	consequently, for the rsh(1) program.  The server provides \
     #	remote execution facilities with authentication based on \
     #	privileged port numbers from trusted hosts.
     service shell
     {
             socket_type		= stream
             wait			= no
             user			= root
             log_on_success		+= USERID
             log_on_failure 		+= USERID
             server			= /usr/sbin/in.rshd -h -L
             disable			= no
     }    


Note the `-h' flag on the server line.  Without it I get the
"permission denied" message on pons.   The `rshd' man page says
that without the flag I can't execute remote commands so this is expected.

When I add the flag I get the "Connection refused" message.
I don't see anything in /var/log/messages or /var/log/auth.log
which helps.

I suspect that PAM is somehow involved in this problem.

Here is my current /etc/pam.d/rsh file on medulla:


    #%PAM-1.0
    # For root login to succeed here with pam_securetty, "rsh" must be
    # listed in /etc/securetty.
    auth       required	/lib/security/pam_nologin.so
    auth       required	/lib/security/pam_securetty.so
    auth       required     /lib/security/pam_env.so
    auth       required     /lib/security/pam_rhosts_auth.so
    account    required	/lib/security/pam_stack.so service=system-auth
    session    required	/lib/security/pam_stack.so service=system-auth


As always, any help in getting this to work will be appreciated.
And, of course I'm in a huge hurry as I'm leaving on a business trip
and need to have this working before I go.


                                  Dean S. Messing
                                  Information Systems Technologies Dept.
                                  Sharp Laboratories of America
                          E-Mail: deanm at sharplabs.com





From m at netpro.to  Sat Jun  8 12:44:02 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Sat, 8 Jun 2002 12:44:02 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Urgent help with `rsh'
In-Reply-To: <20020608192454.4054510E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206081241070.28107-100000@lukem.com>

Here's a link that talks about how to setup rsh, including adding entries
to /etc/securetty (which may be all you need):

http://www.redhat.com/docs/manuals/linux/RHL-7.2-Manual/ref-guide/s1-pam-rexec.html

From pem at nellump.net  Sat Jun  8 12:54:13 2002
From: pem at nellump.net (Paul Mullen)
Date: Sat, 8 Jun 2002 12:54:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Getting Redhat Install to do LBA?
In-Reply-To: <1023476356.7826.275.camel@kat.zotnet.com>; from zot@whiteknighthackers.com on Fri, Jun 07, 2002 at 11:59:16AM -0700
References: <1023476356.7826.275.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
Message-ID: <20020608125413.B2759@nellump.net>

On Fri, Jun 07, 2002 at 11:59:16AM -0700, Zot O'Connor wrote:
> So I added a 20G drive to my sony vaio F540.
> 
> It had a 6G drive in there.
> 
> When I run Redhat 7.3 installer it only sees the CHS drive size of 8G
> (1027 Cyl, not 1024 BTW).
> 
> I cannot seem to convince Redhat's boot process to look at the LBA data.

What bootloader? I had no difficulties getting LILO to work happily with
a 10GB drive in my ancient Gateway P166 laptop (under RH 7.0). I'm not
sure how it would behave now that they seemed to have switched to GRUB,
as I've since installed a BIOS overlay from IBM (necessary to get
Windoze to accept the drive). Contrary to popular expectation, I've had
no problems at all with the BIOS overlay.


Paul

Matt Alexander wrote:
 ::to /etc/securetty (which may be all you need):
 ::
 ::http://www.redhat.com/docs/manuals/linux/RHL-7.2-Manual/ref-guide/s1-pam-rexec.html

Thanks Matt but this will not help.  (I tried it and it doesn't).

I'm not trying to login to medulla's root account.  I'm trying to
execute remote commands via `rsh'.  The advice on the web page
is for allowing root login via rlogin.   (rsh w/o commands == rlogin, by
the way.)

Since I have a `.rhosts' file in the root dir. of medulla, I can already
login w/o the additions to /etc/securetty and without a password---which
is what is required to execute remote commands.

So I'm still in the hole.  Any help will be greatly appreciated.
My flight time approaches.

Dean

 :: --Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

Keep shooting.  Maybe next time you'll hit something.
I just tried putting `pons' in /etc/hosts.equiv.  Same response:
Also tried `+'.  No dice:


[root at pons /root]# rsh medulla /bin/ls
medulla: Connection refused
[root at pons /root]# 

Note that I already have an `.rhosts' in the /root directory of 
medulla which contains "pons" as its only entry.  This makes
a lone `rsh medulla'  instantly return a medulla root command prompt.

But `rsh medulla cmd' gives the above.  I even (without knowing
what I'm really doing) changed every line in `/etc/pam.d/rsh' from

#%PAM-1.0
# For root login to succeed here with pam_securetty, "rsh" must be
# listed in /etc/securetty.
auth       required	/lib/security/pam_nologin.so
auth       required	/lib/security/pam_securetty.so
auth       required     /lib/security/pam_env.so
auth       required     /lib/security/pam_rhosts_auth.so
account    required	/lib/security/pam_stack.so service=system-auth
session    required	/lib/security/pam_stack.so service=system-auth

to


#%PAM-1.0
# For root login to succeed here with pam_securetty, "rsh" must be
# listed in /etc/securetty.
auth       required	/lib/security/pam_permit.so
auth       required	/lib/security/pam_permit.so
auth       required     /lib/security/pam_permit.so
auth       required     /lib/security/pam_permit.so
account    required	/lib/security/pam_permit.so
session    required	/lib/security/pam_permit.so


As I said, I'm shooting from  the hip here as well.  It didn't work.

I also tried doing `msec 0' on medulla (always restarting "xinetd", just
for fun) which basiclly changes the "security level"
of the machine to "Crackers Welcome".
Again no dice.

Nothing works.  Very frustrating.  I've now been here at work for 4
hours to accomplish a task that should have taken 45 minutes (and I
haven't even started on the task!!).

Linux: the ultimate love-hate relationship.

Dean

From m at netpro.to  Sat Jun  8 15:35:31 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Sat, 8 Jun 2002 15:35:31 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Urgent help with `rsh'
In-Reply-To: <20020608192454.4054510E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206081503410.613-100000@lukem.com>

OK, I just setup rsh from the RPM and got it working.  I enabled
/etc/xinetd.d/rsh, /etc/xinetd.d/rlogin, and /etc/xinetd.d/rexec.  I then created
/etc/hosts.equiv and /root/.rhosts and put in the computer name which is
defined in /etc/hosts.  Next, I added rsh, rlogin, and rexec
to /etc/securetty.  /etc/hosts has the FQDN and the hostname for all
hosts involved.



On Sat, 8 Jun 2002, Dean S. Messing wrote:

>
> Sorry for the "urgent" but, well, it's urgent.
>
> I need to use `rsh' as root to accomplish a task.
>
> Aside: please --- no lectures on the security risks involved; I'm fully
>                   aware of these.  To put your minds at rest: the task is
>                   to be performed in a completely
>                   closed env. and after it's done rsh will be removed
>                   from the system.
>
> I've installed `in.rshd' on a mandrake 8.2 system (hostname == `medulla')
> I need to do a sequence of root --> root remote command executions
> like (as root on pons):
>
>       rsh medulla cmd_1
>       rsh medulla cmd_2 ...
>
> In which data will flow between the machines.
>
> I have put  a `.rhosts' file in the root dir. of medulla and
> a lone `rsh medulla' gets me a root prompt so I know that the
> basic communications ports are all working.
>
> But when I do `rsh medulla cmd'  I get either:
>
> "permission denied"  or "Connection refused" as elaborated below.
>
> Here is my current /etc/xinetd.d/rsh file on medulla:
>
>      # default: off
>      # description: The rshd server is the server for the rcmd(3) routine and, \
>      #	consequently, for the rsh(1) program.  The server provides \
>      #	remote execution facilities with authentication based on \
>      #	privileged port numbers from trusted hosts.
>      service shell
>      {
>              socket_type		= stream
>              wait			= no
>              user			= root
>              log_on_success		+= USERID
>              log_on_failure 		+= USERID
>              server			= /usr/sbin/in.rshd -h -L
>              disable			= no
>      }
>
>
> Note the `-h' flag on the server line.  Without it I get the
> "permission denied" message on pons.   The `rshd' man page says
> that without the flag I can't execute remote commands so this is expected.
>
> When I add the flag I get the "Connection refused" message.
> I don't see anything in /var/log/messages or /var/log/auth.log
> which helps.
>
> I suspect that PAM is somehow involved in this problem.
>
> Here is my current /etc/pam.d/rsh file on medulla:
>
>
>     #%PAM-1.0
>     # For root login to succeed here with pam_securetty, "rsh" must be
>     # listed in /etc/securetty.
>     auth       required	/lib/security/pam_nologin.so
>     auth       required	/lib/security/pam_securetty.so
>     auth       required     /lib/security/pam_env.so
>     auth       required     /lib/security/pam_rhosts_auth.so
>     account    required	/lib/security/pam_stack.so service=system-auth
>     session    required	/lib/security/pam_stack.so service=system-auth
>
>
> As always, any help in getting this to work will be appreciated.
> And, of course I'm in a huge hurry as I'm leaving on a business trip
> and need to have this working before I go.

From deanm at sharplabs.com  Sat Jun  8 16:39:56 2002
From: deanm at sharplabs.com (Dean S. Messing)
Date: Sat,  8 Jun 2002 16:39:56 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Urgent help with `rsh' (problem fixed)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206081503410.613-100000@lukem.com> (message from
	Matt Alexander on Sat, 8 Jun 2002 15:35:31 -0700 (PDT))
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206081503410.613-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <20020608233956.DBE0910E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>



I just got off the phone with Matt Alexander who successfully
helped me fix my tricky `rsh' problem.  Thanks a million Matt.

It turns out that the man page (for rshd) is wrong where it says:

     8.   Rshd then validates the user using ruserok(3),  which uses the file
          /etc/hosts.equiv and the .rhosts file found in the user's home di?
          rectory. The -l option prevents ruserok(3) from doing any validation
          based on the user's ``.rhosts'' file (unless the user is the supe?
          ruser and the -h option is used.) If the -h option is not used, su?
          peruser accounts may not be accessed via this service at all.

Note the double negative in the last sentence.

In fact supplying the -h flag seems to inhibit rshd from ever allowing
remote command execution (as root or otherwise).  Also Matt's original
comment regarding an entry in /etc/securetty is correct, thought you
only need an entry for `rsh'.  When I tried his suggestion I had the
-h flag on the daemon and so it appeared that his suggestion made no
difference.

Note that had I  not read the manual I never would have added the -h flag
and all would  have been well.

The fractured moral of this tale of a wasted Saturday is

        "Don't read the manual and everything will be OK".


Dean

From pkbarnett at email.msn.com  Sat Jun  8 19:15:56 2002
From: pkbarnett at email.msn.com (pkbarnett)
Date: Sat, 8 Jun 2002 19:15:56 -0700
Subject: Fw: [PLUG] 1,500,000 records for MySQL?
Message-ID: <007b01c20f5b$97834bc0$0300a8c0@mycomputer>

----- Original Message -----
From: "pkbarnett" <pkbarnett at email.msn.com>
To: <alex at daniloff.com>
Sent: Saturday, June 08, 2002 7:14 PM
Subject: Fw: [PLUG] 1,500,000 records for MySQL?


> This bounced the first time.  Hope it gets through now.
>
> Pete
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "pkbarnett" <pkbarnett at email.msn.com>
> To: <alex at daniloff.com>
> Sent: Saturday, June 08, 2002 7:11 PM
> Subject: Re: [PLUG] 1,500,000 records for MySQL?
>
>
> > I seem to remember your name from my days at Komatsu Silicon.  Did you
do
> > some work for them several years ago?
> >
> > I always used cooked files if I can.  Recoverability can be a real
problem
> > with raw file systems.  As to the type, whatever the OS likes best.
Above
> > all else, the database has to be reliable and recoverable.
> >
> > In the bad old days of database administration, everyone was promoting
> > striped files across many disks.  Spindle count was the dogma of the
day.
> > If you are not using scsi drives and hardware raid, I would still go for
> > spindle count.  Manually striping across several files should give you
> > better performance.  Make sure that the data files and the index files
are
> > on physically separate disks.  Performance really goes in the toilet
fast
> if
> > indexes and data files are the same disks.
> >
> > Depending on the database, memory helps performance.  If you can cache
> > enough of the highly used indexes and data blocks you rarely have to go
to
> > disk.  This saves a lot of time.  Defining 'lots of memory' is a bit
> tricky.
> > I have a box with 12 risc processors, 10G of memory and the database
still
> > gets clobbered.  I also have a simple two way box with 1G of memory and
> the
> > database just cruises.  Generally, more memory is better, but only to a
> > point.   That point can only be determined by actual analysis of the
> > database after it is up and running.
> >
> > Good luck.  If you have additional questions, I will try to answer them,
> but
> > keep in mind that 'it depends' is a common answer for databases.
> >
> > Pete
> >
> > ----- Original Message -----
> > From: "Alex Daniloff" <alex at daniloff.com>
> > To: <pkbarnett at email.msn.com>
> > Sent: Friday, June 07, 2002 6:07 PM
> > Subject: Re: [PLUG] 1,500,000 records for MySQL?
> >
> >
> > > Hello Pete,
> > > I'm sorry for this off PLUG list questions.
> > > However, I'll very appreciate if you find a time to answer.
> > > We are trying to setup resume database for unemployed PLUG members.
> > > But we have some DB structure questions on which we couldn't find
decent
> > > answers.
> > >
> > > As a DB professional what method do you prefer for storing DB data
> file -
> > > raw device or DB data file on top of existing OS file system?
> > >
> > > If you're using native OS file system what is it XFS., EXT3 ?
> > >
> > > What is better performace vise to setup larger e.g. >10GB or couple of
> > small
> > > e.g. 100M datafile /raw partitons to store the data?
> > >
> > > Thank you in advance for your answers.
> > > Alex
> > >
> > >
> > > On Friday 07 June 2002 06:46 pm, pkbarnett wrote:
> > > > As a database administrator for a rather large company, I can
> understand
> > > > the concern about the licensing costs.  It is an ongoing battle with
> > > > management. They want it cheap, reliable and recoverable.  As the
old
> > saw
> > > > goes, you can have two out of three.
> > > >
> > > > We too have legal documents.  We do NOT have the option of losing
even
> > one
> > > > record.  Never, never, never lose a record.  That rules out cheap.
We
> > run
> > > > Oracle and SQL Server in various releases.  Moving to a
> > shareware/freeware
> > > > database simply would not be allowed.
> > > >
> > > > That said, other places I have worked would have let me do literally
> > > > anything I wanted.  However, decisions like this would have been a
> 'You
> > bet
> > > > your job' decision.  As a computer professional my first obligation
is
> > to
> > > > protect the data of my company.  If MySql allows this to happen and
> > saves
> > > > $30K go for it.  If there is even the remotest doubt that you could
> > > > completely recover (as in tested under all possible scenarios before
> > going
> > > > production), then pay the $30K and pass the blame to the vendor if
an
> > > > unrecoverable disaster occurs.
> > > >
> > > > Management pays me good money, sends me to at least one conference a
> > year
> > > > and a couple of classes without complaint because things just work
all
> > the
> > > > time every time.  It doesn't hurt to remind them once in awhile that
> > some
> > > > new feature I learned saved them a bundle.
> > > >
> > > > If you can't have proven reliability and recoverability - skip the
> move
> > to
> > > > something new.
> > > >
> > > > Pete
> > > >

We just had a discussion on the list about the Linux Networking course, 
and several people said that they are interested in taking the course. 
Considering that I sent the email on a Friday afternoon, it got a pretty 
decent response and I bet a few more will express interest next week.

Several people have told me that Ed Sawicki (who teaches many ALC courses) 
is an excellent teacher and excellent teachers are hard to find. People 
have told me that the ALC courses have been useful. That is good enough 
for me.

> Not to sound rude, but it seems these courses are rather bland and can 
> be learned by reading a book.
> How much hands-on experience are they providing?

If you are not interested in the courses, why bother responding to this 
email? I want to get some people interested in taking a few courses this 
summer so the courses will run.

The courses involve some lecture, some demo, and some hands-on. I don't 
know the exact proportions of each.

As for books vs. courses, anything can be learned from a book. I got a 
Bachelor's degree. Could I have learned everything I learned in college 
through indepedent reading? Probably, but I am glad I went to college and 
would do it again no question. I like learning from an instructor. To many 
people it is useful to have a knowledgeable person guiding the learning 
process, answering questions, etc. Also, it can be fun.

If you are not interested in courses you are of course free to not 
participate...

From neil at pacifier.com  Sat Jun  8 20:22:23 2002

> community?

I agree. I think that we should let David Mandel and Karl Hegbloom know
that we do not like the way the lists are configured right now:

1. Few people (if any) use the news gateway, so let's kill that and go
back to a configuration *not* allowing non-subscribers to send to the
lists. This needs to be changed for *each* list.

2. As it stands now, you can change your individual mailman config to be
invisible on the subscriber list. This is easy to do and I recommend that
anyone who values their privacy, take a minute and do so. That's in the
mean time. Soon, very soon, I would like the list config for *each* list
changed so the subscriber list is not available to anyone (subscriber or
not). Granted the format of the list is not very useful as is but a
determined spammer could use the lists.

Since we are a somewhat democratic organization, I think that more than I
should let karl at microsharp and dmandel at microsharp.com know our opinions on
this matter. I have done so but my opinion alone is not enough. Do others
agree with me that these lists should be tightened up?

Let's get on the stick and tighten up the list config.


-- 
Neil Anuskiewicz
neil at pacifier.com

From neil at pacifier.com  Sat Jun  8 20:32:37 2002
From: neil at pacifier.com (Neil Anuskiewicz)
Date: Sat, 8 Jun 2002 20:32:37 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] in the mean time
In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0206082012400.9160-100000@shell.pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0206082028410.28102-100000@shell.pacifier.com>

On Sat, 8 Jun 2002, Neil Anuskiewicz wrote:

> 2. As it stands now, you can change your individual mailman config to be
> invisible on the subscriber list. This is easy to do and I recommend that
> anyone who values their privacy, take a minute and do so. That's in the
> mean time. Soon, very soon, I would like the list config for *each* list
> changed so the subscriber list is not available to anyone (subscriber or
> not). Granted the format of the list is not very useful as is but a
> determined spammer could use the lists.

I might have created a wrong impression here. The only thing available
to subscribers that is a concern, is the subscriber list *not* any sort of
private config info.

For example, if you want to view the plug subscriber list you would get a
list with emails in this sort of format:

neil at pacifier.com

It is purposely formated that way to prevent spam harvesting,
nevertheless, I don't like having these lists available at all. It is
probably harmless to have the list available to subcribers especially in
this format but, as I said, a determined evildoer (spammer) could do some
evil with such lists.


-- 
Neil Anuskiewicz
neil at pacifier.com

Well, this Linux Networking course is $325. I will ask Ed this week how

I don't think $325 is expensive. I just looked at New Horizons Computer
Learning Center and they charge $1,595 for what I think is a week long
course. That is $319/day. ALC is charging $320 for a three day course.
That is about $108/day. In both cases that would be eight hour days. I
think ALC is offering a pretty decent price for this course here locally.

Ed says that they will most likely spread the days out so you have time to
absorb the material, study, practice what you learned, etc. So I think
this means that there would be three full day sessions spread out over
three weeks. You'd have a week between each session. Personally, I feel
pretty enthusiastic about this course and I really hope ALC offers more
courses as well.

> $1240 per term for tuition is more than enough to budget for learning at this
> time.

Hey, if you are a full-time student then you certainly have your hands
full and you might as well focus your full energy on getting that done.
:-)

Subject: [PLUG] Advice on switches for home network

I'm hoping to avoid unnecessary pitfalls of setting up a small
network.

I have a DSL connection with a 2 Linux PCs, and will soon add a
Thinkpad and a printer. I'll need some kind of switch to link
everything up. Any ideas as to what they cost, what features I
need to keep an eye out for, as well as advices on who makes good
(bad!) switches? I'm guessing I'll probably see the best
selection at Fry's??

From neil at pacifier.com  Sat Jun  8 22:22:01 2002
From: neil at pacifier.com (Neil Anuskiewicz)
Date: Sat, 8 Jun 2002 22:22:01 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Other ALC courses
In-Reply-To: <3D02D5F4.4030803@cryptowave.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0206082158590.30575-100000@shell.pacifier.com>

On Sat, 8 Jun 2002, John H. wrote:

> I never said I wasn't interested, I was requesting more information
> about them.

Well, I don't know that much about them other than the fact that several
people have told me that ALC and Ed in particular do a good job of
teaching. As anyone who has taken courses knows, it is really hit or miss
on instructors.

In college, I'd say that about 40% of my instructors were terrible, 40%
were just mediocre, and another 20% were really good. I have not yet taken
a course from Ed but people tell me he is in the really good category.

It is an interesting question as to what makes an instructor bad. I have
had very, very, very knowledgeable instructors who were terrible. Why?
They were so focused on other things (e.g., research) that they did not
put much time into course preparation. They were really smart but had the
communication skills of a tree frog. They had some obscure or discredited
viewpoint they wanted to push at every opportunity. In some cases they
possesed all three of these charming traits.

The worst professor I ever had was for a history course. The course was
supposed to be about the Progressive Era of U.S. history but instead the
professor did nothing but push dime-store Marxism. We learned nothing at
all about the Progressive Era (~1879-1920).

What makes an instructor good? Usually they have some combination of good
subject knowledge, prepare thoroughly for each session, really enjoy
teaching, and have strong enthusiasm for the subject. Also, there are some
intangibles that make an instructor good. With some instructors it just
clicks.


-- 
Neil Anuskiewicz
neil at pacifier.com
