From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sat Jun  8 22:30:58 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Sat, 08 Jun 2002 22:30:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Advice on switches for home network
References: <3D02E038.F3C68C7A@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <3D02E812.5090402@pacifier.com>

Most will work a-okay.  Some have loud fans, some have no fans.  To me, 
quite is best.  Don't think they're available at Fry's, but the Intel 
InBusiness line of hubs and switches work fine and meet my dB criteria.

When I bought my 8-port switch it was cheaper than the 8-port hub.  You 
probably want a switch unless you have a good reason for having a hub. 
(Packet sniffing is better with a hub, but performance is generally better 
with a switch.)

As far as features go, unless you get into managed hubs/switches, they are 
all similiar.  I'd go for 8 ports at least, your setup will need 5 all 
ready.  10/100 gives you flexibility.  I have some hubs/switches that are 
soley one or the other and they sit unused.

--
Cheers,
Kyle Accardi

From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Jun  8 22:47:42 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat, 8 Jun 2002 22:47:42 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] in the mean time
In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0206082012400.9160-100000@shell.pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206082244110.11615-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sat, 8 Jun 2002, Neil Anuskiewicz wrote:
> 1. Few people (if any) use the news gateway, so let's kill that and go
> back to a configuration *not* allowing non-subscribers to send to the
> lists. This needs to be changed for *each* list.

I disagree.  I like the option of a news gateway and I think a few pieces
of spam for a few days or weeks until the filter is in place is a totally
reasonable price to pay for the availability of diverse list access
methods.

> 2. As it stands now, you can change your individual mailman config to
> be invisible on the subscriber list. This is easy to do and I
> recommend that anyone who values their privacy, take a minute and do
> so. That's in the mean time. Soon, very soon, I would like the list
> config for *each* list changed so the subscriber list is not available
> to anyone (subscriber or not). Granted the format of the list is not
> very useful as is but a determined spammer could use the lists.

I think it's best to leave the configuration open and let users modify
their own configuration as they choose.

If the list is set to not provide user lists, then it will not provide
user lists regardless of the will of the individual subscribers.  Whereas,
if the list does provide user lists, it will only provide a list of users
that have chosen or failed to opt out of the list.

Clearly the current configuration is the most flexible.

I understand that it does a poor job of accomodating the lazy, but I don't
think that's the list admin's job.

J.

    jeme at brelin.net

Unless I need something ASAP I try to save money by buying from ebay or 
"online" stores (ala pricewatch.com)

From neil at pacifier.com  Sat Jun  8 22:55:40 2002
From: neil at pacifier.com (Neil Anuskiewicz)
Date: Sat, 8 Jun 2002 22:55:40 -0700 (PDT)

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206082244110.11615-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sat, 8 Jun 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> I disagree.  I like the option of a news gateway and I think a few pieces
> of spam for a few days or weeks until the filter is in place is a totally
> reasonable price to pay for the availability of diverse list access
> methods.

How many people actually use the news gateway? I bet almost nobody. It is
useful to have diverse list access methods if they are used but most
people just prefer either the regular list or the digest.

> I think it's best to leave the configuration open and let users modify
> their own configuration as they choose.

Why have the list open? What purpose does it serve? If you have a
compelling reason then I am willing to listen.

> I understand that it does a poor job of accomodating the lazy, but I don't
> think that's the list admin's job.

Most people, I think, assume that the list is closed by default. I assumed
that when I subsribed. I personally admin a majordomo list (for another
organization) and have the list closed and I think the users appreciate
that. Frankly, I was surprised to learn that the list was not closed.

Neil Anuskiewicz wrote:

> On Sat, 8 Jun 2002, Stuart Mathews wrote:
>
> > Too bad there isn't a course in security.
>
> I am curious, what would you include as the content in a course on
> security?
>
> What constitutes security? I know this is a HUGE area but I am curious
> what you tink would be the basics.
>

I suppose in an ideal situation, you'd have mabey two separate security
classes, the first being a general overview of security concepts, an
intro to security for Linux / Unix, while the other class would be
"Advanved System Security" that went beyond basic security concepts,
delving into the nuts and bolts of recent attacks, the nuts and bolts of
how to prevent such attacks, wireless security issues, etc.

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sat Jun  8 23:09:51 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sat, 8 Jun 2002 23:09:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Advice on switches for home network
In-Reply-To: <3D02E038.F3C68C7A@pcez.com>
References: <3D02E038.F3C68C7A@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <200206082309.51820.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I've been real happy with an 8 port Linksys workgroup switch I got for 
my home network. The cost of the switch was less than $70.00. I paid 
way more for an 8 port 3Com 100BaseTX hub 4 years ago. The switch 
increased the throughput of my network quite a bit with the replacement 
of the hub with the switch. 

I have a gateway/firewall Linux system that does IP Masquearding so my 
switch isn't fancy. I know that Linksys has other routers that do DHCP 
and NAT for DSL or Cable modems so the connection can be shared among 
multiple systems.

Tony

From neil at pacifier.com  Sat Jun  8 23:13:02 2002

On Sat, 8 Jun 2002, Mike De La Mater wrote:

> Neil-
> The list WAS closed. I just found out it was open, too.

Yes, the list was closed and I think we should have been informed of a 
policy change like that. And yes I agree with you that the list should go 
back to being closed.

On the other hand, I would not worry about it too much. To get the list 
you would have to subscribe and the list is not in a format that can 
easily be harvested and used by a spammer. The other thing is that as it 
stands now, you can change your own config to be invisible on the list. 
This is easy to do.

That said, I feel very strongly that either the list should be closed or 
the admin should have announced a change in policy. That way, people could 
have made the choice to be visible or not.


-- 
Neil Anuskiewicz
neil at pacifier.com

From alexlinux at qwest.net  Sat Jun  8 20:44:59 2002
From: alexlinux at qwest.net (alex)
Date: 08 Jun 2002 23:44:59 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] Advice on switches for home network
Message-ID: <1023594299.1972.10.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>

Stuart,
I would think that just getting a router with built-in print server
would be the easiest way to go. I myself use a 4 port 3COM DSL router
that has a built-in print server and it works very well. I did have
trouble getting it to run the way it was supposed to so I just have the
DSL modem hooked into as if it is another computer. I'm running 2 Linux
and a Win98 at my desk and 2 others in different parts of the house. All
can print to the Epson printer that I have hooked up to the router.
Saved me from having to have my computer on 24/7 just so that everyone
else could get online and print.


I'm hoping to avoid unnecessary pitfalls of setting up a small
network.

I have a DSL connection with a 2 Linux PCs, and will soon add a
Thinkpad and a printer. I'll need some kind of switch to link
everything up. Any ideas as to what they cost, what features I
need to keep an eye out for, as well as advices on who makes good
(bad!) switches? I'm guessing I'll probably see the best
selection at Fry's??

Thanks,

Stuart

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Sat Jun  8 23:50:43 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Sat, 8 Jun 2002 23:50:43 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] in the mean time
Message-ID: <94067521.1023605433252.JavaMail.root@monkey>

As a blatant plug (no pun intended) any time I subscribe to a mailing list
or anywhere else my E-mail address might get published, I use a sneakemail
alias.  Check out http://www.sneakemail.com for more info.

This way I at least know who leaked my mail address and who is using it.

That plus spamassassin keeps the spam down to a liveable level.  (barely)

  -- Steve Bonds

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Sat Jun  8 23:59:28 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Sat, 8 Jun 2002 23:59:28 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Advice on switches for home network
Message-ID: <1458576193.1023605957473.JavaMail.root@monkey>

For unmanaged switches/hubs the two big low-cost brands are Linksys and
NetGear.  I've used both quite a bit and have been very happy with NetGear
(formerly Bay Networks).

I have seen a number of strange failures on the Linksys (hubs that weren't
really hubs-- not all traffic was echoed to all ports, intermittent
failures, poor 100BaseT-to-10BaseT buffering, etc.)  The NetGear has been
much more consistent for some fairly heavy use.

I have heard good things on the Linksys from people I trust, so my
experiences might be somewhat unusual.

A good place to get and share opinions on hardware like this is
http://www.epinions.com.

  -- Steve Bonds

On Sat, 8 Jun 2002, Stuart Mathews smathews at pcez.com wrote:

From jorgens at coho.net  Sat Jun  8 23:09:07 2002
From: jorgens at coho.net (Steve Jorgensen)
Date: Sat, 8 Jun 2002 23:09:07 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Advice on switches for home network
Message-ID: <01C20F4B.74790FD0.jorgens@coho.net>

On Saturday, June 08, 2002 9:57 PM, Stuart Mathews [SMTP:smathews at pcez.com] 
wrote:
> I'm hoping to avoid unnecessary pitfalls of setting up a small
> network.
>
> I have a DSL connection with a 2 Linux PCs, and will soon add a
> Thinkpad and a printer. I'll need some kind of switch to link
> everything up. Any ideas as to what they cost, what features I
> need to keep an eye out for, as well as advices on who makes good
> (bad!) switches? I'm guessing I'll probably see the best
> selection at Fry's??

For a home network, you won't usually notice the difference between a hub 
and a switch, especially if you are just printing and sharing an Internet 
connection.  Therefore, if price is an issue, just go with a hub.  A switch 
-will- give you some increased reliability, especially if a NIC on your LAN 
happens to go bad and start spewing junk onto the wire.



From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sun Jun  9 01:26:24 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 09 Jun 2002 01:26:24 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] in the mean time
In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0206082250590.4574-100000@shell.pacifier.com>
References: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0206082250590.4574-100000@shell.pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <86u1oc3ljj.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Neil" == Neil Anuskiewicz <neil at pacifier.com> writes:

Neil> How many people actually use the news gateway? I bet almost
Neil> nobody. It is useful to have diverse list access methods if they
Neil> are used but most people just prefer either the regular list or
Neil> the digest.

Uh, Neil, how do you know what most people prefer?

I have used the news gateway.  It was handy when I was investigating
an intermittent failure in the chain of mail delivery by comparing
what was visible on the news server with what I had received in my
mailbox.

Also, it was suggested to someone (a longtime contributor) recently
who was leaving the immediate area and was going to be at the end of a
narrow phone wire and didn't want to subscribe to the mailing list
with its volume but wanted to check in from time to time.  A newsgroup
would allow him to select the messages to read.

I think the news gateway is valuable.

From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Jun  9 04:01:36 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun, 9 Jun 2002 04:01:36 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] in the mean time
In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0206082250590.4574-100000@shell.pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206090348350.13370-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sat, 8 Jun 2002, Neil Anuskiewicz wrote:
> How many people actually use the news gateway? I bet almost nobody. It
> is useful to have diverse list access methods if they are used but
> most people just prefer either the regular list or the digest.

It doesn't matter how many people use it.

The real matter is whether or not (or how) we can prevent spam from coming
to the list, agreed?

So how about we get let Karl (or his delegate) get spamassassin running
and we can keep the news gateway.  I think we can all stand a spam or two
a day until we clear it up.  Hell, I'm sure each of us ignores that many
of the messages that are SUPPOSED to make it to the list each day.  (I,
for one, pretty much hit 'd' as soon as I see a line that begins "rpm -".)

> > I think it's best to leave the configuration open and let users modify
> > their own configuration as they choose.
> 
> Why have the list open? What purpose does it serve? If you have a
> compelling reason then I am willing to listen.

Let's define some terms (since we've lost a bit in quotes out of context).  
By "leave the configuration open", I meant leaving the list configured
such that member addresses are available to other members by individual
member's choice.

What you're advocating is removing that choice and making all member
addresses unavailable.

Can you really not imagine a situation where a person would WANT their
subscribed address available to other subscribers?

> Most people, I think, assume that the list is closed by default.

Neil, you make the claim that "most people" think like you far too often
for it to hold any credibility whatsoever.

I don't mean this to be a personal attack or the start of a flame-fest,
but I find it odd that you're all for personal choice and freedom until
it's inconvenient (and then you're all for dictatorship, albeit sometimes
dictatorship of the majority).

Simply stating that you believe most people think this or that doesn't
mean anything.  Hopefully you can make your case without appealling to
false authority.

> I assumed that when I subsribed. I personally admin a majordomo list
> (for another organization) and have the list closed and I think the
> users appreciate that. Frankly, I was surprised to learn that the list
> was not closed.

OK, so you were surprised.  Then, I assume, you went and removed your
address from the publicly available list.  So what's the problem?

If we make a global change, then NOBODY will have the option of making
their subscribed address public.  That would be a case of you imposing
your will and expectations on others.  So even if don't buy the argument
that some people might actually want to make their address available, you
should at least be able to see that your request is in conflict with your
own professed ideology.

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From mindglow at dsl-only.net  Sun Jun  9 06:37:13 2002
From: mindglow at dsl-only.net (Doug Davis)
Date: 09 Jun 2002 06:37:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Other ALC courses
In-Reply-To: <3D02ECF5.779FD47D@pcez.com>
References: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0206082222560.30345-100000@shell.pacifier.com> 
	<3D02ECF5.779FD47D@pcez.com>

On Sat, 2002-06-08 at 22:51, Stuart Mathews wrote:

> "Advanved System Security" that went beyond basic security concepts,
> delving into the nuts and bolts of recent attacks, the nuts and bolts of
> how to prevent such attacks, wireless security issues, etc.
Last week, I attended the SANS institutes "Hacker Exploits, Techniques,
and Incident Handling" course here in Portland given by Ed Stoudis. It
was really excellent and I recommend it to anyone who has a chance to
attend. It covered both incident handling as well as exploits and had a
hands on portion that allowed us to try and crack into the 5 servers he
had available. ( I cracked all the Linux boxen and even got root on
one..Yay me!) I'm preparing an hour long presentation for work I'm
calling "Anatomy of a Network Attack". I'm going to show a sample attack
including a buffer overflow and some password cracking. I think it will
be really educational to people to demonstrate how easy it is to get
into a network as well as demonstrate the value of strong password as
well as applying regular patches. Would there be any interest from the
group in hearing my presentation at a PLUG meeting or in an advanced
topics meeting? I will probably be out of town for the July meeting, but
maybe August?

Doug Davis   




From mindglow at dsl-only.net  Sun Jun  9 06:56:36 2002
From: mindglow at dsl-only.net (Doug Davis)
Date: 09 Jun 2002 06:56:36 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PLUG resume database project
In-Reply-To: <200206061646.g56GkbM07628@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200206061646.g56GkbM07628@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <1023630996.12454.40.camel@sneaker.got-roots.com>

On Thu, 2002-06-06 at 09:46, Alex Daniloff wrote:
In case of one RAID0 failure,
> remaining 
> database becomes the master and continue to handle load until failed
> RAID0 
> drive is replaced and array is rebuilt. 
> This approach eliminates nessesity in tape drive and periodical backup
> 
> procedures.
2 notes on this. Isn't RAID0 just striping? It provides no data
redundancy, just balances the data between the 2. If you are looking for
redundancy wouldn't RAID 1 be better? Point 2: RAID is not a replacement
for periodic backups. A corrupted database will replicate through all
the RAID drives and you will have no way to recover your data in this
event. 

Doug




From mindglow at dsl-only.net  Sun Jun  9 07:15:28 2002
From: mindglow at dsl-only.net (Doug Davis)
Date: 09 Jun 2002 07:15:28 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Linux /Windows virus appears (fwd)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206051650480.7270-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206051650480.7270-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1023632128.13543.55.camel@sneaker.got-roots.com>

On Wed, 2002-06-05 at 16:52, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Wed, 5 Jun 2002, Neil Anuskiewicz wrote:
> 
> > Which is pretty much a non-issue because who runs email as root anyway?
> 
> Neil,
> 
>   Don't ask. You might not like the answer.
>  
> > Is Linux pretty much immune from devastating virusus  by virtue of
> > the fact that it can do only so much damage in user space? Well, I guess
> > immune is too strong a word but highly resistant would be apprpriat?
> 
>   That's my understanding. There was one, proof-of-concept virus written,
> but it was benign and done just to see if it could be done.
> 
>   Worms are a different matter. Remember Bob Morris Jr's famous Internet
> Worm of the early 1980s?
> 
> Rich
I think that as virus writers get more sophisticated and Linux becomes a
larger target, this will change. For example, suppose someone makes a
virus that contains a script that launches a buffer overflow, gets root,
then runs itself. I know from experience that many admins put off
applying patches for local exploits since "they need a local account to
run this anyway" Yes, it requires a non sophisticated user to run the
thing, but as more users migrate to Linux that aren't as technologically
savvy as we are, bad things could happen. Additionally, many viruses and
worms are polymorphic lately meaning that they cannot be detected by
virus scanners and network IDSs. Take the position that we are
inherently secure by using Linux at your folly. I'm of the opinion
lately that we are but one step ahead of the bad guys. They have way
more time, motivation, and coordination than we do and frankly, one
mistake and the balance of power can change rapidly.

Doug

I second that.  I took the SANS Institute class Perimeter Defense,
Firewalls and VPNs at the same confrence and it was excellent.  The
instructor was both knowledgable and experienced.  The course was full of
current, practical information and well worth the cost.  If you want vendor
neutral, timely security training with lots of Linux refrences, check out
www.sans.org.  This is for those who have money to spend.

The lowest cost Linux classes in Portland appear to be at www.freegeek.org
and at www.pcc.edu, Freegeek and Portland Community College.  Ed Sawicki
teaches Linux Installation and Configuration this Summer and in the Fall,
he is also teaching Linux Network Administration.  A class in Linux
Security is due Winter term, 2003.  Watch the PCC schedule for details.

Cheers,
Mike

Read file error: ./slogin1.1 No such file or directory
Read file error: ./disable.8 No such file or directory
Read file error: ./reject.8 No such file or directory
Read file error: ./forms.5 No such file or directory

makewhatis trying to read non-existent files? These look almost like man
pages to me, but what's trying to read them?

long.

I'm someone who likes to participate in the PLUG lists, but the volume is 
just getting to much hassle on my dial-up line.  Thus, I would like to 
start using the news server gateway, but I am also concerned about spam. 
 Personally, I think if there is some way to have the news gateway open and 
protected from spam, that would be a good thing.  Also, I hope the e-mail 
addresses are scrambled in some way so they can't be skimmed by spam-bots.

It seems to me that the news server. if it remains, should either be 
subscribers-only or should have e-mail addresses scrambled somehow.



From kens at cad2cam.com  Sun Jun  9 10:31:20 2002
From: kens at cad2cam.com (Kenneth G. Stephens)
Date: Sun, 9 Jun 2002 10:31:20 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Advice on switches for home network
In-Reply-To: <01C20F4B.74790FD0.jorgens@coho.net>
Message-ID: <NMEPJGMCLGBMCOCPJFHKIEHHDJAA.kens@cad2cam.com>

I found at PC Heidens a D-Link firewall/switch.  I have been very happy with
it.  Works for my three computers and occasional Thinkpad.  It freed up my
Linux box so that it can be a workstation instead of a firewall.

http://www.dlink.com/products/broadband/di707/

I would not put any system on DSL/Internet without a firewall.  Especially
after all these security meetings lately.

Ken
> -----Original Message-----
> From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
> [mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]On Behalf Of Steve Jorgensen
> Sent: Saturday, June 08, 2002 11:09 PM
> To: 'plug at lists.pdxlinux.org'
> Subject: RE: [PLUG] Advice on switches for home network
>
>
>
> On Saturday, June 08, 2002 9:57 PM, Stuart Mathews
> [SMTP:smathews at pcez.com]
> wrote:
> > I'm hoping to avoid unnecessary pitfalls of setting up a small
> > network.
> >
> > I have a DSL connection with a 2 Linux PCs, and will soon add a
> > Thinkpad and a printer. I'll need some kind of switch to link
> > everything up. Any ideas as to what they cost, what features I
> > need to keep an eye out for, as well as advices on who makes good
> > (bad!) switches? I'm guessing I'll probably see the best
> > selection at Fry's??
>
> For a home network, you won't usually notice the difference between a hub
> and a switch, especially if you are just printing and sharing an Internet
> connection.  Therefore, if price is an issue, just go with a hub.
>  A switch
> -will- give you some increased reliability, especially if a NIC
> on your LAN
> happens to go bad and start spewing junk onto the wire.




From neil at pacifier.com  Sun Jun  9 10:31:04 2002
From: neil at pacifier.com (Neil Anuskiewicz)

On Sun, 9 Jun 2002, Russell Senior wrote:

> Are we even sure that particular spam came through the news gateway?

The point is *not* the news gateway, the point is that the list admin 
opened the list to emails from non-subscribers to accomodate those who 
might want to use it. The spams are happening as a side-effect resulting 
from the fact that the list is now open to emails from non-subscribers.

neil at pacifier.com

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Joe Pedigo [mailto:jpedigo at oregonfoodbank.org]

> Paul Reich asked me to introduce myself and give you an update on 
> the work we are doing on our website.  
> 
> My name is Joe Pedigo and I am the Inventory Manager at Oregon 
> Food Bank (OFB).  This includes maintaining and developing our 
> Inventory database application, Ceres, which is a  Food Bank 
> version of Navision, a financial application.  The data in Ceres 
> is what we serve up on our internal website for our Regional 
> Coordinating Agencies (RCAs), the recipients of the food we 
> distribute.  There are 20 RCAs, 2 of them are branches of OFB.
> 
> We have our main website at www.oregonfoodbank.org, which is 
> hosted by Europa at an external location.
> We also have the Waterfront Blues Festival site at 
> www.waterfrontbluesfest.com.  I am not sure if Europa hosts this 
> site as well.
> 
> And we have the "Inside OFB" website at 
> http://inside.oregonfoodbank.org (Please contact Joe directly for user
> name and password), which is on our own Windows 2000 web server 
> in this building. 
> 
> Opening day for Inside OFB was April 26th of this year.  The 
> information we provide for the RCAs is related to shipment 
> schedules, and the offering and acceptance of different types of 
> food.  This is work that we did by phone, fax and email in the past.
> 
> A volunteer from Intel who has experience with ASP has been the 
> primary developer.  We have worked to together to gather the data 
> and present it in a way that is meaningful to our audience, the 
> RCAs.  We intend to expand this site to include the submission of 
> quarterly reports, downloading files, and access to Policies and 
> Procedures.  Things like that
> 
> The website draws its data from an Access database which is 
> linked to the Navision proprietary database (Navision won't 
> support web access, until we switch to a SQL Server backend).  We 
> periodically run a routine that updates Navision and synchronizes 
> the two databases.
> 
> An audience that we have not yet addressed is that of the Local 
> Member Agencies (LMAs) of our 2 Branch RCAs.  There are 
> approximately 300 of them (250 for 1, 50 for the other).  A 
> problem we have is that not all the LMAs have the ability to go 
> online.  Some of them (perhaps just a few, now) are quite behind 
> the times and have difficulty even with faxes, although some are 
> quite capable and eager to get information online.
> 
>

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Sun Jun  9 10:42:25 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 09 Jun 2002 10:42:25 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Everything you wanted to know about Linux security and aren't
 afraid to ask (was: Linux /Windows virus appears)
In-Reply-To: <1023632128.13543.55.camel@sneaker.got-roots.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206051650480.7270-100000@appl-ecosys.com> 
	<1023632128.13543.55.camel@sneaker.got-roots.com>
Message-ID: <1023644546.1838.4956.camel@pookie>

All;

Please help me set my mind at ease on the Linux security thing. 

While it is true that Linux built with security in mind from the start
(file/group permissions, e.t.c.) an that (I believe) having the source
code open for peer review are good things, it is the human element of
the security picture that scares me the most:

    1) User receives an email from a cracker posing as a friend. The
sender instructs the user to save the attachment and run it... ``it's a
hoot, '' the cracker says in the message, ``you'll love it!''

    2) User saves attachment in his home directory and runs it.

    3) Script (or binary) performs the following:

       find / -name -exec rm -rf {} \; 2>/dev/null

    4) The script dutifully goes out and deletes every file that the
user has write privileges to including /tmp.

    5) The machine comes to a screeching halt (or at least it's
applications relying on /tmp do). The administrator is in a disarray of
what happened.

Let's suppose further that our hapless user is a member of group
``sales.'' Under this scenario, not only would the user's files be
deleted, but also the files and directories he has write permissions to
in the sales area, also.

``That can't happen,'' you might be saying, ``We will execute the
equivalent of the `file' command on each file as it passes through the
mail server.'' We will allow only documents through.

Okay, fine. The trouble is that email is not the only way to get a file
onto the system. Like so:

    1) The cracker social engineers the user name and password on the
system.

    2) The attacker launches a script that utilizes a known remote
exploit on the server.

    3) The script drops the executable in /tmp , su's to a known user
name (if it is not already working as that user), and runs the
equivalent to the `find' command above.

I've actually had a case like the one above. It exploited a hole in DNS.
It was incredible. It came in, dropped the source code in /tmp, and
compiled it's payload into a binary. The compiled code was designed to
go out to an irc channel and wait for it's author to type in a codeword.
Meanwhile, perhaps other thousands were listening there as well. 

The believe it was designed to destroy files.

It happened on my security officer's home machine. He sent it to me and
I analyzed it. It was written in C.

I'm worried.


-Cooper     




From john at cryptowave.com  Sun Jun  9 10:45:55 2002
From: john at cryptowave.com (John H.)
Date: Sun, 09 Jun 2002 10:45:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PLUG resume database project
References: <200206061646.g56GkbM07628@gate.daniloff.com> <1023630996.12454.40.camel@sneaker.got-roots.com>
Message-ID: <3D039453.3040608@cryptowave.com>

RAID5 + Tape backup = good

Don't even think about IDE RAID because it is absolute crap :)

So I agree with Doug on this one 100%

Doug Davis wrote:

>On Thu, 2002-06-06 at 09:46, Alex Daniloff wrote:
>In case of one RAID0 failure,
>
>>remaining 
>>database becomes the master and continue to handle load until failed
>>RAID0 
>>drive is replaced and array is rebuilt. 
>>This approach eliminates nessesity in tape drive and periodical backup
>>
>>procedures.
>>
>2 notes on this. Isn't RAID0 just striping? It provides no data
>redundancy, just balances the data between the 2. If you are looking for
>redundancy wouldn't RAID 1 be better? Point 2: RAID is not a replacement
>for periodic backups. A corrupted database will replicate through all
>the RAID drives and you will have no way to recover your data in this
>event. 
>
>Doug
>
>
>_______________________________________________
>PLUG mailing list
>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org

From mindglow at dsl-only.net  Sun Jun  9 11:52:18 2002
From: mindglow at dsl-only.net (Doug Davis)
Date: 09 Jun 2002 11:52:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Linux /Windows virus appears (fwd)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206091026020.3089-100000@localhost.localdomain>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206091026020.3089-100000@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1023648738.12454.70.camel@sneaker.got-roots.com>

On Sun, 2002-06-09 at 10:29, Neil Anuskiewicz wrote:
>
> How does one protect against buffer overflows, run Immunix? Or are there 
> other ways? I mean unknown buffer overflows that might be exploited 
> between the time that they are found and exploited and the time that they 
> are fixed and a patch issued and given, as you mentioned, the fact that 
> that not all system admins are good about keeping up with the patches.
> 
Yes, you can apply kernel patches to prevent them in such a way as
Immunix does. Other prevention methods include keeping regular on your
patches and (my favorite) minimizing the use of all service that you
don't use.  For example, if you don't have the wu-ftp service running,
you can't exploit it. Also, don;t run services as root if you can help
it. To explain this one, an explanation of what a buffer overflow is
would be helpful. Basically, the developer does a poor job of checking
the size of a data field before he writes it to memory. This allows the
attacker to run a program that overwrites the return pointer in the
program to point to a line in memory that executes a command of the
attackers choice ( most often a shell). This gets run as the user that
started the program. So essentially if you start wu-ftp as root and
someone runs this program against it ...they have a root shell. From
there...you can guess what happens. The lesson here is to run things
with as little privilege as possible and then only when you need them.

Doug

From john at cryptowave.com  Sun Jun  9 12:38:28 2002
From: john at cryptowave.com (John H.)
Date: Sun, 09 Jun 2002 12:38:28 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PLUG resume database project
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206091103170.23900-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <3D03AEB4.4070300@cryptowave.com>

Shannon C. Dealy wrote:

>>
>>
>>Don't even think about IDE RAID because it is absolute crap :)
>>
>[snip]
>
>Could you elaborate on the reasons and extent of it's crapiness?
>

These days IDE drives (7200rpm) are becoming seemingly as fast as SCSI 
drives, right?
It's all good until you want to start doing multiple reads and writes, 
this is where IDE's performance goes down.
SCSI supports multiple reads and writes (you can have 3 scsi drives on 
the same channel).
IDE isn't going to perform very well when the drives are sitting on the 
same channel...

In short, the more drives you add to an IDE RAID array, the worse it 
will perform when compared to scsi.

Correct me if i'm wrong anyone :)



>
>
>
>

> > 6/8/02 10:47:42 PM, Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> wrote:

already has a facility for those who choose to hide their address to do
so.  We don't need to make a global change to accomodate the few (even if
it's MOST, it's not all) who feel they need their address hidden.

they are on - SCSI drives do not need to do this.
(multiple read/write)

From flee at aracnet.com  Sun Jun  9 12:49:50 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)
Date: Sun, 09 Jun 2002 12:49:50 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Everything you wanted to know about Linux security and aren't afraid to ask (was: Linux /Windows virus appears)
In-Reply-To: <1023644546.1838.4956.camel@pookie> on 09 Jun 2002 10:42:25 PDT.
Message-ID: <200206091949.g59Jno212089@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

I suspect the main reason you don't see linux viruses in the
wild is there aren't enough linux users, and Windows is too
easy a target in comparison.  If I were writing a
self-propagating linux virus, the hard part would be finding
other linux machines to infect.  It's easy to find another
Windows machine.  The Morris Worm spread quickly partly
because it targetted Suns and those were the most common
systems on the Internet at the time.

I've heard that DNS root exploits were the most common way
into linux/unix machines a year or so ago.  Dunno now.
--
[ sometimes it's double or knotting ]

From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Jun  9 13:00:57 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun, 9 Jun 2002 13:00:57 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Everything you wanted to know about Linux security and
 aren't afraid to ask (was: Linux /Windows virus appears)
In-Reply-To: <1023644546.1838.4956.camel@pookie>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206091242090.13820-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 9 Jun 2002, D. Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> Please help me set my mind at ease on the Linux security thing. 

Uh... ease?  How about "easier"?

> While it is true that Linux built with security in mind from the start
> (file/group permissions, e.t.c.) an that (I believe) having the source
> code open for peer review are good things, it is the human element of
> the security picture that scares me the most:
> 
>     1) User receives an email from a cracker posing as a friend. The
> sender instructs the user to save the attachment and run it... ``it's
> a hoot, '' the cracker says in the message, ``you'll love it!''
>     2) User saves attachment in his home directory and runs it.

OK.  Stupid user, but OK.  Let's say that happens.

>     3) Script (or binary) performs the following:
>        find / -name -exec rm -rf {} \; 2>/dev/null
>     4) The script dutifully goes out and deletes every file that the
> user has write privileges to including /tmp.

I get the drift.

>     5) The machine comes to a screeching halt (or at least it's
> applications relying on /tmp do). The administrator is in a disarray of
> what happened.

No.  Not at all.  The user loses his homedir and maybe some other stuff on
the system is lost, but I can't imagine a single service that would
screech to a halt due to this command.

Your example of /tmp is flawed because tmp has (or should have) the sticky
bit set so that only the user who created the file can mv or rm it,
regardless of other permissions.

> Let's suppose further that our hapless user is a member of group
> ``sales.'' Under this scenario, not only would the user's files be
> deleted, but also the files and directories he has write permissions
> to in the sales area, also.

Again, your friend the sticky bit could save you.

> ``That can't happen,'' you might be saying, ``We will execute the
> equivalent of the `file' command on each file as it passes through the
> mail server.'' We will allow only documents through.

That's not why it can't happen.  And, of course, scripts can be
transmitted and executed all kinds of different ways.

> Okay, fine. The trouble is that email is not the only way to get a
> file onto the system. Like so:
[snipped example of exploit]
> I've actually had a case like the one above. It exploited a hole in
> DNS. It was incredible. It came in, dropped the source code in /tmp,
> and compiled it's payload into a binary. The compiled code was
> designed to go out to an irc channel and wait for it's author to type
> in a codeword. Meanwhile, perhaps other thousands were listening there
> as well.

Yeah, irc drones are pretty common.  You can bring your likelihood of
experiencing buffer overflow attacks and the like by running a non-x86
hardware architecture.  These kinds of attacks require the injection of
machine instructions into a process stack (usually through a public
network port).  If your machine doesn't run x86 instructions, the cracker
doesn't get his desired effect.  In some cases, the service will go down,
but no malicious code is run locally... and if you've got any kind of
service watchdog daemon, the blip might be no big deal.

> The believe it was designed to destroy files.
> It happened on my security officer's home machine. He sent it to me
> and I analyzed it. It was written in C.
> I'm worried.

I'm worried about two things:

Admins ignore user education (often they think of their users as "idiots"
or "lusers" and put poor effort into their training in order to maintain
their own feeling of superiority).  We know better than to do certain
things (like give our passwords to other people or run code we haven't
inspected or had inspected), there's no reason why your mom an dad and
brother can't learn the same simple precautions.

Diversity of architecture is poor (being divided mostly between Windows
and Linux on x86 with *BSD on x86 and Solaris on Ultrasparc coming up
behind in distant third and fourth).  A large computer network is a lot
like an ecosystem: destructive organisms have the most drastic effects
where diversity is low.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin

From dealy at deatech.com  Sun Jun  9 13:05:13 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Sun, 9 Jun 2002 13:05:13 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] PLUG resume database project
In-Reply-To: <3D03AEB4.4070300@cryptowave.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206091254200.24463-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Sun, 9 Jun 2002, John H. wrote:

> Shannon C. Dealy wrote:
[snip]
> >Could you elaborate on the reasons and extent of it's crapiness?
> >
>
> These days IDE drives (7200rpm) are becoming seemingly as fast as SCSI
> drives, right?
> It's all good until you want to start doing multiple reads and writes,
> this is where IDE's performance goes down.
> SCSI supports multiple reads and writes (you can have 3 scsi drives on
> the same channel).
> IDE isn't going to perform very well when the drives are sitting on the
> same channel...
>
> In short, the more drives you add to an IDE RAID array, the worse it
> will perform when compared to scsi.

Okay, so what you mean is it's performance won't measure up to SCSI if you
use both channels of the controller(s) for your raid array -- there are
only two channels on an IDE controller.  So if you are looking for
redundancy rather than performance it should be fine, and if you want IDE
raid with high performance all you need to do is install more controllers
and only use the first channel of each controller, or alternatively buy
an IDE raid controller which implements it in hardware and will (most
likely - though it should be verified) use independent channels for each
drive.

Is this correct, or did I miss something?

dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

IDE had its own place in the PC.
In this case, you do get what you pay for.

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sun Jun  9 13:22:20 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sun, 9 Jun 2002 13:22:20 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Advice on switches for home network
In-Reply-To: <1458576193.1023605957473.JavaMail.root@monkey>
References: <1458576193.1023605957473.JavaMail.root@monkey>
Message-ID: <200206091322.20066.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Here's a stupid question for you which I hope doesn't offend you...With 
some or all of the traffic not being broadcast to all ports are you 
sure that a hub was being used? The fundamental difference between a 
hub and switch is that a switch routes packets directly between systems 
and doesn't send packets to all ports unlike a hub. 

I'm not sure I've seen any of those little blue and black boxes from 
Linksys which weren't either a switch or a router. I've not used one of 
their DSL/Cable routers and so I don't know if they are a switch or a 
hub.

Tony

On Saturday 08 June 2002 23:59 pm, Steve Bonds wrote:
> For unmanaged switches/hubs the two big low-cost brands are Linksys
> and NetGear.  I've used both quite a bit and have been very happy
> with NetGear (formerly Bay Networks).
>
> I have seen a number of strange failures on the Linksys (hubs that
> weren't really hubs-- not all traffic was echoed to all ports,
> intermittent failures, poor 100BaseT-to-10BaseT buffering, etc.)  The
> NetGear has been much more consistent for some fairly heavy use.
>
> I have heard good things on the Linksys from people I trust, so my
> experiences might be somewhat unusual.
>
> A good place to get and share opinions on hardware like this is
> http://www.epinions.com.
>
>   -- Steve Bonds
>
> On Sat, 8 Jun 2002, Stuart Mathews smathews at pcez.com wrote:
> > I'm hoping to avoid unnecessary pitfalls of setting up a small
> > network.
> >
> > I have a DSL connection with a 2 Linux PCs, and will soon add a
> > Thinkpad and a printer. I'll need some kind of switch to link
> > everything up. Any ideas as to what they cost, what features I
> > need to keep an eye out for, as well as advices on who makes good
> > (bad!) switches? I'm guessing I'll probably see the best
> > selection at Fry's??
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org

Anthony Schlemmer

From russj at dimstar.net  Sun Jun  9 13:22:37 2002

On Sun, 2002-06-09 at 12:41, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> On 9 Jun 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:
> > Like, we're not asking for a permanent change. Just a little tighter
> > security, until the proper measures can be put in place.
> 
> That's not what anybody's asking.
> 
> Neil was asking to have the list configured to provide no subscriber
> lists, even to members because that's how he assumes a list operates.

Re-read his second post on the subject. He specifically says that
getting a list of subscribers, when you are a subscriber, is ok. 

> This is a permanent change and nobody has suggested that it is a temporary
> measure until something else is put in place.

Re-read the thread. Multiple people have made the suggestion that
TEMPORARILY this be changed, until such time as proper spam handling
capabilities are working. I've read it, obviously, you missed it. 

> > Besides, I thought it *WAS* the sysadmins (or listadmins in this case)
> > job to ensure security where the list is concerned...
> 
> It's the list admin's job to prevent spam from making it to the list.  On
> that, we agree.  And the responsible thing to do here is to install
> spamassassin and leave the news gateway in place.

And until that is done, denying posting unless you subscribe would be an
excellent alternative. It's an easy config change. If spamassassin can
be installed instead, and in a like timeframe, fine. No word one way or
another has been forthcoming from the list admin. It's the list admins
job to ensure the smooth operation of the list. The list being spammed
on a daily basis is not smooth operation. It's annoying behavior that is
easily remedied. 

> As for the SECURITY issue (subscriber address availability), the list
> already has a facility for those who choose to hide their address to do
> so.  We don't need to make a global change to accomodate the few (even if
> it's MOST, it's not all) who feel they need their address hidden.

It should DEFAULT to the higher security. Sort of like your favorite
distribution should default to having services turned off. If folks want
their addresses out there, then they should opt-in to that option.

From russj at dimstar.net  Sun Jun  9 13:33:21 2002

On Sat, 2002-06-08 at 23:13, Neil Anuskiewicz wrote:
> 
> To get the list 
> you would have to subscribe and the list is not in a format that can 
> easily be harvested and used by a spammer. The other thing is that as it 
> stands now, you can change your own config to be invisible on the list. 
> This is easy to do.

Ah, but this is not true. The archives of the list are a prime example
of what spammers crawl the web looking for. If you do a search for your
email address, the first hit is here:

http://plug.skylab.org/200104/msg00781.html

I realize that's the old archive and granted, the new archive shows
everyones address as the list address. This is probably why the list is
being spammed in the first place. 

However, you do have your email address in your sig. This makes it
really easy for someone to harvest your address. Such as on this page: 

https://lists.pdxlinux.org/pipermail/plug/2002-June/004435.html

From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Jun  9 13:56:47 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun, 9 Jun 2002 13:56:47 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] in the mean time
In-Reply-To: <1023654163.5035.14.camel@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206091344180.17315-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 9 Jun 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:
> Re-read his second post on the subject. He specifically says that
> getting a list of subscribers, when you are a subscriber, is ok.

That's how the list is configured, so why'd he bring it up?  Neil?

> Re-read the thread. Multiple people have made the suggestion that
> TEMPORARILY this be changed, until such time as proper spam handling
> capabilities are working. I've read it, obviously, you missed it.

Really?  Because I keep reading posts that say "Close the news
gateway" and "How many people really use this news gateway, anyhow?"

> And until that is done, denying posting unless you subscribe would be
> an excellent alternative.  It's an easy config change. If spamassassin
> can be installed instead, and in a like timeframe, fine.

Fine.  Then we agree, there.  The goal is simply to prevent spam, not to
make people feel like they're in some exclusive club.  So we can open the
list and leave the news gateway, so long as a reasonably successful spam
filter is in place.

> No word one way or another has been forthcoming from the list admin.
> It's the list admins job to ensure the smooth operation of the list.
> The list being spammed on a daily basis is not smooth operation. It's
> annoying behavior that is easily remedied.

Well, I would say that having a public list that rejects posts by
non-members is annoying behavior that is easily remedied.

> > As for the SECURITY issue (subscriber address availability), the list
> > already has a facility for those who choose to hide their address to do
> > so.  We don't need to make a global change to accomodate the few (even if
> > it's MOST, it's not all) who feel they need their address hidden.
> 
> It should DEFAULT to the higher security.

Well, I don't personally believe that it's a security issue.  This is,
after all, a public and publicly archived list.  If it were not, we could
use the mailing list software's ability to turn off subscriber lists
entirely.

Making your own address unavailable is, in my opinion, a special need that
a person can and should meet for themselves (by configuring their personal
preferences).

> Sort of like your favorite distribution should default to having
> services turned off.

A distribution (if you choose to let someone else package your software at
all) should default to having no services installed at all (except those
vital to the running of the system like kmod, of course... but would we
really call that a "service"?  I guess so, in a manner of speaking).

> If folks want their addresses out there, then they should opt-in to
> that option.

I don't see the difference in such a trivial matter.  The software isn't
built for an opt-in, so we use the only option-producing feature that IS
available within the software (the opt-out).

J.

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

On Sun, 2002-06-09 at 14:16, Russell Senior wrote:

> archive: 
>

>      the list because of private archives; and

still only comes up with one address to send to, the list.

>   b) it interferes unacceptably with the ability to mail people
>      privately.

I don't see how. The senders address IS in the mail that you receive
from the list. It's just not available from the web page, which I
personally consider to be a good thing.

From russj at dimstar.net  Sun Jun  9 16:24:08 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: 09 Jun 2002 16:24:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] in the mean time
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206091344180.17315-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206091344180.17315-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1023665050.5034.51.camel@sthelens.dimstar.net>

On Sun, 2002-06-09 at 13:56, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> That's how the list is configured, so why'd he bring it up?  Neil?

OK, on ME re-reading his post, he does say that he doesn't want these
lists available at all. This I'm not inclined to agree with. 

I *DO* however, feel that names should NOT be included by default. Being
listed in the list of subscribers should be opt-in, not opt-out. 

> Really?  Because I keep reading posts that say "Close the news
> gateway" and "How many people really use this news gateway, anyhow?"

Yes, and several that I've read have said it's a good thing, but only
subscribers should be able to post. They went on to say that it should
be temporarily shut down until spamassassin or some such is set up. 

However, I *DO* feel that you should subscribe to the list to be able to
post. This list should not accept posts from just anyone. That's asking
for spam, and even spamassassin isn't perfect. I get two or three per
week that don't trip spamassassins filtering. There's got to be a better
way than having the list be completely open. 

> Fine.  Then we agree, there.  The goal is simply to prevent spam, not to
> make people feel like they're in some exclusive club.  So we can open the
> list and leave the news gateway, so long as a reasonably successful spam
> filter is in place.

Actually, I disagree with having a completely open list. There must be a
better alternative. 


> Well, I would say that having a public list that rejects posts by
> non-members is annoying behavior that is easily remedied.

There are thousands (millions?) of mailing lists that require
subscribing to post. I find this to be highly effective when it comes to
making sure you keep an excellent signal to noise ratio. Of course, this
list has been deteriorating lately, but I digress.

> Well, I don't personally believe that it's a security issue.  This is,
> after all, a public and publicly archived list.  If it were not, we could
> use the mailing list software's ability to turn off subscriber lists
> entirely.

That's MY information, and NO WHERE does it say that my information will
be available publicly. There should be a notice posted monthly, or it
should default to off. Other options are unacceptable. 

> Making your own address unavailable is, in my opinion, a special need that
> a person can and should meet for themselves (by configuring their personal
> preferences).

That's like saying, "Bank of America will sell your information, unless
you send us a certified notice to have us remove you from our list." The
option should be with the user to choose to distribute, not to choose to
not distribute. 

> > Sort of like your favorite distribution should default to having
> > services turned off.
> 
> A distribution (if you choose to let someone else package your software at
> all) should default to having no services installed at all (except those
> vital to the running of the system like kmod, of course... but would we
> really call that a "service"?  I guess so, in a manner of speaking).

Exactly, and choosing to distribute someone elses information, without
their prior consent, is exactly the same thing, in my book anyway.
Subscribing to a mailing list is not the same as giving someone else
permission to distribute those email addresses. We're going so far
(address munging, etc.) to hide the addresses, then we distribute a
list? That's exactly the opposite direction. Why munge the posters
address in the list, if the list is available for download? 

> I don't see the difference in such a trivial matter.  The software isn't
> built for an opt-in, so we use the only option-producing feature that IS
> available within the software (the opt-out).

See my bank analogy above. 

-- 
"The power to untie is stronger than the power to tie."                 
                                                                        
Well, yeah, otherwise my shoes would tie themselves.

Russ Johnson                                                            
Stargate Online                                                         
                                                                        
http://www.dimstar.net

On Sun, Jun 09, 2002 at 10:31:04AM -0700, Neil Anuskiewicz wrote:

> 
> > Are we even sure that particular spam came through the news gateway?
> 
> The point is *not* the news gateway, the point is that the list admin 
> opened the list to emails from non-subscribers to accomodate those who 
> might want to use it. The spams are happening as a side-effect resulting 
> from the fact that the list is now open to emails from non-subscribers.

Is it even necessary to allow non-members to post to the mailing list
in order to enable subscribers to post through the newsgroup? 

- Aj



From shahms at shahms.com  Sun Jun  9 16:32:26 2002
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms E. King)
Date: 09 Jun 2002 16:32:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] in the mean time

> 
> That's like saying, "Bank of America will sell your information, unless
> you send us a certified notice to have us remove you from our list." The
> option should be with the user to choose to distribute, not to choose to
> not distribute. 

I happen to like the idea of making the list subscriber only (for a
number of reasons, the most important being spam, but the "please CC me
as I'm not subscribed" gets on my nerves occasionally as well).  But the
reason I actually wrote this email was to correct the above paragraph:
BofA (and in fact, any bank/financial institution) can (as of a short
while ago) and probably do, sell your information and you DO have to
send them written notice if you don't want them to be able to do so.

--Shahms

From allen_brown at agilent.com  Sun Jun  9 17:08:06 2002
From: allen_brown at agilent.com (Allen Brown)
Date: Sun, 09 Jun 2002 17:08:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [lug] Everything you wanted to know about Linux security and
 aren'tafraid to ask (was: Linux /Windows virus appears)
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206051650480.7270-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

Until the security model of Linux is revamped avoiding this requires,
as you say, the social element.  We must never give ourselves more
permissions than the task at hand requires.  The most outrageous
violations of this principal that I have seen have been by profesional
sysadmins who do everything as root, including reading email and
browsing the net.  Stupid!

From m at netpro.to  Sun Jun  9 17:25:08 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Sun, 9 Jun 2002 17:25:08 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [lug] Everything you wanted to know about Linux
 security and aren'tafraid to ask (was: Linux /Windows virus appears)
In-Reply-To: <3D03EDE6.A63B7529@agilent.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206091714400.9697-100000@lukem.com>

On Sun, 9 Jun 2002, Allen Brown wrote:

> Until the security model of Linux is revamped avoiding this requires,
> as you say, the social element.  We must never give ourselves more
> permissions than the task at hand requires.

I don't see anything inherently wrong with the current Linux security
model.  How would you go about deciding when a user should and should not
be allowed to delete their own files?  It's been pointed out that we as
sysadmins need to educate users to not run email attachments.  I think
that's the best we can do.  If a user runs an email attachment that
deletes all their files, then hopefully they'll learn a good lesson.
Cooper's paranoia stemmed from the fact that he wasn't aware of the sticky
bit that is almost always set on the /tmp directory, which several others
have already corrected him on.

> The most outrageous
> violations of this principal that I have seen have been by profesional
> sysadmins who do everything as root, including reading email and
> browsing the net.  Stupid!

What's so stupid about reading root's email while logged in as root?
~M

On Sun, 2002-06-09 at 17:25, Matt Alexander wrote:
> What's so stupid about reading root's email while logged in as root?

root's email shouldn't go to a "root" mailbox. It should be redirected,
either to a special (unprivileged) account, or it should go to the
sysadmins regular email account.

> > What's so stupid about reading root's email while logged in as root?
>
> root's email shouldn't go to a "root" mailbox. It should be redirected,
> either to a special (unprivileged) account, or it should go to the
> sysadmins regular email account.

Which is what I do.  All root messages are redirected to me.  This is
convenient since I don't have to login as root to get the messages (log
messages are sent to a remote logging server anyway, so there's not much
mail for root), but I still don't see what's so insecure about having a
root mailbox.  Maybe there's some glaringly obvious security hole I'm
overlooking right now...




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sun Jun  9 18:47:02 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sun, 9 Jun 2002 18:47:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] cron.weekly read file errors
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206091753230.29177-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206091753230.29177-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200206091847.02658.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Here's where our distros start to diverge. Under SuSE Linix there is not 
man page for "makewhatis" and in looking at my system "makewhatis" is a 
Bourne shell script that doesn't even support a "-w" argument. Perhaps 
some with a RedHat installation will be able to help you here.

As best as I can tell it looks like "makewhatis" goes through all of the 
man page files on a system and builds a cache file from those files. 
The usual format for a man page files is <command>.<section-number>. 
You might look at the appropriate man directory for the files that are 
causing the errors.

On my system the man pages reside in /usr/share/man/manX where X is the 
section number. At one time I thought that /usr/man/manX was the place 
where man files reside and I've seen this on non-Linux systems. On 
extra stuff that is installed locally into /usr/local the man pages 
reside in /usr/local/man.

HTH,

Tony


On Sunday 09 June 2002 17:54 pm, Rich Shepard wrote:

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sun Jun  9 18:56:12 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sun, 9 Jun 2002 18:56:12 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Everything you wanted to know about Linux security and aren't afraid to ask (was: Linux /Windows virus appears)
In-Reply-To: <1023644546.1838.4956.camel@pookie>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206051650480.7270-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <1023632128.13543.55.camel@sneaker.got-roots.com> <1023644546.1838.4956.camel@pookie>
Message-ID: <200206091856.12773.aschlemm@attbi.com>

You don't even need a virus to get step 3 to occur. I'm man enough to 
admit to the fact that I accidently "rm -rf'ed" my home directory off 
of a system at work one time. Thankfully we had a great SA that had our 
server setup to take nightly backups of our home directories so I 
didn't lose anything. 

As a longtime user of Unix it took me 16 years before I ever made that 
sort of Unix mistake. I'm not sure I'll ever live that "uh oh" down. 
Our SA ribbed me about it for a while although he said it's not the 
first time he's seen someone do that.

Hanging my head in shame,

Tony

On Sunday 09 June 2002 10:42 am, D. Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> All;
>
> Please help me set my mind at ease on the Linux security thing.
>
> While it is true that Linux built with security in mind from the
> start (file/group permissions, e.t.c.) an that (I believe) having the
> source code open for peer review are good things, it is the human
> element of the security picture that scares me the most:
>
>     1) User receives an email from a cracker posing as a friend. The
> sender instructs the user to save the attachment and run it... ``it's
> a hoot, '' the cracker says in the message, ``you'll love it!''
>
>     2) User saves attachment in his home directory and runs it.
>
>     3) Script (or binary) performs the following:
>
>        find / -name -exec rm -rf {} \; 2>/dev/null
>
>     4) The script dutifully goes out and deletes every file that the
> user has write privileges to including /tmp.
>
>     5) The machine comes to a screeching halt (or at least it's
> applications relying on /tmp do). The administrator is in a disarray
> of what happened.
>
> Let's suppose further that our hapless user is a member of group
> ``sales.'' Under this scenario, not only would the user's files be
> deleted, but also the files and directories he has write permissions
> to in the sales area, also.
>
> ``That can't happen,'' you might be saying, ``We will execute the
> equivalent of the `file' command on each file as it passes through
> the mail server.'' We will allow only documents through.
>
> Okay, fine. The trouble is that email is not the only way to get a
> file onto the system. Like so:
>
>     1) The cracker social engineers the user name and password on the
> system.
>
>     2) The attacker launches a script that utilizes a known remote
> exploit on the server.
>
>     3) The script drops the executable in /tmp , su's to a known user
> name (if it is not already working as that user), and runs the
> equivalent to the `find' command above.
>
> I've actually had a case like the one above. It exploited a hole in
> DNS. It was incredible. It came in, dropped the source code in /tmp,
> and compiled it's payload into a binary. The compiled code was
> designed to go out to an irc channel and wait for it's author to type
> in a codeword. Meanwhile, perhaps other thousands were listening
> there as well.
>
> The believe it was designed to destroy files.
>
> It happened on my security officer's home machine. He sent it to me
> and I analyzed it. It was written in C.
>
> I'm worried.
>
>
> -Cooper
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at attbi.com

From alex at daniloff.com  Sun Jun  9 18:04:06 2002
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)
Date: Sun, 9 Jun 2002 18:04:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PLUG resume database project
In-Reply-To: <1023630996.12454.40.camel@sneaker.got-roots.com>
References: <200206061646.g56GkbM07628@gate.daniloff.com> <1023630996.12454.40.camel@sneaker.got-roots.com>
Message-ID: <02060918040600.14237@gate>

Hi, 
Let me give you some numbers for Iwil Side Raid 100 
dual channel controller which I've got during system I/O scaling and testing.
Assume, that each HD is connected to its own channel on the raid controller.
Each hard drive is 40GB IBM 7.2K RPM with 2MB buffer.
Each HD's  own speed is 34.78 MB/sec
System bus I/O speed is 250.98 MB/sec

RAID0 implementation of two HD's gives in average 70.33 MB/sec data transfer 
rate at chunk size 4 kb and 68.82 MB/sec at chunk size 32 kb. Bus I/O 250.98 
MB/sec.

RAID0 of four HD's on two raid controllers gives 84.21 MB/sec at chunk size 4 
kb, 82.05 MB/sec at chunk size 8 kb, 81.01 MB/sec at chunk size 16 kb,
75.29 MB/sec at chunk size 32 kb and 70.33 MB/sec at chunk size 64 kb. Bus 
I/O 250.98 MB/sec.

RAID1 of two HD's gives just 8.65 MB/sec at chunk size 32 kb and 6.35 at 
chunk size 4 kb. Bus I/O 206.45 MB/sec.

RAID1 of four HD's on two raid controllers gives just 4.56 MB/sec at chunk 
size 32 kb and 3.91 MB/sec at chunk size 4 kb. Bus I/O 206.45 MB/sec.

RAID5 of four HDs on two raid controllers gives only 6.48 MB/sec at chunk 
size 128 kb. Bus I/O 134.74 MB/sec.

RAID0+1 gives 70.33 MB/sec at chunk size 4 kb and 69.57 MB/sec at chunk size 
32 kb on each independent RAID0. 
RAID1 of two RAID0's gives 36.57 MB/sec at chunk size 4 kb and 34.59 MB/sec 
at chunk size 32 kb. Bus I/O 250.98 MB/sec.

RAID1+0 gives 4.76 MB/sec at chunk size 32 kb on each independent RAID1.
RAID0 of two RAID1's gives 16.98 MB/sec at chunk size 4 kb. Bus I/O 193.94 
MB/sec.

You can conclude by yourself what solution is the best in here.
That is why I'm running simultaneously two MySQL DB's as master - slave 
replication schema. 
Each one of them is writing to its own data partition on independent RAID0.
If one RAID0 goes fishing the remaining DB becomes a master until failed 
RAID0 is back in business again.

Alex  
 


On Sunday 09 June 2002 06:56 am, you wrote:
>
> 2 notes on this. Isn't RAID0 just striping? It provides no data
> redundancy, just balances the data between the 2. If you are looking for
> redundancy wouldn't RAID 1 be better? Point 2: RAID is not a replacement
> for periodic backups. A corrupted database will replicate through all
> the RAID drives and you will have no way to recover your data in this
> event.
>
> Doug
>
>

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sun Jun  9 19:24:59 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sun, 9 Jun 2002 19:24:59 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Everything you wanted to know about Linux security and aren't afraid to ask (was: Linux /Windows virus appears)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206091910300.5926-100000@localhost.localdomain>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206091910300.5926-100000@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <200206091924.59552.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I was cleaning up some subdirectories within my home directory. Somehow 
my fingers got crossed up and I pressed "." rather than entering the 
subdirectory name and then hit the <return> key. There was no going 
back from there.

I tend to alias "rm" to "rm -i" now so I can't make this mistake again. 
It's just one of those things that happens. I've certainly seen people 
nuke an entire subdirectory by accident over the years and nuking a 
home directory isn't much different. If you're cleaning up a directory 
within your home directory and if you're one level up boom! your home 
directory is gone instead of the subdirectory. 

I think the best way to avoid this is to always specify the directory by 
name that you want to remove. Don't use "*" or "." as that can nuke 
your current working directory which might be your home directory.

Tony

On Sunday 09 June 2002 19:11 pm, Neil Anuskiewicz wrote:
> On Sun, 9 Jun 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> > You don't even need a virus to get step 3 to occur. I'm man enough

> > great SA that had our server setup to take nightly backups of our
> > home directories so I didn't lose anything.

> the time?

Anthony Schlemmer

Since we're on the discussion of 'rm -rf'. I'll add my command that you don't
want to try:

tar cf - / | (cd /disk2; tar xvpf - )

Anyone guess what this does incorrectly?

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sun Jun  9 19:33:12 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sun, 9 Jun 2002 19:33:12 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Everything you wanted to know about Linux security and aren't afraid to ask (was: Linux /Windows virus appears)
In-Reply-To: <200206091924.59552.aschlemm@attbi.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206091910300.5926-100000@localhost.localdomain> <200206091924.59552.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Opps I pressed "*" not "."...See I can't type sometimes...:) I took out 
all of the subdirectories within my home directory but left all of my 
.xxxx (dot) files intact so it didn't really remove my home directory 
per se. With all of my working directories gone it really just as bad a 
taking out the entire directory. Now it is possible to take out your 
home directory completely if you do an "rm -rf <user> from /home.

Tony

On Sunday 09 June 2002 19:24 pm, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> I was cleaning up some subdirectories within my home directory.
> Somehow my fingers got crossed up and I pressed "." rather than
> entering the subdirectory name and then hit the <return> key. There
> was no going back from there.
>
> I tend to alias "rm" to "rm -i" now so I can't make this mistake
> again. It's just one of those things that happens. I've certainly
> seen people nuke an entire subdirectory by accident over the years
> and nuking a home directory isn't much different. If you're cleaning
> up a directory within your home directory and if you're one level up
> boom! your home directory is gone instead of the subdirectory.
>
> I think the best way to avoid this is to always specify the directory
> by name that you want to remove. Don't use "*" or "." as that can
> nuke your current working directory which might be your home
> directory.
>
> Tony
>
> On Sunday 09 June 2002 19:11 pm, Neil Anuskiewicz wrote:
> > On Sun, 9 Jun 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> > > You don't even need a virus to get step 3 to occur. I'm man
> > > enough to admit to the fact that I accidently "rm -rf'ed" my home
> > > directory off of a system at work one time. Thankfully we had a
> > > great SA that had our server setup to take nightly backups of our
> > > home directories so I didn't lose anything.
> >
> > Just curious, how did you do it? I mean, what were trying to do at
> > the time?

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at attbi.com
>>>>This machine was last rebooted:  12 days 19:54 hours ago<<




From dealy at deatech.com  Sun Jun  9 19:31:18 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Sun, 9 Jun 2002 19:31:18 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] cron.weekly read file errors
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206090803290.28897-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206091928470.25356-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Sun, 9 Jun 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Each Sunday, the cron daemon sends root a report with the results of
> run-parts on cron.weekly. The only file in /etc/cron.weekly is
> makewhatis.cron. There's nothing in that script that leads me to understand
> the source of these error messages:
>
> Read file error: ./cancel. No such file or directory
> Read file error: ./slogin1.1 No such file or directory
> Read file error: ./disable.8 No such file or directory
> Read file error: ./reject.8 No such file or directory
> Read file error: ./forms.5 No such file or directory
>
>   Can someone please give me some insight into the source of these? Is
> makewhatis trying to read non-existent files? These look almost like man
> pages to me, but what's trying to read them?

Sometimes these kinds of errors are due to dangling symlinks trying to be
indexed as files.  In other words, if you search your man paths for these
files are all of them symbolic links which point to nothing?

From flee at aracnet.com  Sun Jun  9 19:45:46 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)
Date: Sun, 09 Jun 2002 19:45:46 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Everything you wanted to know about Linux security and aren't afraid to ask (was: Linux /Windows virus appears)
In-Reply-To: <200206091924.59552.aschlemm@attbi.com> on Sun, 09 Jun 2002 19:24:59 PDT.
Message-ID: <200206100245.g5A2jkV13363@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

Anthony Schlemmer <aschlemm at attbi.com>:
> I tend to alias "rm" to "rm -i" now so I can't make this mistake again. 

This is the wrong thing to do.  It trains you into thinking
that typing "rm" is safe, and if you go to some environment
other than your own, it's likely that there won't be that
alias, so you're more likely to get screwed.

A better thing to do is either get in the habit of typing
"rm -i" all the time, or make an alias that _isn't_ called
"rm" and use that instead of "rm".
--
[ sometimes androids dream of translucent electric trouser snakes ]

A guy I knew in college did this as well;  He meant to type:

rm -rf *~

But by typing hastily, he accidentaly bounced on the space bar:

rm -rf * ~

And got:

rm: ~ not found.

He was reportedly confused for a few seconds, then nearly barfed.

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sun Jun  9 20:11:55 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sun, 9 Jun 2002 20:11:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Everything you wanted to know about Linux security and aren't afraid to ask (was: Linux /Windows virus appears)
In-Reply-To: <200206100245.g5A2jkV13363@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>
References: <200206100245.g5A2jkV13363@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>
Message-ID: <200206092011.55828.aschlemm@attbi.com>

A check of "alias rm" tells me if "rm" is aliased or not. All I can say 
is a mistake like this really sticks with me and I plan on never 
repeating it. I am not trained into thinking that "rm" is always 
aliased to "rm -i". Before doing any large directory cleanups I check 
what "rm" I am using and I make sure I specify the directory names and 
don't use any wildcard characters. 

That's what works for me but what I do may not work for anyone else.

Tony

On Sunday 09 June 2002 19:45 pm, Felix Lee wrote:

a bigger gun to shoot their toes off with...I've seen people nuke 
directories because they were in a hurry and the auto completion wasn't 
what they were expecting but they had already pressed the <return> key 
before they realized it. :O

From aapuch at attbi.com  Sun Jun  9 20:52:48 2002
From: aapuch at attbi.com (Andrew Puch)
Date: 09 Jun 2002 20:52:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] PLUG resume database project
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206091254200.24463-100000@critter.deatech.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206091254200.24463-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <1023681169.9204.358.camel@brain>

On Sun, 2002-06-09 at 13:05, Shannon C. Dealy wrote:
> On Sun, 9 Jun 2002, John H. wrote:
> 
> > Shannon C. Dealy wrote:
> [snip]
> > >Could you elaborate on the reasons and extent of it's crapiness?
> > >
> >
> > These days IDE drives (7200rpm) are becoming seemingly as fast as SCSI
> > drives, right?

7200 is slow, scsi does 15,000 rpm. So it is twice as fast. 

Fujitsu's Silent Strike: The MAM3184MP With Ultra160 and 15,000 rpm 
http://www4.tomshardware.com/storage/02q2/020415/index.html

I believe that Seagate had 15,000 drive out 2 years ago, too. 

Old oracle dba I know love allot of small drives. 

> > It's all good until you want to start doing multiple reads and writes,
> > this is where IDE's performance goes down.
maybe, it is a function of the ide controller. 

the best performing ide raid card have one control per drive, the card
are FULL Length cards.  

here are a set of reviews, 2/2002 
 http://www.xbitlabs.com/storage/raid-roundup/

IDE raid does not scale well, in short it is a hack.
By scale I mean there are only so many drives before your case is a sea
of ide cables. IDE need a set length before it dies.

I have yet to see a 64 bit @ 66 Mhz controller for IDE raid. 

This is where the scsi cards are. 

How fast is Raid 5, is directly based on how fast the controller do the
raid checksum. 

While I worked for IBM doing Intel Xeon processors control flow dumps to
a 4~16 gig ram array. We made magic device that sat between the Intel
processor and the mother board. We did software raid 5. It was way
faster, then the slow little power pc based raid control that we bench
marked. Keep in mind that the box  for software Raid 5 were  2 way PIII,
4 way ppro and pIII xeons. Software Raid code uses the Katmi
instructions from MMx 2 I believe.   

If you look at the SCSI solution, is fading away at the high end as
people move to fiber channel. To increase the range of their cables,
then use scsi/160  at the drive.

http://www.adaptec.com/worldwide/product/proddetail.html?sess=no&prodkey=DuraStor7220SS&cat=/Technology/External+Storage/Storage+Subsystems

I know that I would try

tar cf - /| ( cd /disk2 && tar xvpf -)
