From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sun Jun  9 21:56:32 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 09 Jun 2002 21:56:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] in the mean time
In-Reply-To: <1023663726.5034.30.camel@sthelens.dimstar.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206082309070.1760-100000@localhost.localdomain>
	<1023654801.5034.25.camel@sthelens.dimstar.net>
	<868z5o2lw9.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<1023663726.5034.30.camel@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <86y9dn20lb.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Russ" == Russ Johnson <russj at dimstar.net> writes:

me> I dislike the current behaviour of munging the From: line in the
me> archive:

me> a) it is pointless unless you also munge each email going through
me> the list because of private archives; and

Russ> That's just it. If it's a "private" archive, how can it be
Russ> different?  Each email going through the list IS munged. If I do
Russ> a reply to all, it still only comes up with one address to send
Russ> to, the list.

The _archive_ currently munges the From: address.  That is in addition
to the "Reply-To: munging (also harmful) that occurs for normal
message propagation.  For example, your message in the archive says
something like: "From: Russ Johnson <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>", rather
than: "From: Russ Johnson <russj at dimstar.net>".  Anyone subscribed to
the list will get your "real" email address.  The only protection from
that is to not post to the list.

Also, private archives can become public.  If the current practice of
"From" munging persists, I'll consider publishing my own private
archive without the munging.

Munging introduces entropy into the data which makes future data
archeology (such as to create a future archive) more difficult.  As
someone who does data archeology for a living, it is something that I
find immensely annoying.

me> b) it interferes unacceptably with the ability to mail people
me> privately.

Russ> I don't see how. The senders address IS in the mail that you
Russ> receive from the list. It's just not available from the web
Russ> page, which I personally consider to be a good thing.

Suppose you are researching something posted a year ago.  If you want
to ask the person privately what they meant or how things turned out
or whatever, you can't, because you don't readily have a way to do
that.  You'd have to post to the mailing list (which they might not
still even be subscribed to) to try to reach them, which is wasteful.

Basically, it imposes an unnecessary cost of complexity and
obstruction for an illusory benefit.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``The two chiefs turned to each other.        
seniorr at aracnet.com      Bellison uncorked a flood of horrible       
                         profanity, which, translated meant, `This is
                         extremely unusual.' ''                      



From seant at q7.com  Sun Jun  9 22:03:51 2002

From flee at aracnet.com  Mon Jun 10 04:07:14 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 04:07:14 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Everything you wanted to know about Linux security and aren't afraid to ask (was: Linux /Windows virus appears)
In-Reply-To: <200206092011.55828.aschlemm@attbi.com> on Sun, 09 Jun 2002 20:11:55 PDT.
Message-ID: <200206101107.g5AB7Gu14780@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

Anthony Schlemmer <aschlemm at attbi.com>:
> A check of "alias rm" tells me if "rm" is aliased or not. All I can say 
> is a mistake like this really sticks with me and I plan on never 
> repeating it. I am not trained into thinking that "rm" is always 
> aliased to "rm -i". Before doing any large directory cleanups I check 
> what "rm" I am using and I make sure I specify the directory names and 
> don't use any wildcard characters. 

Are you always that diligent with everything?  I know I'm
not.  Since you did slip up once before, it seems plausible
you may slip up again.  And it sounds to me like all the
steps you're going through is a lot more work than just
typing "rm -i" all the time.  I have periodic backups for
the big mistakes, and I type "rm -i" when I'm feeling unsure
of my competence.

Really, I'm arguing this because it annoys me to no end when
I sit down in front of someone else's shell and type "rm"
and get "rm -i" instead.  "unalias rm" is often the second
or third command I type.

And there's no rm option that will undo the -i option.
"rm -i -f" is not the same as just "rm".
--
[ sometimes staying in hostiles is more fun ]

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Jun 10 07:22:53 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 07:22:53 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Shell command question
In-Reply-To: <20020610134143.38410347EF@ados.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206100717550.21422-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 10 Jun 2002, guy1656 wrote:

> I have a bunch of files in directory 'A' and copies of MOST of these
> files in directory 'B.'
> 
> What is a command which would remove files in 'A' with the same
> names as the ones which appear in 'B' (so I am only deleting the
> extra copies?)
> 
> The files which are to remain in 'A' are all ones which do not
> appear in 'B.'

  cd /path/to/B
  for f in *
  do
    rm -f "/path/to/A/$f"
  done

or

  cd /path/to/A
  for f in *
  do
    [ -f "/path/to/B/$f" ] && rm -f $f
  done

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

On Sun, 2002-06-09 at 19:24, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> I was cleaning up some subdirectories within my home directory. 

[snip]

> I tend to alias "rm" to "rm -i" now so I can't make this mistake again. 

Just for fun, the following also works:

  find /directory/you/wish/deleted -ok rm -rf {} \;

It will ask you before deleting each file and directory.


-Cooper

On Mon, 2002-06-10 at 08:29, D. Cooper Stevenson wrote:

> [snip] 

>   find /directory/you/wish/deleted -ok rm -rf {} \;

Correction:

    find /directory/you/wish/deleted -depth -ok rm -rf {} \;
 

It will ask you before deleting each file and directory.


-Cooper




From scott_ogilvie at agilent.com  Mon Jun 10 08:43:12 2002
From: scott_ogilvie at agilent.com (Scott Ogilvie)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 08:43:12 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [lug] Everything you wanted to know about Linuxsecurity 
 and aren'tafraid to ask (was: Linux /Windows virus appears)
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206091714400.9697-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <3D04C910.76ACCE3F@agilent.com>

Matt Alexander wrote:
> 
> On Sun, 9 Jun 2002, Allen Brown wrote:
> 
> > Until the security model of Linux is revamped avoiding this requires,
> > as you say, the social element.  We must never give ourselves more
> > permissions than the task at hand requires.
> 
> I don't see anything inherently wrong with the current Linux security
> model. ...

I do.
Linux and Unix securities trust is based on what a user is allowed to
do.
Much of what is running on my machine I have no idea what it is doing or
supposed to do.  In the networked world we live in now we really need
privileges that can be set that limit what an executable is allowed to
do no matter who is running it. We could prohibit some executables from
doing anything but display to the screen and allow others to write and
read
from the disk but not modify any files it did not create. Trust needs to
be the intersection of what a user is allowed to do and what an
executable
is allowed to do.
> 
> > The most outrageous
> > violations of this principal that I have seen have been by profesional
> > sysadmins who do everything as root, including reading email and
> > browsing the net.  Stupid!
> 
> What's so stupid about reading root's email while logged in as root?

Some mailers are capable of running an attached executable if you open
the
mail. It would run with root privileges.

Sincerely,

Scott Ogilvie

From pem at nellump.net  Sun Jun  9 20:15:09 2002
From: pem at nellump.net (Paul Mullen)
Date: Sun, 9 Jun 2002 20:15:09 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] File Deletion Mishaps  WAS: Everything you wanted to know about Linux security...
In-Reply-To: <200206100245.g5A2jkV13363@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>; from flee@aracnet.com on Sun, Jun 09, 2002 at 07:45:46PM -0700
References: <200206091924.59552.aschlemm@attbi.com> <200206100245.g5A2jkV13363@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>
Message-ID: <20020609201508.D5841@nellump.net>

On Sun, Jun 09, 2002 at 07:45:46PM -0700, Felix Lee wrote:
> Anthony Schlemmer <aschlemm at attbi.com>:
> > I tend to alias "rm" to "rm -i" now so I can't make this mistake again. 
> 
> This is the wrong thing to do.  It trains you into thinking
> that typing "rm" is safe, and if you go to some environment

It also trains you to use 'rm -f' by force of habit, which effectively
negates the usefulness of the alias.

> A better thing to do is either get in the habit of typing
> "rm -i" all the time, or make an alias that _isn't_ called
> "rm" and use that instead of "rm".

Another idea is to make use of a 'trash' directory in conjunction with
a simple shell script and a separate cron job. The following is crude,
but it works:

	#!/bin/bash
	# mv files specified to the designated "trashcan" directory.
	
	# location of the "trashcan"
	trash=~/trash
	
	if [ $1 = '-v' ]; then
	    errs=yes
	    shift
	fi
	
	for file in "$@" 
	do
	    if [ -d $file ]; then
		type=directory
	    elif [ -f $file ]; then
		type=file
	    else
		type=unknown
	    fi
	
	    if [ $errs ]; then
		mv $file $trash
	    else    
	        mv $file $trash 2> /dev/null
	    fi
	
	    if [ $? == 0 ]; then
		echo "$file : $type trashed"
	    else
	        echo "$file : $type could not be trashed"
	    fi
	done


Then have cron run 'tmpwatch' every day, and have it delete any files
unaccessed in more than N days.


Paul



From russj at dimstar.net  Mon Jun 10 09:31:42 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 09:31:42 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] in the mean time

Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020610092841.0213bdd0@localhost>

So, do this:

Connect to your home machine via ssh, and view your email through the 
encrypted ssh pipe. Keeps the prying eyes out.

Use Opera with "Refuse pop-up windows". If you run a proxy at home, you can 
forward those requests through the ssh pipe too, but this would be slow.

Just a thought. I've never worked in an environment that was this (insert 
favorite word here) about network traffic.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jun 10 09:21:56 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 09:21:56 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Multiple Boxes
In-Reply-To: <3D04C961.4080100@sun.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206100920100.31373-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 10 Jun 2002, Richard Langis Jr. wrote:

> What method do you use to keep users/groups/logins/passwords/everything 
> else synchronized?  Or do you?

Richard,

  On the three workstation, two portable network I have here, I use
/etc/hosts rather than anything more complicated. Machines don't change and
it's just easier to copy the same files to each box than try to install and
maintain another dynamic protocol for a static situation.

Rich




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Mon Jun 10 09:37:45 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 09:37:45 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Everything you wanted to know about Linux security and aren't afraid to ask (was: Linux /Windows virus appears)
In-Reply-To: <200206101107.g5AB7Gu14780@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>
References: <200206101107.g5AB7Gu14780@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>
Message-ID: <200206100937.45423.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Trust me...if you blow away your home directory and potentially lose a 
months worth of work and have to fret about telling your manager why 
the schedule may slide a whole month makes you that diligent. Again the 
only thing that saved my butt was our excellent SA that setup our 
server to do nightly backups of our home directories and Clearcase 
views.

Tony

On Monday 10 June 2002 04:07 am, Felix Lee wrote:
> Anthony Schlemmer <aschlemm at attbi.com>:
> > A check of "alias rm" tells me if "rm" is aliased or not. All I can
> > say is a mistake like this really sticks with me and I plan on
> > never repeating it. I am not trained into thinking that "rm" is
> > always aliased to "rm -i". Before doing any large directory
> > cleanups I check what "rm" I am using and I make sure I specify the
> > directory names and don't use any wildcard characters.
>
> Are you always that diligent with everything?  I know I'm
> not.  Since you did slip up once before, it seems plausible
> you may slip up again.  And it sounds to me like all the
> steps you're going through is a lot more work than just
> typing "rm -i" all the time.  I have periodic backups for
> the big mistakes, and I type "rm -i" when I'm feeling unsure
> of my competence.
>
> Really, I'm arguing this because it annoys me to no end when
> I sit down in front of someone else's shell and type "rm"
> and get "rm -i" instead.  "unalias rm" is often the second
> or third command I type.
>
> And there's no rm option that will undo the -i option.
> "rm -i -f" is not the same as just "rm".

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at attbi.com





From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon Jun 10 09:46:17 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 10 Jun 2002 09:46:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] in the mean time
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206092220030.7023-100000@localhost.localdomain>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206092220030.7023-100000@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <86r8jf13qe.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Neil" == Neil Anuskiewicz <neil at pacifier.com> writes:

Russell> Munging introduces entropy into the data which makes future
Russell> data archeology (such as to create a future archive) more
Russell> difficult.  As someone who does data archeology for a living,
Russell> it is something that I find immensely annoying.

Neil> What is data archeology? 

For me, it is about discovering (as in cases where the data are under
documented) and preserving semantics.  

When I began collecting old PLUG mailing list traffic, I discovered
that the skylab archive at the time only went back a few years.
Luckily, their archives were available in an unmunged form (i.e., an
mbox format with messages as they were received from the list).  I
have been able to collect contributions from other people in a similar
form (i.e., the full messages with all headers).  I can merge these
together and with some minimal munging (actually, just removing the
local delivery headers, the parts that were unique to delivery to a
particular subscriber) I can reproduce with good accuracy the common
parts of the message.  This approximates, close to perfection, the
messages as they passed through the mailing list host.  The result is
something that can be used for the next would-be archivist.

In (part of) my job, I am typically trying to preserve data sets from
scientific studies where data preservation wasn't their top priority.
Collecting and analyzing data, and then writing a report or paper was
their priority.  However, the funders usually have an interest in
maximizing the value available from the considerable investment they
dumped into the data collection and so for _them_ preservation _is_ a
priority.  As a result, I get a bunch of stuff in a box (disks and
reports, hopefully with a contact who still remembers what they did)
and I try to sort it out, describe and organize it coherently, and
preserve it such that it can be used again.

Neil> How is it diff from data mining?

I don't know, since I don't do "data mining".  My sense is that "data
mining" is more of a statistical inferential operation.  You are
trying to extract probabilistic meaning from a blob of data.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``The two chiefs turned to each other.        
seniorr at aracnet.com      Bellison uncorked a flood of horrible       
                         profanity, which, translated meant, `This is
                         extremely unusual.' ''

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jun 10 11:16:38 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 11:16:38 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] A shell scripting lesson
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206101112190.31799-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I know that I can replace file suffixes with a loop that renames files one
by one as the variable is incremented. If I want to change one character in
a series of file names, can I do this all in one fell swoop with a loop?

  Specifically, I have a bunch of digital images files named, for example,
0606_*.jpg, and I want to change them all to be 0605_*,jpg. Will it work to
run

for i in $i; exec 'mv 0606i 0605i'; done

?

  I don't want to blow away files or spend the rest of today working it all
out, so I'm asking.

Thanks,

Rich




From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Jun 10 11:55:37 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 11:55:37 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] A shell scripting lesson
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206101112190.31799-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206101154500.27644-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 10 Jun 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   I know that I can replace file suffixes with a loop that renames files one
> by one as the variable is incremented. If I want to change one character in
> a series of file names, can I do this all in one fell swoop with a loop?
> 
>   Specifically, I have a bunch of digital images files named, for example,
> 0606_*.jpg, and I want to change them all to be 0605_*,jpg.

for file in 0606_*; do mv $file `echo $file|sed -e 's/^0606/0605/'`; done

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Jun 10 12:01:26 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 12:01:26 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] A shell scripting lesson
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206101112190.31799-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206101157500.22804-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 10 Jun 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> Specifically, I have a bunch of digital images files named, for
> example, 0606_*.jpg, and I want to change them all to be 0605_*,jpg.
> Will it work to run
> 
> for i in $i; exec 'mv 0606i 0605i'; done

no. try this:

  cd /whereever/the/jpgs/are
  for f in 0606*
  do
    mv $f 0605_${f#0606_}
  done

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon Jun 10 12:17:25 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 10 Jun 2002 12:17:25 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] A shell scripting lesson
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206101157500.22804-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

Message-ID: <86lm9n0wqi.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Paul" == Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com> writes:

Rich> Specifically, I have a bunch of digital images files named, for
Rich> example, 0606_*.jpg, and I want to change them all to be
Rich> 0605_*,jpg.  Will it work to run
Rich> 
Rich> for i in $i; exec 'mv 0606i 0605i'; done

Paul> no. try this: [...]

And, in case you aren't total clear on how the replacement works, try
with "echo" replacing the "mv" first:

  for f in 0606* ; do echo $f 0605_${f#0606_} ; done

From shahms at shahms.com  Mon Jun 10 12:09:44 2002
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms E. King)
Date: 10 Jun 2002 12:09:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] A shell scripting lesson
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206101157500.22804-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: 
	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206101157500.22804-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <1023736184.931.1.camel@shahms>

If you're using a recent distribution (or one with a util-linux version
of util-linux-2.11n-12 or higher -- that's from an RH7.3 box YMMV)
you can simply use the rename command.

rename 0606 0605 0606_*.jpg 

will do what you want.

--Shahms

> And, in case you aren't total clear on how the replacement works, try
> with "echo" replacing the "mv" first:
> 
>   for f in 0606* ; do echo $f 0605_${f#0606_} ; done

Russell's approach is more elegant, and in the long run probably more
useful. When I am faced with doing something hazardous, I usually create
a copy in a separate directory somewhere and test the action on the
copy.

From sandy at herring.org  Mon Jun 10 12:59:29 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 12:59:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] A shell scripting lesson
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206101221570.31970-100000@appl-ecosys.com>; from rshepard@appl-ecosys.com on Mon, Jun 10, 2002 at 12:22:40PM -0700

On Mon, 10 Jun 2002, Rich Shepard wrote: 
> On 10 Jun 2002, Shahms E. King wrote:
> 
> > If you're using a recent distribution (or one with a util-linux version
> > of util-linux-2.11n-12 or higher -- that's from an RH7.3 box YMMV)

> 
>   I have a bash-2 rename script and a couple of rename man pages.

> Rich

And if you grok perl regexp's and want to take it a step beyond, check out
rename.pl:

http://www.sial.org/code/perl/scripts/rename.pl.html

That's what I use to rename the .jpg's from my Olympus D490Z to yyyymmddnnn
format from it's crufty kluge...

    Pmddnnnn.jpg

...where "P" is a literal, and the single digit month uses "a" for October,
"b" for November and "c" for December - and the year is not noted.

Sandy

From gilmanhunt at attbi.com  Mon Jun 10 13:08:20 2002
From: gilmanhunt at attbi.com (gilmanhunt at attbi.com)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 20:08:20 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] A shell scripting lesson
Message-ID: <20020610200820.RKMX2751.rwcrmhc52.attbi.com@rwcrwbc56>

I have done this, for a similar exercise
(saving this as a file, and chmod +x'ing it
-----------
#!/bin/bash
  FILES="`ls *.jpg.jpg`"
  for i in $FILES
   do
      x=`echo "$i" | sed 's/\.jpg\.jpg$/\.jpg/g;'`
      mv "$i" "$x"
   done
echo "process complete"
------------
You can probably see how to alter it to make your stuff
happy.  But Jeme and Paul's solution are probably better.

-Russ

From pem at nellump.net  Mon Jun 10 13:55:58 2002
From: pem at nellump.net (Paul Mullen)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 13:55:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] How does 'ls' determine file type for colorization purposes?
Message-ID: <20020610135558.A7978@nellump.net>

As the title says... How does 'ls' determine file type for purposes of
color-coding it's listings? The man and info pages don't seem to give
any clue.

My question stems from my desire to have files of, say, *.tiff displayed
the same as those of *.tif (truncated file-type extensions are one of
my pet peeves). Currently, the image files with short extensions are
colored some garish pink, while the "proper" extensions are not colored
at all. Argh.


Paul

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Mon Jun 10 13:57:38 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 10 Jun 2002 13:57:38 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] (no subject)
References: <mailman.1023718871.29594.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <867kl6yhq5.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Sean" == Sean Whitney <sean_whitney at bigfoot.com> writes:

Sean> for x in `ls /directoryb'; do rm /directorya/$x;done

Seriously broken for whitespace-containing filenames.  Bah!

Here's a safe version of that:

perl -e 'chdir "/directoryb" or die; unlink map "/directorya/$_", <*>'

No problem with whitespace now.

From bdhruva at gmx.net  Mon Jun 10 14:00:05 2002
From: bdhruva at gmx.net (Dhruva B. Reddy)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 15:00:05 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] How does 'ls' determine file type for colorization purposes?
In-Reply-To: <20020610135558.A7978@nellump.net>
References: <20020610135558.A7978@nellump.net>
Message-ID: <20020610210005.GA12522@dr.mobizinc.com>

There is a utility called dircolors.  This associates extensions and
permissions with various colors.  The output on my system is:

WAY2FONKY$ dircolors 
LS_COLORS='no=00:fi=00:di=01;34:ln=01;36:pi=40;33:so=01;35:do=01;35:bd=40;33;01:cd=40;33;01:or=40;31;01:ex=01;32:*.tar=01;31:*.tgz=01;31:*.arj=01;31:*.taz=01;31:*.lzh=01;31:*.zip=01;31:*.z=01;31:*.Z=01;31:*.gz=01;31:*.bz2=01;31:*.deb=01;31:*.rpm=01;31:*.jar=01;31:*.jpg=01;35:*.jpeg=01;35:*.png=01;35:*.gif=01;35:*.bmp=01;35:*.pbm=01;35:*.pgm=01;35:*.ppm=01;35:*.tga=01;35:*.xbm=01;35:*.xpm=01;35:*.tif=01;35:*.tiff=01;35:*.mpg=01;35:*.mpeg=01;35:*.avi=01;35:*.fli=01;35:*.gl=01;35:*.dl=01;35:*.xcf=01;35:*.xwd=01;35:*.ogg=01;35:*.mp3=01;35:';
export LS_COLORS
WAY2FONKY$

According to the man page, you can specify a file that contains this
information, and it will use that instead of its own database.

Dhruva

From ali at axian.com  Mon Jun 10 14:08:58 2002
From: ali at axian.com (Alice Corbin)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 14:08:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] How does 'ls' determine file type for colorization purposes?

Do an `echo $LS_COLORS' and you'll see what its default settings are.
Capture that and you can twiddle it to your heart's desire.

From mark at mjbynum.org  Mon Jun 10 14:30:33 2002
From: mark at mjbynum.org (Mark Bynum)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 14:30:33 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Commands you don't want to try
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206092203080.9329-100000@q7.q7.com> <20020610044829.9E84E2EFC6@einstein.seansdomain.org>
References: <20020610044829.9E84E2EFC6@einstein.seansdomain.org> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206092203080.9329-100000@q7.q7.com> <20020609192835.A11976@agora.rdrop.com> <20020610044829.9E84E2EFC6@einstein.seansdomain.org>
Message-ID: <20020610143033.A61626@agora.rdrop.com>

Two guesses? They're both good but not the right answer. Here it is:

The original was:

tar cf - / | (cd /disk2; tar xvpf - )

What would happen here is that tar is extracting absolute pathnames,
in effect overwriting every file on the system. When it gets to the 
system files, ones that you need while the system is running, 
it overwrites them. A crash in the making.

The correct command would be:

cd /
tar cf - . | (cd /disk2; tar xvpf -)

But even that may put you in a circular loop because disk2 is mounted.
It'd probably be best to specify the files specifically instead of everything.
Something like:

cd /
tar cf - var etc home | (cd /disk2; tar xvpf -)

would be better.

Mark

On Sun, Jun 09, 2002 at 09:48:29PM -0700, Sean Whitney wrote:
> I know that I would try
> 
> tar cf - /| ( cd /disk2 && tar xvpf -)
> 
> Which should prevent you from trying to overwrite your files if you 
> fat-finger the directory.  What else am I missing?
> 
> 
> Sean
> 

On Sun, Jun 09, 2002 at 10:03:51PM -0700, Sean Lewis wrote:
> Looks to me like it would put you into a loop of tarring the same file
> (the tar itself) over and over again.

> On Sunday 09 June 2002 19:28, you hammered at the keyboard:
> > Since we're on the discussion of 'rm -rf'. I'll add my command that you
> > don't want to try:
> >
> >
> > Anyone guess what this does incorrectly?
> >
> >
> > Mark

On Mon, Jun 10, 2002 at 07:22:53AM -0700, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Mon, 10 Jun 2002, guy1656 wrote:
> 
> > I have a bunch of files in directory 'A' and copies of MOST of these
> > files in directory 'B.'
> > 
> > What is a command which would remove files in 'A' with the same
> > names as the ones which appear in 'B' (so I am only deleting the
> > extra copies?)
> > 
> > The files which are to remain in 'A' are all ones which do not
> > appear in 'B.'
> 
>   cd /path/to/B
>   for f in *
>   do
>     rm -f "/path/to/A/$f"
>   done
> 
> or
> 
>   cd /path/to/A
>   for f in *
>   do
>     [ -f "/path/to/B/$f" ] && rm -f $f
>   done
> 
> --Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>
>

From aj at haightmail.org  Mon Jun 10 15:21:37 2002
From: aj at haightmail.org (Aj Lavin)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 15:21:37 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] We need to block non-member posts
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206101029450.29831-100000@cohiba.fork.com>
References: <20020609070134.527AF20958A@core.emailerotica.com> <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206101029450.29831-100000@cohiba.fork.com>
Message-ID: <20020610222137.GG4976@zappa>

On Mon, Jun 10, 2002 at 10:37:20AM -0700, Dan Haskell wrote:
> 
> The Usenet gateway needs to be shut off until it can be done without
> opening us up to abuse from the whole world.

I do not believe that it is even necessary to open up the mailing list
to non-member posts in order to enable members to post through the
newsgroup. The current Mailman setting is basically a mis-
configuration, AFAICT.

A Mailman list can be configured to receive posts from members only
and to verify members by checking the From: header. Both SMTP and NNTP
have a From: header, so using this policy, Mailman should use the NNTP
From: header to verify members who post through the news group. So if
you post to the newsgroup using a From: field that is a member's email
address, then the post will be sent to the mailing list as well.

This policy would have prevented the recent SPAM while allowing list
members to post through the news gateway.

A tighter policy would use the unixfrom envelope instead of the From
header for authorization. It looks like for Usenet posts, the Mailman
gate_news script sets the unixfrom header to the list administrator's
email address. As long as the list administrator can post to the list,
then all Usenet posts would be sent to the mailing list using this
policy. However, this policy might cause grief for people who
regularly post from different computers.

- Aj

From russj at dimstar.net  Mon Jun 10 15:31:26 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 15:31:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] We need to block non-member posts
In-Reply-To: <20020610222137.GG4976@zappa>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206101029450.29831-100000@cohiba.fork.com>
 <20020609070134.527AF20958A@core.emailerotica.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206101029450.29831-100000@cohiba.fork.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020610152641.02176958@localhost>

However, I believe the intent of the list operator was to enable people to 
read and post to the list, through the news server, without receiving the 
messages via email at all.

I would think there would be software out there that would gate messages in 
this manner, without the need to open the list to abuse. i.e., all messages 
in a newsgroup are gated to a mailing list, and vice versa. Unfortunately, 
spam gets injected into news servers as well, so then you can't let the 
newsgroup be propagated through the news servers of the world. And you have 
to require people to log into the news server to post and/or receive.

At 03:21 PM 6/10/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>A Mailman list can be configured to receive posts from members only
>and to verify members by checking the From: header. Both SMTP and NNTP
>have a From: header, so using this policy, Mailman should use the NNTP
>From: header to verify members who post through the news group. So if
>you post to the newsgroup using a From: field that is a member's email
>address, then the post will be sent to the mailing list as well.

Russ Johnson
http://www.dimstar.net


Love is the triumph of imagination over intelligence.
                 -- H. L. Mencken





From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Jun 10 15:34:44 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 15:34:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] We need to block non-member posts
In-Reply-To: <20020610222137.GG4976@zappa>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206101532090.29115-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 10 Jun 2002, Aj Lavin wrote:
> I do not believe that it is even necessary to open up the mailing list
> to non-member posts in order to enable members to post through the
> newsgroup.

I think you're right in the sense that messages coming through the news
gateway should very well carry the original From: header and if that's a
list member, it should accept the post.

This is easily tested.

And if a person wanted to use the news gateway, they could simply
subscribe and select the "no mail" option.

However, I still think that a spam filter is the best solution.

> The current Mailman setting is basically a mis- configuration, AFAICT.

That's a judgment call I'm not prepared to make.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------

 http://www.openlaw.org





From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Jun 10 15:36:11 2002

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Mon Jun 10 15:36:21 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 10 Jun 2002 15:36:21 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ps2pdf for physically large pages
In-Reply-To: <20020610151442.G12138@dalsemi.com>
References: <20020610151442.G12138@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <1023748581.27403.335.camel@pookie>

Colin;

On Mon, 2002-06-10 at 15:14, Colin Kuskie wrote:
> I need to create some PDFs of 11x17 pages, but my initial attempts to
> make the PDFs show that all of them are cropped at 8x11. 

[snip]

If you are creating the postscript files from Latex and ave the `dvi'
file then might I suggest dvipdf or dvipdfm. 

I have used neither of them with 11x17 but the man page for dvipdfm (I
have found dvipdfm to produce higher-quality output and supports more
PDF features) indicate that you can use it with the -p switch to specify
paper size. It is available at CTAN's sight, www.ctan.org.

Hopefully someone will be able to answer the root of your question. If
you are creating PDF's from Latex files, though, this may be the answer.


-Cooper





From shahms at shahms.com  Mon Jun 10 15:34:28 2002

Well since ps2pdf* all use ghostscript, you can check out that man page,
and from a cursory glance it looks like you should be able to pass
-sPAPERSIZE=11x17 to ps2pdf and have it work.

From neil at pacifier.com  Mon Jun 10 16:28:54 2002
From: neil at pacifier.com (Neil Anuskiewicz)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 16:28:54 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] What PLUG needs
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206101606050.1837-100000@localhost.localdomain>

Okay, I am going to go out on a limb here and suggest that PLUG needs to 
re-organized a bit in order to be more effective. I think that this 
discussion is on-topic but I ask that if this discussion ranges beyond the 
very focused discussion on PLUG then please let's move it to plug-talk.

1. Officer elections.

I believe that PLUG needs officer elections for a number of different 
posts. One of the monthly meetings should be completely devoted to this 
election. We should probably determine the posts ahead of time.


2. Better list admin.

The list needs a small cadre of list admins who spend some time thinking 
about list config *and* some sort of moderation is needed. Not moderation 
before a post makes it to the list but I would say more along the lines of 
a polite reminder and then actually moving threads to plug-talk if they 
range too far off topic.

I like an active list but even I think the list noise is a bit too much 
now. Of course, I have contributed to this noise -- as have many others -- 
but I think it is important for us to get this under control if we are 
going to retain members. We don't want people unsubscribing because of 
list noise. That is stupid.

I am sure we could easily get together a half-dozen informal moderators 
who would be willing to help nudge the list back on topic.

3. A better Web site.

Unfortunately, there is not much of a Web site to speak of right now. 
There were plans for build a custom back-end, etc., but those 
plans seem to be going nowhere right now. What we need is a core of 
practical developers/designers/content people/admin people to put something 
together. To get something good up there relatively efficiently.

I am willing to do my part and write content but that is all I am 
interested in doing (actually, that will take quite a bit of time). I have 
written some already but we need a better site.

Do we have a designer or two out there willing to put together a nice 
site? Someone to setup Zope or something like that? We need to just move 
forward on something in this area. Please join plug-web and state your 
interest in making something happen.

4. More speakers and substantive meetings.

We have had some good speakers no question about it but I think a lot more 
could be done in this area. My feeling is that this is related to 1 above. 
If we can get a core of officers then I think more can happen in these 
areas.



-- 
Neil Anuskiewicz




From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon Jun 10 16:58:45 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 10 Jun 2002 16:58:45 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] What PLUG needs
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206101606050.1837-100000@localhost.localdomain>

>>>>> "Neil" == Neil Anuskiewicz <neil at pacifier.com> writes:

Neil> Okay, I am going to go out on a limb here and suggest that PLUG
Neil> needs to re-organized a bit in order to be more effective. [...]

More effective _at what_?

Neil> 1. Officer elections.

Neil> I believe that PLUG needs officer elections for a number of
Neil> different posts. One of the monthly meetings should be
Neil> completely devoted to this election. We should probably
Neil> determine the posts ahead of time.

I disagree that PLUG needs "official" officers.  David does a fine job
of coordinating things.  The danger of the kind of bureaucracy you are
suggesting is that someone gets into a position of "authority" and
then for whatever reason (e.g. "burnout", "distractions", "malice",
etc.)  becomes an "obstruction".  No authority, no obstruction, people
with the energy just "do".

Neil> [ ... middle section elided ... ]

Neil> 4. More speakers and substantive meetings.

Neil> We have had some good speakers no question about it but I think
Neil> a lot more could be done in this area. [...]

"big-name" speakers idea?  You need to do a better job of motivating
this idea.  _Why_ is it a good idea?  _How_ will it advance _which_
goals?

We've had a series of outstanding speakers and presentations recently.
It is hard to see how we could be "doing better".  Maybe you didn't
see them.

From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Jun 10 17:26:16 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 17:26:16 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] What PLUG needs

On 10 Jun 2002, Russell Senior wrote:
> More effective _at what_?
> 
> I disagree that PLUG needs "official" officers.  David does a fine job
> of coordinating things.  The danger of the kind of bureaucracy you are
> suggesting is that someone gets into a position of "authority" and
> then for whatever reason (e.g. "burnout", "distractions", "malice",
> etc.)  becomes an "obstruction".  No authority, no obstruction, people
> with the energy just "do".
> 
> We've had a series of outstanding speakers and presentations recently.
> It is hard to see how we could be "doing better".  Maybe you didn't
> see them.

At the risk of sending a simple "me too" post, I have to say that I agree
wholeheartedly with Russell on this one.

We don't need some hierarchical power structure to tell us how to share
our thoughts and experiences in the GNU/Linux/Unix community and
workplace.

The speakers in the past six months have been EXCELLENT (Ward's talk was
probably one of the high points of my year) and people organize events
when they are passionate and can make it happen.  I can't imagine how the
consolidation of power into the hands of the few would improve things.

And really, as long as the list isn't discussing the list, the volume and
signal/noise ratio stays totally reasonable.

From neil at pacifier.com  Mon Jun 10 17:28:47 2002
From: neil at pacifier.com (Neil Anuskiewicz)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 17:28:47 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] What PLUG needs
In-Reply-To: <86vg8qd6tm.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206101723530.2503-100000@localhost.localdomain>

On 10 Jun 2002, Russell Senior wrote:

> More effective _at what_?

That is not up to me to decide. That would be for the officers and the 
members of PLUG.

> I disagree that PLUG needs "official" officers.  David does a fine job
> of coordinating things.  The danger of the kind of bureaucracy you are
> suggesting is that someone gets into a position of "authority" and
> then for whatever reason (e.g. "burnout", "distractions", "malice",
> etc.)  becomes an "obstruction".  No authority, no obstruction, people
> with the energy just "do".

Yes, and David could stand for election and be elected. He could then ask 
what the group wants to see happen and coordinate making it happen. This 
is *not* in any way denigrating his leadership.

I think we need leadership that is directly accountable to the members. 
One year terms to reduce the possibility of burnout. And, if someone is 
getting tired, they simply say so and call early elections. No shame in 
saying look I am tired of this. If an officer still wants to continue in 
one year then he or she says so and stands for election again.

> What do you mean by "more could be done"?  Are you referring to your
> "big-name" speakers idea?  You need to do a better job of motivating
> this idea.  _Why_ is it a good idea?  _How_ will it advance _which_
> goals?

Again, the goals are not up to me. I am merely suggesting that there is no 
process in place for any sort of goals.

As for my big speakers idea, yes, that could possibly be one of the goals. 
If we had officers then yes we could recruit more officers.

> We've had a series of outstanding speakers and presentations recently.
> It is hard to see how we could be "doing better".  Maybe you didn't
> see them.

And I said yes we have had good speakers. I was not in any way denigrating 
the speakers.


-- 
Neil Anuskiewicz




From neil at pacifier.com  Mon Jun 10 17:34:34 2002

> We don't need some hierarchical power structure to tell us how to share
> our thoughts and experiences in the GNU/Linux/Unix community and

control your ability to express your thoughts and experiences in the 
GNU/Linux/Unix community.

> The speakers in the past six months have been EXCELLENT (Ward's talk was
> probably one of the high points of my year) and people organize events

Well, there have recently been discussions of politics and even a thread

posted one sentence top posts about this.

This is the last I am going to say about this in defense of the idea 
(unless anyone wants clarification of the idea or if we want to move 
forward mainly because I don't want to argue and take up a lot of list 
space. If people like the idea let's do it; if not then forget it.

From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Jun 10 17:39:13 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 17:39:13 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] What PLUG needs
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206101723530.2503-100000@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206101731080.29633-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 10 Jun 2002, Neil Anuskiewicz wrote:
> On 10 Jun 2002, Russell Senior wrote:
> > More effective _at what_?
> 
> That is not up to me to decide. That would be for the officers and the
> members of PLUG.

But clearly you think that PLUG is not effective ENOUGH.  You want it to
be MORE effective.  Is it not possible that we are optimally effective at
meeting our shared mandate?

> Yes, and David could stand for election and be elected. He could then
> ask what the group wants to see happen and coordinate making it
> happen. This is *not* in any way denigrating his leadership.

You misunderstand.  David just organizes things because he has the time
and wants to do it.  If I called Dave and said, "Dave, I'd really like to
make particular arrangements for such and such meeting."  I think Dave
would say "Go for it."

Dave is de facto organizer, but I don't think anyone thinks he has some
power derived from the membership.  Such power simply does not exist in
this organization.

> I think we need leadership that is directly accountable to the
> members.

Accountability is only an issue if there is an abuse of power.  Without
power, there is no abuse.

And how do you propose a group such as ours carry out this
"accountability"?  Do we start banning people from meetings or
posting?  Do we take away their beer privileges?

While there is no power to abuse or corrupt, there is also no power to
punish or intimidate.  Accountability is a meaningless term in a
non-hierarchical organization of people.

Nobody's giving paychecks.  Nobody pulls the strings.

> Again, the goals are not up to me. I am merely suggesting that there
> is no process in place for any sort of goals.

Yes, there is.  If I have a goal, I say, "Hey, who wants to meet this
goal?" and folks join or not.

Look at the resume database project for a recent example.

> If we had officers then yes we could recruit more officers.

Isn't that like raising funds to fund fundraising?

> And I said yes we have had good speakers. I was not in any way
> denigrating the speakers.

You're implying that, as an organization, we're not effective.  You want
to increase this ephemeral "effectiveness" but are also trying to say that
everyone's doing a good job.  So what's the deal?  Why impose power where
none is needed?

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Jun 10 18:42:01 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 18:42:01 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] What PLUG needs
In-Reply-To: <86vg8qd6tm.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206101828220.14177-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On 10 Jun 2002, Russell Senior wrote:

> I disagree that PLUG needs "official" officers.

I agree with Russell's disagreement. (Is "disagreement" a word? :-)

I don't see much benefit. It's one thing to reach consensus on
appointing people to take care of some tasks. If we've been lax in
that regard, then we all need to step up more -- but I seriously doubt 
that electing officers is going to help us function better.

Better, perhaps, would be an agreed-upon list of who's doing what so 
we know who, if anyone, has responsibilities in a given area. The 
current list as I know it is

* Meetings: Dave
* Clinics: Paul, Dan, Eric
* Mailing list: the fine folks at Micro Sharp
* Advanced topics: Zot

The only standing responsibility to which I can't attach a name is

* Web site

To my way of thinking, this arrangement is fine. The official-task 
folks have two responsibilities as far as I'm concerned:

1. Take care of the duties for which they volunteered.
2. Let us know when they can no longer do #1.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Mon Jun 10 17:52:05 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 17:52:05 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] The PLUG Web Page (was: What PLUG Needs)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206101727240.25512-100000@joan.burling.com>

Neil wrote (inter alia):

> Unfortunately, there is not much of a Web site to speak of right now.
> There were plans for build a custom back-end, etc., but those
> plans seem to be going nowhere right now. What we need is a core of
> practical developers/designers/content people/admin people to put something
> together. To get something good up there relatively efficiently.
>
> I am willing to do my part and write content but that is all I am
> interested in doing (actually, that will take quite a bit of time). I have
> written some already but we need a better site.
>
> Do we have a designer or two out there willing to put together a nice
> site? Someone to setup Zope or something like that? We need to just move
> forward on something in this area. Please join plug-web and state your
> interest in making something happen.

I guess you weren't at the last PLUG meeting, where I set out the future
plans for the Web Site, Neil. What will be done is as follows:

As Interim Web Page Development Leader, I will be updating parts of what's
currently there to fix state links & so forth. I will also be adding a
page to help announce the topic of every meeting, & will be building an
archive of links to prior meeting topics. My principal stumbling block at
this point (& why all of this happen for the last meeting) is that I'm
having some issues with ssh.

Dave Mandel has a brief history of PLUG that we need to add to the
Web page.

Currently, Wil Cooley has rebuilt the web site in PHP format. Writing
static PHP content is quite simple: I learned how to do it in less than
half an hour.

What we have is not the wonderful site people talked about creating six
months ago, but it exists & gets the job done.

NOW, if you don't like what's there, or you want to help in creating
content, my advice is very simple: Do it. Write the content, create a
new page template, rewrite the web site in Zope, roll-your-own Perl
scripts, or VisualBasic. But do the work & offer the content.

I can add the content if you send it to me. If you need an account, contact
either Karl Hegbloom or Wil Cooley. (Karl has told me that if a person
proves him or her a trustworthy & capable person, he has no qualms about
giving the root password to drizzle.)

What sunk the web page earlier this year, I believe, was the fact people
got into a cycle of talking about what to do, & never got around to
creating anything concrete. This is not unique to PLUG: Alan Cox noted
that this has happened in the past, & how he feels it should be fought --
see his article ``Cathedrals, Bazaars and the Town Council" on Slashdot,
http://slashdot.org/features/98/10/13/1423253.shtml

As Interim Web Page Development Leader, I give everyone permission to
contribute what they feel the web page needs. PLUG has a lot of capable
folks in the group, some of whom don't believe they are capable of
contributing. Let's get some new stuff up on the web site, & start asking
the PLUG membership for their feedback. Should the unimaginable happen,
& we have too much activity & people are getting in each others' way,
then we'll have a meeting & sort things out.

But let's stop saying we should do something, & simply DO IT. As my
high school wrestling coach used to say, even doing the wrong thing
is better than sitting around doing nothing.

(If you agree with this, don't send a follow-up to the list saying
something like ``M3 T00". Write content. And if you can't think of what
to do, I have some ideas. Ideas that a few folks threw out after last
Thursday's meeting included a wikiwiki page & a database for trading
computer books. If you think these are good ideas, get an account on
drizzle & start setting them up.)

Geoff

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon Jun 10 20:50:20 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 10 Jun 2002 20:50:20 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] What PLUG needs
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206101723530.2503-100000@localhost.localdomain>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206101723530.2503-100000@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <86heka1nk3.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Neil" == Neil Anuskiewicz <neil at pacifier.com> writes:

Russell> More effective _at what_?

Neil> That is not up to me to decide. That would be for the officers
Neil> and the members of PLUG.

But what would you _like_ them to be more effective at?  You must have
some sense of why you want these officers.  It isn't obvious to me
that PLUG isn't being "effective", so I don't really see the need for
change for the sake of change.  Show us why officers are necessary
and/or desirable.

Russell> I disagree that PLUG needs "official" officers.  David does a
Russell> fine job of coordinating things.  The danger of the kind of
Russell> bureaucracy you are suggesting is that someone gets into a
Russell> position of "authority" and then for whatever reason
Russell> (e.g. "burnout", "distractions", "malice", etc.)  becomes an
Russell> "obstruction".  No authority, no obstruction, people with the
Russell> energy just "do".

Neil> Yes, and David could stand for election and be elected. He could
Neil> then ask what the group wants to see happen and coordinate
Neil> making it happen. This is *not* in any way denigrating his
Neil> leadership.

Neil, maybe David doesn't _want_ to become the servant of the group.
Maybe he likes doing what he is doing, sees that it is effective and
contributes towards his goals and is satisfied with that.

Neil> I think we need leadership that is directly accountable to the
Neil> members.  

We _have_ leadership (or not) that is accountable.  Someone has an
idea and either people agree and help or they don't and don't.  I
think it works pretty well and pretty organically, with not a lot of
overhead.  Unless you can come up with some desireable goal that can't
be accomplished with the organic leadership we have now, then I don't
see why we should change.

Neil> As for my big speakers idea, yes, that could possibly be one of
Neil> the goals.  If we had officers then yes we could recruit more
Neil> officers.

Did you mean to say "speakers" there?  Do you have any evidence that
not having "officers" is preventing us from getting desirable
speakers?


--

                         extremely unusual.' ''

> I guess you weren't at the last PLUG meeting, where I set out the future
> plans for the Web Site, Neil. What will be done is as follows:
> 
> As Interim Web Page Development Leader, I will be updating parts of what's
> currently there to fix state links & so forth. I will also be adding a
> page to help announce the topic of every meeting, & will be building an
> archive of links to prior meeting topics. My principal stumbling block at
> this point (& why all of this happen for the last meeting) is that I'm
> having some issues with ssh.
> 
> Dave Mandel has a brief history of PLUG that we need to add to the
> Web page.
> 
> Currently, Wil Cooley has rebuilt the web site in PHP format. Writing
> static PHP content is quite simple: I learned how to do it in less than
> half an hour.
> 
> What we have is not the wonderful site people talked about creating six
> months ago, but it exists & gets the job done.
> 
> NOW, if you don't like what's there, or you want to help in creating
> content, my advice is very simple: Do it. Write the content, create a
> new page template, rewrite the web site in Zope, roll-your-own Perl
> scripts, or VisualBasic. But do the work & offer the content.
> 
> I can add the content if you send it to me. If you need an account, contact
> either Karl Hegbloom or Wil Cooley. (Karl has told me that if a person
> proves him or her a trustworthy & capable person, he has no qualms about
> giving the root password to drizzle.)
> 
> What sunk the web page earlier this year, I believe, was the fact people
> got into a cycle of talking about what to do, & never got around to
> creating anything concrete. This is not unique to PLUG: Alan Cox noted
> that this has happened in the past, & how he feels it should be fought --
> see his article ``Cathedrals, Bazaars and the Town Council" on Slashdot,
> http://slashdot.org/features/98/10/13/1423253.shtml
> 
> As Interim Web Page Development Leader, I give everyone permission to
> contribute what they feel the web page needs. PLUG has a lot of capable
> folks in the group, some of whom don't believe they are capable of
> contributing. Let's get some new stuff up on the web site, & start asking
> the PLUG membership for their feedback. Should the unimaginable happen,
> & we have too much activity & people are getting in each others' way,
> then we'll have a meeting & sort things out.
> 
> But let's stop saying we should do something, & simply DO IT. As my
> high school wrestling coach used to say, even doing the wrong thing
> is better than sitting around doing nothing.
> 
> (If you agree with this, don't send a follow-up to the list saying
> something like ``M3 T00". Write content. And if you can't think of what
> to do, I have some ideas. Ideas that a few folks threw out after last
> Thursday's meeting included a wikiwiki page & a database for trading
> computer books. If you think these are good ideas, get an account on
> drizzle & start setting them up.)
> 
> Geoff

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Mon Jun 10 23:56:05 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 23:56:05 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Advice on switches for home network
Message-ID: <1949927613.1023778555570.JavaMail.root@monkey>

Anthony:

I'm never one to get offended by "stupid" questions meant to clarify
things.  Your question was completely legitimate.

Yes, the linksys hubs in question were marketted as hubs, but behaved
strangely.  The uplink port echoed to every other port, but the non-uplink
ports only echoed unicast traffic to the uplink port.  Multicasts and
broadcasts went to all ports.  Strange, eh?

I wish I could remember the model of these.  They didn't all do it
either-- I suspect that they might have used some strange internal chipset
for one production run that was flawed.

This was pre-blue and black when they were white.  ;-)

I've found the NetGear equipment to be far more consistent.  (Consistency
is worth the extra 15% to me...)

  -- Steve

On Sun, 9 Jun 2002, Anthony Schlemmer aschlemm at attbi.com XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

> Here's a stupid question for you which I hope doesn't offend you...With 
> some or all of the traffic not being broadcast to all ports are you 
> sure that a hub was being used? The fundamental difference between a 
> hub and switch is that a switch routes packets directly between systems 
> and doesn't send packets to all ports unlike a hub. 
> 
> I'm not sure I've seen any of those little blue and black boxes from 
> Linksys which weren't either a switch or a router. I've not used one of 
> their DSL/Cable routers and so I don't know if they are a switch or a 
> hub.
> 
> Tony
> 
> On Saturday 08 June 2002 23:59 pm, Steve Bonds wrote:
> > For unmanaged switches/hubs the two big low-cost brands are Linksys
> > and NetGear.  I've used both quite a bit and have been very happy
> > with NetGear (formerly Bay Networks).
> >
> > I have seen a number of strange failures on the Linksys (hubs that
> > weren't really hubs-- not all traffic was echoed to all ports,
> > intermittent failures, poor 100BaseT-to-10BaseT buffering, etc.)  The
> > NetGear has been much more consistent for some fairly heavy use.
> >
> > I have heard good things on the Linksys from people I trust, so my
> > experiences might be somewhat unusual.
> >
> > A good place to get and share opinions on hardware like this is
> > http://www.epinions.com.
> >
> >   -- Steve Bonds
> >
> > On Sat, 8 Jun 2002, Stuart Mathews smathews at pcez.com wrote:
> > > I'm hoping to avoid unnecessary pitfalls of setting up a small
> > > network.
> > >
> > > I have a DSL connection with a 2 Linux PCs, and will soon add a
> > > Thinkpad and a printer. I'll need some kind of switch to link
> > > everything up. Any ideas as to what they cost, what features I
> > > need to keep an eye out for, as well as advices on who makes good
> > > (bad!) switches? I'm guessing I'll probably see the best
> > > selection at Fry's??

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Mon Jun 10 22:42:47 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 22:42:47 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] What PLUG needs
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206101828220.14177-100000@billings.heinlein.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206102229020.25512-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Mon, 10 Jun 2002, Paul Heinlein wrote:

> On 10 Jun 2002, Russell Senior wrote:
>
> > I disagree that PLUG needs "official" officers.
>
> I agree with Russell's disagreement. (Is "disagreement" a word? :-)
>
> I don't see much benefit. It's one thing to reach consensus on
> appointing people to take care of some tasks. If we've been lax in
> that regard, then we all need to step up more -- but I seriously doubt
> that electing officers is going to help us function better.
>
> Better, perhaps, would be an agreed-upon list of who's doing what so
> we know who, if anyone, has responsibilities in a given area. The
> current list as I know it is
>
> * Meetings: Dave
> * Clinics: Paul, Dan, Eric
> * Mailing list: the fine folks at Micro Sharp
> * Advanced topics: Zot
>
> The only standing responsibility to which I can't attach a name is
>
> * Web site
>
> To my way of thinking, this arrangement is fine. The official-task
> folks have two responsibilities as far as I'm concerned:
>
> 1. Take care of the duties for which they volunteered.
> 2. Let us know when they can no longer do #1.
>
There is one good point to adopting a more formal structure: Dave Mandel
has mentioned that there are several benefits if PLUG incorporated as
a non-profit organization. We could collect dues, donations, & grants to
bring in speakers from outside the Portland area, buy needed equipment
(e.g., it would be nice to know we had a projector for each meeting),
be able to rent space for functions (PSU may not always want grant space
to our unofficial organization), sponsor conferences or attendence at
conferences, & perhaps pass on grants or scholarships to further interest
in Linux & UNIX. Another benefit is that as a formal organization we could
negotiate group discounts or benefits for all members (e.g. some of us
are self-employed & may benefit from a group medical plan). A third
benefit would allow PLUG to affiliate or enter into mutually beneficial
agreements with other professional organizations like the IEEE, the ACM,
or even the Software Association of Oregon.

None of these, admittedly, are sufficient reasons to incorporate tomorrow
or even this year, but I suspect there are some benefits here that all
of us could appreciate on one level or another, & thus are worth talking
about -- or at least thinking about. I invite everyone to at least think
about this.

Geoff




From geoff at agora.rdrop.com  Mon Jun 10 23:05:46 2002
From: geoff at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Mon, 10 Jun 2002 23:05:46 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] The PLUG Web Page (was: What PLUG Needs)
In-Reply-To: <B92AC5CA.31AA%verso@mac.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206102243030.25512-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Mon, 10 Jun 2002, Kelly Guimont wrote:

> I would be willing to generate content (I'm in the unemployed SIG, I gots
> the time, yo) but I don't know what you need. If you give me a couple of
> pointers I'd be happy to help. It'd keep my brain even further from atropy
> and that's always good. (:
>
Some ideas:

1. Augment the content that is already there --
   * Add to the FAQ
   * Add to the collection of Linux resources
   * Add to the collection of Open Source in the NW links

2. New content --
   * Periodically people ask questions about the best computer stores
     in town, specialty electronics stores, used computer stores, &
     computer repair shops. We could use a list of these that is kept
     up to date.
   * An idea I had -- but have not been able to develop -- is a list of
     resources for the Linux enthusiast who has installed Linux
     successfully on her/his system, has some skill with the command
     line & a text editor, but now wonders ``What's next?" This
     could be a collection of URLs, books or periodicals that help plumb
     the mysteries of X, printing under Linux, databases, & so on.
     Or it could be a Howto.

3. Magazine-like content --
   * Howtos, descriptions of how you started as an innocent with a given
     computer application & learned how to master it.
   * Articles on Linux in the NW. One fact about Linux, *BSD & the other
     Unices is that we have an underappreciated concentration of talent
     here in Portland: we need to publicize this talent, & record its
     history here. Otherwise, people will mistakenly believe that all
     important computer developments take place in Silicon Valley, the
     North Carolina research triangle, the Boston/New York/Washington DC
     sprawl -- & nowhere else.

I know this last catagory sounds an awful like what Computer Bits,
Linux Gazette, & the other publications might publish to a larger audience.
My point for suggesting these topics is to encourage everyone to cast our
nets wide & see what we catch, & learn which items we have caught are
worth keeping. And if a disappointed author leaves our humble website to
contribute for one of these other venues, I feel we have still done our job
by creating one more Linux-savvy journalist. And we all know we can never
have too many of these.

Lastly, look over the last 6 to 12 months of the PLUG mailing list.
I feel that there are many ideas there. If nothing else, a weekly digest
or review like the ones done for the Linux Kernel mailing list would be
quite useful -- & allow people to enjoy the wheat without dealing with
either the chaff or the flamewars of the PLUG list.

Geoff





From neil at pacifier.com  Tue Jun 11 04:03:45 2002
From: neil at pacifier.com (Neil Anuskiewicz)
Date: Tue, 11 Jun 2002 04:03:45 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] What PLUG needs
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206102229020.25512-100000@joan.burling.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0206110130380.12918-100000@shell.pacifier.com>

On Mon, 10 Jun 2002, Geoff Burling wrote:

> None of these, admittedly, are sufficient reasons to incorporate tomorrow
> or even this year, but I suspect there are some benefits here that all
> of us could appreciate on one level or another, & thus are worth talking
> about -- or at least thinking about. I invite everyone to at least think
> about this.

Well, since one person has expressed a bit of interest in this idea, I am
going to jump back in. Part of the process of having formal officers and
so on would be to incorporate as a non-profit. I know from a few private
conversations that there are others who are very interested in this as
well.

We would have a budget so we can pay the cost of a big name speaker or
two. When I researched speakers, I found that many of them do cost some
money if they are from out of town. Again, this is in *not* suggesting
that we don't have good speakers now because clearly we do get
outstanding speakers now, I am just suggesting it might be interesting to
broaden the pool a bit.

With a budget we could do other things as well, though we would of course
be very conservative in how we spent the money. My first instinct is to
suggest that the yearly dues would be low: something like $15 per year.
And I am guessing that we would get some grants from companies and
organizations for special purposes -- companies and foundations might
contribute to a speaker's fund or a K-12 project fund (very important) or
possibly a technology budget to buy things like a projector.

A partial officer list might look something like this:

President - run meetings, arrange speakers, coordinate PLUG
Vice-president - assist President and stand-in in President's absense.
Secretary - meeting minutes, etc
PLUG for Education Coordinator - Coordinate the various K-12 projects.
Fundraiser and Grant Coordinator - Solicit donations and write and submit
grant proposals to companies and foundations.
Webmaster - Web site coordinator.
Events Coordinator - Organizes clinics, etc.
Outreach Coordinator - Public relations about PLUG to the press.

These people would largely have coordination roles and several of these
roles, as has been pointed out, have de facto occupants. For example,
David Mandel now de facto holds the President's position; Eric Harrison
I believe is now de facto PLUG for Education Coordinator position.

In some cases it may be obvious who should hold a given position but we
should still hold elections and validate these assumptions through a
reasonable electoral process.

Just to  be clear, this is not about power trips for the officers. They
would be coordinators. This would in no way hinder other's freedom.

So, we would have officers, a budget, and a more activist stance in the
community and play a stronger role in education, private industry, and
government in Oregon.

We can continue as we are and have the status quo, which is pretty
good, or we can incorporate, have officers, and really make some progress.
Maybe PLUG could even become the model of what a LUG can achieve in a city
and state. Maybe we could be the catalyst that is needed to really move
Linux forward the various sectors.

I have heard that we are a remarkably large and active group -- much
larger, for example, than the Seattle LUG. Portland has a strong and
committed LUG community. Let's do something exciting with it.


-- 
Neil Anuskiewicz

From mark at planetwills.com  Tue Jun 11 08:27:13 2002
From: mark at planetwills.com (Mark Wills)
Date: Tue, 11 Jun 2002 08:27:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] What PLUG needs
In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0206110130380.12918-100000@shell.pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <CAENLEIHEHPLANCLMFKMMEGKCIAA.mark@planetwills.com>

Neil Anuskiewicz said:

> Well, since one person has expressed a bit of interest in this idea, I am
> going to jump back in. Part of the process of having formal officers and
> so on would be to incorporate as a non-profit. I know from a few private
> conversations that there are others who are very interested in this as
> well.

Speaking as the president of a non-profit trying to re-establish 501c3
status, there are certain aspects of non-profits you should be aware of.
(see more details at http://www.filinginoregon.com/bic/nonprofit.htm)

There are two types of non-profits that apply here:

1. Mutual benefit.
2. Public benefit. (IRS code 501c3)

If you want donors to give tax deductible grants to the organization , you
need 501c3 status.
In order to get 501c3 status, you have to have very explicit by-laws that
include:
You can't force people to join, in order to benefit from the organization,
which means collecting dues is a voluntary thing.

What I'm getting at, is unless you anticipate significant grants, the
overhead isn't worth all the effort.

Mark

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Tue Jun 11 09:42:33 2002
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Tue, 11 Jun 2002 09:42:33 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ps2pdf for physically large pages
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206101530350.29115-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>; from jeme@brelin.net on Mon, Jun 10, 2002 at 03:32:05PM -0700
References: <20020610151442.G12138@dalsemi.com> <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206101530350.29115-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20020611094232.A14062@dalsemi.com>

On Mon, Jun 10, 2002 at 03:32:05PM -0700, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> I've created PDFs of up to 36x36 inches.
> 
> It would help if you explained your process for creating PDFs.

Gotcha.

Print Postscript file from multi-million dollar CAD software.

Examine postscript with ghostview and confirm that it's 11x17

Read ps2pdf manpage, ps2pdf13 manpage, ps2pdfwr manpage, none of
which have any really useful information about options to those
programs.

Look at ghostscript.com, ditto about the information.

ps2pdf file.{ps,pdf}

acroread file.pdf

PDF file is cropped to 8.5x11.


On Mon, Jun 10, 2002 at 03:32:05PM -0700, Shahms King wrote:

> it looks like you should be able to pass
> -sPAPERSIZE=11x17 to ps2pdf and have it work.

It does.  Although I have to admit that I'm confused why the switch
is needed.  The page size is in the postscript file.  Maybe I should
submit a bug/feature report.

Colin

From derek at infotects.com  Tue Jun 11 12:51:25 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 11 Jun 2002 12:51:25 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] - umount samba share as non-root
Message-ID: <1023825085.26090.60.camel@dereklinux>

Hi all,

I have set up things so that as a normal user I can mount samba shares. 
But when I'm done with the share, and would like to mount something else
on that mount point, I find I can't umount the share as a normal user (I
get an error saying I need to be root), I had to su to root to get the
job done.  The odd thing is, that I can mount and umount the floppy as a
normal user, and the message "You can't do that, you need to be root"
doesn't get displayed.

Does anyone know how to do this, or what group I need to be included in?

Thanks,

Derek Loree




From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Tue Jun 11 13:46:28 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 11 Jun 2002 13:46:28 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] - umount samba share as non-root
In-Reply-To: <1023825085.26090.60.camel@dereklinux>
References: <1023825085.26090.60.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <1023828388.6822.70.camel@pookie>

Derek;

On Tue, 2002-06-11 at 12:51, Derek Loree wrote:
> Hi all,
> 

Hi.

[snip]

> I find I can't umount the share as a normal user (I
> get an error saying I need to be root), I had to su to root to get the
> job done.  The odd thing is, that I can mount and umount the floppy as a
> normal user, and the message "You can't do that, you need to be root"
> doesn't get displayed.

This is because of your floppy entry in /etc/fstab. Check out the line
in /etc/fstab that talks about /dev/fd0. Pay special attention to the
options in the last column (users, noauto, e.t.c). You will likely be
able to simply copy the floppy line and modify it to your needs for the
Samba share. Change /dev/f0, for example to
/dev/your_drive_partition_to_mount and the mount destination directory,
for example.

Further information, from the `mount' man page...


       ``Only  the  user that mounted a filesystem can unmount it
again....If  any  user should  be able to unmount, then use users
instead of user in the fstab line.  The owner option  is  similar  to 
the user  option,  with  the restriction that the user must be the owner
of the special file. This may be useful e.g. for /dev/fd  if a login
script makes the console user owner of this device.''
> 
> Does anyone know how to do this, or what group I need to be included in?

P'sha. Of course we do :)

> 
> Thanks,

You bet.

> 
> Derek Loree
> 


-Cooper




From charles.schmidt at timberline.com  Tue Jun 11 13:48:17 2002
From: charles.schmidt at timberline.com (Charles Schmidt)
Date: Tue, 11 Jun 2002 13:48:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] - umount samba share as non-root
Message-ID: <BADD847784EB7546A1B1CC69190990C60A686DEC@daspost.timberline.com>

You might try setting the suid permission on smbmnt? and smbumount.


Charles

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Tue Jun 11 15:37:06 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 11 Jun 2002 15:37:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] - umount samba share as non-root
In-Reply-To: <1023834002.21349.98.camel@dereklinux>
References: <1023825085.26090.60.camel@dereklinux> 
	<1023828388.6822.70.camel@pookie>  <1023834002.21349.98.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <1023835026.6822.158.camel@pookie>

Derek;

I'm working on a project right now, but here's a few thoughts that come
to mind:

1) You can pass options to the mount command, like so:

   mount -o users -o noauto /dev/device_mounting_from
/destination_directory

2) You can put this is a script and run it from the command line.

3) Red Hat used to have a graphical mount tool. I assume other
distributions do, too. Red Hat aficionados can help you here if you have
Red Hat. Some restrictions may apply, see your dealer for details.

You may want to search for ``mount'' or ``mount tool'' on
www.freshmeat.net.

4) We're modest, too.

I will follow up with this if you don't get satisfactory results.


-Cooper

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Jun 11 16:09:46 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue, 11 Jun 2002 16:09:46 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] - umount samba share as non-root
In-Reply-To: <1023834002.21349.98.camel@dereklinux>
References: <1023828388.6822.70.camel@pookie>
 <1023825085.26090.60.camel@dereklinux>
 <1023828388.6822.70.camel@pookie>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020611160724.00b8fcc8@localhost>

You don't need to have a separate mount point for each samba share, unless 
you want to mount them all at once.

if you use the mount command like this:

mount -t smbfs -o username=user,password=pass /machine/share /dir/to/mount/on

At 03:20 PM 6/11/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>Ugg, I really don't want a separate mount point for every samba share I
>mount.

Russ Johnson
http://www.dimstar.net


In order to ask a question, you must already know 95% of the answer

> to mind:

> /destination_directory

smbmount //winbox/"My Documents" /home/derek/mnt -o username=derek -o

which mounted, but won't umount unless I'm root.  If I swap the order of
the options, the mount will fail.  If I place the -o user right after
the smbmount, I get an incorrect usage error; which does not list "user"
as a valid option.

I get the "you must be root" error.

> 
> 3) Red Hat used to have a graphical mount tool. I assume other
> distributions do, too. Red Hat aficionados can help you here if you have
> Red Hat. Some restrictions may apply, see your dealer for details.
I use debian unstable, and can't get any of the GUI tools to work, my
thinking is that if I can get it to work from command line, I have a
much better shot at getting the GUI to work (not that I need to, once
the command line is working).
> 
> You may want to search for ``mount'' or ``mount tool'' on
> www.freshmeat.net.

That turned out to be a great idea!  I didn't find a program, but I did
find a link to a How-To that I hadn't seen before, and it mentioned the
command smbumount (now that I see it, duh).  So:

smbumount /home/derek/mnt 

did the trick!!

Life with SMB is looking much less complicated now.

Thanks

Derek
