From jeff at jhenshaw.com  Tue Jun 11 12:03:02 2002
From: jeff at jhenshaw.com (J Henshaw)
Date: Tue, 11 Jun 2002 19:03:02 -0000
Subject: [PLUG] Sounds good to me ;)
Message-ID: <00c901c2117a$9c257ce0$0400a8c0@oem2k>

"There will be a time," predicts Moby, "when you will be able to use a
laptop to create a song that sounds as if it were recorded by a band in a
studio, and no one will be able to tell the difference. In the next few
years, I wouldn't be surprised if they invent singing programs. You will
type in a phrase and tell the program to have it sung by a Caucasian woman,
eighteen years old, with whatever inflection you choose. Whoever invents
that will make a lot of money."




From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Jun 11 19:46:26 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue, 11 Jun 2002 19:46:26 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Sounds good to me ;)
In-Reply-To: <00c901c2117a$9c257ce0$0400a8c0@oem2k>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206111934220.9500-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 11 Jun 2002, J Henshaw wrote:
> "There will be a time," predicts Moby, "when you will be able to use a
> laptop to create a song that sounds as if it were recorded by a band
> in a studio, and no one will be able to tell the difference. In the
> next few years, I wouldn't be surprised if they invent singing
> programs. You will type in a phrase and tell the program to have it
> sung by a Caucasian woman, eighteen years old, with whatever
> inflection you choose.

I'm with you until right here.  He's probably right and that's very cool.

> Whoever invents that will make a lot of money."

Now, if he thinks that a well-paid programmer makes "a lot of money", then
I'd say he's right.  But if by "a lot of money" he means "more than is
usually commensurate for his profession", I'd say he's dead wrong.

I see one of two likely scenarios at this critical stage in human
social development:

1.  The "industry" that privatizes thoughts and ideas will be crippled or
disabled by the time such a thing is created.  The person who initially
creates this software (assuming it can be implemented wholly in software)
will have no more ability to use this success to create personal wealth
than dozens of other highly skilled programmers.  The software will be
(rightly) unredeemable in trade, but his originality and skill (assuming
the creation wasn't an admitted fluke) will still be tradeable and,
therefore, economically valuable.

2.  The existing trend of great economic power translating to great
political and legal power will continue and very little information will
be considered "public".  The person who initially creates said software
(again with the assumption that it's just software) will be a student
working under a corporate grant or a contractually-bound employee of a
private corporation and the fruits of his labor will belong to the
corporate entity and not to himself.  The corporate owners will take this
"property" and use it to accrue heaping piles of cash... but the person
who created it will be no more rewarded than any other skilled programmer.

Anyway, those are the two most likely scenarios in my book.

Cassandra speaks.

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Jun 11 22:07:59 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue, 11 Jun 2002 22:07:59 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Sendmail Antivirus
Message-ID: <1272451459.1023858468827.JavaMail.root@monkey>

This might also be helpful:

http://www.sng.ecs.soton.ac.uk/mailscanner/

It's free (odd license, tho) and links in with a number of UNIX/linux
scanners (like F-Prot, which I've previously plugged here...)

I haven't used it, but it looked promising for your purpose.  I generally
prefer draconian enforcement of resident scanner installation rather than
relying on E-mail filters which are slow and do little but alert you to an
infestation that got in via other means.

  -- Steve

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Jun 11 22:13:52 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue, 11 Jun 2002 22:13:52 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] in the mean time
Message-ID: <1641582979.1023858821743.JavaMail.root@monkey>

On 9 Jun 2002, Russell Senior seniorr at aracnet.com XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

> Munging introduces entropy into the data which makes future data
> archeology (such as to create a future archive) more difficult.  As
> someone who does data archeology for a living, it is something that I
> find immensely annoying.
> 
> me> b) it interferes unacceptably with the ability to mail people
> me> privately.
> 
> Russ> I don't see how. The senders address IS in the mail that you
> Russ> receive from the list. It's just not available from the web
> Russ> page, which I personally consider to be a good thing.
> 
> Suppose you are researching something posted a year ago.  If you want
> to ask the person privately what they meant or how things turned out
> or whatever, you can't, because you don't readily have a way to do
> that.  You'd have to post to the mailing list (which they might not
> still even be subscribed to) to try to reach them, which is wasteful.
> 
> Basically, it imposes an unnecessary cost of complexity and
> obstruction for an illusory benefit.

I can only imagine how horribly things like my sneakemail address mess up
data archeology.  Unfortunately, the free ranging spammers have forced me
to take such measures to protect my "real" E-mail address.

I've been at this same address for many years.  Given how much spam I get
just from people accidently or ignorantly posting my private E-mail in
messages or forwarded E-mails to Usenet, I shudder to think how bad it
would be if I didn't guard it so closely.

Fortunately for the archeologists, I've been signing my messages the same
way for years.  ;->

  -- Steve Bonds






From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Jun 11 22:20:14 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue, 11 Jun 2002 22:20:14 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Multiple Boxes
Message-ID: <1942147459.1023859203543.JavaMail.root@monkey>

Richard:

NIS (aka yp) is the de facto standard for such things in the UNIX
environment.  If you want something a bit harder to implement but with
more potential for compatibility then something like an LDAP server might
be more appropriate.  (This also makes it simpler to have NT/UNIX/Other
with the same username and passwords and a single point for updates.)

NIS can have issues on widely distributed networks, whereas LDAP usually
doesn't.  Just don't use LDAP for a general-purpose database.  Its feeble
backup and recovery methods will make that a disaster waiting to happen.

  -- Steve Bonds

On Mon, 10 Jun 2002, Richard Langis Jr. richard.langis at sun.com XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

> This is a question for those of you with multiple linux machines on the 
> same network.
> 
> What method do you use to keep users/groups/logins/passwords/everything

> not sure if it's the right solution.  I'll have a firewall, web/email 
> server, and 2 additional machines for futzing around with soon, and I'd 
> like to keep my environment relatively sane between them all.
> 
> Any ideas?
> 
> --

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Jun 11 22:22:35 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue, 11 Jun 2002 22:22:35 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Everything you wanted to know about Linux security and
 aren't afraid to ask (was: Linux /Windows virus appears)
Message-ID: <1910624643.1023859345387.JavaMail.root@monkey>

This is when that NetApp with the automatic 5-minute-old snapshots of your
home directory really pays for itself.

It's just a matter of time before a commonly-used linux filesystem
supports something like that.  (If there's one that does already, please
let me know!)

  -- Steve Bonds

On Mon, 10 Jun 2002, Anthony Schlemmer aschlemm at attbi.com XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

> Trust me...if you blow away your home directory and potentially lose a 
> months worth of work and have to fret about telling your manager why 
> the schedule may slide a whole month makes you that diligent. Again the 
> only thing that saved my butt was our excellent SA that setup our 
> server to do nightly backups of our home directories and Clearcase 
> views.
> 
> Tony
> 
> On Monday 10 June 2002 04:07 am, Felix Lee wrote:
> > Anthony Schlemmer <aschlemm at attbi.com>:
> > > A check of "alias rm" tells me if "rm" is aliased or not. All I can
> > > say is a mistake like this really sticks with me and I plan on
> > > never repeating it. I am not trained into thinking that "rm" is
> > > always aliased to "rm -i". Before doing any large directory
> > > cleanups I check what "rm" I am using and I make sure I specify the
> > > directory names and don't use any wildcard characters.
> >
> > Are you always that diligent with everything?  I know I'm
> > not.  Since you did slip up once before, it seems plausible
> > you may slip up again.  And it sounds to me like all the
> > steps you're going through is a lot more work than just
> > typing "rm -i" all the time.  I have periodic backups for
> > the big mistakes, and I type "rm -i" when I'm feeling unsure
> > of my competence.
> >
> > Really, I'm arguing this because it annoys me to no end when
> > I sit down in front of someone else's shell and type "rm"
> > and get "rm -i" instead.  "unalias rm" is often the second
> > or third command I type.
> >
> > And there's no rm option that will undo the -i option.
> > "rm -i -f" is not the same as just "rm".
> 
> -- 
> Anthony Schlemmer
> aschlemm at attbi.com
> 
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
> 





From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Jun 11 22:28:52 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue, 11 Jun 2002 22:28:52 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Commands you don't want to try
Message-ID: <174543235.1023859720652.JavaMail.root@monkey>

All the more reason to always use GNU tar.  ;->

Then you know that if some idiot tarred up /dev/kmem inside the file
you just downloaded from www.hosemysystem.com, your lack of wisdom in
untarring it as root won't be immediately fatal.

I usually install it and then link it in as "gtar" so that the real system
tar is available for broken scripts that require the original.

  -- Steve Bonds


On Mon, 10 Jun 2002, Mark Bynum mark at mjbynum.org XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

> Two guesses? They're both good but not the right answer. Here it is:
> 
> The original was:
> 
> tar cf - / | (cd /disk2; tar xvpf - )
> 
> What would happen here is that tar is extracting absolute pathnames,
> in effect overwriting every file on the system. When it gets to the 
> system files, ones that you need while the system is running, 
> it overwrites them. A crash in the making.
> 
> The correct command would be:
> 
> cd /
> tar cf - . | (cd /disk2; tar xvpf -)
> 
> But even that may put you in a circular loop because disk2 is mounted.
> It'd probably be best to specify the files specifically instead of everything.
> Something like:
> 
> cd /
> tar cf - var etc home | (cd /disk2; tar xvpf -)
> 
> would be better.
> 
> Mark
> 
> On Sun, Jun 09, 2002 at 09:48:29PM -0700, Sean Whitney wrote:
> > I know that I would try
> > 
> > tar cf - /| ( cd /disk2 && tar xvpf -)
> > 
> > Which should prevent you from trying to overwrite your files if you 
> > fat-finger the directory.  What else am I missing?
> > 
> > 
> > Sean
> > 
> 
> On Sun, Jun 09, 2002 at 10:03:51PM -0700, Sean Lewis wrote:
> > Looks to me like it would put you into a loop of tarring the same file
> > (the tar itself) over and over again.
> 
> > On Sunday 09 June 2002 19:28, you hammered at the keyboard:
> > > Since we're on the discussion of 'rm -rf'. I'll add my command that you
> > > don't want to try:
> > >
> > >
> > > Anyone guess what this does incorrectly?
> > >
> > >
> > > Mark
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

From CurtisE at CurtisE.net  Wed Jun 12 01:17:08 2002
From: CurtisE at CurtisE.net (CurtisE)
Date: Wed, 12 Jun 2002 01:17:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Article Proofread
In-Reply-To: <1023849982.7997.15.camel@pookie>
Message-ID: <GJELJBAKILGBFNJHBMKGMEKBCEAA.CurtisE@CurtisE.net>

Nice job Cooper.  Good information.  Being fairly new to Linux, I learned a
few things.

Here are a few things I caught.  I didn't really check for spelling,
grammatical or technical accuracy errors as I figured others would be better
suited.

I hope you don't take offence at my suggestions.  I tend to be fairly anal
and critical when proof reading.  There were a few things that I thought
were not explained as clearly as they could have been and some, what I would
call, "scattery" paragraphs.   Being sort of a stylistic thing, I didn't
point those out but I can if you want me to.

Ok, here goes:

-----------------------------------------------------------------

The first 2 figures were not really tied in very well.  No references to
them, or descriptions, etc.  As a reader, I found myself wondering why they
were there and what I was supposed to glean from them.  Particularly the one
with the VPN links.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

In Section - 4.1.2 NFS
...NFS provides transparent access to remote servers on the network; NFS
shares look to the user the same as a local directory.

Consider revising this sentence to something like:  To the user, NFS shares
look the same as a local directory.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

In Section - 4.2.2 Advanced E?mail Services
Advanced E?mail communications include online scheduling, group distribution
lists, and online scheduling.

Online scheduling appears twice.  FYI, I don't know Exim, but Sendmail also
supports group distribution nicely.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

In section - 4.3 Web Server
This is in contrast to Microsoft IIE?s 22 per cent.

That should be Microsoft IIS.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

In Section - 4.4 Print Server
Linux and Unix in general make excellent print servers; often handling
correctly
large print jobs (such as Power Point Presentations) to printers with
limited
memory. The Linux printing system is robust and performs well even with
several users connected to the system.

I'm not sure who your target audience is, but if you're trying to sell them
on Linux, I would really consider reworking this whole paragraph.  It's very
weak.  "often handling correctly large print jobs"...  What does it do with
them the rest of the time?  How does it compare to a NT or Novel based print
server?  Does it handle large print jobs going to printers with less memory
better than some other print server?  "...performs well even with several
users connected to the system."  I would hope a print server would perform
well with more that a few users connected.  Isn't that what print servers
are supposed to do?

-----------------------------------------------------------------

In Section - 4.4.1 CUPS
Finally, CUPS is backwards comparable and supports both the BSD and
System V style print commands.

I think you mean CUPS is backward compatible...

-----------------------------------------------------------------

In Section - 4.5.1 Oracle
Oracle has included support for their database line since Oracle 8i in July
1998.

I'm pretty sure Oracle supported their database line long before 8i.  Do you
mean they included Linux support...?

-----------------------------------------------------------------

In Section - 5 Linux On The Desktop
Figure 5.3.3 is significant not only because it illustrates
Linux?s desktop functionality, but also because the system was actually
running
on a different system than the one from which screen image was captured.

The figure I think you are referring to (on page 17 in the PDF) is labeled
"figure 3"
not figure 5.3.3.  You might consider comparing the X11 architecture picture
you paint with Citrix or MS Terminal Server for the benefit of those more
familiar with that technology.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

In Section - 5.1.2 OpenOffice
There are some tools absent from OpenOffice that you will find in
StarOffice.
One of these is lack of support for databases.

I would remove "lack of" from the last sentence.  If one interprets these
two sentences literally, it would mean that StarOffice lacks database
support.  I think you actually meant the opposite.  It's sort of a double
negative thing.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

Also in Section - 5.1.2 OpenOffice
See Figure 5.3.3 for and example of what OpenOffice looks like on the
desktop.

Is this the same figure referenced above?  If so, change to figure 3 or
change the label of the figure to 5.3.3.  The former would be more
appropriate as there is no figure 5.3.2 and so on.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

In Section - 5.2.1 Mozilla
See Figure 5.3.3 for an image of the Mozilla browser on the desktop.

Same "figure 3" deal here.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

In Section - 5.2.2 Ximian Evolution
Ximian Evolution can function as a Microsoft 2000 client
with the purchase of the optional add?in, Ximian Connector. See Figure 5.3.3
for an image of Ximian Evolution?s summary screen on the Linux desktop.

What is a Microsoft 2000 client?  Do you mean a Microsoft Exchange 2000
client?
Also, same "figure 3" deal here.

-----------------------------------------------------------------



>Would you proofread this please? Any feedback is greatly appreciated.

>-Cooper

From sandy at herring.org  Wed Jun 12 06:05:43 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Wed, 12 Jun 2002 06:05:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Everything you wanted to know about Linux security and aren't afraid to ask (was: Linux /Windows virus appears)
In-Reply-To: <1910624643.1023859345387.JavaMail.root@monkey>; from 1s7k8uhcd001@sneakemail.com on Tue, Jun 11, 2002 at 10:22:35PM -0700
References: <1910624643.1023859345387.JavaMail.root@monkey>
Message-ID: <20020612060543.A27731@kippered.herring.org>

On Tue, 11 Jun 2002, Steve Bonds wrote: 
> This is when that NetApp with the automatic 5-minute-old snapshots of your
> home directory really pays for itself.

That saved my butt once on Teleport's Solaris shell machine.

[...]
> On Mon, 10 Jun 2002, Anthony Schlemmer aschlemm at attbi.com XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:
> 
> > Trust me...if you blow away your home directory and potentially lose a 
> > months worth of work and have to fret about telling your manager why 
> > the schedule may slide a whole month makes you that diligent. Again the 
> > only thing that saved my butt was our excellent SA that setup our 
> > server to do nightly backups of our home directories and Clearcase 
> > views.
> > 
> > Tony
[...]

I now protect directories I never want to `rm -f *' by accident with this
simple trick...

    cd /dir/you/care/about
    touch '-i'

When the wild card is expanded, it treats the file `-i' as a switch :) No
more accidental `rm -f globfor *'.

Sandy

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Jun 12 06:17:30 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 12 Jun 2002 06:17:30 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Everything you wanted to know about Linux security and
 aren't afraid to ask (was: Linux /Windows virus appears)
In-Reply-To: <1910624643.1023859345387.JavaMail.root@monkey>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206120609500.25132-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 11 Jun 2002, Steve Bonds wrote:

> This is when that NetApp with the automatic 5-minute-old snapshots
> of your home directory really pays for itself.

NetApps rock the house. They're worth every of the several dollars you 
spend on them.

> It's just a matter of time before a commonly-used linux filesystem
> supports something like that.  (If there's one that does already,
> please let me know!)

The Logical Volume Manager for Linux (LVM) reportedly has snapshot
capabilities. See part 7 of the LVM HOWTO, "Making snapshots for
consistent backups":

  http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/LVM-HOWTO-7.html

There used to be a project called SnapFS. The author tried to emulate 
NetApp functionality in a free fs, but it looks as if the effort has 
died completely.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

Steve Bonds wrote:

> Richard:
> 
> NIS (aka yp) is the de facto standard for such things in the UNIX
> environment.  If you want something a bit harder to implement but with
> more potential for compatibility then something like an LDAP server might
> be more appropriate.  (This also makes it simpler to have NT/UNIX/Other
> with the same username and passwords and a single point for updates.)
> 
> NIS can have issues on widely distributed networks, whereas LDAP usually
> doesn't.  Just don't use LDAP for a general-purpose database.  Its feeble
> backup and recovery methods will make that a disaster waiting to happen.
> 
>   -- Steve Bonds

authentication
routing to the Internet

Subject: [PLUG] problems logging in with wu-ftp, real user
Message-ID: <20020612175309.94046.qmail@iname.com>

I'm posting this from an un-subscribed address, since we're having mail problems...

I've been working on this for a solid day, now, and I've got it to here.

Here's a clip from my log:

Jun 12 10:11:24 www xinetd[438]: START: ftp pid=3632 from=63.230.184.132
Jun 12 10:11:25 www ftpd[3632]: USER thunderbird
Jun 12 10:11:25 www ftpd[3632]: PASS password
Jun 12 10:11:25 www ftpd[3632]: PAM unable to resolve symbol: pam_sm_open_session
Jun 12 10:11:25 www ftpd[3632]: PAM unable to resolve symbol: pam_sm_close_session
Jun 12 10:11:27 www ftpd[3632]: failed login from dsl-184-132.ipns.com [63.230.184.132]
Jun 12 10:11:27 www ftpd[3632]: FTP session closed
Jun 12 10:11:27 www xinetd[438]: EXIT: ftp pid=3632 duration=3(sec)

Any help appreciated, I can modify PAM with my webmin from here.

Mike

From announce at Xpostit.com  Wed Jun 12 12:28:26 2002
From: announce at Xpostit.com (XPostIt.com)
Date: Wed, 12 Jun 2002 12:28:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Hi Candidate !  Our Resume Distribution Program adv.
Message-ID: <MDBrhPvFPOwsMJu4ayc00008382@toon.fws.net>

Dear Candidate,

Your email address was forwarded to us by a member of our network.  If you are 
still looking for a better job opportunity, then please read this email.  You 
have NOT been placed on a mailing list and you will not hear from us again.  
If you don't want this email, simply ignore it and accept our apologies.

I'm contacting you because your profile fits what many of our recruiters, from 
our association of over 10,587 recruiters, want to see.  Because of your background, 
we can help you in your job search, as we have helped many others in your field 
before.

Does the following describe your situation?
* You posted a resume on the Internet but haven't received enough good leads.
* You would like to uncover the hidden job market and access the best local or 
national jobs.
* You want to find more good recruiters that are targeted to your profession 
and industry.
* You have exhausted your networking channels and need a larger and newer network.
* You are concerned about confidentiality and protecting your identity.

If so, we can help.  XpostIt.com is a small, tightly-focused resource for proactive 
job seekers.  We have the largest database of top recruiters that have asked 
us to send them job seekers targeted to their interests.  We connect you to the 
right recruiters, en masse, the same day you enroll.  This "in their face" approach 
works because it's hard to get noticed on the Internet any other way.  

Mass Career Marketing
XPostit.com intelligently connects you to the recruiters across the country matching 
your profession, industry, and location preferences to theirs.  You can pick 
how many recruiters will see your resume.  On average, each job seeker's profile 
gets distributed to over 1,100 targeted recruiter connections.  Imagine the opportunities 
that are uncovered by our clients!

Are you lost in the crowd?
Did you know that there are over 20 million resumes, in hundreds of databanks, 
on the Internet?  And, over 2 million new resumes added each month!  "Waiting 
to be found" has never worked and, with the Internet, it especially does not. 
Of course, some recruiters will find you on the Internet (just as I have), but 
not the hundreds of targeted recruiters as with XPostit.com.

Our service helps you find the hidden opportunities even in your own back yard. 
We can also be used to uncover national and international opportunities too, 
if you are interested in them.

Our Database
Our recruiter database covers everything from the most specialized professional 
recruiters to professional generalists, independent professionals to international 
organizations.  We have extensive representation in most every industry and job 
function across the country.  Many recruiters are not posting jobs to find candidates. 
They are relying on their internal database, referrals, and our leads.  Our recruiters 
have profiled themselves in our system and have asked to receive our targeted 
job seekers.  We are exclusively 100% opt-in.  This ensures that they will read 
your resume because they are looking for what we send them.  We have worked very 
hard to develop this asset.  We believe it's the best!

Our Job Seekers
If you earn between $40,000 and $300,000 per year then our service is designed 
to determine which recruiters are right for you.   

So, if you are looking to find more opportunities, even in your own city, signup 
now for your membership and get connected to the recruiters looking for you. 
With prices as low as $49, you may select a service that meets your needs and 
fits your budget!  Nothing is as effective, at any price.

Best wishes in your career,
http://www.XPostit.com
Cross post it and harness the power of the 'net!  

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
Please, forward this email to any of your friends that could use our help!
<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

Copyright 2001, Xpostit.com
http://www.Xpostit.com

From neil at pacifier.com  Wed Jun 12 13:09:17 2002
From: neil at pacifier.com (Neil Anuskiewicz)
Date: Wed, 12 Jun 2002 13:09:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Hi Candidate !  Our Resume Distribution Program adv.
In-Reply-To: <3D07A420.5060704@sun.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0206121301450.17354-100000@shell.pacifier.com>

On Wed, 12 Jun 2002, Richard Langis Jr. wrote:

> It's not necessarily the news gateway.  The list IS wide-open to anyone
> who sends a message to plug at pdxlinux.org, regardless if they're
> subscribed or not.
>
> I've confirmed this, Sandy Herring has confirmed this, what more do we
> have to do to fix the hole?

I asked Karl (the list manager) about this last week and he told me that
the list is open to non-subscribers because of the news gateway. That is,
is is necessary for the list to be open to non-subscribers in order to
accomodate teh non-subscribers who wish to use the news gateway.

In other words, the spam is a side-effect of opening the list to
non-subscribers in order to accomodate those who use the news gateway.

So the solution is to either figure out how to make the news gateway
workable without keeping the list open to non-subscribers or close down
the news gateway and close the list to non-subsribers.

This is the problem. If you have a solution or suggestion send it to
karl at microsharp.com and dmandel at microsharp.com

However, I don't think it is useful to just comment on each individual
spam with a one line top post. If you have a solution or opinion send it
to the list admin, otherwise, please just have some patience. In a
non-profit volunteer organization things rarely happen fast. The endless
back and forth about *each* individual spam is far worse than the spam
itself.


-- 
Neil Anuskiewicz




From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Jun 12 13:43:08 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed, 12 Jun 2002 13:43:08 -0700
Subject: Open Gateway, was: [PLUG] Hi Candidate !  Our Resume
  Distribution Program adv.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0206121301450.17354-100000@shell.pacifier.co
 m>
References: <3D07A420.5060704@sun.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020612134057.00bb3ec8@localhost>

According to others in the list, it's possible to subscribe, choose the "No 
Mail" option, and then be able to post as normal to the closed list.

It seems to me that this would be the best option. Make the list closed, 
and have instructions posted (on the website, in a monthly posting to the 
list, etc) that include these details.

At 01:09 PM 6/12/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>So the solution is to either figure out how to make the news gateway
>workable without keeping the list open to non-subscribers or close down
>the news gateway and close the list to non-subsribers.

From neil at pacifier.com  Wed Jun 12 13:50:19 2002

On Wed, 12 Jun 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:

> According to others in the list, it's possible to subscribe, choose the "No
> Mail" option, and then be able to post as normal to the closed list.
>
> It seems to me that this would be the best option. Make the list closed,
> and have instructions posted (on the website, in a monthly posting to the
> list, etc) that include these details.

Please tell karl at microsharp.com and dmandel at microsharp.com.

I am not sure if they monitor the list so would see that solution (which
has been posted here at least once). I believe that they need to be told
directly of the solution and then we need to be patient and tolerate a few
more spams. This is especially true since Karl says he does not have time
to deal with the list.

Times of transition means that this may happen even slower -- it may be
the next list manager(s) who does it.

The key is that it will happen but it may take a little while. I think we
should ignore the next few spams and not bring it up again unless nothing
happens over the next week or two.


-- 
Neil Anuskiewicz

>From today's SANS news:

 --5 June 2002  Microsoft Admits Contribution to Think Tank That
                Published Anti Open-Source Paper

Microsoft admits that it provides funding to the Alexis de Tocqueville
Institution, the think tank that recently released a white paper that
maintains open source software is not secure and that government should
instead use proprietary software.  The Institution will not comment on
specific funding for the report.
	http://www.wired.com/news/business/0,1367,52973,00.html

[Editor's (Paller) Note: Last year, the same think tank published a paper
extolling the benefits of Microsoft's certification programs.]

From sandy at herring.org  Wed Jun 12 14:28:01 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Wed, 12 Jun 2002 14:28:01 -0700
Subject: {PLUG] Spammers, ugh. (Was: [PLUG] Hi Candidate !  Our Resume Distribution Program adv.)
In-Reply-To: <gxm26j.lh@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>; from sjhoward@nyx.net on Wed, Jun 12, 2002 at 01:56:42PM -0700
References: <mailman.1023912615.31549.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <gxm26j.lh@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20020612142801.B31220@kippered.herring.org>

It is possible to use nnrpaccess to authenticate...

# Set these variables if you need to authenticate to your NNTP server for
# Usenet posting or reading.  If no authentication is necessary, specify None
# for both variables.
NNTP_USERNAME = None
NNTP_PASSWORD = None

...by including the appropriate info in ~mailman/Mailman/mm_cfg.py. It's
also possible to require list membership in general, but waive the
requirement on a per user basis in the General Posting Filters section...

Addresses of members accepted for       This settings can be used to designate
posting to this list without implicit   posting privileges to persons who are
approval requirement.                   not subscribers to the list. It may
                                        also be used to specify persons who
                                        are exclusively allowed to post.
                                        Please see the chart below for
                                        explanation. 

See the "GNU Mailman List Management Guide v 2.0" guide for details:

http://web.aurora.edu/~ckolar//mailman/mailman-administration-v2.html

Note that the above features are also available in v 
On Wed, 12 Jun 2002, Scott Howard wrote: 
> Ugh... the news gateway is the only way I can manage the volume of 
> traffic in PLUG.
> 
> Why not make news access authenticated? It's not perfect, but you could 
> post the authentication info somewhere on the plug website to slow down 
> jerks who've stumbled into the server via a portscan.
> 
> Additionally, try to log IPs and put spammers on a bozo list.

From rlangis at geekfest.net  Wed Jun 12 14:48:28 2002
From: rlangis at geekfest.net (rlangis at geekfest.net)
Date: Wed, 12 Jun 2002 14:48:28 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] [plug-mmtest-admin@lists.pdxlinux.org: Your message to PLUG-mmtest awaits moderator approval]
Message-ID: <20020612214828.GB13987@geekfest.net>

Just did a quick test with wilco and texno (Wil Cooley and AJ Lavin) on
the plug-mmtest list.

Wilco disabled posting from non-members, AJ sent a couple of messages
via the news gateway AND via SMTP, and we got a few people from the IRC
channel to send messages from non-subscribed addresses.

The following mail was what was sent back to me when I posted from
home...which is where I'm posting to THIS list right now (and I
shouldn't be able to).

After a little more tweaking, the main list should be set up the same
way.

-Richard

From cp at onsitetech.com  Wed Jun 12 16:31:54 2002
From: cp at onsitetech.com (Curtis Poe)
Date: Wed, 12 Jun 2002 16:31:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Perl Mongers Meeting - Perl Object Environment
References: <mailman.1023912615.31549.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <gxm26j.lh@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> <20020612142801.B31220@kippered.herring.org> <20020612143818.C31220@kippered.herring.org>
Message-ID: <000c01c21269$563560c0$1a01a8c0@ot.onsitetech.com>

Ugh, I should have sent sooner, but I just plum forgot.  Many of you use
Perl, but if you feel such announcements are inappropriate, please let me
know.

Tonight, Todd Caine will be giving a presentation on POE (Perl Object
Environment).  From an introduction on perl.com
(http://www.perl.com/pub/a/2001/01/poe.html)

    POE is a framework for building Perl programs that lends
    itself naturally to tasks which involve reacting to
    external data, such as network communications or user
    interfaces. Programs written in POE are completely non-
    linear; you set up a bunch of small subroutines and
    define how they all call each other, and POE will
    automatically switch between them while it's handling
    your program's input and output.

Place:          Onsite! Technology, Inc.
Address:        333 SE 3rd, Portland, OR
Date and Time:  2002-06-12 at 7:00 PM
URL:            http://www.onsitetech.com/

There will be a social meeting at the Rose and Raindrop
(http://nwbrewpage.com/orpubs/RoseRain.html) at 6:00 PM. The address is 532
S.E. Grand and it's about 3 blocks from the Onsite! Technology offices.

--
Cheers,
Curtis Poe
Senior Programmer
ONSITE! Technology, Inc.
www.onsitetech.com

From dh at mda.huntbros.net  Wed Jun 12 18:10:47 2002
From: dh at mda.huntbros.net (dh at mda.huntbros.net)
Date: Wed, 12 Jun 2002 18:10:47 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Open relays and "homeland" security
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206121656280.11865-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206121750350.1387-100000@mda.huntbros.net>

IMHO, the headers are all forged, with the exception of salmo's, which
gives as "subdimension.com" an IP number belonging to a telco in Brazil.
Also, if my memory serves me corectly, spam was not yet a problem in the
year 0102, as given in the timestamps of all four remaining headers. I may
be wrong, but I think this came from the spammer's SMTP client direct to
salmo. Were these the only received headers?

-- 
David Hunt <dh at mda.huntbros.net>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jun 12 18:22:17 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 12 Jun 2002 18:22:17 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Open relays and "homeland" security
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206121750350.1387-100000@mda.huntbros.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206121820330.12245-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 12 Jun 2002 dh at mda.huntbros.net wrote:

> IMHO, the headers are all forged, with the exception of salmo's, which
> gives as "subdimension.com" an IP number belonging to a telco in Brazil.
> Also, if my memory serves me corectly, spam was not yet a problem in the
> year 0102, as given in the timestamps of all four remaining headers. I may
> be wrong, but I think this came from the spammer's SMTP client direct to
> salmo. Were these the only received headers?

David,

  Yes, the only missing lines are "Reply to: " and "To: ".

  My understanding is that the domain names are easily spoofed in the HELO
and FROM lines, but that the IP addresses were accurate. Why would a spammer
forge a series of "Received: " lines when sending directly?

Thanks,

Rich

  Still seems to me to be more effort than most spammers would invest. They

time to come up with a bunch of phony hops. Heck, with that much effort they

> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
-- 
"The power to untie is stronger than the power to tie."

There are some pretty evil programs designed for Marketing.

From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Wed Jun 12 21:46:34 2002
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Wed, 12 Jun 2002 21:46:34 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] rdist
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206122120280.31324-100000@zulu.launi.com>
References: <1023940104.26297.4.camel@sthelens.dimstar.net>
        <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206122120280.31324-100000@zulu.launi.com>
Message-ID: <64799.12.231.181.15.1023943594.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>

Rsync can be tunneled in ssh.

Something like

rsync -avz -e ssh username at foo.com:/dir/to/sync/to/ /dir/to/sync/from

If you use RSA keys w/ no passphrase, you can have this be automated, ie
no logging in. I'll let someone else debate the relative security of this
kind of setup.
-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District

From bl.nordlund at verizon.net  Wed Jun 12 22:06:08 2002
From: bl.nordlund at verizon.net (Brian & Lori Nordlund)
Date: Wed, 12 Jun 2002 22:06:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] New Install won't let me Telnet, FTP, or http
Message-ID: <002701c21298$07bdbf80$021ea8c0@nisse>

I've searched various archives, but I have not found the reason for my problem.  I am running a "server" in the closet as a firewall to my DSL account.  Previously, I was running an earlier version of Mandrake.  With that installation, telnet, ftp, and apache all were accessable from the inside by default (I didn't have to do anything or know anything to make it work!).  Since I updated to Mandrake 7.2 none of these services respond at all, even from an xterm on the machine itself (response to telnet is "telnet: unable to connect to remote host: Connection refused").  I am guessing that later versions of mandrake have become more paranoid so thay don't come with everything turned on like they used to.  That doesn't help the bumblers like me.


Some points:

I am running static IP's on the inside (eth1) with the server and two other machines (running DHCP to the DSL side (eth0)).  I can ping from the inside to the server, and through to the outside.  In fact all the ipchains stuff is working great as far as my internet access is concerned.

There is no guest account on the machine (would it be needed for these services?).


I read through http://www.acm.org/crossroads/xrds6-1/linuxsec.html  to try and check a few things, during which I collected the following information:

hosts.allow has a single entry for my subnet (ALL: 192.18.30.0/255.255.255.0).  hosts.disallow has a single entry of ALL:ALL.


I have HUP'ed xinetd a few times.  When I did it to inetd, it came back saying "inetd: no process killed"

I am assuming that xinetd is running rather than inetd.  However, etc/inetd.conf does exsist and includes:
ftp    stream tcp  nowait root   /usr/sbin/tcpd       in.ftpd -l -a
telnet stream tcp  nowait root   /usr/sbin/tcpd       in.telnetd



/etc/xinetd.conf is small enough to include in its entirety:
defaults
{
   instancees          =60
   log_type              = SYSLOG authpriv
   log_on_success  = HOST PID
   log_on_failure      = HOST RECORD
}
includedir  /etc/xinetd.d


In looking at /etc/xinetd.d this directory includes the following files:
wu-ftpd
time-udp
time
swat
rsh
rlogin
rexec
linuxconf-web
ipop3
imap
echo-udp
echo
daytime-udp
daytime
chargen-udp
chargen


/etc/services has almost every port open, especially the ones associated with ftp, telnet and http.

There is no /etc/rc.inet2 file

tcpd exists in /usr/sbin 



My head hurts and I hope someone can catch what is probably a simple ommission so I can get some rest.  Thanks for any help or direction you can provide.

Thanks,
Brian.
-------------- next part --------------

URL: http://lists.pdxlinux.org/pipermail/plug/attachments/20020612/6ea689b5/attachment.html 

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Wed Jun 12 22:23:06 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 12 Jun 2002 22:23:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] New Install won't let me Telnet, FTP, or http
In-Reply-To: <002701c21298$07bdbf80$021ea8c0@nisse>
References: <002701c21298$07bdbf80$021ea8c0@nisse>
Message-ID: <1023945786.15512.19.camel@pookie>

Brian;

Add a /etc/inetd.d/telnet file with the following and send an HUP to
xinetd:

# default: off
# description: A chargen server. This is the tcp \
# version.

service telnet
{
#       type            = INTERNAL
        id              = telnet
        socket_type     = stream
        protocol        = tcp
        user            = root
        wait            = no
        disable         = no
}

From dmandel at MicroSharp.com  Wed Jun 12 22:52:10 2002
From: dmandel at MicroSharp.com (David Mandel (MS))
Date: Wed, 12 Jun 2002 22:52:10 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: {PLUG] Spammers, ugh. (Was: [PLUG] Hi Candidate !  Our Resume
 Distribution Program adv.)
In-Reply-To: <20020612142801.B31220@kippered.herring.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206122245030.1596-100000@sco302.avalongroup.net>

Karl,

    Please take care of this if at all possible.  Sandy is right.  We are
getting too much SPAM.  We need to restrict posting to members only
and we need to do this on all PLUG lists, ie. PLUG, PLUG-WEB, PLUG-TALK,
etc.  If you can figure out a way to authenticate news postings do so.
Otherwise, make the NEWs gateway read only.  I would help you with this,
but I can't for a week or so and I think this needs to be done sooner
than that.

                                                   Dave

On Wed, 12 Jun 2002, Sandy Herring wrote:

> It is possible to use nnrpaccess to authenticate...
>
> # Set these variables if you need to authenticate to your NNTP server for
> # Usenet posting or reading.  If no authentication is necessary, specify None
> # for both variables.
> NNTP_USERNAME = None
> NNTP_PASSWORD = None
>
> ...by including the appropriate info in ~mailman/Mailman/mm_cfg.py. It's
> also possible to require list membership in general, but waive the
> requirement on a per user basis in the General Posting Filters section...
>
> Addresses of members accepted for       This settings can be used to designate
> posting to this list without implicit   posting privileges to persons who are
> approval requirement.                   not subscribers to the list. It may
>                                         also be used to specify persons who
>                                         are exclusively allowed to post.
>                                         Please see the chart below for
>                                         explanation.
>
> See the "GNU Mailman List Management Guide v 2.0" guide for details:
>
> http://web.aurora.edu/~ckolar//mailman/mailman-administration-v2.html
>
> Note that the above features are also available in v
> On Wed, 12 Jun 2002, Scott Howard wrote:
> > Ugh... the news gateway is the only way I can manage the volume of
> > traffic in PLUG.
> >
> > Why not make news access authenticated? It's not perfect, but you could
> > post the authentication info somewhere on the plug website to slow down
> > jerks who've stumbled into the server via a portscan.
> >
> > Additionally, try to log IPs and put spammers on a bozo list.
>

From allyn at well.com  Wed Jun 12 23:31:36 2002
From: allyn at well.com (Mark Allyn)
Date: Wed, 12 Jun 2002 23:31:36 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Editing PDF files
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.4.42.0206122323570.25089-100000@well.com>

Hello:

I have been playing around with this for a while and I
still don't like the results.

I need to be able to take a pdf file, read it into something
where I can add stuff to it; write it out to a file (I don't
care what kind of file, as long as it can be printed); and then
print the file.

The pdf file that I am working with is an employment application.
It has blanks for name, employers, etc. They expect me to print
it, write by hand the information, and then send it in. I am
hopeing to figure out a way to read the file into something that
would allow me to enter my information in the blanks and then
print/mail the results in via snail mail.

I tried exporting the file to .ps (via the acroread utility);
reading the file into ghostscript to convert it into .pgm and
then reading that into xpaint. I seem to lose some detail
in the file and the tiny prints gets garbled up.

I tried to read in the file using gimp, but gimp is very
hard to work with.

I tried using xfig, but xfig does not seem to have any
capability to read in either jpg,pgm,tiff,ps, or any
other file except its own format. (Please tell me that
I am missing something obvious.

I currently have only linux (no windows whatsoever).
If there is some sort of solution that I have missed,
I would love to know about it.

As I am still looking for work, I don't want to shell out
the $100 for the commercial software that is used to make
the pdf files.

For any of those who are familiar, the pdf files are for
the OHSU employment application.

Thanks for any help

Mark Allyn




From mikedela at ipns.com  Wed Jun 12 23:39:54 2002
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)

Subject: [PLUG] Editing PDF files
In-Reply-To: <Pine.SOL.4.42.0206122323570.25089-100000@well.com>

You might trry this-
I take them into a graphics program (Corel Draw) and place text over the blanks 
and then print. Works like a charm, and I don't have to edit their stupid files.

Mike

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Wed Jun 12 23:33:12 2002
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Wed, 12 Jun 2002 23:33:12 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Other ALC courses
In-Reply-To: <3D02BAF5.7060502@cryptowave.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206122324310.1555-100000@sco302.avalongroup.net>

On Sat, 8 Jun 2002, John H. wrote:

> I've never heard of ALC before and they don't seem to have much
> information on their website.
> How much credability do they have? (I notice the site has some broken
> links, too)
>
> Not to sound rude, but it seems these courses are rather bland and can
> be learned by reading a book.
> How much hands-on experience are they providing?
>

ALC is one of Ed Sawicki's projects.  Actually, it is his major thing.
Altho I've never taken any of Ed's classes, I've worked with Ed quite
a bit.  He is good and gives good classes.  I've talked with numerous
ALC students and most all of them give the classes high marks no
matter who taught the class they took.

Thus, ALC (or any other training program) may not be right for everyone,
but is right for many people.  ALC is a quality act.

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Thu Jun 13 00:13:45 2002
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 00:13:45 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Other ALC courses
In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0206082143480.1477-100000@shell.pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206122339580.1555-100000@sco302.avalongroup.net>

On Sat, 8 Jun 2002, Neil Anuskiewicz wrote:

>
> On Sat, 8 Jun 2002, AthlonRob wrote:
>
> > Having not taken many computer classes before... are they all this (~$350?)
> > expensive?
>

Private computer instruction is expensive.
I haven't looked at prices in a while, but it seems to me that
places like New Horizons charge about $250 per day for their
low level classes and about $500 per day for their high level
classes.  I believe Ed's classes are much cheaper.

Actually, the price of this sort of education is a real problem.
Ed is offering one alternative that lowers this cost a good deal.
People like Free Geek are trying a different approach.
And I suppose I've been trying still other approaches.

>
> > $1240 per term for tuition is more than enough to budget for learning at this
> > time.
>

Public colleges have often have larger classes than those in private
computer workshops.  They are also tax supported, so naturally they
charge lower tuitions.

More importantly, the type of education you get in college is very
different from what you get in computer workshops.  College education
should educate students in the arts and sciences and give them skills
that will last their entire lives.  Computer workshops are designed to
intensive instruction in some specialized field which may only be
useful for a short period of time.  In other words, you learn
triangle trigonometry in college and you learn to operate a card punch
in a computer workshop.


                                          Sincerely,
                                          David Mandel
                                          Chief Activist
                                          Portland Linux/Unix Group
                                          1440 NE 59th
                                          Portland, Oregon 97213
                                          (360) 260-2066 at work
                                          (541) 730-5285 cell

From pjohnston at inetarena.com  Thu Jun 13 00:36:05 2002
From: pjohnston at inetarena.com (Paul Johnston)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 00:36:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Motherboard sound
Message-ID: <3.0.5.32.20020613003605.00793860@mail.inetarena.com>

My old Linux box is down, so I'm building a new one.  My question arises
from the fact that I will be changing from an old motherboard to a new one.

Since I'm buying parts for a Linux (RH7.3) system, compatibility is my
prime concern.  My new box will be based on a Athlon XP 1800+ CPU and DDR
RAM.  The good folks at Pacific Solutions told me that the most common
Linux motherboard issue is sound drivers.

I am not a gamer and have been quite happy with my simple Ensoniq PCI128
sound card (SB-compatible) for about seven years.  It was supported by Red
Hat 5.2.

Should I get a motherboard without built-in sound (or with built-in sound
disabled) and use a simple sound card with known support for Linux?  Is the
driver problem due to the built-in sound, or is it due to the fact that the
most current Linux distros may not support the most current sound technology?

Thanks for your help.
-----------------------------------------------------
Linux in every box, and C.S. Lewis in every bookpile.

Paul Johnston

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jun 13 00:55:36 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 00:55:36 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Motherboard sound
In-Reply-To: <3.0.5.32.20020613003605.00793860@mail.inetarena.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206130049580.23907-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 13 Jun 2002, Paul Johnston wrote:
> Should I get a motherboard without built-in sound (or with built-in
> sound disabled) and use a simple sound card with known support for
> Linux?  Is the driver problem due to the built-in sound, or is it due
> to the fact that the most current Linux distros may not support the
> most current sound technology?

I'm going to go out on a speculative limb here and suggest that perhaps
the problem is that many on-board sound solutions use short-run
proprietary chipsets (or single-chip solutions, more likely) that aren't
common enough for the community to develop useful drivers OR are designed
to run with significant software emulation under MS Windows.

A 2.4 kernel supports a staggering variety of sound devices, to my eye,
and if you include those supported by the ALSA project, you get nearly
every major device, current and antiquated.

I would suggest taking the extra few minutes to double-check the chipset
on the board against the supported lists (directly supported by the
kernel, its OSS modules, or ALSA) and just avoid anything that isn't
there.  If you have or can acquire a cheap sound card that is supported
and you're not an audiophile, then go ahead and get a board without sound
and use the cheap card.  I can't recommend the third option of disabling
the onboard sound in order to use an off-board sound card because I've had
terrible experiences disabling on-board features with some motherboards.  
It's not a sure-fire problem, but I just try to avoid the situation
entirely if I can.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Jun 13 01:05:02 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 01:05:02 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] rdist
Message-ID: <6012481.1023955494083.JavaMail.root@monkey>

Some versions of rdist allow you to tunnel it over ssh, thereby making it
secure.

I usually use rsync (http://rsync.samba.org) instead since it has a huge
set of features including ssh tunnelling, compression, auto-bandwidth
throttling, auto-resume, and differential-only sending.  Overkill for an
/etc/passwd file, perhaps, but useful in other places.

Whatever solution you come up with, be sure it's immune to the zero-length
passwd file problem (i.e. transfer clobbers your file with nothing or with
garbage.)  It really sucks to have your only means of login destroyed.  I
encourage you to leave a back door someplace if you can, and test that it
works if the passwd file is dorked up.

  -- Steve

On Wed, 12 Jun 2002, launi launi at zaramyth.net XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

> Can rdist be used securely?  I want to synchronize my passwd file between 
> two servers. Is this the right tool?
> 
> --

> Lonnie Wormley             launi at zaramyth.net

> ______________________________________________
>

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Jun 13 01:11:55 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 01:11:55 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Editing PDF files
Message-ID: <305806913.1023955905071.JavaMail.root@monkey>

Heh, I remember sending that OHSU application monstrosity several months
ago.  Never heard back.  Not even a "thanks for sending us that brick of
paper" message.  I figure it was their loss.  ;-)

You might try editing the raw PostScript file.  Not the prettiest way to
go about things, but it's definately in the UNIX spirit.  I'm sure some
poor fool has built a lisp PS-mode for Xemacs...

I recall seeing a Perl module that parses PostScript.  I have not tried it
though.  My motivation to save my DMV fill-in PDFs in a permanent form
gave out before I actually put it to use.

In any case I would avoid converting it to an image format.  It will not
look good when printed when compared to the crisp text of the original
PDF.

  -- Steve

On Wed, 12 Jun 2002, Mark Allyn allyn at well.com XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

>

> still don't like the results.

> where I can add stuff to it; write it out to a file (I don't
> care what kind of file, as long as it can be printed); and then
> print the file.
> 
> The pdf file that I am working with is an employment application.
> It has blanks for name, employers, etc. They expect me to print
> it, write by hand the information, and then send it in. I am
> hopeing to figure out a way to read the file into something that
> would allow me to enter my information in the blanks and then
> print/mail the results in via snail mail.
> 
> I tried exporting the file to .ps (via the acroread utility);
> reading the file into ghostscript to convert it into .pgm and
> then reading that into xpaint. I seem to lose some detail
> in the file and the tiny prints gets garbled up.
> 
> I tried to read in the file using gimp, but gimp is very
> hard to work with.
> 
> I tried using xfig, but xfig does not seem to have any
> capability to read in either jpg,pgm,tiff,ps, or any
> other file except its own format. (Please tell me that
> I am missing something obvious.
> 
> I currently have only linux (no windows whatsoever).
> If there is some sort of solution that I have missed,
> I would love to know about it.
> 
> As I am still looking for work, I don't want to shell out
> the $100 for the commercial software that is used to make
> the pdf files.
>

> the OHSU employment application.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Jun 13 01:17:00 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 01:17:00 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Motherboard sound
Message-ID: <798129729.1023956209775.JavaMail.root@monkey>

My experience has been that built-in sound tends to be done using whatever
sound chipset was the cheapest available the week the board was
designed.  As if that isn't bad enough, often they can't be disabled (or
even when they are, they aren't *fully* disabled.)

For linux, I would definately go brand-name modular and save yourself some
pain.  Unless you like pain.

Oh, wait.  You're a UNIX/PC hacker.  Of course you like pain.  ;-)

  -- Steve

On Thu, 13 Jun 2002, Paul Johnston pjohnston at inetarena.com XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

> Should I get a motherboard without built-in sound (or with built-in sound
> disabled) and use a simple sound card with known support for Linux?  Is the
> driver problem due to the built-in sound, or is it due to the fact that the
> most current Linux distros may not support the most current sound technology?

From keith at ahapala.net  Thu Jun 13 07:11:14 2002
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 07:11:14 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Motherboard sound
In-Reply-To: <3.0.5.32.20020613003605.00793860@mail.inetarena.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206130657560.16679-100000@skua.ahapala.net>

On Thu, 13 Jun 2002, Paul Johnston wrote:

> Should I get a motherboard without built-in sound (or with built-in sound
> disabled) and use a simple sound card with known support for Linux?  Is the
> driver problem due to the built-in sound, or is it due to the fact that the
> most current Linux distros may not support the most current sound technology?
> 

Paul,

I just yesterday bought an Amptron K7-830XLM with an Athlon XP 1900+ for
my workstation upgrade from Pacific Solutions. I'm running RH7.3 and I
just reran sndconfig and the onboard sound was detected. Since I was
upgrading I just dropped my old NIC in and I suspect the onboard LAN could
be configured as well.

I first tried the K7-841XLM and I could not get the onboard video to work, 
nor would it acccept a PCI video card (I tried two RH supported ones).

Both of these boards allow you to turn off the onboard audio in the BIOS 
if you'd like to keep your old audio card.

Keith




From montagne at boora.com  Thu Jun 13 08:03:14 2002
From: montagne at boora.com (Michael Montagne)

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Thu Jun 13 10:01:33 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 10:01:33 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] New Install won't let me Telnet, FTP, or http
References: <004d01c21299$588e1d00$021ea8c0@nisse>
Message-ID: <3D08CFED.7060905@pacifier.com>

Brian & Lori Nordlund wrote:

> Since I updated to Mandrake 7.2 none of these services respond at
> all, even from an xterm on the machine itself (response to telnet is
> "telnet: unable to connect to remote host: Connection refused").  I am
> guessing that later versions of mandrake have become more paranoid so thay
> don't come with everything turned on like they used to.  That doesn't help
> the bumblers like me.

<snip>

> In looking at /etc/xinetd.d this directory includes the following files:
> wu-ftpd
> time-udp
> time
> swat
> rsh
> rlogin
> rexec
> linuxconf-web
> ipop3
> imap
> echo-udp
> echo
> daytime-udp
> daytime
> chargen-udp
> chargen
>

$10 says that wu-ftpd has a line
	disable	=	yes

change that to 'no' and restart xinetd

Looks like you'll have to create a telnet file like D. Cooper Stevenson 
said.  As far as http, at least in RedHat, it is not under control of 
xinetd, but rather started seperately in the runlevel dirs (/etc/rc.d/)

Cheers,
Kyle Accardi




From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Jun 13 10:12:02 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 10:12:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] New Install won't let me Telnet, FTP, or http
In-Reply-To: <3D08CFED.7060905@pacifier.com>
References: <004d01c21299$588e1d00$021ea8c0@nisse>
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20020613101031.01fc2f88@localhost>

Either that, or install the telnet-server RPM, which adds that file, and 
some others. Then, change the "disabled =" line.

For a console app to change these things, try "ntsysv". Works in Redhat and 
Mandrake, others too.

At 10:01 AM 6/13/2002 -0700, you wrote:
>Looks like you'll have to create a telnet file like D. Cooper Stevenson 
>said.  As far as http, at least in RedHat, it is not under control of 
>xinetd, but rather started seperately in the runlevel dirs (/etc/rc.d/)

Russ Johnson
http://www.dimstar.net

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Jun 13 10:24:19 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 10:24:19 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] New Install won't let me Telnet, FTP, or http
In-Reply-To: <5.1.0.14.0.20020613101031.01fc2f88@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206131017020.26593-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 13 Jun 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:

> Either that, or install the telnet-server RPM, which adds that file,
> and some others. Then, change the "disabled =" line.
> 
> For a console app to change these things, try "ntsysv". Works in
> Redhat and Mandrake, others too.

The chkconfig utility that ships with Red Hat can be used to manage 
xinetd services, too:

  # list what chkconfig can manage
  /sbin/chkconfig --list

  # tweak /etc/xinetd.d/telnet to turn on telnet server and HUP xinetd 
  # to activate it
  /sbin/chkconfig telnet on

  # check syslog to make sure we got what we wanted
  tail -n 40 /var/log/messages

At that point, you can edit /etc/xinetd.d/telnet to add, say, 
host-based exclusions using "only_from" or "no_access" directives. The 
xinetd.conf(5) man page is helpful in that regard.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

import a graphics file.

From derek at infotects.com  Thu Jun 13 11:47:47 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 13 Jun 2002 11:47:47 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] New Install won't let me Telnet, FTP, or http
In-Reply-To: <004d01c21299$588e1d00$021ea8c0@nisse>
References: <004d01c21299$588e1d00$021ea8c0@nisse>
Message-ID: <1023994067.890.5.camel@dereklinux>

On Wed, 2002-06-12 at 22:15, Brian & Lori Nordlund wrote: 
> Sorry about the previous post with the formatting junk in it.  A clean
> version follows................
> 
> 
> 
> I've searched various archives, but I have not found the reason for my
> problem.  I am running a "server" in the closet as a firewall to my DSL
> account.  Previously, I was running an earlier version of Mandrake.  With
> that installation, telnet, ftp, and apache all were accessable from the
> inside by default (I didn't have to do anything or know anything to make it
> work!).  Since I updated to Mandrake 7.2 none of these services respond at
> all, even from an xterm on the machine itself (response to telnet is
> "telnet: unable to connect to remote host: Connection refused").  I am
> guessing that later versions of mandrake have become more paranoid so thay
> don't come with everything turned on like they used to.  That doesn't help
> the bumblers like me.
> 
> 
> Some points:
> 
> I am running static IP's on the inside (eth1) with the server and two other
> machines (running DHCP to the DSL side (eth0)).  I can ping from the inside
> to the server, and through to the outside.  In fact all the ipchains stuff
> is working great as far as my internet access is concerned.
> 
> There is no guest account on the machine (would it be needed for these
> services?).
> 
> 
> I read through http://www.acm.org/crossroads/xrds6-1/linuxsec.html  to try
> and check a few things, during which I collected the following information:
> 
> hosts.allow has a single entry for my subnet (ALL:
> 192.18.30.0/255.255.255.0).  hosts.disallow has a single entry of ALL:ALL.
This is probably it, any host not in your subnet (Do you have exclusive
control of the whole subnet?) including your internal subnet (I assume
it is a non-routable set of addresses) will be denied access by your
hosts.disallow.  To open everything (not recommended, but easy) comment
out the entry in the host.disallow, and change the host.allow to

ALL: ALL

The man page for hosts_access (at least that is what it is called on my
debian box) will give much more useful information.


Good Luck

Derek Loree

From jon at manymoons.net  Thu Jun 13 12:21:05 2002
From: jon at manymoons.net (Jon Jacob)
Date: 13 Jun 2002 12:21:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Apache.pm failed to load
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206131119190.13485-100000@lukem.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206131119190.13485-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <1023996065.1392.84.camel@lana.manymoons.net>

Searched on google and found this page:

http://theoryx5.uwinnipeg.ca/guide/troubleshooting/_Apache_pm_failed_to_load_.html

Which may help.

What you have is a mod_perl setup that is failing.  I have never used
stronghold so I can't tell you for sure, but it sounds as if you either
need to install mod_perl, reinstall mod_perl, disable in the httpd.conf
(or whatever stronghold uses), or enable it.  Of course, its all your
choice depending on what your needs are.

Hope that helps.

From derek at infotects.com  Thu Jun 13 12:59:09 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 13 Jun 2002 12:59:09 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Motherboard sound
In-Reply-To: <3.0.5.32.20020613003605.00793860@mail.inetarena.com>
References: <3.0.5.32.20020613003605.00793860@mail.inetarena.com>
Message-ID: <1023998355.1372.27.camel@dereklinux>

On Thu, 2002-06-13 at 00:36, Paul Johnston wrote:
> My old Linux box is down, so I'm building a new one.  My question arises
> from the fact that I will be changing from an old motherboard to a new one.
> 
> Since I'm buying parts for a Linux (RH7.3) system, compatibility is my
> prime concern.  My new box will be based on a Athlon XP 1800+ CPU and DDR
> RAM.  The good folks at Pacific Solutions told me that the most common
> Linux motherboard issue is sound drivers.
> 
> I am not a gamer and have been quite happy with my simple Ensoniq PCI128
> sound card (SB-compatible) for about seven years.  It was supported by Red
> Hat 5.2.
> 
> Should I get a motherboard without built-in sound (or with built-in sound
> disabled) and use a simple sound card with known support for Linux?
Most on-board sound chipsets rely heavily on the CPU for doing most of
the grunt work that dedicated sound cards take care of, your PCI128
probably has more features and better sound quality than most on-board
solutions.  If you are capable of compiling your own kernel, being able
to disable the sound chipset is not really important (if the kernel
doesn't look for it, it doesn't get used).  The only drawback may be
that the IRQ won't be free to be used by something else.

Beware of the volatile mix of the VIA southbridge, on-board sound and
the Phoenix BIOS.  This combination has many problems and doesn't work
well under an OS that automatically detects hardware, even if it is
disabled in the BIOS, it is still detected, but broken.

My advice is to hold out for a board without sound.  You're going to end
up adding a sound card anyway.

Good Luck

Derek Loree




From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Jun 13 13:32:13 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 13:32:13 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] shell override in NIS env.
In-Reply-To: <20020613192806.GB3824@subtend.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206131328550.26593-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 13 Jun 2002, Kris wrote:

> > What do the passwd, shadow, and group entries look like in your 
> > /etc/nsswitch.conf file?
> > 
> passwd:     files nisplus nis
> shadow:     files nisplus nis
> group:      files nisplus nis

glibc 2.x (for a reason I've never bothered to research) needs special 
syntax in nsswitch.conf. Try

passwd: compat
shadow: compat
group: compat

passwd_compat: nis
group_compat: nis
shadow_compat: nis

See section 7.5 or the NIS HOWTO for more info:

  http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/NIS-HOWTO/x227.html

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From briand at aracnet.com  Thu Jun 13 09:37:09 2002
From: briand at aracnet.com (briand at aracnet.com)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 09:37:09 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Motherboard sound
In-Reply-To: <3.0.5.32.20020613003605.00793860@mail.inetarena.com>

Message-ID: <15624.51765.308317.770105@soggy.deldotd.com>

So far I've had good luck with sound chipsets on Motherboards.
Something like 3 for 3.  Laptops are another story...

If you are interested in "premium" sound then you don't want an
on-board chipset anyway.

I think it's best to go with a PCI sound card of some sort.

Brian

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jun 13 15:44:39 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 15:44:39 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Debian GNU/Linux "woody" apache/perl problems.
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206131539300.31896-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

Yo.

In this environment, I'm building a kind of internal workgroup server.  
For various reasons (not open to debate), I'm using some old hardware and
have to use a binary distribution.  I chose Debian GNU/Linux (also not
open to debate), but because of past problems and the desire to use a
modern kernel, I chose the "testing" branch, codenamed Woody.

The system build went rather smoothly and everything appears to be up to
date.  I installed all of the important services and everything seems to
be working (ssh, cvs, bind, etc.), but then I decided that I'd like to
have a web server on this host as well.  For various reasons (of course,
not open to debate), I decided that Apache was the way to go.

However, when I suggested to the package manager that I should install one
of the several available Apache packages, the package manager told me that
it must back-rev Perl to an unacceptable degree (from 5.6.1 to 5.005).

Does anyone have Perl 5.6.1 and Apache running on a Woody system without
building either from source?

I'm certainly not opposed to building from source, but the system is dog
slow for such things and I was hoping to be able to rely on Debian package
managers to handle upgrades in the future.

Any help is appreciated.

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

From bill at coho.net  Thu Jun 13 15:01:47 2002
From: bill at coho.net (Bill)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 15:01:47 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Adding disk partitions to an existing system
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206131431580.32406-100000@ns1.billmercer.com>

Pluggers--I've got a system that has a partition with that -other- 
operating system on it that I want to get rid of.  What I would like to do 
is

1. Nuke the ntfs partitions and make 4 ext2 partitions
2. Move the contents of my existing /tmp and /var directories to two of 
the partitions, then mount the new partitions as /tmp and /var
3. Mount another partition off my home directory for more space, leaving 
the last partition to plug in whereever I need space in the future.

I know or can figure out how to play with mtab/fstab to get partitions 
mounted where I need them, and I guess I can use linux's fdisk to get rid 
of the ntfs partitions, but I'm a little confused about how I go about 
reformatting them and getting them ready.  And once I have them formatted, 
would I just mount them at an arbitrary location to copy my current /var 
and /tmp directories over, then remove the current /var and 
/tmp directories?  And do I need to go into single user mode to do this 
kind of fooling around, so nothing important is trying to write to 
nonexistant files while the transition is taking place?  

Also, I currently have 3 primary and one extended partitions--two primary 
ntfs and one primary ext3 partitions plus an extended partition which is 
entirely occupied by my swap part at hda5:

hda1 boot partition 	ntfs
hda2   			ntfs
hda3			Extended		
hda4			Linux	
hda5			Linux swap (in hda3 extended partition)

Am I gonna run into any 
hassles 
because of he number of primary partitions?  I don't give a rat's tookus 
about remaining compatable 
with DOS's fdisk, but how many primary partitions can Linux's fdisk/mount 
deal with?

Another question--I have been booting linux off a floppy while 
doing the 
dual-boot thing--how do I rewrite the boot sector (or whatever needs to be 
rewritten) so as to be able to boot off the hd?


Thanks for any suggestions!

Bill

> However, when I suggested to the package manager that I should install one
> of the several available Apache packages, the package manager told me that

That sounds weird, maybe you need to check your sources.list and verify
the entries.  I have several woody boxes running the combination you are
wanting.  dpkg shows me this
ii  perl           5.6.1-7
ii  apache         1.3.24-3

Here is the sources.list on that box.

deb http://ftp.us.debian.org/debian/ woody main
deb-src http://ftp.us.debian.org/debian/ woody main
deb http://non-us.debian.org/debian-non-US woody/non-US main
deb-src http://non-us.debian.org/debian-non-US woody/non-US main
deb http://security.debian.org/ stable/updates main

-- 
David

I upgraded a server yesterday from Potato to Woody, and it is now running
the Woody Perl package 5.6.1-7 and Apache 1.3.24-3.  I didn't do anything

Are you sure you have the latest version of testing?  I keep a full
mirror of Debian for x86, so the copy of testing I used for the upgrade
would have been current as of early Wednesday morning.
