From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jun 13 16:41:55 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 16:41:55 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Adding disk partitions to an existing system
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206131431580.32406-100000@ns1.billmercer.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206131628510.32119-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 13 Jun 2002, Bill wrote:
> 1. Nuke the ntfs partitions and make 4 ext2 partitions
> 2. Move the contents of my existing /tmp and /var directories to two
> of the partitions, then mount the new partitions as /tmp and /var
> 3. Mount another partition off my home directory for more space,
> leaving the last partition to plug in whereever I need space in the
> future.

I'm just preserving this so we all keep the goals in sight when we give
advice.

> I know or can figure out how to play with mtab/fstab to get partitions
> mounted where I need them, and I guess I can use linux's fdisk to get
> rid of the ntfs partitions, but I'm a little confused about how I go
> about reformatting them and getting them ready.

If that wasn't just a typo or if you're already quite familiar with the
stock fdisk, ignore the rest of this paragraph.  I think you'll probably
have better luck with cfdisk than fdisk.  It's got a nicer interface
(full-screen, kinda like MS fdisk) for someone who wants to see what
they're doing as they do it.  Plain fdisk is really for scripts and piping
around variable output... a straight command-line utility.

And I'm sure you can be trusted with your own fstab.  Don't touch mtab,
though, that's all auto-generated.

> And once I have them formatted, would I just mount them at an
> arbitrary location to copy my current /var and /tmp directories over,
> then remove the current /var and /tmp directories?

GNU tar can be run with appropriate switches to preserve symlinks and
permissions.  I'm the sort of person that always has to look 'em up,
though, so let Paul or somebody rattle them off the top of his big ol'
noggin.

> And do I need to go into single user mode to do this kind of fooling
> around, so nothing important is trying to write to nonexistant files
> while the transition is taking place?

Eh... I wouldn't unless it was a production machine (with external users
that rely on constant uptime).  Just stop the obvious services, don't be
running X and try to be as atomic as possible when swapping the new /var
for the old one.

<edit fstab to reflect new mountpoint at /var for /dev/whatever, but
don't actually mount it>
<command to copy contents of var to new location>
rm -rf /var && mount /var

The end.

> Also, I currently have 3 primary and one extended partitions--two
> primary ntfs and one primary ext3 partitions plus an extended
> partition which is entirely occupied by my swap part at hda5:
> 
> hda1 boot partition 	ntfs
> hda2   			ntfs
> hda3			Extended		
> hda4			Linux	
> hda5			Linux swap (in hda3 extended partition)
> 
> Am I gonna run into any hassles because of he number of primary
> partitions? I don't give a rat's tookus about remaining compatable
> with DOS's fdisk, but how many primary partitions can Linux's
> fdisk/mount deal with?

Well, according to the man page, fdisk numbers primary partitions as 1-4
and starts numbering extended partitions at 5.

But that's not reflected in what I see in your email.  Is that right?

> Another question--I have been booting linux off a floppy while doing
> the dual-boot thing--how do I rewrite the boot sector (or whatever
> needs to be rewritten) so as to be able to boot off the hd?

Depends on which bootloader you're using.  If it's lilo, edit
/etc/lilo.conf so that one of the sections reads boot=<your boot device>
and run lilo as root.

Realize that lilo can be configured with its boot block on a particular
partition or in the MBR of the disk.  If you want lilo to install in the
MBR, you've got to give the raw device for the disk (/dev/hda instead of
/dev/hda[0-9]).


Anyway, that's how I'd do things on a home network.
J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org




From derek at infotects.com  Thu Jun 13 16:43:20 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 13 Jun 2002 16:43:20 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Adding disk partitions to an existing system
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206131431580.32406-100000@ns1.billmercer.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206131431580.32406-100000@ns1.billmercer.com>
Message-ID: <1024011800.1684.46.camel@dereklinux>

Hi Bill

On Thu, 2002-06-13 at 15:01, Bill wrote:
> Pluggers--I've got a system that has a partition with that -other- 
> operating system on it that I want to get rid of.  What I would like to do 
> is
> 
> 1. Nuke the ntfs partitions and make 4 ext2 partitions
Nuking is easy, making 4 partitions from 2 is more difficult, especially
with the extended partition being used by your swap.
> 2. Move the contents of my existing /tmp and /var directories to two of 
> the partitions, then mount the new partitions as /tmp and /var
> 3. Mount another partition off my home directory for more space, leaving 
> the last partition to plug in whereever I need space in the future.
> 
> I know or can figure out how to play with mtab/fstab to get partitions 
> mounted where I need them, and I guess I can use linux's fdisk to get rid 
> of the ntfs partitions, but I'm a little confused about how I go about 
> reformatting them and getting them ready.  And once I have them formatted, 
> would I just mount them at an arbitrary location to copy my current /var 
> and /tmp directories over, then remove the current /var and 
> /tmp directories? 
You don't need to remove the contents of the current directories in
order to mount the new partitions (kind of nice for testing purposes),
that disk space will not be available to the root file system though.
 
 And do I need to go into single user mode to do this 
> kind of fooling around, so nothing important is trying to write to 
> nonexistant files while the transition is taking place?

Single user mode is a very good idea for this type of operation.
  
> 
> Also, I currently have 3 primary and one extended partitions--two primary 
> ntfs and one primary ext3 partitions plus an extended partition which is 
> entirely occupied by my swap part at hda5:
> 
> hda1 boot partition 	ntfs
> hda2   			ntfs
> hda3			Extended		
> hda4			Linux	
> hda5			Linux swap (in hda3 extended partition)

I would create a new swap partition (what is that command for creating a
swap file system mkswap?)from the free space left after the ntfs nuke,
change your fstab to mount the new swap partition, reboot, then nuke the
extended partition.  You'll then have something like:

hda1		swap
hda4		linux

and a bunch of free space to cut up into however many pieces you want.
This can be either 2 more primaries, or one more primary and an extended
with more partitions in it.
> 
> Am I gonna run into any 
> hassles 
> because of he number of primary partitions?  I don't give a rat's tookus 
> about remaining compatable 
> with DOS's fdisk, but how many primary partitions can Linux's fdisk/mount 
> deal with?
4, but one needs to be extended if you have more than 4 partitions.  I
personally like cfdisk better than fdisk, though I've had times when
cfdisk could delete a partition but fdisk (linux version, not DOS) was
able to.
> 
> Another question--I have been booting linux off a floppy while 
> doing the 
> dual-boot thing--how do I rewrite the boot sector (or whatever needs to be 
> rewritten) so as to be able to boot off the hd?

This depends on your boot loader, please supply more information about
what program you will be using to control the boot.
> 
> 
> Thanks for any suggestions!
> 
NP, Good Luck

Derek Loree

From gilmanhunt at attbi.com  Thu Jun 13 16:45:08 2002
From: gilmanhunt at attbi.com (gilmanhunt at attbi.com)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 23:45:08 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] Sendmail Help
Message-ID: <20020613234511.SLMI11426.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@rwcrwbc57>

Sendmail version:sendmail-8.12.4
Bind version: 9.2 (I think, stock version with Slackware
8.1)

Error:Succinctly put:
---------
554 5.0.0 MX list for hotp.com. points back to
mail.hotp.com
554 5.3.5 Local configuration error
---------
I'm sure people have seen this before; I have too, and I
thought it had something to do with the sendmail.cw file,
and that file not having the domains listed in it. That
file has apparently been replaced with the
/etc/mail/local-host-names file, which follows:
---------
hotp.com
mail.hotp.com
---------
It's listed there.

This was my original sendmail.mc (in case I missed
something obvious that I need):
------------
include(`../m4/cf.m4')
VERSIONID(`linux for smtp-only setup')dnl
OSTYPE(linux)
FEATURE(always_add_domain)dnl
FEATURE(dnsbl,`blackholes.mail-abuse.org',` Mail from
$&{client_addr} rejected, see
http://mail-abuse.org/cgi-bin/lookup?$&
{client_addr}')dnl
FEATURE(dnsbl,`relays.mail-abuse.org',` Mail from
$&{client_addr} rejected; see
http://mail-abuse.org/cgi-bin/nph-rss?$&
{client_addr}')dnl
FEATURE(dnsbl,`dialups.mail-abuse.org',` Mail from
dial-up rejected; see
http://mail-abuse.org/dul/enduser.htm')
FEATURE(virtusertable, 'hash /etc/mail/virtusertable')dnl
FEATURE(access_db)dnl
FEATURE(relay_mail_from)dnl
MAILER(local)dnl
MAILER(smtp)dnl
-----------

And for some bizarre reason, I think you need part of the
DNS file for the network:
--------------------
$TTL    1D
@       IN      SOA     hotp.com. root.hotp.com. (
                2002061314 ; Serial
                8H      ; Refresh
                2H      ; Retry
                4W      ; Expire
                1D )    ; Minimum
        IN      NS      dns.hotp.com.           ; this
computer
;       IN      NS      ns.telestream.com.      ; the
telestream folks
        IN      MX      10      mail.hotp.com.
        TXT     "Hot Off The Press"

; public hotp domain
hotp.com.       IN A    208.187.236.225
mail.hotp.com.  IN A    10.10.10.221w
-----------------------
"dig hotp.com @10.10.10.221 any " shows this:
-----------------------------
 
; <<>> DiG 9.1.2 <<>> hotp.com @10.10.10.221 any
;; global options:  printcmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 35924
;; flags: qr aa rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 5, AUTHORITY: 0,
ADDITIONAL: 2
 
;; QUESTION SECTION:
;hotp.com.                      IN      ANY
 
;; ANSWER SECTION:
hotp.com.               86400   IN      SOA     hotp.com.
root.hotp.com. 2002061314 28800 7200 2419200 86400
hotp.com.               86400   IN      NS     
dns.hotp.com.
hotp.com.               86400   IN      MX      10
mail.hotp.com.
hotp.com.               86400   IN      TXT     "Hot Off
The Press"
hotp.com.               86400   IN      A      
208.187.236.225
 
;; ADDITIONAL SECTION:
dns.hotp.com.           86400   IN      A      
10.10.10.221
mail.hotp.com.          86400   IN      A      
10.10.10.221
 
;; Query time: 27 msec
;; SERVER: 10.10.10.221#53(10.10.10.221)
;; WHEN: Thu Jun 13 16:45:42 2002
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 184
--------------------------
so it's going in right...

So what gives? What am I missing with that
local-host-names file? Or is it something else?

Thanks :)

-Russ



From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jun 13 16:46:56 2002

From dbridges at austin.rr.com  Thu Jun 13 17:22:16 2002
From: dbridges at austin.rr.com (David Bridges)

Message-ID: <20020614002216.GB1222@austin.rr.com>

> > wanting.  dpkg shows me this
> > ii  perl           5.6.1-7
> > ii  apache         1.3.24-3
> 
> Duh... dpkg is confusing me.  What was teh command line that yielded this
> output?

Well it actually gives a little more data than I posted, but I did it
with this command.

dpkg -l | grep 'perl\|apache' | grep ^ii

I'm sure that some of the wizards on this list can do it better.  ;)

> I did have an issue at install where the wrong sources.list was installed,
> but I put in the right data and ran apt-get dist-upgrade.  I don't believe
> anything was even installed while those sources were active.  but the
> data's in my database.  How can I purge the apt cache and download a fresh
> list without harming the db of installed software?
 
apt-get clean  <--- cleans out all packages that have been downloaded
apt-get update  <-- updates the database of available packages

-- 
David

> > ii  apache         1.3.24-3

> output?

dpkg -l package

> > Here is the sources.list on that box.
> > 
> > deb http://ftp.us.debian.org/debian/ woody main
> > deb-src http://ftp.us.debian.org/debian/ woody main
> > deb http://non-us.debian.org/debian-non-US woody/non-US main
> > deb-src http://non-us.debian.org/debian-non-US woody/non-US main
> > deb http://security.debian.org/ stable/updates main
> 
> 
> This is identical to my sources.list except s/woody/testing/ and
> s/stable/testing/ on the last line.

This should be ok.

> I did have an issue at install where the wrong sources.list was installed,
> but I put in the right data and ran apt-get dist-upgrade.  I don't believe
> anything was even installed while those sources were active.  but the
> data's in my database.  How can I purge the apt cache and download a fresh
> list without harming the db of installed software?
>

This may sound stupid, but you did run apt-get update? Nevermind... it
is. :)

What packages were you trying to install? Maybe you hit a package that's
there but is not updated yet. How did you do the update? 

Here is some info I got from apt the bot on OpenProjects #debian

potato->woody

apt> it has been said that potato->woody is edit /etc/apt/sources.list,
changing all non-local mentions of "potato" or "stable" (except
security.debian.org) to "woody" (examples: ask me about "woody
sources.list"). Then "apt-get update", "apt-get install apt-utils
debconf dpkg" and "apt-get dist-upgrade", et voila! Also, ask me about
"woody install warnings".

woody install warnings

<apt> woody install warnings is, like, ask me about "install xf4" if
your startx is missing, or ask about "libdb3 problem" if you're getting
libdb.so.3 errors, or try "apt-get install perl perl-5.6-base libperl5.6
debconf apt-utils" for miscellaneous perl issues, or "apt-get install
man-db" if man disappears, or until woody's released,
/etc/apt/sources.list must say "woody" and not "stable", so check that.

HTH,

Jeff

alexandria:~# dpkg -l perl apache perl-base
Desired=Unknown/Install/Remove/Purge/Hold
| Status=Not/Installed/Config-files/Unpacked/Failed-config/Half-installed
|/ Err?=(none)/Hold/Reinst-required/X=both-problems
(Status,Err: uppercase=bad)
||/ Name           Version        Description
+++-==============-==============-============================================
pn  perl           <none>         (no description available)
pn  apache         <none>         (no description available)
ii  perl-base      5.6.1-7        The Pathologically Eclectic Rubbish Lister.

When I check the version of the perl package available (using dselect... I
can't get apt-cache to give me the info I want on that package), it says
5.005.  So clearly, the problem here is that the perl packages are showing
old versions and perl-base doesn't seem to provide perl (even though it
clearly does).

Oddly enough, on another system that was installed exactly the same way
(same floppies and everything), I don't have this problem (I just checked:

jeme at barrel:~$ dpkg -l perl|grep ^ii
ii  perl           5.6.1-7        Larry Wall's Practical Extraction and Report

So that's fine).

So it was something during the installation... like that brief moment
where I had the wrong sources.list, but didn't actually install anything
(though I may have run an update or something to modify the cache without
updating the packages themselves).

From bill at coho.net  Thu Jun 13 16:55:03 2002
From: bill at coho.net (Bill)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 16:55:03 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Adding disk partitions to an existing system
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206131628510.32119-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206131634490.1870-100000@ns1.billmercer.com>

On Thu, 13 Jun 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

Jeme and other helpful souls--I probably made the partition table for 
this puppy with W2k's fdisk (it's been a while).  What I've done so far is 
to juggle swap partitions to where my current swap partition is in the 
same physical location on the disk but is now a primary partition (I 
actually didn't plan to do it that way, but I found after making a 
new swap partition and turning it on I had my disk sliced up in a bad way, 
with non-contiguous free space that I couldn't put in an extended partition, so 
I juggled things around with a minimum of good planning until I had a 
usable setup).

I now have

(output from fdisk -l)
Disk /dev/hda: 128 heads, 63 sectors, 969 cylinders
Units = cylinders of 8064 * 512 bytes

   Device Boot    Start       End    Blocks   Id  System
/dev/hda1           919       969    205632   82  Linux swap
/dev/hda2             1       406   1636960+   5  Extended
/dev/hda4   *       407       918   2064384   83  Linux
/dev/hda5   *         1       194    782145   83  Linux
/dev/hda6           195       267    294304+  83  Linux
/dev/hda7           268       340    294304+  83  Linux
/dev/hda8           341       406    266080+  83  Linux

A mess I know, but workable.  All I have mounted right now is 
hda4 
with hda1 as the working swap space.  Now, what do I do to get my new 
linux partitions (hda5-8) formatted as ext2?  I know this sounds ignorant, 
but I am a bit puzzled.  Also, what is the preferred method for copying 
whole directories, since I wanna get the entire current contents of /var 
and /tmp into hda6&7, and presumably permissions and symlinks gotta stay 
absolutely the same?

I understand that once I have the formatting and copying done, I can 
update /etc/fstab and 
rm -rf /tmp && mount /tmp
or do i need 
rm -rf /tmp && mkdir /tmp && mount /tmp 
to make the directory where I'm a-gonna mount the new partition?

Many thanks,


Bill













 
> Depends on which bootloader you're using.  If it's lilo, edit
> /etc/lilo.conf so that one of the sections reads boot=<your boot device>
> and run lilo as root.
> 
> Realize that lilo can be configured with its boot block on a particular
> partition or in the MBR of the disk.  If you want lilo to install in the
> MBR, you've got to give the raw device for the disk (/dev/hda instead of
> /dev/hda[0-9]).
> 
> 
> Anyway, that's how I'd do things on a home network.
> J.
> 




From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jun 13 18:26:32 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 18:26:32 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Adding disk partitions to an existing system
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206131634490.1870-100000@ns1.billmercer.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206131804340.383-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 13 Jun 2002, Bill wrote:
> On Thu, 13 Jun 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> Jeme and other helpful souls

I'm not sure if the word "other" is appropriate here.

> I now have
> 
> (output from fdisk -l)
> Disk /dev/hda: 128 heads, 63 sectors, 969 cylinders
> Units = cylinders of 8064 * 512 bytes
> 
>    Device Boot    Start       End    Blocks   Id  System
> /dev/hda1           919       969    205632   82  Linux swap
> /dev/hda2             1       406   1636960+   5  Extended
> /dev/hda4   *       407       918   2064384   83  Linux
> /dev/hda5   *         1       194    782145   83  Linux
> /dev/hda6           195       267    294304+  83  Linux
> /dev/hda7           268       340    294304+  83  Linux
> /dev/hda8           341       406    266080+  83  Linux

Again, for the purpose of consistent, on-topic followups, I'll recap.

/dev/hda4 is mounted as /, /dev/hda1 is swap.  /dev/hda5-8 are new and
contain nothing useful.

What's /dev/hda2 again?

> Now, what do I do to get my new linux partitions (hda5-8) formatted as
> ext2?

Most basically?

mkfs -t ext2 /dev/hda5

If, for some reason, you don't have a mkfs script, you can do
mkfs.ext2 /dev/hda5
or
mke2fs /dev/hda5
and that should work.

> I know this sounds ignorant, but I am a bit puzzled.

Ignorance is ok.  At least you CAN learn.  There are many less fortunate
than yourself.

> Also, what is the preferred method for copying whole directories,
> since I wanna get the entire current contents of /var and /tmp into
> hda6&7, and presumably permissions and symlinks gotta stay absolutely
> the same?

mount /dev/hda5 /mnt
tar clpsvC /tmp .|tar xlpsv /mnt

Should that do it?

I haven't tested that.  Don't trust me.

> I understand that once I have the formatting and copying done, I can 
> update /etc/fstab and 
> rm -rf /tmp && mount /tmp
> or do i need 
> rm -rf /tmp && mkdir /tmp && mount /tmp 
> to make the directory where I'm a-gonna mount the new partition?

Heh.  Caught me there.  Yeah, you'll have to mkdir the damned thing first.

But as was pointed out earlier, you don't have to blow away the contents
before mounting something on top.  mount will just make the new mountpoint
and ignore any other pointers to data in /tmp that isn't at the new
mountpoint.  Does that make sense?

So you can have something like this:
Host:/$ ls /tmp
foo
bar
Host:/$ mount /dev/hdb2 /tmp
Host:/$ ls /tmp
baz
Host:/$ umount /tmp
Host:/$ ls /tmp
foo
bar

Dig?

So you can do the rm after you know everything works.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From rsteff at attbi.com  Thu Jun 13 20:39:46 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 20:39:46 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Reply from Sen. Wyden on S. 2048
Message-ID: <3D096582.415BD03@attbi.com>

Several weeks back we had a thread on the "Consumer Broadband and
digital Television Promotion Act (S. 2048)" in which a number of us
talked about contacting our elected national representatives. I sent the
same information to Senators Smith and Wyden and to Representative
Hooley. In each case, I sent my comments via the e-mail interface on the
respective legislator's web page. I received a snail mail reply from
each, although spaced a good bit apart. First came a letter from Senator
Smith, then one from Representative Hooley. Today I heard from Senator
Wyden.

In the cases of both Senator Smith and Representative Hooley, I received
polite, non-commital replys. Senator Smith's reply was pretty much a
form letter that simply acknowledged receipt of my comments.
Representative Hooley's reply restated my concerns, but was otherwise
non-coommital. Today's letter from Senator Wyden was better thought-out.
In 4 paragraphs, the letter not only restates my concerns, but also
states Senator Wyden's position. Here are the last two paragraphs of his
letter to me:

  The issue of digital content protection has raised significant
  questions about our copyright regime as we struggle to determine
  whether and how existing intellectual property laws can adapt to the
  changing environment in this digital age. It seems clear to me that
  the distribution of media over the Internet is an exciting development
  that we cannot and should not try to block. Like you, I am wary of
  having government dictate specific technology standards, because there
  is a risk of locking in an inflexible, one-size-fits-all approach. I
  am also concerned about the possibility that the new protections could
  erode or undermine existing consumer rights to fair use. At the same
  time, we do need to make sure that the legitimate rights of those who
  create such medea are protected.

  Please rest assured that as the Senate debates this issue, I will keep
  your views in mind. Thank you again for keeping me apprised of the
  issues that are important to you."

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
"Quando Omni Flunkus Moritati"
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/




From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Jun 13 20:57:03 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 20:57:03 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Editing PDF files
Message-ID: <233535696.1024027012141.JavaMail.root@monkey>

PostScript is its own stack-based formatting language, (Reverse Polish
Notation on HP calculators is also stack-based, to give you the feel for
it.)  Most of the stuff at the beginning of auto-generated PostScript is
meaningless headers, definitions that are never used, and a bunch of other
junk.

It *is* its own language, so unless you think it would be "neat" to learn
it, you're probably better off just getting the Adobe software.

Some handy links for more information:
http://astronomy.swin.edu.au/~pbourke/dataformats/postscript/
http://www.cs.indiana.edu/docproject/programming/postscript/postscript.html

  -- Steve

On Thu, 13 Jun 2002, Dhruva B. Reddy bdhruva at gmx.net XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

> Forgot to add that I tried to edit this in emacs, using the PostScript
> mode that came with it.
> 
> On Thu, Jun 13, 2002 at 07:23:11AM -0600, quoth Dhruva B. Reddy:
> > I just tried to convert a PDF document to PostScript (using pdf2ps)
> > (http://www.indianconsulate-sf.org/visa/visaform.pdf).  I don't know
> > anything about PostScript--I expected to find the text of the document
> > in there.  Did I do something wrong?
> > 
> > On Thu, Jun 13, 2002 at 01:11:55AM -0700, quoth Steve Bonds:
> > > Heh, I remember sending that OHSU application monstrosity several months
> > > ago.  Never heard back.  Not even a "thanks for sending us that brick of
> > > paper" message.  I figure it was their loss.  ;-)
> > > 
> > > You might try editing the raw PostScript file.  Not the prettiest way to
> > > go about things, but it's definately in the UNIX spirit.  I'm sure some
> > > poor fool has built a lisp PS-mode for Xemacs...
> > > 
> > > I recall seeing a Perl module that parses PostScript.  I have not tried it
> > > though.  My motivation to save my DMV fill-in PDFs in a permanent form
> > > gave out before I actually put it to use.
> > > 
> > > In any case I would avoid converting it to an image format.  It will not
> > > look good when printed when compared to the crisp text of the original
> > > PDF.
> > > 
> > >   -- Steve
> > > 
> > > On Wed, 12 Jun 2002, Mark Allyn allyn at well.com XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:
> > > 
> > > >

From dealy at deatech.com  Thu Jun 13 22:45:14 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Thu, 13 Jun 2002 22:45:14 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Debian GNU/Linux "woody" apache/perl problems.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206132155430.1538-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206132231080.5215-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Thu, 13 Jun 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

[snip]
> How can I just blow away the list of available packages without losing the
> list of installed packages?
>
> I assume that regenerating the list of available packages (from only the
> sources in my current sources.list) will solve my problem.
>
> Both the "clean" and "update" commands to apt-get have failed.
[snip]

clean only cleans out the repository of fetched packages, it has nothing
to do with the database.

update just updates the index of available packages

given what I remember from your previous postings, I would try running the
following set of commands in sequence:

   apt-get check
   apt-get update
   apt-get dist-upgrade

after doing this, if you wish to use deselect, after you start deselect,
first select "Access" and verify that it is configured to use "apt", next
run "Update" from within dselect, then go ahead and do your selections or
examine the configuration.


Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com




From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Jun 13 23:06:47 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 13 Jun 2002 23:06:47 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian GNU/Linux "woody" apache/perl problems.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206132155430.1538-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206132155430.1538-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <863cvq9yx4.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

Jeme> How can I just blow away the list of available packages without
Jeme> losing the list of installed packages?

Jeme> I assume that regenerating the list of available packages (from
Jeme> only the sources in my current sources.list) will solve my
Jeme> problem.

I *think* that "apt-get update" is effectively just downloading the
contents of some files on the source site to a file called
/var/lib/dpkg/available.  The "list of installed packages" is stored
in the "^Status:" field of /var/lib/dpkg/status.  If you've got a
"working" system to compare, you might try "diff"ing these files
between systems.

I don't think "dpkg -i foo" can damage your system.  If installed
packages rely on something that "dpkg -i" would mutate away, dpkg
should let you know about it.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``The two chiefs turned to each other.        
seniorr at aracnet.com      Bellison uncorked a flood of horrible       
                         profanity, which, translated meant, `This is
                         extremely unusual.' ''                      



From bl.nordlund at verizon.net  Thu Jun 13 23:13:23 2002

References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206131017020.26593-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

So far, I have still struck out, even with all the good suggestions.
However, the "/sbin/chkconfig telnet on" resulted in a log entry that might
be the clue I need.  One of the lines resulting from "tail -n 40
/var/log/messages" reads as follows:

(date) (host name) xinetd[26042] service telnet missing attribute server

Does this give me a direction to look?

Thanks for all help so far,
Brian.


----- Original Message -----
From: Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>
To: <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>
Sent: Thursday, June 13, 2002 10:24 AM
Subject: Re: [PLUG] New Install won't let me Telnet, FTP, or http


> On Thu, 13 Jun 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:
>
> > Either that, or install the telnet-server RPM, which adds that file,
> > and some others. Then, change the "disabled =" line.
> >
> > For a console app to change these things, try "ntsysv". Works in
> > Redhat and Mandrake, others too.
>
> The chkconfig utility that ships with Red Hat can be used to manage
> xinetd services, too:
>
>   # list what chkconfig can manage
>   /sbin/chkconfig --list
>
>   # tweak /etc/xinetd.d/telnet to turn on telnet server and HUP xinetd
>   # to activate it
>   /sbin/chkconfig telnet on
>
>   # check syslog to make sure we got what we wanted
>   tail -n 40 /var/log/messages
>
> At that point, you can edit /etc/xinetd.d/telnet to add, say,
> host-based exclusions using "only_from" or "no_access" directives. The
> xinetd.conf(5) man page is helpful in that regard.
>
> --Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug




From dan at headzofstate.com  Thu Jun 13 23:38:03 2002
From: dan at headzofstate.com (Dan Stone)
Date: 13 Jun 2002 23:38:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] New Install won't let me Telnet, FTP, or http
In-Reply-To: <001501c2136a$9722da20$021ea8c0@nisse>
References: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0206131017020.26593-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> 
	<001501c2136a$9722da20$021ea8c0@nisse>
Message-ID: <1024036684.651.22.camel@musashi>

> So far, I have still struck out, even with all the good suggestions.
> However, the "/sbin/chkconfig telnet on" resulted in a log entry that might
> be the clue I need.  One of the lines resulting from "tail -n 40
> /var/log/messages" reads as follows:
> 
> (date) (host name) xinetd[26042] service telnet missing attribute server
> 
> Does this give me a direction to look?
> 
> Thanks for all help so far,
> Brian.
> 
> 

Well, I'd say it's a good indicator of something going wrong.  The
server attribute in /etc/xinetd.conf tells xinetd what program to
execute to invoke that particular service.  Open up xinetd.conf with the
editor of your choice, and search for "service telnet"...see what the
entry for it looks like =)

~Dan A. Stone

From mindglow at dsl-only.net  Fri Jun 14 05:31:32 2002
From: mindglow at dsl-only.net (Doug Davis)
Date: 14 Jun 2002 05:31:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] New Install won't let me Telnet, FTP, or http
In-Reply-To: <001501c2136a$9722da20$021ea8c0@nisse>
References: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0206131017020.26593-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> 
	<001501c2136a$9722da20$021ea8c0@nisse>
Message-ID: <1024057893.28151.5.camel@sneaker.got-roots.com>

On Thu, 2002-06-13 at 23:13, Brian & Lori Nordlund wrote:
>  One of the lines resulting from "tail -n 40
> /var/log/messages" reads as follows:
> 
> (date) (host name) xinetd[26042] service telnet missing attribute server
> 
> Does this give me a direction to look?
> 
Sounds to me like you don't have the telnet server rpm installed. What
does rpm -qa | grep telnet show you? Ive got to ask though...is there a
real need for you to use telnet and ftp? A better alternative would be
to use a secure alternative like ssh and sftp. Telnet and ftp send all
their info in clear text and shouldn't be used if you control the box (
which it sounds like you do) This is even more true if you offer these
services over the internet. Once the ssh suite is set up, it is
functionally the same as the insecure alternatives.

Doug

Microsoft accidentally distributes virus

By Robert Lemos
Staff Writer, CNET News.com
June 14, 2002, 10:35 AM PT

update Microsoft accidentally sent the virulent Nimda worm to South Korean 
developers when it distributed Korean-language versions of Visual Studio .Net 
that carried the virus, the company acknowledged Friday.

Microsoft's flagship developer tools picked up the digital pest when a 
third-party company translated the program into Korean, said Christopher 
Flores, lead product manager for Visual Studio .Net. Flores stressed that no 
other foreign-language versions of the program were found to carry the worm, 
and he said the worm had not actually executed on any developers' systems. ...

From rkurth at starband.net  Fri Jun 14 21:32:23 2002
From: rkurth at starband.net (Richard Kurth)
Date: Fri, 14 Jun 2002 21:32:23 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] setting up a network
Message-ID: <149107601242.20020614213223@starband.net>

I have a network set up using a hub on my primary computer the one
that is connected to the Internet I am running win2000 Then I have a win
98 computer connected to the hub and the last computer I have connected
is running RedHat Linux 7.2. My question is how do I set Apache up on
the Linux server so that I can access it with a browser from the
windows box. What server name would I add to the http.conf file and
any thing else I need to make this just like I was accessing a server
on the web. I can access the server with telnet with no problem.

  

-- 
Best regards,
 Richard                          mailto:rkurth at starband.net




From mikedela at ipns.com  Fri Jun 14 21:34:08 2002
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Fri, 14 Jun 2002 21:34:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] setting up a network
In-Reply-To: <149107601242.20020614213223@starband.net>
Message-ID: <HE87VPRZTIH641ZD8D8MJMECEDHDZV.3d0ac3c0@miked>

You can use the ip address of the RH box, like http://192.168.10.10 if you want, 
it doesn't need a name, unless you want one. You must use the htp:// on the IP 
address for it to access by IP. You can enter the ip in hosts.conf on your 
winboxen so they don't need DNS.

Mike

From robbert at vafam.com  Fri Jun 14 22:34:28 2002
From: robbert at vafam.com (Robbert van Andel)
Date: Fri, 14 Jun 2002 22:34:28 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Screenshots
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206142204170.19654-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <000001c2142e$529039b0$6401a8c0@robbert>

Is there a way to make screenshots like you can on Windows with the
Print Screen button, either key combination or program?

Robbert van Andel




From bhoran at hexdev.com  Fri Jun 14 23:11:25 2002
From: bhoran at hexdev.com (Brian Horan)
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 02:11:25 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] Screenshots
In-Reply-To: <000001c2142e$529039b0$6401a8c0@robbert>
References: <000001c2142e$529039b0$6401a8c0@robbert>
Message-ID: <E17J6Pr-0004XR-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

you can do it with Gimp and save it as any format you want, or use the 
following:

xwd -root -out filename
# generates an X window dump
# or import
import -window root root.jpeg
# will dump the screenshot to a jpeg file

On Saturday 15 June 2002 01:34 am, you wrote:
> Is there a way to make screenshots like you can on Windows with the
> Print Screen button, either key combination or program?
>
> Robbert van Andel
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

Brian Horan

From m at netpro.to  Fri Jun 14 23:25:01 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Fri, 14 Jun 2002 23:25:01 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] setting up a network
In-Reply-To: <149107601242.20020614213223@starband.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206142323010.5308-100000@lukem.com>

The simplest method would be to make up a name for your webserver and put
it and the server's IP address in the hosts file on your Windoze boxes.
So, for example, your hosts file could contain:

myhappyfunserver	192.168.1.100

Then you can browse to http://myhappyfunserver to access your files.


On Fri, 14 Jun 2002, Richard Kurth wrote:

>
> I have a network set up using a hub on my primary computer the one
> that is connected to the Internet I am running win2000 Then I have a win
> 98 computer connected to the hub and the last computer I have connected
> is running RedHat Linux 7.2. My question is how do I set Apache up on

The file is called "hosts" and it's in some obscure location like
C:\winnt\system32\drivers\etc on Win2K, if I remember correctly.

Use the Windows search utility to find it on your Win98 box.

From cccs at teleport.com  Sat Jun 15 01:39:18 2002
From: cccs at teleport.com (Rick Konold)
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 01:39:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Screenshots
In-Reply-To: <000001c2142e$529039b0$6401a8c0@robbert>
References: <000001c2142e$529039b0$6401a8c0@robbert>
Message-ID: <E17J9Cg-00022V-00@epic.mail.pas.earthlink.net>

On Friday 14 June 2002 22:34, you hammered the keyboard to write:
> Is there a way to make screenshots like you can on Windows with the
> Print Screen button, either key combination or program?
>
> Robbert van Andel

You did not say what Dist/ver or Desktop you are running.  I am running RH7.2 
with Gnome.  I just went through the menu [ Applets > Utility > 
ScreenShooter] to add the screenshooter applet to my panel.  It creates two 
icons in a box on your panel.  The left will give you cross-hairs to select 
any part of the screen and the one on the right will just select the whole 
screen.  It saves your selection to your home directory with a date/time 
stamp as a jpeg file.  There are other settings you can tweak, including 
adding a border, if you right click on the applet.  Hope that helps.

Rick Konold ~~ Linux Advocate



From jeff at jhenshaw.com  Fri Jun 14 19:25:43 2002
From: jeff at jhenshaw.com (J Henshaw)
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 02:25:43 -0000
Subject: [PLUG] SQL DB structure question
References: <200206142126.g5ELQob22404@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <004001c21413$f32cf860$0400a8c0@oem2k>

Don't they have books for this stuff?
So far I haven't heard mentioned any book,  perhaps one that is looked to as
a required reading for DBA types,  such as the O'Reilly "Cricket" book is to
BIND and DNS...

If they do,  I would sure hope they address the BASICS like this stuff:


> Assume that all tables in DB have the same number of columns e.g.10.
> What is better for DB performance to have few of bigger/longer tables
> or lot of smaller/shorter tables?





From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Sat Jun 15 02:57:26 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 02:57:26 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] SQL DB structure question
Message-ID: <1132851136.1024135037905.JavaMail.root@monkey>

The answer, as with most database performance questions, is "it depends".

If you are doing a lot of full table reads then the single larger table is
going to perform better.  If the accesses are indexed and fairly
randomized then the shorter tables can perform better.

The best answer is to try both and measure the performance given your
database software, your data access patterns, on your server.

Some databases provide the ability to simulate and/or test different
configurations.  (i.e. Oracle "EXPLAIN PLAN" and related commands.)

  -- Steve

On Fri, 14 Jun 2002, Alex Daniloff alex at daniloff.com XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

> Hello Linux folkz,
> 
> Could somebody experienced in SQL DB answer this question.
> Assume that all tables in DB have the same number of columns e.g.10.
> What is better for DB performance to have few of bigger/longer tables 
> or lot of smaller/shorter tables?
> Thanks in advance for any responses.
> 
> Alex 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Sat Jun 15 03:00:25 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 03:00:25 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Screenshots
Message-ID: <265631217.1024136417053.JavaMail.root@monkey>

I usually use the Gimp with the single-window capture on about a 3 second
delay.  Start the timer, highlight the window you want and magically it
appears in the Gimp when the timer expires.

I always save screenshots as PNG files or a similar non-lossily compressed
format.  JPEG blurs the nice sharp edges of your screenshot and makes it
look like crap and will actually have a larger image size than the PNG
file for images with large areas of the same color.  (JPEG is better for
images with lots of tonal transitions and areas of varying color--
i.e. photographs.)

  -- Steve

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Jun 15 07:33:32 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 07:33:32 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] SQL DB structure question
In-Reply-To: <004001c21413$f32cf860$0400a8c0@oem2k>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206150720000.20844-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Sat, 15 Jun 2002, J Henshaw wrote:

> Don't they have books for this stuff?

  Yes, there are many textbooks out on database design and structure.

  An (old) book that I found very useful is McFadden & Hoffer's "Database
Management", Third Ed. (1991). I'm sure the more current books are even
better.

> > Assume that all tables in DB have the same number of columns e.g.10.
> > What is better for DB performance to have few of bigger/longer tables
> > or lot of smaller/shorter tables?

  Unfortunately, this is the wrong question. The focus of this thread
appears to be optimizing disk reads (and, perhaps, writes) to the physical
file structure on disk. Every database book I've read, and all the
discussions in which I've been involved in the past couple of decades, focus
on optimizing the logical structure of the database; i.e., normalizing to
third or fourth Normal Form, and when to violate those rules.

  Physical -- hardware -- access will vary with the components installed.
Performance tuning is almost always a function of database logical structure
because that determines how data are accessed or written. Most folks select
the dbms backend based on features they require or want and allow that
backend to control the writing and reading of data on and off the hard
drives. The dbms programmer can then focus on the system schema and writing
the most efficient SQL statements to query the data and maintain as many of
Cobb's 12 rules for data integrity as are implemented in the software.

Rich







From paynoattention at anarchysoftware.com  Sat Jun 15 07:52:33 2002
From: paynoattention at anarchysoftware.com (Richard Seymour)
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 07:52:33 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Ipchains question
Message-ID: <3D0B54B1.501@anarchysoftware.com>

I have the following chunk of rules in my firewall:


# Enable logging for selected denied packets
ipchains -A input  -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p tcp \
                    -d $IPADDR -l -j DENY
ipchains -A input  -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p udp \
               -d $IPADDR $PRIVPORTS -l -j DENY
ipchains -A input  -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p udp \
               -d $IPADDR $UNPRIVPORTS -l -j DENY
ipchains -A input  -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p icmp \
               -s $ANYWHERE 5 -d $IPADDR -l -j DENY
ipchains -A input  -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p icmp \
               -s $ANYWHERE 13:18 -d $IPADDR -l -j DENY

I also have a summary of my logs emailed to me daily. I've been getting 
so many hits on port 1433 (some SQL server exploit thingy), that it's 
getting hard to ready the summary emails. I'd like to keep denying port 
1433, but NOT log it.

What's the proper way to do this?

--

From collord at linuxfund.org  Sat Jun 15 09:09:48 2002
From: collord at linuxfund.org (Jerritt Collord)
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 09:09:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Editing PDF files
In-Reply-To: <233535696.1024027012141.JavaMail.root@monkey>
References: <233535696.1024027012141.JavaMail.root@monkey>
Message-ID: <20020615090948.56bb36c5.collord@linuxfund.org>

I usually do PDF --(pdf2ps)--> PS --(pstoedit)--> SK or AI, then use Sketch to import and then place text and when done take it to PS or PDF again. Of course SK or AI could be SVG or FIG or whatnot and you use sodipodi or xfig or whatnot--and there's a whole diversity of whatnot. 

The quality varies in the pstoedit portion of the game seems to depend on which backend it is and how complicated the .ps is.

The main goal is to avoid rasterizing it, which even in the above chain is sometimes tricky depending on what fonts the PDF uses... under some conditions Ghostscript rasterizes certain characters for fonts it doesn't deal well with.

Doesn't the xfig picture import even from a .ps/.eps rasterize it?

Jerritt

From sharbours at yahoo.com  Sat Jun 15 10:20:11 2002
From: sharbours at yahoo.com (Sean, Sharon and Kyle Harbour)
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 10:20:11 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Cisco PIX firewall DMZ and Redhat 7.3
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206151003230.15650-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20020615172011.65289.qmail@web14407.mail.yahoo.com>

I have a strange problem. I've got a Redhat 7.3 box plugged directly
into a DMZ port on a Cisco PIX. Everything is fine until I reboot the
Redhat box, then it refuses to bring up eth0 because it detects
another host using the assigned address, even though it is the only
box in the DMZ at this point. If I unplug the cable while booting,
then plug it back in, it works fine. This happened at quitting time
on Friday, and it's not a production server yet, so I let it go for
now. I'll put a sniffer on it to see whats going on Monday, but it
seems like the box is detecting a response from the PIX when
initializing the interface. Has anybody run into this before? Is
there a way to force an interface to come up with a certain IP
address, even if another host on the subnet is already using it?
The DMZ gateway is 172.16.1.65, the server is
172.16.1.66/255.255.255.224

Sean Harbour


__________________________________________________
Do You Yahoo!?
Yahoo! - Official partner of 2002 FIFA World Cup
http://fifaworldcup.yahoo.com



From dealy at deatech.com  Sat Jun 15 10:20:31 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 10:20:31 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Ipchains question
In-Reply-To: <3D0B54B1.501@anarchysoftware.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206151004220.4162-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Sat, 15 Jun 2002, Richard Seymour wrote:

[snip]
> # Enable logging for selected denied packets
> ipchains -A input  -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p tcp \
>                     -d $IPADDR -l -j DENY
> ipchains -A input  -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p udp \
>                -d $IPADDR $PRIVPORTS -l -j DENY
> ipchains -A input  -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p udp \
>                -d $IPADDR $UNPRIVPORTS -l -j DENY
> ipchains -A input  -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p icmp \
>                -s $ANYWHERE 5 -d $IPADDR -l -j DENY
> ipchains -A input  -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -p icmp \
>                -s $ANYWHERE 13:18 -d $IPADDR -l -j DENY
[snip]
> getting hard to ready the summary emails. I'd like to keep denying port
> 1433, but NOT log it.
[snip]

Insert a line like the following into your firewall script before the
rules which log the packets:

  ipchains -A input  -i $EXTERNAL_INTERFACE -dport 1433 -j DENY

alternatively, you can probably configure whichever log reporting program
you are using (which sends you the email) to ignore the port 1433
messages.  Unless it is literally overloading your hard drive, I would be
inclined to not muck with the firewall, and just filter what is emailed to
you, otherwise you will be regularly tinkering with the firewall script as
each new exploit is introduced, and the more often you tinker with it, the
greater the chance of a mistake which leaves you open to attack.

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com




From m at netpro.to  Sat Jun 15 10:49:27 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 10:49:27 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Cisco PIX firewall DMZ and Redhat 7.3
In-Reply-To: <20020615172011.65289.qmail@web14407.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206151030450.19576-100000@lukem.com>

Unplug the new server and try pinging 172.16.1.66 from another box within
your DMZ.  If you get a response, then you've either got another server
with the same IP address or you've inadvertently assigned .66 to your DMZ
interface.  I've worked a lot with the Cisco PIX, so let me know if you
need any help configuring your rules between the inside, outside, dmz, and
any other interfaces you might have.
~M

From m at netpro.to  Sat Jun 15 10:58:20 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 10:58:20 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Cisco PIX firewall DMZ and Redhat 7.3
In-Reply-To: <20020615172011.65289.qmail@web14407.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206151049540.22204-100000@lukem.com>

Frick...  sorry...  I just reread your post and you said the RH box was
the only box in the DMZ.  Do a "write mem" and then "show config" and see
if you've got 172.16.1.66 assigned anywhere.  You can try pinging the .66
address from the PIX as well (make sure to specify which interface to
ping on).  Also, your "inside" interface should be at a higher security
level than your "dmz" interface, so you could try pinging 172.16.1.66 from
a computer on the inside, assuming you've configured your PIX properly for
the DMZ.
If you'd like, you could give me access to your PIX and I'll poke around
and let you know if I find anything unusual.  :-)
~M


On Sat, 15 Jun 2002, Sean, Sharon and Kyle Harbour wrote:

> I have a strange problem. I've got a Redhat 7.3 box plugged directly
> into a DMZ port on a Cisco PIX. Everything is fine until I reboot the
> Redhat box, then it refuses to bring up eth0 because it detects
> another host using the assigned address, even though it is the only
> box in the DMZ at this point. If I unplug the cable while booting,
> then plug it back in, it works fine. This happened at quitting time
> on Friday, and it's not a production server yet, so I let it go for
> now. I'll put a sniffer on it to see whats going on Monday, but it
> seems like the box is detecting a response from the PIX when
> initializing the interface. Has anybody run into this before? Is
> there a way to force an interface to come up with a certain IP
> address, even if another host on the subnet is already using it?
> The DMZ gateway is 172.16.1.65, the server is
> 172.16.1.66/255.255.255.224
>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Jun 15 18:17:08 2002

  Today I noticed that when I shut down my notebook and start it up again
the date changes to March 26, 2002 and some time early in the morning. It
used to hold the date regardless of whether it was plugged in or not, on or
off.

  Any suggestions what might cause this loss of date and time? I keep the

wonder what it might be. The unit's a Toshiba Portege 3025CT.

TIA,

Rich





From briand at aracnet.com  Sat Jun 15 18:50:36 2002
From: briand at aracnet.com (briand at aracnet.com)
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 18:50:36 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Not so portable time
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206151816120.21516-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206151816120.21516-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <15627.61164.945147.282940@soggy.deldotd.com>

CMOS clocks have a back-up battery.  Yours is having trouble.  I have
had this problem once on a motherboard.  They were using a weird
battery size so it was a pain to find a new one.

If you are lucky it may just be the connection to the battery,
i.e. the clip has lost some of its spring or some other mechanical
problem.

Brian

From dealy at deatech.com  Sat Jun 15 20:07:01 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 20:07:01 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Not so portable time
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206151905560.21516-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Sat, 15 Jun 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

[snip]
>   Thanks, Brian. I wondered if that was the problem. Now to dig out the
> manual and see where the battery is hidden.
>

A little warning, some systems don't have a battery as such, it is built
into the chip that provides the real-time clock and is supposed to last
ten years, though sometimes they don't.  If this is the case, you may not
be able to do anything other than send the unit in for repair, in which
case I hope it is still under warranty.

   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com




From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Sat Jun 15 13:20:03 2002
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 20:20:03 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] 64-bit programming
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206151905560.21516-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206151905560.21516-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200206160311.g5G3BW925012@smtp.easystreet.com>

Any thoughts on programming for a 64-bit cpu like the Itanium, other than it 
sounds like a speech impediment? Are there practical reasons? Kylix is 
strictly IA32, and may someday support 64-bit cpus. Then again, maybe not. 
gcc of course has IA64 and Alpha support. I'm wondering does it really matter 
in these days of distributed computing and low-cost clusters and SMP, why 
complicate things by introducing yet another complication? Just string a herd 
a them IA32s together.

Thanks,
Carla



From paynoattention at anarchysoftware.com  Sat Jun 15 20:35:11 2002
From: paynoattention at anarchysoftware.com (Richard Seymour)
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 20:35:11 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Not so portable time
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206152002420.6879-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <3D0C076F.5040201@anarchysoftware.com>

Shannon C. Dealy wrote:
> On Sat, 15 Jun 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:
> 
> [snip]
> 
>>  Thanks, Brian. I wondered if that was the problem. Now to dig out the
>>manual and see where the battery is hidden.
>>
> 
> 
> A little warning, some systems don't have a battery as such, it is built
> into the chip that provides the real-time clock and is supposed to last
> ten years, though sometimes they don't.  If this is the case, you may not
> be able to do anything other than send the unit in for repair, in which
> case I hope it is still under warranty.

Yep. We run into this at FREE GEEK all the time, especially on low end 
pentiums. Look first for a silver colored "button" battery. If you find 
it (and it's not soldered on), you're in luck. If you can't find one, 
look for a rectangular boxy dark grey square that may of may no be 
marked "ODIN" or "DALLAS". Example at:

http://dbserv.maxim-ic.com/images/timekeeping.jpg

Sometimes these can be replaced. Often not. (I saw one Sparc with a 
Lithium button battery soldered on as a hardware kludge.)

There may also be a jumper on the board that lets you hook up to another 
battery.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Jun 15 21:19:40 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 21:19:40 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux overseas
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206152112330.22434-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  To put the K12linux and FreeGeek projects in perspective, here's some
information from the July Linux Journal that showed up today [1]:

	The government of Extremadura, a rural area called the poorest in
Spain, burned 80,000 cds with Debian linux so the discs could be distributed
as newspaper inserts.

	There are 670 schools in Extremadura.

	There are 32 technology centers in Extremadura.

	The expected annual savings to the Extremaduran community is $7
million.

	The number of government offices and schools expected in the
Extremadura extranet by the end of this year is 1,478.

	There are 15,000 teachers expected to be trained on the use of linux
in the classroom.

Rich

[1] Those of you with your own subscriptions can skip this message and read
it in the magazine.

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Sat Jun 15 22:45:44 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 22:45:44 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] 64-bit programming
In-Reply-To: <200206160311.g5G3BW925012@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.31.0206152153370.1170-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Carla -

There's an excellent paper on this topic, entitled "The myths and
realities of 64-bit computing" [1].

To summarize, the purpose of 64-bit computing is to provide a
64-bit address space, so you can use more than 4 GB of memory. A
64-bit processor will not by itself provide any increase in performance;
in fact, the performance of your program will be hurt slightly because
your pointers must occupy twice as much space in the cache, reducing the
hit ratio.

The ability to perform single instruction arithmetic on gigantic numbers
can also be useful, in some rare applications. Usually however, 64 bit
data operands are disabled in favor of 32-bit, again to free up the cache.

1. http://www.anandtech.com/guides/viewfaq.html?i=112


Tyler

____________________________
Tyler F. Creelan
College of Engineering
Oregon State University
http://www.cs.orst.edu/~creelan/

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Sun Jun 16 08:36:06 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Sun, 16 Jun 2002 08:36:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Not so portable time 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Sat, 15 Jun 2002 20:35:11 PDT."
             <3D0C076F.5040201@anarchysoftware.com> 
Message-ID: <200206161536.g5GFa6t29500@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> 
> Yep. We run into this at FREE GEEK all the time, especially on low end 
> pentiums. Look first for a silver colored "button" battery. If you find 
> it (and it's not soldered on), you're in luck. If you can't find one, 
> look for a rectangular boxy dark grey square that may of may no be 
> marked "ODIN" or "DALLAS". Example at:
> 
> http://dbserv.maxim-ic.com/images/timekeeping.jpg
> 
> Sometimes these can be replaced. Often not. (I saw one Sparc with a 
> Lithium button battery soldered on as a hardware kludge.)
> 

That was a very carefully constructed kludge!  I bought a replacement
RTC module.  After installing it, I discovered (by searching the net)
that the clock silicon had been revised slightly, such that the 
firmware in my Sparcstation 2 didn't like it.  Thus I decided to hack
in a new battery instead.

ST Microelectronics is another major manufacturer of battery-backed RTC
modules.  You can buy their parts from Mouser (www.mouser.com).

galen






From due.gatti at gmx.net  Sat Jun 15 19:09:41 2002

From dcf at aracnet.com  Sun Jun 16 10:21:20 2002
From: dcf at aracnet.com (David Fleck)
Date: Sun, 16 Jun 2002 10:21:20 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] CVS Question.
In-Reply-To: <20020615162656.6f690c48.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206161017120.21410-100000@linux.sourballs.org>

On Sat, 15 Jun 2002, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> I hope this isn't too OT, but I figure you folks might know.  Is there a
> way to exclude certain directories from a CVS checkout?  The local
> .cvsignore files only work for local stuff, not directories in the
> repository.  (For example, how do I check out the root without getting
> CVSROOT along with the rest?)

You could put a global cvsignore file (not '.cvsignore') in your CVSROOT
directory, containing the pattern CVSROOT.

(Not that I've tried this, it just seems like it ought to work.)
The cvs.info file entry on cvsignore may contain helpful information.


--
 David Fleck
 dcf at aracnet.com

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sun Jun 16 12:40:25 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Sun, 16 Jun 2002 12:40:25 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] CVS Question.
References: <20020615162656.6f690c48.jason@vancleve.com>	<Pine.LNX.4.33.0206161017120.21410-100000@linux.sourballs.org> <20020616115053.7d41ab9c.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <3D0CE9A9.40407@pacifier.com>

Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> On Sun, 16 Jun 2002 10:21:20 -0700 (PDT)
> David Fleck <dcf at aracnet.com> wrote:
> 
> 
>>You could put a global cvsignore file (not '.cvsignore') in your
>>CVSROOT directory, containing the pattern CVSROOT.
> 
> 
> Thanks, David, but I think that file works on client-side files, as with
> the local ones.  And anyway, I don't want to make it impossible to check
> out any such directory, just to supress it on some clients.  CVSROOT was
> just an example.  I'm actually thinking of other things I've checked in.

Normally, you define modules in (CVSROOT/modules) that list which dir/s are 
aliased to a given name.

(can't remember if you have to create this file the first time or not.)  See 
the docs at cvshome.org.

Kyle Accardi

From shark at sharky.dyndns.org  Sun Jun 16 20:14:31 2002
From: shark at sharky.dyndns.org (Peter W)
Date: 16 Jun 2002 20:14:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Article Proofread
In-Reply-To: <1023849982.7997.15.camel@pookie>
References: <1023849982.7997.15.camel@pookie>
Message-ID: <1024283671.12651.286.camel@sharky>

On Tue, 2002-06-11 at 19:46, D. Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> All;
> 
> I have written an article outlining Linux's capabilities in the server
> room and the desktop.
> 
> I have posted the PDF version and the HTML version here:
> 
>   www.cooper.stevenson.name
> 
> I strongly recommend the PDF version, it is formatted much better.
> 
> Would you proofread this please? Any feedback is greatly appreciated.

Here are a few things I saw.  If there is anything here that I seem
wrong about, I probably am (I suck at writing. ;)).  

All in all, great job!  Things like this could be extremely useful tools
for advocates. ;)


---------------------------------------------------

First: you might want to add a footnote near the beginning explaining
that when you say "Linux" you are really refering to the whole system
(including end user apps) which is sometimes (and "more accuratly")
called "GNU/Linux".  Just say you are calling it Linux for the sake of
brevity.

---------------------------------------------------
Section 2 (Linux TCO):
"...cost is more than offset bye Microsoft's ..."
'bye' s/b 'by'.

Also, below table 1 you say: "Reduced Downtime - Linux reduces cost
through higher reliability."  We all know this is true, but it would be
nice if you had a footnote here pointing doubting readers to a study.
(Sorry I don't have any links to suggest though.)

--------------------------------------------------
Section 4.2 (Email Server):
"This catagory is largely comprised of E-mail and calendar sharing."
Here you mention "calendar sharing", but below in 4.2.2 you mention
"online scheduling".  I now assume those are the same thing(?) but at
first I was confused that "calendar sharing" didn't appear in 4.2.2.   

--------------------------------------------------
Section 4.3 (Web Server):
"Modules such as server-side scripting is installed with a minimum of
hassle." Perhaps this should be "Modules such as server-side scripting
may be installed with a minimum of hassle."
(change "is" to "may be".)

--------------------------------------------------
Section 5 (Linux on the Desktop):
At the bottom of the first paragraph you say, "In fact, entire windowing
systems can be exported from the server".  This is a little confusing I
think.  I think that what is meant is that the system (server, client,
network) can be set up in such a way that all of the applications and
the desktop environment itself is actually running on the server but
just being displayed on the client; but by using the term "entire
windowing system" I am not sure what that means.  Perhaps a better term
would be "entire graphical environment"?

--------------------------------------------------
Section 5.1.1 (StarOffice):
"uses XML file formats so that it's documents can be read across
multiple operating systems"

shouldn't that "it's" be "its"?  

--------------------------------------------------
Section 5.1.2 (OpenOffice):
"...OpenOffice shares many of the features of StarOffice, including
cross-platform document handling including Microsoft Office."
The use of "including" twice is a bit confusing, and maybe "Microsoft
Office" should say "Microsoft Office files".  

So perhaps:
"...OpenOffice shares many of the features of StarOffice, including
cross-platform document handling and the ability to read Microsoft
Office files."

--------------------------------------------------
Section 5.2.1 (Mozilla):
"Mozilla was written from scratch shortly after Netscape released the
source code for its browser."

But Mozilla has at least some code from Netscape Navigator - I believe
that it is only the page rendering engine that was re-written.  Also,
under 5.2 (Internet Apps) it says "Several full-featured Web
browsers..."; maybe the Mozilla sentance should read:

"Mozilla is one of the web browsers available for Linux ^15.5. It is
based on the Netscape Navigator code, although part of its core program
was rewritten in order to fix problems that Netscape was unable to. 
Mozilla features..."

15.5: Mozilla is also available for the Windows and Apple platforms. See
www.mozilla.org.

--------------------------------------------------
Section 5.2.2 (Evolution):

"...ability to run the application remotely..." This seems to be covered
in the first paragraph of Section 5 - maybe you should say "remember
that there is...ability to run the application remotely..." or something
to that effect?

--------------------------------------------------
Section 5.3.1 (CodeWeavers):
"CodeWeavers is an application that allows you..."
might more truthfully read:
"The CodeWeavers company offers applications which allow you..."

then later,
"Other CodeWeavers crossover applications include QuickTime, ShockWave,
Windows Media Player, and others."
could say:
"CodeWeavers also offers Crossover Plugin, supporting applications such
as QuickTime, ShockWave, Windows Media Player, and others."

--------------------------------------------------
Section 5.3.2 (VMWare):

" VMWare is a hardware emulator for the x86 based PC hardware. After you
install VMWare on your computer, clicking VMWare's icon will open a
window showing the memory count of the virtual machine. In effect,
VMWare emulates your computers' hardware. It is a platform to install an
operating system. It is like having a computer inside of a computer."

1) redundancy: "VMWare is a hardware emulator" and "VMWare emulates your
computers' hardware" (+ "computers'" s/b "computer's" maybe?)

2) In the second sentance, "window showing the memory count...": I'm not
sure what this means... maybe it should say "window showing another
Operating System running"?

3) "It is a platform to install an [OS]"... not sure exactly what is
meant here either. Maybe this is combined with the "window showing
memory count" so we have "A window opens, showing the 'computer' booting
up.  At this point, you can install another operating system on the
virtual computer"? Oh.  Judging from the following paragraph, I think
this is what is meant.  Maybe it'll all make more sense after #1 is
fixed. ;)

--------------------------------------------------
Section 6 (Open Source Advantage):

(3rd paragraph):
"It is not necessary under some circumstances to release your in-house
modifications to the rest of the world. You may find this useful if your
business climate is highly competitive. The Gnu Protection Liscence
(GPL)   (the governing license of most Open Source  code) states that
modifications made to applications covered under the GPL need to be
re-distributed only if that company distributes the code. "

"Gnu Protection License" s/b "GNU General Public License". 
Last sentance could be: "...modifications made to applications covered
under the GPL need to be re-distributed only if the modified application
is distributed."

--------------------------------------------------



>Finally, this article is free for your use. Consider it GPL'd as long
as
>I am given credit for the work.

Perhaps you could copyright this document under either the GNU FDL or
OpenContent Licence. See:

http://www.gnu.org/licenses/fdl.html
http://opencontent.org/openpub/

I'm not exactly sure how it works, but you could include the doc's
license in "Appendix A" or something. (I am interested in this because I
like your document a lot and would be interested in modifying it to have
a "school focused" version of it.

Thanks,

~Peter

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Sun Jun 16 23:13:53 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Sun, 16 Jun 2002 23:13:53 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] 64-bit programming
Message-ID: <979721543.1024294423744.JavaMail.root@monkey>

Two big reasons:

1) Memory space (no 4GB limit)
2) Single-threaded performance (SMP is great for multithreaded apps, but
not everything can be multithreaded)

  -- Steve

On Sat, 15 Jun 2002, Carla Schroder pluglist at bratgrrl.com XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

> Any thoughts on programming for a 64-bit cpu like the Itanium, other than it 
> sounds like a speech impediment? Are there practical reasons? Kylix is 
> strictly IA32, and may someday support 64-bit cpus. Then again, maybe not. 
> gcc of course has IA64 and Alpha support. I'm wondering does it really matter 
> in these days of distributed computing and low-cost clusters and SMP, why 
> complicate things by introducing yet another complication? Just string
a herd 
> a them IA32s together.
> 
> Thanks,

From jhoblitt at ifa.hawaii.edu  Sun Jun 16 23:20:40 2002
From: jhoblitt at ifa.hawaii.edu (Joshua Hoblitt)
Date: Sun, 16 Jun 2002 20:20:40 -1000 (HST)
Subject: [PLUG] 64-bit programming
In-Reply-To: <979721543.1024294423744.JavaMail.root@monkey>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206162018310.20706-100000@tiu>

One more... if you need 64 bit int support you will pay a heavy
performance cost on a x86 cpu.  SMP does not equal 32 x 2 = 64 bit
support (the amount of shared data needed is prohibitive).

-J

From briand at aracnet.com  Sun Jun 16 23:44:52 2002
From: briand at aracnet.com (briand at aracnet.com)
Date: Sun, 16 Jun 2002 23:44:52 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] 64-bit programming
In-Reply-To: <979721543.1024294423744.JavaMail.root@monkey>
References: <979721543.1024294423744.JavaMail.root@monkey>
Message-ID: <15629.34148.404828.450836@soggy.deldotd.com>

>>>>> "Steve" == Steve Bonds <1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com> writes:

  Steve> Two big reasons:
  Steve> 1) Memory space (no 4GB limit)

Not really true.  For execution there is no reason why the memory
access needs to be limited to the data bus width.  I could easily make
my memory accesses take place on a 128 bit bus and fetch only 16, 32,
64, etc, at a time.  In theory the design might be a little ugly since
I now need to do 128 bit math for the program counter but it could be
done.  A 64 bit wide instruction set is pretty much a waste.

  Steve> 2) Single-threaded performance (SMP is great for
  Steve> multithreaded apps, but not everything can be multithreaded)

 Single threaded performance definitely benefits from moving the 64
 bit chunks around.  An interesting class of programs are the math
 intensive, or CAD oriented programs.  Heavy duty math programs are
 almost ALWAYS very parellizable (is that a word ?).  They typically
 do a lot of matrix math.

The future is in parallelization.  For math applications there is no
doubt in my mind that people should be focusing on lots of little
processes working together - and to a large extent they are - hence
all the hoopla about clusters.

As for the "lay person" bigger and better CPU's are already a dead
end.  Who the hell needs a 1.8GHz P4 for word processing, or instant
messaging ?  Even BillG is starting to have trouble generating enough
code bloat to slow down modern processors.  The only reason I've ever
upgraded my system was to crunch FP faster.  As far as usability and
day-to-day use I could get by with a K2-233.  The boost in HD
performance has really made the difference for everyday use.

More performance for the 3D graphics world still has lots of life left
in it.  Visualization is very BW and computationally expensive.
Again, graphics are also very parallelizable.

Bottom line is that Intel and AMD need to put out bigger and better
chips strictly for profit margins, and they desperately need to make
people think that they need them - but they don't.


Brian


  Steve>   -- Steve

  Steve> On Sat, 15 Jun 2002, Carla Schroder pluglist at bratgrrl.com XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX wrote:

  >> Any thoughts on programming for a 64-bit cpu like the Itanium, other than it 
  >> sounds like a speech impediment? Are there practical reasons? Kylix is 
  >> strictly IA32, and may someday support 64-bit cpus. Then again, maybe not. 
  >> gcc of course has IA64 and Alpha support. I'm wondering does it really matter 
  >> in these days of distributed computing and low-cost clusters and SMP, why 
  >> complicate things by introducing yet another complication? Just string
  Steve> a herd 
  >> a them IA32s together.
  >> 
  >> Thanks,
  >> Carla
  >>
