From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Mon Jun 17 00:46:20 2002
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Mon, 17 Jun 2002 00:46:20 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Samba as a print only server
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206170009340.24730-100000@antares.mpcu.com>

I've been asked to setup what is essentailly an end of life pc (P133) as a 
print server with one locally laserjet on lp0.  Its been awhile since I've 
touched samba and the changes, well, are dramatic.  A phenomenal amount of 
functionality has been added.  In going thru "Samba-HOWTO-Collection" pdf, 
the focus seems to be integrating into  MS-Windows Domain structure.  In 
my case, there is a PDC (NT 4) but as this host only will be doing print 
serving I don't see a need to configure for "normal" user authentication.  
The are no restrictions as to who can print using this network resource.

My question stems from the changes that the docs are saying to do to 
/etc/pam.d/ with respect to supporting winbind.  The doc says make changes 
to /etc/pam.d/* .  In peoples experience, is this really necessary?  Seem 
overkill to me.  Is winbind even the right path to persue?  

/etc/pam.d/* has 66 items.  Egad.





One tangential question.  Is there such a thing as a "loopback" for an AT 
keyboard plug?  This would allow a socket 7 motherboard to boot without 
whining about a missing keyboard?




From shark at sharky.dyndns.org  Mon Jun 17 01:50:48 2002
From: shark at sharky.dyndns.org (Peter W)
Date: 17 Jun 2002 01:50:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] What PLUG needs (benifits of 501c3)
In-Reply-To: <CAENLEIHEHPLANCLMFKMMEGKCIAA.mark@planetwills.com>
References: <CAENLEIHEHPLANCLMFKMMEGKCIAA.mark@planetwills.com>
Message-ID: <1024303848.12653.324.camel@sharky>

On Tue, 2002-06-11 at 08:27, Mark Wills wrote:

 [snip]

> What I'm getting at, is unless you anticipate significant grants, the
> overhead isn't worth all the effort.
> 
> Mark
> 

I wonder how much $ we could get in donations?  It could definitely be
worth it if we ended up with some money. ;)  


It seems to me that PLUG does a great job of supporting PLUG (current
Linux/Unix users).  What PLUG doesn't seem to do as good a job of is
converting lots of M$ users to Linux (please forgive me if I'm wrong).

Two benefits I see of having an "official" organization:

1) $$*.  With this, we can buy hardware (including projector) and
(possibly) speakers from afar; with those two things might come more
people to meetings.  From this, we have more $.  And eventually, with
more $$ we can also do a variaty of advocacy (we can do it now, but not
certain types).  We could help schools buy huge Xeon systems so they
could convert old labs to K12LTSP Linux Labs.  We could buy Linux or
Linux-related books to put in both public libraries and school
libraries.  We could buy ads in the paper, or cool posters (placed in
college campuses or any other place lots of possible converts hang
out).  We could buy flags for rallys and protests ... (ok, you get the
picture.) ;)     

2) (better?) Public relations.  Currently, we all know (or can figure
out) who to go to if we want to talk w/ the "main guy" begind the group
or the server or ...  But the media doesn't.  If KGW wanted to do a
Linux-related story, they might have better luck getting our perspective
if there were an "official" PR person listed on the website or
something.  If PLUG decides it has issues with current bills, we could
have the "PLUG President" call up the senator and say "I represent PLUG
which has 1000 members and we don't like House Bill 10032".  This is
also more possible if we have "official members" (or a count of how many
there are on the PLUG website).  


So it seems to that if we care about advancing the state of Linux
related things and increasing the number of people using it then having
plug be an "official" .ORG would be helpful.  If we can do these things
without bothering with "official" .ORG hassles (and we want to do these
things) then thats fine w/ me. :)
 

*: Eventually, after everyone in portland is member and we have lots of
$$, we can pay our unemployed members to write us some nifty software.
;)


~Peter

p.s.- one LUG i know of that acts this way is LUGOD.  See:
http://www.lugod.org (esp. Services>Documents>Objectives).  I've emailed
one of there members about advantages/disadvantages of 501c3 and will
forward the response here.




From gherteg at herteg.net  Mon Jun 17 06:46:36 2002
From: gherteg at herteg.net (Geoffrey Herteg)
Date: Mon, 17 Jun 2002 06:46:36 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] What PLUG needs (benifits of 501c3)
In-Reply-To: <1024303848.12653.324.camel@sharky>
References: <CAENLEIHEHPLANCLMFKMMEGKCIAA.mark@planetwills.com> <1024303848.12653.324.camel@sharky>
Message-ID: <20020617134636.GA16907@valinux.com>

As a member of LUGOD up to a week ago (new job here in PDX), I can
say that we definitely benefitted from our 501c7 status (though IIRC the
treasurer had to deal with some interesting tax issues).

LUGOD would typically make decent scratch from donations, both at meetings
and through various other outlets (I was a member of the LERT project,
where we'd accept donations for coming out to a person's house to fix a
Linux problem that couldn't wait until the next install-fest).
Donations from businesses also helped a lot (demo computer from VA
Linux/Software/Whatever Larry's calling it this week, books from
O'Reilly, etc).  Having something to present to businesses seems to help
loosen the purse strings.

In my opinion, LUGOD does benefit from its organization, but what it
also benefits from is the dedication of individuals like Pete Salzman,
Bill Kendrick, Henry House and several other individuals whom I know I
should mention but don't have the space...  They throw a lot of their
free time into the LUG.  That, and the small college town of Davis has
its advantages, as its usually easier to meet in a central location that
is convenient for all involved (no freeway traffic to battle for most of
us, though there were a few individuals who came from the Bay Area and
parts of Sacramento for meetings).

Anyway, sorry for a rant as my first formal post to the list.  Hope to
meet some of you in RL at the next meeting!

- Geoffrey Herteg

From greg at green-mind.org  Mon Jun 17 07:44:09 2002
From: greg at green-mind.org (Greg Robillard)
Date: Mon, 17 Jun 2002 07:44:09 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Converting MS SQL to MySQL?
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206161929250.25327-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <009501c2160d$70c156e0$6401a8c0@gandalf>

I believe there is a wizard in MS SQL to both dump data into text files and
automatically generate your db creation scripts. In MS SQL enterprise
manager,
you right click on the db you wish to use. In 'All Tasks' you'll see two
options: generate SQL scripts and Export data. It should be fairly easy then
to import data and structure into MySQL

GR
----- Original Message -----
From: "Matt Alexander" <m at netpro.to>
To: <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>
Sent: Sunday, June 16, 2002 7:32 PM
Subject: [PLUG] Converting MS SQL to MySQL?

From mike at computer-arts.net  Mon Jun 17 09:22:17 2002

Subject: [PLUG] /var/spool/mail/.forward
Message-ID: <3D0E0CB8.39B494BD@computer-arts.net>

The message:

  "forward /var/spool/mail/.forward: Group writable directory"

Showed up in the log of my mail server this morning. I've never
seen this before. Can anyone enlighten me as to what this might
mean. There is no such file there now. /var/spool/mail is owned
by the user "mail" and has, itself group write permissions. So,
I suppose this could be a temporary file created by either root
of mail. I'm just trying to understand if this is anything to
worry about.

This is RedHat 7.2 / Sendmail

-Mike

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jun 17 11:15:02 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 17 Jun 2002 11:15:02 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] ppp connection problem
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206171106190.1355-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I'm trying to connect to my shell account at my ISP using my notebook
computer and cellular telephone (Kyocera QCP-6035). Despite my efforts, and
those of Dan and Geoff at last Saturday's clinic, I cannot complete the
connection.

  Here is a typical session as seen in /var/log/messages. Ignore the date
and time, the CMOS battery is dying (I just ordered a replacement):

Mar 26 04:42:14 lemna pppd[862]: pppd 2.3.11 started by root, uid 0

lines I never saw when connecting via the pcmcia modem and a land line:

Mar 26 04:42:38 lemna chat[870]: send (rshepard^M)
Mar 26 04:42:38 lemna chat[870]: expect (ssword:)

Here:	Mar 26 04:42:39 lemna chat[870]:  rshepard^M
Mar 26 04:42:39 lemna chat[870]: Password:
Mar 26 04:42:39 lemna chat[870]:  -- got it 

and here:	Mar 26 04:42:39 lemna chat[870]: send (<passwd-removed>^M)

  Does anyone here have insight into what might be happening?

  Alternatively, what can I do to try to generate more information that
might yield a reason for the lack of connection?

TIA,

Rich




From sharbours at yahoo.com  Mon Jun 17 11:33:40 2002
From: sharbours at yahoo.com (Sean, Sharon and Kyle Harbour)
Date: Mon, 17 Jun 2002 11:33:40 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Unreal
In-Reply-To: <000001c21569$cda531a0$0401a8c0@tina>
Message-ID: <20020617183340.43561.qmail@web14401.mail.yahoo.com>

Never had a problem with the default setup you describe. It should
'Just Work' (c). Got any firewall rules in place? Make sure they
allow UDP port 7777 through.

If you want to host a game, you need to modify your NAT to forward
UDP ports 7777 through 7799 back to your workstation. This will allow
you to serve about 20 connections, extend the top of the range if you
need more.

Sean Harbour

From shark at sharky.dyndns.org  Mon Jun 17 11:39:16 2002
From: shark at sharky.dyndns.org (Peter W)
Date: Mon, 17 Jun 2002 11:39:16 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ssh authentication
Message-ID: <20020617113916.A29911@sharky.dyndns.org>

Has anyone ever had problems using ssh to connect from Linux to Solaris (that is, OPENSSH to Solaris SSH?).

I have a ~/.ssh (which is NFS mounted on both Solaris and Linux) which has:
id_dsa (private key encrypted with DSA - I'm pretty sure both SSH's support this)
id_dsa.pub
authorized_keys (which is "cp id_dsa.pub authorized_keys")
known_hosts

Does anyone know if the Solaris SSH server expects diferent files?

Thanks,

~Peter



From neil at pacifier.com  Mon Jun 17 11:37:20 2002
From: neil at pacifier.com (Neil Anuskiewicz)
Date: Mon, 17 Jun 2002 11:37:20 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Networking course a go
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206171113300.2015-100000@localhost.localdomain>

Okay, Ed Sawicki and the Accelerated Learning Center (ALC) have now 
scheduled the Linux Networking Course. So far,  Carla Schroder and I have 
committed to taking the course (and several others have expressed 
interest). We need a total of six people to sign up for it to be viable 
for ALC to run the course. I really hope that at least four more people 
sign up for the course!

Dates: Three Thursdays in July - 11th, 18th, and 25th.

Time: 8:30 AM - 4:30 PM

Place: Novell's Portland office. You can find directions and a map here:
http://www.panug.org/meetings/index.htm#direct

Course Outline: 
http://www.alcpress.com/training/courses/linuxnetworking.htm

Text: ALC gives a textbook to each student.

Cost: $325

How to register: Call ALC's office at 503-635-6370

I consider this course an experiment of sorts. ALC runs these courses all 
over the country (charging $595) but was reluctant to run the course in 
Portland because of concerns about enrollment. I had to lobby a bit to 
persuade them to run the course in Portland.

If this course is a success in terms of enrollment, then it is much more 
likely that ALC will regularly run Linux Networking here in Portland. In 
addition, it is more likely that ALC will run Apache Bootcamp, DNS 
bootcamp, Linux System Administration, etc. Since Portland is home to ALC 
we will likely get fairly substantial discounts on the cost of each course.

I've never taken a course from Ed but I have heard from several people 
that he is an excellent instructor. I look forward to this course. It will 
be a lot of fun.


-- 
Neil Anuskiewicz

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Jun 17 11:49:29 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 17 Jun 2002 11:49:29 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] ssh authentication
In-Reply-To: <20020617113916.A29911@sharky.dyndns.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206171147180.6176-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 17 Jun 2002, Peter W wrote:

> Has anyone ever had problems using ssh to connect from Linux to
> Solaris (that is, OPENSSH to Solaris SSH?).

Until the very recently released version 9, Solaris never shipped with 
ssh or sshd. Admins always had to build/install them by hand (or via a 
package from a source like sunfreeware.com).

So chances are the sshd in question doesn't do protocol 2.

What does 'ssh -V' report on the Solaris machine?

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

I believe you are correct.  Personally, I've seen anonmolous behaviour 
when going between openssh and SSH.  We choose the openssh route for all 
linux and solaris hosts.  Just checked with www.sunfreeware.com and they 
have packages for Solaris 2.7 and 8.  I'd recommend using them.

From derek at infotects.com  Mon Jun 17 12:49:53 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 17 Jun 2002 12:49:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Samba as a print only server
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206170009340.24730-100000@antares.mpcu.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206170009340.24730-100000@antares.mpcu.com>
Message-ID: <1024343394.890.67.camel@dereklinux>

Hi Keith,

On Mon, 2002-06-17 at 00:46, Keith Morse wrote:
> 
> I've been asked to setup what is essentailly an end of life pc (P133) as a 
> print server with one locally laserjet on lp0.  Its been awhile since I've 
> touched samba and the changes, well, are dramatic.  A phenomenal amount of 
> functionality has been added.  In going thru "Samba-HOWTO-Collection" pdf, 
> the focus seems to be integrating into  MS-Windows Domain structure.  In 
> my case, there is a PDC (NT 4) but as this host only will be doing print 
> serving I don't see a need to configure for "normal" user authentication.  
> The are no restrictions as to who can print using this network resource.
> 
> My question stems from the changes that the docs are saying to do to 
> /etc/pam.d/ with respect to supporting winbind.  The doc says make changes 
> to /etc/pam.d/* .  In peoples experience, is this really necessary?  Seem 
> overkill to me.  Is winbind even the right path to persue?
I'm not positive, but this doesn't seem necessary, since you will be
setting it up as a guest account that doesn't require authentication.
  
> 
> /etc/pam.d/* has 66 items.  Egad.
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> One tangential question.  Is there such a thing as a "loopback" for an AT 
> keyboard plug?  This would allow a socket 7 motherboard to boot without 
> whining about a missing keyboard?
This I know more about, you will need to change the BIOS setting to
ignore keyboard errors (or all but disk errors).  Linux doesn't really
care if there is a keyboard present or not, it just states that
something is wrong, but continues booting.

HTH

Derek Loree





From russj at dimstar.net  Mon Jun 17 13:04:51 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)

Subject: [PLUG] ssh authentication
In-Reply-To: <20020617113916.A29911@sharky.dyndns.org>

I didn't know that Solaris had their own implementation of SSH. I always 
use the openssh distributed from www.sunfreeware.com. In that regard, they 
are identical as far as what files each explect, assuming a similar build 
configuration.

At 11:39 AM 6/17/2002 -0700, you wrote:

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Mon Jun 17 13:12:21 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Mon, 17 Jun 2002 13:12:21 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Q: Gimp - Pasting multiple images into canvas
Message-ID: <3D0E42A5.9040905@pacifier.com>

I'm certainly not a gimp whiz (I suck actually), and if there is a better 
tool for this, I'd love to know.

Trying to create an 11x17 canvas and paste several jpeg photos onto the 
canvas so I can print then cut out the "prints" with scissors.  Want to be 
able to rotate/size the images to fit as many as possible on a sheet

I start with the correct size canvas, but when I paste an image, gimp tries 
to make it fill the canvas.  When I try to resize (shrink) the image, the 
canvas also shrinks.

Briefly looked at ImageMagick, but it didn't seemed geared toward this kind 
of thing.

--
Kyle Accardi




From sandbox at pacifier.com  Mon Jun 17 13:31:31 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Mon, 17 Jun 2002 13:31:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Q: Gimp - Pasting multiple images into canvas
References: <3D0E42A5.9040905@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <3D0E4723.4070806@pacifier.com>

Of course, I just figured it out.

Open each image seperately, scale, copy, paste into to big one.  Cool.

--
Kyle Accardi

I wrote:
> I'm certainly not a gimp whiz (I suck actually), and if there is a 
> better tool for this, I'd love to know.

From raanders at acm.org  Mon Jun 17 14:13:13 2002
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Mon, 17 Jun 2002 14:13:13 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] ppp connection problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206171106190.1355-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206171406001.7062-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Mon, 17 Jun 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> Mar 26 04:42:39 lemna pppd[862]: Connect: ppp0 <--> /dev/modem
> Mar 26 04:43:10 lemna pppd[862]: LCP: timeout sending Config-Requests 

Could be someone's not sarting the ppp daemon.  Does you ISP
automatically start a ppp connection?  Do you need to issue the command?

   In this day and age of MS Windows I don't think this should be
happening so you should check your /etc/ppp/options file to insure noauth
is in there.  Strange as it seems I've seen the same error when it was an
authority issue.
   Also depending on how your connection was configured, redhatppp, 
Linuxconf, etc. you might need a noipdefault in the file also.


Rod
-- 
         Please don't tell my mother I'm a System Administrator.
                  She thinks I play piano in a bordello.




From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Mon Jun 17 14:56:13 2002
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Mon, 17 Jun 2002 14:56:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Is it illegal for Oregon Counties to do business with MicroSoft?
Message-ID: <20020617145613.C21077@dalsemi.com>

I don't know how often y'all read Slashdot, but this is pretty interesting:

http://slashdot.org/articles/02/06/17/1651231.shtml?tid=103

Basically, the policies of a county in Arizona prevent it from doing
business with people or companies convicted of violating county, state
or federal law.

So while the penalty phase is ongoing (and of questionable value), why
not press the issue and see if we can use our own laws to get our duly
elected government to deal Linux/BSD a hand in the game?

Colin



From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Jun 17 14:55:53 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 17 Jun 2002 14:55:53 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] ssh authentication
In-Reply-To: <5.1.0.14.0.20020617130326.00b902a8@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206171437130.6176-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 17 Jun 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:

> I didn't know that Solaris had their own implementation of SSH. I
> always use the openssh distributed from www.sunfreeware.com.

Sun didn't ship its own port of OpenSSH until Solaris 9, which I'm now 
running at home:

  [heinlein at irvine heinlein]$ uname -a
  SunOS irvine 5.9 Generic sun4u sparc SUNW,Sun-Blade-100
  [heinlein at irvine heinlein]$ ssh -V
  SSH Version Sun_SSH_1.0, protocol versions 1.5/2.0.

It's definitely OpenSSH:

  [heinlein at irvine heinlein]$ strings /usr/lib/ssh/sshd | grep BSD   
  @(#)$OpenBSD: sshd.c, v 1.132 2000/10/13 18:34:46 markus Exp $
  ... 44 more entries deleted ...

The rcs info indicates that Sun ported the version current as of early 
2001, but it's not immediately clear to me what they did or didn't 
patch since that time.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

> I'm not positive, but this doesn't seem necessary, since you will be
> setting it up as a guest account that doesn't require authentication.
>   
> > 
> > One tangential question.  Is there such a thing as a "loopback" for an AT 
> > keyboard plug?  This would allow a socket 7 motherboard to boot without 
> > whining about a missing keyboard?
> This I know more about, you will need to change the BIOS setting to
> ignore keyboard errors (or all but disk errors).  Linux doesn't really
> care if there is a keyboard present or not, it just states that
> something is wrong, but continues booting.
> 
> HTH
> 


Specifically this is not possible as this bios does not support that. 
Hence the question.

leave an old keyboard plugged.

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Mon Jun 17 16:39:47 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Mon, 17 Jun 2002 16:39:47 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] ppp connection problem 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Mon, 17 Jun 2002 15:48:33 PDT."
             <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206171546540.1983-100000@appl-ecosys.com> 
Message-ID: <200206172339.g5HNdlt01560@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> On Mon, 17 Jun 2002, Galen Seitz wrote:
> 
> > Can you login via a shell dialup?  That's where I would start.  Once that
> > is working, I would try starting up ppp manually from the shell prompt.
>  
> galen,
> 
>   Using minicom, I can dial in (using the same phone number) and the ppp
> connection is apparently started automatically. All I/we see on the screen
> is gibberish. The assumption is that Aracnet's trying to establish a ppp
> connection with minicom.
> 
>   Is there a different approach? I'm always open to learning more.
> 

I recommend reviewing the ppp howto.  In particular, Chapter 17 is relevant
for your situation.  http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/PPP-HOWTO/manual.html
Failing that, you might consider asking tech support at aracnet to
temporarily set your account for shell access.  In that mode ppp will not
automatically start on the remote end.  This assumes aracnet will allow
a shell user to manually start ppp.

BTW, I'm operating from memory on this.  It's been about 3 years since I
did this myself.

galen






From jhoblitt at ifa.hawaii.edu  Mon Jun 17 16:52:56 2002
From: jhoblitt at ifa.hawaii.edu (Joshua Hoblitt)
Date: Mon, 17 Jun 2002 13:52:56 -1000 (HST)
Subject: [PLUG] Samba as a print only server

Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206171351210.26481-100000@tiu>

I've had this issue before.  There are devices out there called ghosts
that "fake" a keyboard but they are hard to find.  Blackbox sells serial
mouse ghosts at the moment.  If you find a keyboard one please let us
know.

-J

From dealy at deatech.com  Mon Jun 17 17:00:15 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Mon, 17 Jun 2002 17:00:15 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] ppp connection problem 
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206171546540.1983-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206171637110.704-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Mon, 17 Jun 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

[snip]
>   Is there a different approach? I'm always open to learning more.
[snip]

Try setting the "record /var/tmp/some_file_name" option in your ppp
options file, this will allow you to record the entire session at the byte
level with timing and everything, then try connecting again with ppp.
Once your session has failed, use the pppdump command (I think it gives
the most useful display with the -p option) to display/interpret the file.

NOTE: with regard to the LCP timeout, LCP is a low level protocol used for
managing the PPP link, the timeout indicates that when your side made a
request to your ISP's side of the link, it didn't get any response.

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

On Mon, Jun 17, 2002 at 03:48:33PM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
> 
>   Is there a different approach? I'm always open to learning more.

Have you tried wvdial? I use it on all my boxes and it works great --
takes all the brainwork out of dial-up. It seems to be included with
Red Hat, so you probably have it on a CD somewhere. I can't see the
point in setting up PPP by hand unless you've got a special situation.
It looks like your is a special situation, but I'd try the lazy way,
anyhow. :-)


Paul

From bl.nordlund at verizon.net  Mon Jun 17 19:30:47 2002
From: bl.nordlund at verizon.net (Brian & Lori Nordlund)
Date: Mon, 17 Jun 2002 19:30:47 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] New Install won't let me Telnet, FTP, or http
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206131017020.26593-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu> <5.1.0.14.0.20020614091704.00b4f510@localhost>
Message-ID: <002c01c21670$2825a860$021ea8c0@nisse>

Thanks all-
I found that the telnet module (client-side) is all that was installed.
Apparently, my previous installation used the older telnet module that
performed both client and server services.  The new installation only
installed the telnet module.

After I installed the telnet server RPM I found that it still didn't work.
It wrote a config file called "telnet.conf.newRPM" (or something like that)
rather than replacing the old telnet.conf (apparently both the client and
server modules share the config file).  Once I did some deleting / renaming,
so it would use the new conf file, then it started to work.

Thanks again,
Brian.

kernel: nfs: task 25171 can't get a request slot
kernel: nfs: task 25172 can't get a request slot
kernel: nfs: task 25173 can't get a request slot
...

I'm on a Redhat 7.3 (kernel 2.4.18-3) machine, mounting /home over NFS from
a Solaris 7 server (not sure how to tell nfs version?).

It seems like something new (this problems) in the latest Linux kernels
but I'm not sure.

> a Solaris 7 server (not sure how to tell nfs version?).

> It seems like something new (this problems) in the latest Linux kernels
> but I'm not sure.
> 

The FAQ at nfs.sourceforge.net mentions this, though I don't know if
the answer applies to your situation.

galen






From shark at sharky.dyndns.org  Tue Jun 18 00:12:34 2002

From shark at sharky.dyndns.org  Tue Jun 18 00:53:58 2002
From: shark at sharky.dyndns.org (Peter W)
Date: 18 Jun 2002 00:53:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Dual booting linux distros
In-Reply-To: <1024373959.15236.16.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>
References: <1024373959.15236.16.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>
Message-ID: <1024386839.15003.10.camel@sharky>

On Mon, 2002-06-17 at 21:19, alex wrote:
> I have a spare machine just sitting around and I was wondering how hard
> it is to dual boot several different Linux distros. I am currently dual
> booting Mandrake (I know, "newbie") and 98se (for games only). That was
> easy but I haven't found much of anything regarding getting various
> versions of Linux on the same box. Any pointers or websites I might have
> overlooked would be appreciated.
> 
> Alex McCreary

Once you have spare room it shouldn't be to hard.  Usually Lilo or Grub
is installed in the MBR of your hard drive.  If you wanted to add
another distro, just tell it to place its boot program  in the beginning
of the partition you installed that distro in (e.g. hda5 or something)
and then tell mandrake's lilo.conf or grub.conf to boot Debian (for
example) from /dev/hda5.

i'm tired, so if that didn't make sense or isn't enough info to help ya,
email me again and I'll see if i can dig up some links.

~Peter




From shark at sharky.dyndns.org  Tue Jun 18 00:57:20 2002

From jeffy at myrealbox.com  Tue Jun 18 01:02:04 2002
From: jeffy at myrealbox.com (Jeff Forsyth)
Date: 18 Jun 2002 01:02:04 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Dual booting linux distros
In-Reply-To: <1024373959.15236.16.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>
References: <1024373959.15236.16.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>
Message-ID: <1024387325.842.24.camel@BigShit>

Hmmmm....Lots of possibilities...

Are you interested in running different Linux Kernel Versions?
Or running different Mandrake Versions?
Or running different Distributions?

As for Kernel Versions, LILO and GRUB offer the ability to boot under
different kernel versions easily.

Different Drake Versions:  Sorry not a 'Drake fan.

Different Distributions:  
		Keep the Home partition the same across all distributions.
		Use the same swap and tmp space.
	
Partitioning examples:
		
			hdx1	swap
			hdx2	tmp
			hdx3	home
			hdx5	root (RedHat)
			hdx6	root (Drake)
			hdx7	root (Debian)



On Mon, 2002-06-17 at 21:19, alex wrote:
> I have a spare machine just sitting around and I was wondering how hard
> it is to dual boot several different Linux distros. I am currently dual
> booting Mandrake (I know, "newbie") and 98se (for games only). That was
> easy but I haven't found much of anything regarding getting various
> versions of Linux on the same box. Any pointers or websites I might have
> overlooked would be appreciated.

> Alex McCreary

Isn't there a group called the Blue Group (Linux newbies)? If you hold an 
install fest, then you might want to promote to that group as well.

Also, PLUG currently holds Saturday clinics which include install 
instruction. You might want to join up with them and hold your workshop in 
conjunction with their monthly Saturday clinics. The clinics are normally 
on the third Saturday of the month at clinics Riverdale Elementary School. 
Here is a web site: 
http://server.riverdale.k12.or.us/~danh/

From sandy at herring.org  Tue Jun 18 08:51:05 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Tue, 18 Jun 2002 08:51:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] /var/spool/mail/.forward
In-Reply-To: <3D0E0CB8.39B494BD@computer-arts.net>; from mike@computer-arts.net on Mon, Jun 17, 2002 at 09:22:17AM -0700
References: <3D0E0CB8.39B494BD@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <20020618085105.B29753@kippered.herring.org>

Mike,

Sounds like you have a user with $MAIL set to /var/spool/mail rather than
/var/spool/mail/$USER - either that or $USER is null for some user.

Sandy

On Mon, 17 Jun 2002, Mike Witt wrote: 
> The message:
> 
>   "forward /var/spool/mail/.forward: Group writable directory"
> 
> Showed up in the log of my mail server this morning. I've never
> seen this before. Can anyone enlighten me as to what this might
> mean. There is no such file there now. /var/spool/mail is owned
> by the user "mail" and has, itself group write permissions. So,
> I suppose this could be a temporary file created by either root
> of mail. I'm just trying to understand if this is anything to
> worry about.
> 
> This is RedHat 7.2 / Sendmail
> 
> -Mike

> >
> > Meeting is at 7:00 pm at It's a Beautiful Pizza on Belmont
> >

> [snip]
>
> What day is this being held? Today?

Thanks to all of you who so politely pointed out that the date was in the
subject line :-)  I was a victim of being old and set in my ways :-) I've
been reading email with full headers turned on for something like 14
years, and it didn't use to be a problem because the headers were very
short and simple.  These days, the headers are so long that I generally
can't find the subject line even if I do look for it, so I just start
reading the message.  To prevent this from happening again in the future,
I finally took the time to figure out how to turn the full header display
off, so now I will have to find some new way to embarrass myself :-)

From athlonrobnf at cs.com  Tue Jun 18 21:41:09 2002
From: athlonrobnf at cs.com (AthlonRob)
Date: Tue, 18 Jun 2002 21:41:09 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Slackware 8.1 is out
References: <001801c21743$2e27c080$0200a8c0@robxp>
Message-ID: <004701c2174b$8a5cd180$0200a8c0@robxp>

According to those who have been able to get it already, Slackware RC3 as of
6-16-02 is 8.1, release.  :-)

ftp.eunet.be has ISOs dated the 15th, but if you check the changelogs, there
were mainly just some RAID issues worked out there.

ftp.slackware.at/data has been reported to be a very fast mirror... one guy
is reporting 300KB/sec off it.

Slackware, for those who don't know... it the 'oldest commercial linux
distro' ... if you're used to RedHat or Mandrake, it is a bit different.
More of a do-it-yourself-so-you-know-it-is-right kinda distro.  The main
selling point for me was the lack of RPMs (although you can install some
RPMs... not recommended) and the BSD-style init.

I've been running 8.1 Beta 2 on an old laptop since it was released.  It's
been working wonderfully, I only found a few small problems which Pat worked
out before I was even able to report them to him.

Rob

From pem at nellump.net  Tue Jun 18 12:38:43 2002
From: pem at nellump.net (Paul Mullen)
Date: Tue, 18 Jun 2002 12:38:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] How does 'ls' determine file type for colorization purposes?
In-Reply-To: <20020610140858.A24898@zaphod.axian.com>; from ali@axian.com on Mon, Jun 10, 2002 at 02:08:58PM -0700
References: <20020610135558.A7978@nellump.net> <20020610140858.A24898@zaphod.axian.com>
Message-ID: <20020618123842.A6165@nellump.net>

> On Mon, Jun 10, 2002 at 01:55:58PM -0700, Paul Mullen wrote:
> > As the title says... How does 'ls' determine file type for purposes of
> > color-coding it's listings? The man and info pages don't seem to give

Thanks to Dhruva and Ali for pointing out that 'ls' gets its
colorization info from the environment variable "LS_COLORS". The
'dircolors' utility handily creates a revised LS_COLORS if fed a custom
config file.

I opted to modify my LS_COLORS variable via /etc/profile. I didn't bother
to dig around and see if 'dircolors' itself is called upon by some rc
script at system startup.

One thing I did learn (the long, frustrating way), is that starting a
new xterm does *not* count as an entirely new login (which seems to be
necessary in order for any changes made to your BASH config files to
take effect). Argh. :-P


Paul

From m at netpro.to  Tue Jun 18 21:55:41 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Tue, 18 Jun 2002 21:55:41 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] How does 'ls' determine file type for colorization
 purposes?
In-Reply-To: <20020618123842.A6165@nellump.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206182150521.17782-100000@lukem.com>

On Tue, 18 Jun 2002, Paul Mullen wrote:

> One thing I did learn (the long, frustrating way), is that starting a
> new xterm does *not* count as an entirely new login (which seems to be
> necessary in order for any changes made to your BASH config files to
> take effect). Argh. :-P

Your .bash_profile is read once, when you first login.  Your .bashrc,
however, is run with each new terminal you startup.  If you want to load
changes you've made to .bash_profile without logging out, just type this:

. .bash_profile

for that new instance of xterm.

From jason at vancleve.com  Wed Jun 19 01:41:57 2002
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Wed, 19 Jun 2002 01:41:57 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Runlevel Processes As Different User
Message-ID: <20020619014157.63d08414.jason@vancleve.com>

O ye wise and powerful sysadmin types,

I have a problem, for which I have a solution I don't much like.  I want
to run my database server from an init script as a different user, for
purposes of security.  But this database, Sybase SQL Anywhere 7, doesn't
seem to have any options for changing the user when run as a daemon. 
Apparently Sybase is confident in the security of their products.

Anyway, I started writing an init script to use the su command with the
"-c" option--the only way I can find to do this.  But su can be tricky,
and I quickly found it impracticable to stuff everything into the string
following "-c".  For one thing, su tweaks the path, so I would have to
wedge "export PATH=$PATH;" in there to get around that.  And then there
is the command(s) itself, which may contain quotes, so I have embedded
quotes to wrestle with.  Oh, and if I want the $USER variable to be
right, I need to add the "-" option, which fubars the rest of my
environment.

Thus, my solution was to create a script that takes the standard init
commands (start|stop|restart, etc.) and call that from my runlevel
script, in this general form:

	su - $RUN_USER -c "$RUN_SCRIPT start"

This allowed all of the environment logic to go in the other script, yet
it still seems redundant to have to create a separate script in order
just to su to a daemon user at boot time.  So I'm just wondering if
anyone has a more elegant solution on hand.


Also and by the way, what's an easy way to find files matching a given
date or time?  The best I can do is something like this:

	find /starting/path -printf "%p - %c\n" | grep "Jun 12 20:53"

Thanks once more,

--Jason Van Cleve



From jason at vancleve.com  Wed Jun 19 02:17:01 2002
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Wed, 19 Jun 2002 02:17:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] How does 'ls' determine file type for colorization purposes?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206182150521.17782-100000@lukem.com>
References: <20020618123842.A6165@nellump.net>
	<Pine.GSO.4.33.0206182150521.17782-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <20020619021701.5285678c.jason@vancleve.com>

On Tue, 18 Jun 2002 21:55:41 -0700 (PDT)
Matt Alexander <m at netpro.to> wrote:

> Your .bash_profile is read once, when you first login.  Your .bashrc,

On my system it seems .bash_profile is read with each terminal window I
open, but maybe that constitutes a login.  .bashrc, on the other hand,
is reread for each shell I start, even within an existing terminal.  One
interesting thing to note is, .bashrc is NOT read automatically when I
first open a terminal, though it is read for child shells.  I have to
explicitly read it in .bash_profile to get my aliases in a new terminal.
 Thought that was kinda strange.

--Jason

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Jun 19 06:06:27 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 19 Jun 2002 06:06:27 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Runlevel Processes As Different User
In-Reply-To: <20020619014157.63d08414.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206190559080.5569-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On Wed, 19 Jun 2002, Jason Van Cleve wrote:

> Thus, my solution was to create a script that takes the standard init
> commands (start|stop|restart, etc.) and call that from my runlevel
> script, in this general form:
> 
> 	su - $RUN_USER -c "$RUN_SCRIPT start"
> 
> This allowed all of the environment logic to go in the other script, yet
> it still seems redundant to have to create a separate script in order
> just to su to a daemon user at boot time.  So I'm just wondering if
> anyone has a more elegant solution on hand.

Writing wrapper scripts has long been part of Unix administration.  
Lots of third-party apps get invoked that way simply because, as you
discovered, managing all those environment variables is very 
difficult.

If you don't want to do the full init script thing, you might look at 
sudo to see if it meets your needs, but it's likely you'll end up with 
a wrapper regardless :-(

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

Or perhaps (and this is a little further out there, but hey, you've gotta 
consider everything =P), the ATA controller on the motherboard you replaced 
was going bad, wrote data to the drives in an, ah, *interesting* (read: wrong 
=P) fashion, and now the new motherboard is having problems with the drives 
because it can't figure out how the data was written to the drive?  *shrug*

~D. A. Stone

> 
> I would like to be able to use a cron type job to verify the
> availability of a list of video content, sort of like a ping test for a
> list of url's.

How about this? 

http://www.jmarshall.com/tools/cl/

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Jun 19 16:43:29 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed, 19 Jun 2002 16:43:29 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] command line check for streaming content
In-Reply-To: <1024529229.1372.128.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206191633210.4864-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 19 Jun 2002, Derek Loree wrote:
> I would like to be able to use a cron type job to verify the
> availability of a list of video content, sort of like a ping test for
> a list of url's.

wget.

wget -S --spider -i url.list

This'll go through the list of URLs in the file url.list and return the
HTTP responses for each URL in turn.

You've gotta parse those responses, though.

> I've searched the web, and looked long and hard at the lynx man page,
> but I'm not sure where to begin.  I guess that I just need a tool that
> will give a "yes" or "no" depending on whether or not it could find
> the file on a streaming server.

Oh, a streaming server?  Is it just http?  If it's any of that
mms: garbage, wget won't do it.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From derek at infotects.com  Wed Jun 19 17:38:01 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 19 Jun 2002 17:38:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] command line php execution
Message-ID: <1024533481.1684.153.camel@dereklinux>

Hi All,

I've got another problem that I need ideas for.  I would like to be able
to have a php script (or program -- I'm not sure what to call it) run as
a cron job.  From what I can tell, the interpreter has to be run through
the web server, which means that I need to be able to call a .php file
from a command line browser, then have it die when the php script has
finished doing the voodoo that it needs to do.  Calling the .php file is
not a big problem, lynx does it well enough from a shell script, but
convincing it to die at the appropriate time is more problematic.

I'm sure this is possible, this is linux after all. I think what I need
is to be able to grab the PID, stuff it in a variable, then kill that
process.  I can't figure out how to grab the PID though.

Are there other ways to get this job done?

TIA

Derek Loree 





From codeyeti at yahoo.com  Wed Jun 19 17:43:56 2002
From: codeyeti at yahoo.com (Michael Smith)
Date: Wed, 19 Jun 2002 17:43:56 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] command line php execution
References: <1024533481.1684.153.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <3D11253E.49EEB5D8@yahoo.com>

Sure, install the cgi version of php, that makes an executable php that you
can use in a script with #!/bin/php just like a regular shell script.

There also is a php shell... look around for it.
--Mike

From m at netpro.to  Wed Jun 19 18:47:13 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Wed, 19 Jun 2002 18:47:13 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Limiting a user to scp and not ssh
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0206191822060.10369-100000@lukem.com>

I'm trying to configure a box so people can scp files to it, but can't
actually ssh in.  I created a script named scpsh with this in it:

#!/bin/sh
#
exec /usr/bin/scp -t $HOME


Then I added scpsh to /etc/shells and made it their shell in /etc/passwd.
So now users can use scp to copy files over just fine, but when they try
to ssh, it sits there until they hit a key, at which point they get:

scp: protocol error: unexpected <newline>
Connection to 1.2.3.4 closed.


Is this the best way to handle this?  Is there a better way that anyone
knows of?
Thanks,
~M

>

>

and their $MAIL variables are all set to /var/spool/mail/$USER

(this machine only has four users, including root)

From kens at cad2cam.com  Wed Jun 19 21:52:26 2002

Subject: [PLUG] weird NFS behavior
In-Reply-To: <20020617213911.A30263@sharky.dyndns.org>
Message-ID: <NMEPJGMCLGBMCOCPJFHKOEAKDKAA.kens@cad2cam.com>

We get these at work a lot between Linux and Solaris.  Means the NFS client
cannot get a connection to the Sun NFS server.  The server is busy doing
something else.

Ken

From kens at cad2cam.com  Wed Jun 19 21:57:34 2002
From: kens at cad2cam.com (Kenneth G. Stephens)
Date: Wed, 19 Jun 2002 21:57:34 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Runlevel Processes As Different User
In-Reply-To: <20020619014157.63d08414.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <NMEPJGMCLGBMCOCPJFHKCEALDKAA.kens@cad2cam.com>

Take a look at functions in the /etc/rc.d/init.d directory (RedHat).  There
is a daemon function that will start up a service with a specified user.

Ken

> -----Original Message-----
> From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
> [mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]On Behalf Of Jason Van Cleve
> Sent: Wednesday, June 19, 2002 1:42 AM
> To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> Subject: [PLUG] Runlevel Processes As Different User
>
>
> O ye wise and powerful sysadmin types,
>
> I have a problem, for which I have a solution I don't much like.  I want
> to run my database server from an init script as a different user, for
> purposes of security.  But this database, Sybase SQL Anywhere 7, doesn't
> seem to have any options for changing the user when run as a daemon.
> Apparently Sybase is confident in the security of their products.
>
> Anyway, I started writing an init script to use the su command with the
> "-c" option--the only way I can find to do this.  But su can be tricky,
> and I quickly found it impracticable to stuff everything into the string
> following "-c".  For one thing, su tweaks the path, so I would have to
> wedge "export PATH=$PATH;" in there to get around that.  And then there
> is the command(s) itself, which may contain quotes, so I have embedded
> quotes to wrestle with.  Oh, and if I want the $USER variable to be
> right, I need to add the "-" option, which fubars the rest of my
> environment.
>
> Thus, my solution was to create a script that takes the standard init
> commands (start|stop|restart, etc.) and call that from my runlevel
> script, in this general form:
>
> 	su - $RUN_USER -c "$RUN_SCRIPT start"
>
> This allowed all of the environment logic to go in the other script, yet
> it still seems redundant to have to create a separate script in order
> just to su to a daemon user at boot time.  So I'm just wondering if
> anyone has a more elegant solution on hand.
>
>
> Also and by the way, what's an easy way to find files matching a given
> date or time?  The best I can do is something like this:
>
> 	find /starting/path -printf "%p - %c\n" | grep "Jun 12 20:53"
>
> Thanks once more,
>
> --Jason Van Cleve
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>




From sandy at herring.org  Thu Jun 20 05:18:40 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 05:18:40 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] up2date && apache
Message-ID: <20020620051840.A15319@kippered.herring.org>

A heads-up on the RH up2date on Apache. I loaded the update last night. No
.rpmnew files were created, and `rpm -q apache' showed the apache had been
upgraded to apache-1.3.22-6, so I went to bed thinking all was well. This
morning, I wasn't able to connect to www.herring.org, and discovered httpd
was dead (although the PID was valid). I restarted httpd and it came up
fine. Here's what I found in /etc/httpd/error_log:

[Thu Jun 20 00:01:22 2002] [warn] child process 10952 did not exit, sending another SIGHUP
[Thu Jun 20 00:01:22 2002] [notice] SIGHUP received.  Attempting to restart
Syntax error on line 36 of /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf:
Cannot load /etc/httpd/modules/mod_log_config.so into server: /etc/httpd/modules/mod_log_config.so: undefined symbol: ap_escape_logitem
[Thu Jun 20 04:38:59 2002] [notice] Apache/1.3.22 (Unix)  (Red-Hat/Linux) mod_ssl/2.8.5 OpenSSL/0.9.6b DAV/1.0.2 PHP/4.0.6 mod_perl/1.26 configured -- resuming
normal operations

The last line was written after the `service httpd restart' I did when I got
up this morning. After the restart, the config file is fine...

[root at kippered conf]# service httpd configtest
Syntax OK

I'd suggest restarting httpd after doing an up2date for the apache bug fix
before cron.daily triggers syslogd.

Sandy

On Thu, 20 Jun 2002, Sandy Herring wrote:

> .rpmnew files were created, and `rpm -q apache' showed the apache had been
> upgraded to apache-1.3.22-6, so I went to bed thinking all was well. This
> morning, I wasn't able to connect to www.herring.org, and discovered httpd

I've run into similar problems with some services.  Typically I shut the 
service down, do the update, then start the service.  Some RPMs just don't 
handle this well but it could be an issue with updating a running service 
instead of a RPM construction.
   Best case(?) was I had named crash (stopped responding) on me after an 
update.

He heard there oft the flying sound
Of feet as light as linden-leaves,
Of music welling underground,
In hidden hollows quavering.
Now withered lay the hemlock-sheaves,
And one by one with sighing sound
Whispering fell the beechen leaves
In the wintry woodland wavering.

He sought her ever, wandering far
Where leaves of years were thickly strewn,
By light of moon and ray of star
In frosty heavens shivering.
Her mantle glinted in the moon,
As on a hill-top high and far
She danced, and at her feet was strewn
A mist of silver quivering.

When winter passed, she came again,
And her song released the sudden spring,
Like rising lark, and falling rain,
And melting water bubbling.
He saw the elven-flowers spring
About her feet, and healed again
He longed by her to dance and sing
Upon the grass untroubling.
		-- J. R. R. Tolkien

From karlheg at microsharp.com  Thu Jun 20 09:28:24 2002
From: karlheg at microsharp.com (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 09:28:24 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian GNU/Linux "woody" apache/perl problems.
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206131539300.31896-100000@shaft.bitmine.net> <20020613230940.GA1222@austin.rr.com>
Message-ID: <3D1202A8.2070305@microsharp.com>

David Bridges wrote:
>>However, when I suggested to the package manager that I should install one
>>of the several available Apache packages, the package manager told me that
>>it must back-rev Perl to an unacceptable degree (from 5.6.1 to 5.005).
> 
> 
> That sounds weird, maybe you need to check your sources.list and verify
> the entries.  I have several woody boxes running the combination you are
> wanting.  dpkg shows me this
> ii  perl           5.6.1-7
> ii  apache         1.3.24-3

Yes, that is what is wrong.  If you installed from a recent CD image, 
the installer may have been set up so that it wrote lines for "stable" 
into the "/etc/apt/sources.list" file, since that will be correct upon 
release.  But, Woody has not been released yet, and thus is symlinked as 
"testing" rather than "stable" still.  It's just one of those 
transitional things.

Here's what I would do...  Copy in the attached "/etc/apt/sources.list" 
AND "/etc/apt/preferences" (taken from drizzle.pdxlinux.org), then run 
"# apt-get update".  That will add both "testing" and "unstable" to your 
sources list, and the "man apt_preferences" will tell it that "testing" 
is default, but allow install of "unstable" versions iff you specify 
"--target-release unstable" on the "apt-get" command line.  This also 
works from inside "aptitude" -- it will auto select only the default 
release, but you may hand select from the other release(s) if you like. 
  Note that this can theoreticly give you a downgrade path; I've never 
tested that myself.

At the package archive server, "stable" is currently a symlink to 
"potato", "testing" is currently a symlink to "woody", and "unstable" is 
currently a symlink to "sid".  That will change after the release -- 
"stable" will be a symlink to "woody", etc.  So, if you want "woody" and 
  "sid", not "testing" and "unstable", then be sure to edit that 
"sources.list", s/testing/woody/g and s/unstable/sid/g.  The 
"preferences" is already set up for either "woody" or "testing" to be at 
default priority.

Have you ever used "aptitude"?  If not, I strongly suggest "# apt-get 
install aptitude", and try it out.  It's a LOT BETTER than "dselect". 
No other package management user interface can match it!

> 
> This just appears to delete downloaded packages, no?  Does it actually
> clean out the package database?

RTFM, Folks.  If you are not sure what manuals there are, try "dpkg 
--list <PKG> | grep '/man/'" to see a list of them.  Also check the 
"/usr/share/doc/PKGNAME" directory, plus run "aptitude search 
PKGBASENAME" to see if there are additional "-doc" packages available.

Also see "# apt-get" with no arguments for a breif help message.

> It doesn't appear to do so.
> 

I think there is another switch for that function.

> Just so's y'all know, the working system and broke-ass system both use the
> same sources.list (OK, not the same file, but files with identical
> contents).
> 
> J.

perhaps "/etc/apt/preferences" (man apt_preferences), run "apt-get 
update", and it will have done what you want here.

From: Richard Steffens [mailto:rsteff at attbi.com]

From karlheg at microsharp.com  Thu Jun 20 09:44:14 2002
From: karlheg at microsharp.com (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 09:44:14 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian GNU/Linux "woody" apache/perl problems.
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206131644121.32119-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <3D12065E.9020002@microsharp.com>

Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> I did have an issue at install where the wrong sources.list was installed,
> but I put in the right data and ran apt-get dist-upgrade.  I don't believe
> anything was even installed while those sources were active.  but the
> data's in my database.  How can I purge the apt cache and download a fresh
> list without harming the db of installed software?

After you edit "/etc/apt/sources.list", you must run "apt-get update" to 
cause Apt to download the "Packages.gz" and "Sources.gz" files from the 
archive server.  After it downloads them, it automaticly rebuilds it's 
binary cache from that ascii rfc822 format package meta data.

You don't have to purge anything -- just fix up "sources.list" and run 
"apt-get update", THEN install packages.  If you are using "testing" or 
"unstable", you must run "apt-get update" quite often, since Debian is a 
very dynamic moving target.

>> Richard:
>>
>> NIS (aka yp) is the de facto standard for such things in the UNIX
>> environment.  If you want something a bit harder to implement but with
>> more potential for compatibility then something like an LDAP server might
>> be more appropriate.  (This also makes it simpler to have NT/UNIX/Other
>> with the same username and passwords and a single point for updates.)
>>
>> NIS can have issues on widely distributed networks, whereas LDAP usually
>> doesn't.  Just don't use LDAP for a general-purpose database.  Its feeble
>> backup and recovery methods will make that a disaster waiting to happen.
>>
>>   -- Steve Bonds

I recommend the book about "Directory Enabled Networks" (?), forest 
green with a photo of a suspension bridge on the cover.

From sandy at herring.org  Thu Jun 20 10:24:07 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Re: News Gateway

On Thu, 20 Jun 2002, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:

> > reading the list via nntp. I think that'd be a reasonable compromise.

> > mike at culbertson.info
> 
> Ok, there's one, and Mike's vote for sure counts.  So, what we need to 
> do is figure out how to make the news interface "closed" -- open to 
> subscribers only.  I think it's supposed to support authenticated 
> access, so we should look into that.  Anyone want to spend some time on 
> this task?  I'm WAY too busy right now.

Back on 6/12 I posted...


It is possible to use nnrpaccess to authenticate...

# Set these variables if you need to authenticate to your NNTP server for
# Usenet posting or reading.  If no authentication is necessary, specify None
# for both variables.
NNTP_USERNAME = None
NNTP_PASSWORD = None

...by including the appropriate info in ~mailman/Mailman/mm_cfg.py.


You could then dole that information out to those who want access via NNTP
(like Randal S.).

However, as I've previously noted, the SPAM we've seen so far hasn't been
inserted via NNTP, it's been SMTP. The list needs to be subscriber only to
prevent that. I also pointed out that it's also possible to require list
membership in general, but waive the requirement on a per user basis in the
General Posting Filters section...

Addresses of members accepted for       This settings can be used to designate
posting to this list without implicit   posting privileges to persons who are
approval requirement.                   not subscribers to the list. It may
                                        also be used to specify persons who
                                        are exclusively allowed to post.
                                        Please see the chart below for
                                        explanation.

See the "GNU Mailman List Management Guide v 2.0" guide for details:

http://web.aurora.edu/~ckolar//mailman/mailman-administration-v2.html

Sandy
--

=>http://herring.org/techie.html  |/\__/     http://herring.org/pub-key.asc

References: <DB4CCE75C758D211818F0008C7B1408933742580@beavertn-svr-78.nike.com>

page? I tried man rc, man rc.local, and man ja but find that there is
"No manual entry for rc," or any of the others. There is a man entry for
local, but it only has a list of builtin commands, including local.

From richard.langis at sun.com  Thu Jun 20 10:34:31 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis Jr.)
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 10:34:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian GNU/Linux "woody" apache/perl problems.
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206131644121.32119-100000@shaft.bitmine.net> <3D12065E.9020002@microsharp.com>
Message-ID: <3D121227.6050207@sun.com>

For what it's worth, I have a cron job that runs 'apt-get update' every 
day, and 'apt-get -d dist-upgrade' (-d = download only) every sunday 
morning (while I'm still asleep and not using my limited bandwidth).

So far it's worked quite well.  If I had more bandwidth available, I'd 
dist-upgrade every day.  'stable' users should also consider ading the 
security url to sources.list:

deb http://security.debian.org/ potato/updates main contrib non-free

-Richard


Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:


> You don't have to purge anything -- just fix up "sources.list" and run 
> "apt-get update", THEN install packages.  If you are using "testing" or 
> "unstable", you must run "apt-get update" quite often, since Debian is a 
> very dynamic moving target.


-- 
s u n  m i c r o s y s t e m s

   ~ Richard Langis Jr. ~
   richard.langis at sun.com




From Ben.Mazhary-Clark at nike.com  Thu Jun 20 10:47:16 2002
From: Ben.Mazhary-Clark at nike.com (Mazhary-Clark, Ben)
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 10:47:16 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Kiosk machines
Message-ID: <DB4CCE75C758D211818F0008C7B1408933742582@beavertn-svr-78.nike.com>

Richard,
Well my understanding with rc.local is it works similar to how autoexec.bat
did in the old DOS days.  Anything that is put on a line in that file will
get executed after all the other services have been started on the system.

I use the one under /etc/rc.d/rc.local to make additions to.  This is on a
RedHat 6.2 system with a 2.2.x kernel.  I don't know if other distros are
different, Debian doesn't seem to have that structure.
--ben
(Why aren't you all on #orlug? :)

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Jun 20 12:09:01 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 12:09:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Other Local Technical Lists/Groups
In-Reply-To: <20020620114036.B12610@agora.rdrop.com>
References: <20020620114036.B12610@agora.rdrop.com>
Message-ID: <200206201209.01253.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I also subscribe to the Specialized Systems Consultant (SSC) 
"linux-list". I've seen some people call it the Seattle Linux List but 
you don't have to be in the Seattle area to subscribe to the list and I 
see posts from people in other countries on the list as well. If you 
don't know what company SSC is, it's the one that publishes the "Linux 
Journal" magazine. The list of mailing lists they run can be found 
through this URL:

http://www.ssc.com/pipermail/index.html

Tony

From sandy at herring.org  Thu Jun 20 12:24:26 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 12:24:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Kiosk machines
In-Reply-To: <DB4CCE75C758D211818F0008C7B1408933742582@beavertn-svr-78.nike.com>; from Ben.Mazhary-Clark@nike.com on Thu, Jun 20, 2002 at 10:47:16AM -0700
References: <DB4CCE75C758D211818F0008C7B1408933742582@beavertn-svr-78.nike.com>
Message-ID: <20020620122426.A19159@kippered.herring.org>

Ben's explanation is correct. Check the comments in rc.local...

#!/bin/sh
#
# This script will be executed *after* all the other init scripts.
# You can put your own initialization stuff in here if you don't
# want to do the full Sys V style init stuff.


There's no `man' or `info' page - but it really doesn't need one. Also, note
that...

[bigfish at kippered bigfish]$ ls -l /etc/rc.d/rc.local /etc/rc.local
-rwxr-xr-x    1 root     root          220 Jul 10  2001 /etc/rc.d/rc.local
lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root           13 Feb 20 19:57 /etc/rc.local -> rc.d/rc.local

.../etc/rc.local is a symlink to /etc/rc.d/rc.local.

Sandy

p.s.    I don't have /usr/share/man/ja/man5/rc.local.5.gz on my system
        (RH7.2, full install)

From karlheg at microsharp.com  Thu Jun 20 13:34:05 2002
From: karlheg at microsharp.com (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 13:34:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Debian GNU/Linux "woody" apache/perl problems.
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206131644121.32119-100000@shaft.bitmine.net> <3D12065E.9020002@microsharp.com> <3D121227.6050207@sun.com>
Message-ID: <3D123C3D.8070304@microsharp.com>

Richard Langis Jr. wrote:
> For what it's worth, I have a cron job that runs 'apt-get update' every 
> day, and 'apt-get -d dist-upgrade' (-d = download only) every sunday 
> morning (while I'm still asleep and not using my limited bandwidth).

# apt-get install cron-apt






From karlheg at microsharp.com  Thu Jun 20 13:42:26 2002
From: karlheg at microsharp.com (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 13:42:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Adding disk partitions to an existing system
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206131431580.32406-100000@ns1.billmercer.com>
Message-ID: <3D123E32.3090603@microsharp.com>

I've had pretty good luck so far with "EVMS".  You would need a fresh 
hard drive to start with, and lots of know how to get it installed, 
since the current installers do not support it.  What I did was make a 
500 Mb "/" partition, a 1Gb swap, and the rest of the drive a Linux LVM 
type partition, to use for EVMS.  I installed a minimal Debian "woody" 
system in "/", then hand built a patched kernel (by using the Debian 
"kernel-package" system, "kernel-source-2.4.18" and "kernel-patch-evms") 
on another box to install there, then used "apt-get" to install the EVMS 
toolset on it.  I then logged into it from my X terminal via "ssh -X", 
and ran the "evmsgui" program.  I used that to make logical volumes in 
the big partition, made filesystems on them (XFS), mounted them (on 
"/mnt/tmp"), copied stuff on (tar -C /usr/ -cf - | tar -C /mnt/tmp -x) 
then moved aside the old "/usr", created a new mount point there, then 
mounted the new copy there.  Don't forget to adjust the "/etc/fstab" 
before a reboot!

From CurtisE at CurtisE.net  Thu Jun 20 14:09:30 2002

From karlheg at microsharp.com  Thu Jun 20 14:13:51 2002
From: karlheg at microsharp.com (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 14:13:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: News Gateway
References: <00be01c211a8$3e8581b0$6e00a8c0@mikeistan> <3D120A05.7080303@microsharp.com> <20020620102407.A18014@kippered.herring.org> <3D124322.6090904@sun.com>
Message-ID: <3D12458F.7000608@microsharp.com>

Richard Langis Jr. wrote:
> I believe Wil Cooley and AJ Lavin have fixed this after a few tests.  I 
> could be wrong - a message posted to the list from a non-subscribed 
> address would verify that it wasn't working as I thought.
> 
> -Richard
> 
> Sandy Herring wrote:
> 
> 
>> However, as I've previously noted, the SPAM we've seen so far hasn't been
>> inserted via NNTP, it's been SMTP. The list needs to be subscriber 
>> only to
>> prevent that. I also pointed out that it's also possible to require list
>> membership in general, but waive the requirement on a per user basis 
>> in the
>> General Posting Filters section...

Ok, does the news gateway still work?  It would be alright to set up 
authenticated access to the nntp server, and to keep the subscriber 
lists in sync somehow.  If that requires hacking "mailman", then we 
should first off "apt-get source" a copy and check it into CVS to work 
with.  I wonder how well the "cvs-buildpackage" scripts work nowadays? 
We can install them on drizzle and try them out.  The general idea is to 
start with known installable and working sources, fix them in a 
diff-able and maintainable way, use "debian/rules binary" to create an 
installable package, and install that.  Then, use "aptitude hold 
mailman" to put it on hold, to prevent an auto-upgrade that would 
replace our modified version.

Ideally, our patch can be sent off to the Mailman maintainers.

next generation Mailman.

Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:

> The general idea is to 
> start with known installable and working sources, fix them in a 
> diff-able and maintainable way, use "debian/rules binary" to create an 
> installable package, and install that.  Then, use "aptitude hold 
> mailman" to put it on hold, to prevent an auto-upgrade that would 
> replace our modified version.

This is what I did with the "uw-imapd-ssl" that is installed on 
"drizzle".  I did not, at the time, know how to get "/etc/c-client.cf" 
to work ("I accept the responsibility"), so I patched the sources to 
make the default user mailbox directory be "~/Mail" rather than "~", 
which I found annoying, especially on a box that I also log into and 
actually use my home directory there for things other than email mbox files.

From John.Hampton at gijoes.com  Thu Jun 20 15:12:18 2002

>>         (RH7.2, full install)
>
>My system is RH7.0, full install.

Ok, somebody please correct me if I am wrong, but the way that I understand how the man pages are laid out is that they are under /usr/share/man/<locale>/man<page number>/

so the location there is the Japanese (?) man pages since they are under /usr/share/man/ja/

your English man pages (or at least US) would be under /usr/share/man/us or maybe just /usr/share/man<page>

hope that is right :)

John Hampton
Programmer Analyst
G.I. Joe's, Inc.
john.hampton at gijoes.com

From verso at mac.com  Thu Jun 20 16:21:18 2002
From: verso at mac.com (Kelly Guimont)
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 16:21:18 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OT Cell Phone and PDA
In-Reply-To: <3D123EDF.CAE5903B@anodizing.com>
Message-ID: <B937B17E.3547%verso@mac.com>

Abraham (and whoever else),

There are a number of products that have tried to do just such a thing. By
and large these products fail primarily because you either get a gizzy that
is a bit bigger than a comfy cell phone, and a bit smaller than a comfy PDA.
It's one of the first gen of crossbreeding devices, and opinions on it are
varied. For the most part people are content to carry two devices to get the
full functionality out of each of them. Even now, items such as the Treo and
a few other PhoneDAs are making some sort of sacrifice, and the trick is to
find something that makes the sacrifice that you're willing to make.

To actually get started on shopping, you want to consider plans. Without
getting into a dreadful amount of detail, not all phones work on all
networks, so you need to think about what sort of cellular plan you need,
and how important coverage/pricing/airtime is vs. the device you really
want. Also, you said it was a department meeting...how many people are in
your department? That might be leverage for a corporate rate plan or some
sort of discount on the units themselves. (I worked in a company where the
rate plan was offered to every employee to help get the better deal, but
only certain people had their bill paid by the company. It was such a good
rate plan there was no upgrade until about two weeks ago. I had the same
plan for over 3 years!)

Treo is good, I have a lot of faith in Handspring and I think they might
have figured it out. From what little I've played with a Treo, it seems that
they get it and seemed to do it right. You may be able to find the Kyocera
palm phone on a discount, it was a first generation device. Samsung, I
believe, (but can't confirm since the mobile section of the site doesn't
work for me) makes a phone that has the same PhoneDA functionality. Verizon
is now selling a Thera from Audiovox, which appears to be a pocketpc phone.
Nokia just came out with one that looks pretty slick:
http://www.nokiausa.com/communicator/features/1,4983,,00.html
And there's a PocketPC Phone Edition on the Voicestream site now:
http://www.voicestream.com/pocketpc/default.asp

You also need to consider what you want from the combo: some Nokia phones
(and others, I'm guessing) offer scheduling and address books. Do you want
more? I ask because of pricing. To get the combo, you're pretty much going
to be paying the price of two devices.

Well! I hope I haven't overwhelmed anyone with all this info or bored
anybody. I hope this answers your question, Abraham. It felt kinda good to
flex my brain, and even better to answer a question on PLUG! So many of them
fly waaaaaaay over my head.

Hope this helps,
-Kelly


Empire had the better ending! All Jedi had was a buncha muppets!  -Clerks

From mike at computer-arts.net  Thu Jun 20 17:35:41 2002
From: mike at computer-arts.net (Mike Witt)
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 17:35:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Kiosk machines
References: <DB4CCE75C758D211818F0008C7B1408933742582@beavertn-svr-78.nike.com> <mailman.1024601119.24800.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <3D1274DD.812E7EA3@computer-arts.net>

> #!/bin/sh
> #
> # This script will be executed *after* all the other init scripts.
> # You can put your own initialization stuff in here if you don't
> # want to do the full Sys V style init stuff.

My experience (FWIW) is that a little care is required here. Although
rc.local executes last, "last" means that all the commands in the
previous scripts have been *initiated*.  Whether they have been
*completed* or not, is dependent on the specific command. For example,
when rc.local starts executing, there may be daemons in the process
of initializing themselves, but not completely up and running yet.

Just something to thing about. 

-Mike

-- 
Mike Witt 
Computer Arts, West Linn Oregon, USA
http://www.computer-arts.net/~mike


From carla at bratgrrl.com  Thu Jun 20 11:26:08 2002
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 18:26:08 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] RH 7.3 Install Issue
In-Reply-To: <E50C78AF1CD9C7468CE52A3399B617440169729C@ljcbs067>
References: <E50C78AF1CD9C7468CE52A3399B617440169729C@ljcbs067>
Message-ID: <200206210116.g5L1GvR11749@smtp.easystreet.com>

A lot of people have had problems with homegrown RH 7.3 cds. I had a stubborn 
Disk2, and what's really irritating is there is no option to try another 
disk- the whole installation has to start over. I've always used CDRWs, 
because I test a lot of distros & don't care to have bales of CDRs cluttering 
up the joint. I made RH 7.3 finally install by burning Disk2 to a TDK CDR. I 
don't know if it's some funkiness with the ISO, maybe RH is using finicky 
bits, or if CDRWs are getting crappier.

Carla

Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 18:45:42 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] /var/spool/mail/.forward
In-Reply-To: <3D11592F.6F6E9809@computer-arts.net>; from mike@computer-arts.net on Wed, Jun 19, 2002 at 09:25:19PM -0700
References: <3D0E0CB8.39B494BD@computer-arts.net> <mailman.1024415538.12097.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <3D11592F.6F6E9809@computer-arts.net>
Message-ID: <20020620184542.C21881@kippered.herring.org>

On Wed, 19 Jun 2002, Mike Witt wrote: 
> Sandy Herring wrote:
> > 
> > Mike,
> > 
> > Sounds like you have a user with $MAIL set to /var/spool/mail rather than
> > /var/spool/mail/$USER - either that or $USER is null for some user.
> > 
> > Sandy
> 
> Could a "user" include someone like apache, squid, named, and so on? 
> I checked all the regular users (root + every one with a login)
> and their $MAIL variables are all set to /var/spool/mail/$USER
> 
> (this machine only has four users, including root)

Mike,

It's extremely unlikely that apache, squid, et al. would be sending email.
Here are some things to investigate...


Do any of your users have a .forward file?

        If so, what are the permissions on the user's home directory?

        I'll wager this is where your problem is. See...
        http://www.ii.com/internet/robots/procmail/qs/#setPermissions

Failing that...

You don't have a user with /var/spool/mail for a home directory, do you?!

Have you checked to make sure that $USER is getting set correctly for each
of the 4 users on your system?

What are the permissions on /var, /var/spool and /var/spool/mail?

What MTA are you using?

    If it's sendmail, what is ForwardPath set to in sendmail.cf?


Hope that helps,
Sandy
--

From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Jun 20 20:01:17 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 20:01:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] RH 7.3 Install Issue
In-Reply-To: <200206210116.g5L1GvR11749@smtp.easystreet.com>
References: <E50C78AF1CD9C7468CE52A3399B617440169729C@ljcbs067>
	<200206210116.g5L1GvR11749@smtp.easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <20020620200117.23ba4901.russj@dimstar.net>

Actually, there's a "check disk" option in the RH 7.3 setup. When the first screen comes up, you can choose that, and then it will do MD5s on each disk prior to installation. That way you can be sure of having good media.

On Thu, 20 Jun 2002 18:26:08 +0000
Carla Schroder <carla at bratgrrl.com> wrote:

> bits, or if CDRWs are getting crappier.

From revans at e-z.net  Thu Jun 20 20:30:41 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 20:30:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Adding disk partitions to an existing system
In-Reply-To: <3D123E32.3090603@microsharp.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206131431580.32406-100000@ns1.billmercer.com>
    <3D123E32.3090603@microsharp.com>
Message-ID: <20020621032838.XUKW1547.sccrmhc02.attbi.com@downtown>

thought was better in one or the other,  any technical issues with either, and

Russell



On Thu, 20 Jun 2002 13:42:26 -0700, Karl M. Hegbloom said:

> I've had pretty good luck so far with "EVMS".  You would need a fresh 
>  hard drive to start with, and lots of know how to get it installed, 
>  since the current installers do not support it.  What I did was make a 
>  500 Mb "/" partition, a 1Gb swap, and the rest of the drive a Linux LVM 
>  type partition, to use for EVMS.  I installed a minimal Debian "woody" 
>  system in "/", then hand built a patched kernel (by using the Debian 
>  "kernel-package" system, "kernel-source-2.4.18" and "kernel-patch-evms") 
>  on another box to install there, then used "apt-get" to install the EVMS 
>  toolset on it.  I then logged into it from my X terminal via "ssh -X", 
>  and ran the "evmsgui" program.  I used that to make logical volumes in 
>  the big partition, made filesystems on them (XFS), mounted them (on 
>  "/mnt/tmp"), copied stuff on (tar -C /usr/ -cf - | tar -C /mnt/tmp -x) 
>  then moved aside the old "/usr", created a new mount point there, then 
>  mounted the new copy there.  Don't forget to adjust the "/etc/fstab" 
>  before a reboot!
>  
>  
>  
>  _______________________________________________
>  PLUG mailing list
>  PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>  http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>  
>  




From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jun 20 20:29:38 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 20:29:38 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Debian GNU/Linux "woody" apache/perl problems.
In-Reply-To: <3D12065E.9020002@microsharp.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206202027450.19690-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 20 Jun 2002, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> After you edit "/etc/apt/sources.list", you must run "apt-get update"
> to cause Apt to download the "Packages.gz" and "Sources.gz" files from
> the archive server.  After it downloads them, it automaticly rebuilds
> it's binary cache from that ascii rfc822 format package meta data.
> 
> You don't have to purge anything -- just fix up "sources.list" and run
> "apt-get update", THEN install packages.  If you are using "testing"
> or "unstable", you must run "apt-get update" quite often, since Debian
> is a very dynamic moving target.

I thought I made it clear that this had already been done multiple times.

Sorry if that wasn't properly expressed.

I find that if I use apt-get install <packagename>, I get the latest
versin of the package, but dselect lists "stable" versions of all the
packages that aren't installed.

It's very odd.

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jun 20 20:40:46 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Re: News Gateway

On Thu, 20 Jun 2002, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> Ok, does the news gateway still work?  It would be alright to set up
> authenticated access to the nntp server, and to keep the subscriber
> lists in sync somehow.

I've seen the idea tossed around, but I haven't seen a rebuttal yet:

What is preventing the news gateway from properly working when the list is
set to subscriber-only?

Doesn't the news gateway read the From: header of news posts and check
them against the subscriber list?

Then, if someone wants to use the news gateway primarily, they can simply
check the "no mail" option within mailman.

Someone please post to the list (or me personally, I suppose, but I'll
likely just restate it to the list) why this wouldn't work.

Thanks.

I still think the group could go through one last name change:

Portland Unix-GNU/Linux Users Group

This gets us more in line with proper nomenclature (for PR purposes, of
course WE all know what the GNU system is and why it is an inherent part
of this organization, but the rest of the world could use the
clarification and edification) and meets all the requirements to get
Stallman to talk to the group specifically.  (I'm semi-involved in a
project that might include Stallman coming to speak in town anyway, but he
wouldn't be coming to PLUG.)

And we get the cooler and more likely unique acronym PUGLUG.

And puglug.org is ours (well, mine until the group wants it).
