From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jun 20 20:47:10 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 20:47:10 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Kiosk machines
In-Reply-To: <3D11EA84.B47AA5AE@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206202044500.19690-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 20 Jun 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:
> What concept do I need to read up on to understand how to set up a
> Linux machine so that it will run a kiosk application? The problem I'm
> trying to figure out is how to have the machine automatically log in
> as a limited ability user after a power up and start the kiosk
> application when no one is around.

You should look at the init and login processes.

Init doesn't have to call login at all.  You could do something else
entirely.

Or, if you want an X app, you could use gdm or xdm from an init script and
auto-login as a particular user with a .xsession that runs your kiosk
application as the root window and disables X-specific key bindings.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org




From codeyeti at yahoo.com  Thu Jun 20 20:50:08 2002
From: codeyeti at yahoo.com (Michael Smith)
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 20:50:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Compromise
Message-ID: <3D12A26B.916DB567@yahoo.com>

Hey guys

There's an exploit for apache that could get ugly
here fairly soon... it was announced earlier this
week and now somebody's saying that they've had a
kit for it for several months.

http://online.securityfocus.com/news/493

The bottom line is: if you're running a version of
apache lower than 1.3.24 or 2.0.36, you might have
a problem.  If you're running apache on windows,
then you've got something to worry about.

Here's the deal from the apache people:
http://httpd.apache.org/info/security_bulletin_20020617.txt

--Mike

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jun 20 21:34:50 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Kiosk machines

On Thu, 20 Jun 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:
> > You should look at the init and login processes.
> 
> Thanks. That's the answer I was looking for: what to study up on.

Right.  I knew that.  Glad to help.

But, again, also look at XSession scripts related to X display managers.

They could probably hold a more direct key without mucking about in the
lower level init and login stuff.

(However, you'll find that changing the behavior of init is just a matter
of modifying your /etc/inittab.  It's even kind of straightforward.)

Actually, there's a "check disk" option in the RH 7.3 setup. When the first
screen comes up, you can choose that, and then it will do MD5s on each disk
prior to installation. That way you can be sure of having good media.

From neil at pacifier.com  Fri Jun 21 09:09:31 2002
From: neil at pacifier.com (Neil Anuskiewicz)
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 09:09:31 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Networking course update
Message-ID: <Pine.BSO.4.33.0206210907090.9544-100000@shell.pacifier.com>

I talked to Ed, of ALC, and he tells me 5 people have now signed up for
Linux Networking. That means that the course is definately going to go forward
(enough people signed up). Excellent!

If anyone else is interested here is the info:

------

Okay, Ed Sawicki and the Accelerated Learning Center (ALC) have now
scheduled the Linux Networking Course. So far,  Carla Schroder and I have
committed to taking the course (and several others have expressed
interest). We need a total of six people to sign up for it to be viable
for ALC to run the course. I really hope that at least four more people
sign up for the course!

Dates: Three Thursdays in July - 11th, 18th, and 25th.

Time: 8:30 AM - 4:30 PM

Place: Novell's Portland office. You can find directions and a map here:
http://www.panug.org/meetings/index.htm#direct

Course Outline:
http://www.alcpress.com/training/courses/linuxnetworking.htm

Text: ALC gives a textbook to each student.

Cost: $325

How to register: Call ALC's office at 503-635-6370

I consider this course an experiment of sorts. ALC runs these courses all
over the country (charging $595) but was reluctant to run the course in
Portland because of concerns about enrollment. I had to lobby a bit to
persuade them to run the course in Portland.

If this course is a success in terms of enrollment, then it is much more
likely that ALC will regularly run Linux Networking here in Portland. In
addition, it is more likely that ALC will run Apache Bootcamp, DNS
bootcamp, Linux System Administration, etc. Since Portland is home to ALC
we will likely get fairly substantial discounts on the cost of each
course.

I've never taken a course from Ed but I have heard from several people
that he is an excellent instructor. I look forward to this course. It will
be a lot of fun.

From John.Hampton at gijoes.com  Fri Jun 21 10:48:32 2002
From: John.Hampton at gijoes.com (John Hampton)
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 10:48:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] RH 7.3 Install Issue
Message-ID: <76CAC90361FD1B4EABBCDEE0B822B844014CF2@gilligan.gijoes.com>

Carla said:
>That's a good notion- thing is, I've burned and installed dozens of Linuxes 
>from ISO- Red hat, Mandrake, Debian, Slackware- and only RH 7.3 has had this 
>particular trouble.  My CDROM drives are all less than two years old. I have 
>an old HP CDRW and a new Liteon 24x10x40 which I adore, hasn't made a coaster 
>yet. 
>

Don't really want to be redundant, but I too think that it is a burning problem.  I haven't installed RedHat, but I had this problem with Mandrake.  When I burned the CDs at 8x some of them worked fine and others didn't.  However, when I burned the images at 1x (only takes about 75 minutes :) all of my CDs seemed to work fine.  Now I only burn ISOs at 1 speed (unless I am in a hurry and don't care about coasters).  So take it for what it is worth, but I would try again burning them at 1x (unless, of course, you burned them at 1x in the first place).

John Hampton
Programmer Analyst
G.I. Joe's, Inc.
john.hampton at gijoes.com




From dealy at deatech.com  Fri Jun 21 11:34:02 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 11:34:02 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] RH 7.3 Install Issue
In-Reply-To: <3D1363BF.70003@sun.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206211125230.10176-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Fri, 21 Jun 2002, Richard Langis Jr. wrote:

> Interesting theory...  I guess my old Portege 660cdt (150mhz Pentium
> Laptop) and 4x cd-rom shouldn't be able to read the new Debian 2.2r5
> cdr's that Ben brought over the other day...  Oh, wait it did.  ;)
>
> Of course, I'm sure it's more dependant on the drive maker and the
> quality standards they use in mfg than it is the CDR's.
>
> You get what you pay for.  :)
[snip]

It's important to remember that the specs for CDR and CDRW are not the
same as for standard CDs, so older CDROM drives that were not spec'd for
reading CDR/CDRW while they may work, are working at or beyond their
specifications.  It also makes a difference what hardware was used for
writing the disks, all three of my old CDROM drives have trouble reading
anything written on first or second generation HP CD writers, though two
of them generally work if the disk was written using some other hardware,
but even then they are often rather slow with lots of retrys.  Only one of
these was a somewhat cheap drive, but they are all old (four to seven
years).

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com




From matchboy at tearitalldown.com  Fri Jun 21 12:40:37 2002
From: matchboy at tearitalldown.com (r0bbY russell aka MaTcHBoY)
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 12:40:37 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] apache conf question
Message-ID: <00de01c2195b$845cd570$7cf397d0@imarkpdx.com>

On a server I have a folder called /files

well. people can upload to that folder...and rather than me limit what they
can upload (checking for php,php3, phtml, pl...etc) i want them to be able
to upload anything..but i dont want those files to be ran on that folder.

so if someone went to /files/runscript.php  it would run... right now.. is
there a directive that will tell apache to not run a file like it would
normally? perhaps it would just display it as the file code, correct?
I'm sure that there is some simple directive that I just need to add to my
httpd.conf file, correct?

-robby




From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Jun 21 12:48:55 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 12:48:55 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] apache conf question
In-Reply-To: <00de01c2195b$845cd570$7cf397d0@imarkpdx.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206211243380.1438-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On Fri, 21 Jun 2002, r0bbY russell aka MaTcHBoY wrote:

> On a server I have a folder called /files
> 
> well. people can upload to that folder...and rather than me limit what they
> can upload (checking for php,php3, phtml, pl...etc) i want them to be able
> to upload anything..but i dont want those files to be ran on that folder.
> 
> so if someone went to /files/runscript.php  it would run... right now.. is
> there a directive that will tell apache to not run a file like it would
> normally? perhaps it would just display it as the file code, correct?
> I'm sure that there is some simple directive that I just need to add to my
> httpd.conf file, correct?

If you want everything to be treated as a text file, you can tell 
Apache that:

  <Location /files>
    ForceType text/plain
  </Location>

Or, if you only need to stop CGI and PHP execution, you could be a bit 
more selective:

  <Location /files>
    AddType  text/plain .php
    Options  -ExecCGI -Includes
  </Location>

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>





From athlonrobnf at cs.com  Fri Jun 21 13:05:41 2002
From: athlonrobnf at cs.com (AthlonRob)
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 13:05:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Firewall Suggestions?
Message-ID: <005401c2195f$07848cb0$0200a8c0@robxp>

Hi-

I'm trying to set up a firewall.  I've just been following the IPMasq Howto for the most part, and do have a basic firewall set up.  However, I want something a little bit more secure.  Folks inside my LAN will be able to open VNC sessions and have SSH access (including X11 forwarding) to the server... I don't want them to be able to (for instance) open up a SOCKS proxy on a high port which folks could tunnel through to get inside the LAN.

I don't want to mess with connections originating from inside the LAN... but I don't want anybody to be able to set up a LISTENING service which people could access from the Internet... unless I, root, say they can.

Any suggestions as to an iptables-based firewall configuration program or script or something?  :-)

I'm running Slackware 8.1... and usually do these kinds of things by hand... but I'm just having a heck of a time understanding the different commands and rules you use to get a firewall going.

Rob
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: http://lists.pdxlinux.org/pipermail/plug/attachments/20020621/0eaa0fcd/attachment.html 

From sandy at herring.org  Fri Jun 21 14:01:44 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 14:01:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Firewall Suggestions?
In-Reply-To: <005401c2195f$07848cb0$0200a8c0@robxp>; from athlonrobnf@cs.com on Fri, Jun 21, 2002 at 01:05:41PM -0700
References: <005401c2195f$07848cb0$0200a8c0@robxp>
Message-ID: <20020621140144.F29133@kippered.herring.org>

On Fri, 21 Jun 2002, AthlonRob wrote: 
> Hi-
> 
> I'm trying to set up a firewall. [...]
> 
> I don't want to mess with connections originating from inside the LAN...
> but I don't want anybody to be able to set up a LISTENING service which
> people could access from the Internet... unless I, root, say they can.
> 
> Any suggestions as to an iptables-based firewall configuration program or
> script or something?  :-)

You may have a shorter learning curve with TCP Wrappers than with iptables
or ipchains. Just edit /etc/hosts.allow and /etc/hosts.deny and restart
xinetd. See `man 5 hosts_access' and `man host_options'. You can easily
allow outbound traffic and limit inbound connections. 

A good firewall FAQ can be found at: http://www.interhack.net/pubs/fwfaq/

hth,
Sandy
--

From skullone at servuhome.net  Fri Jun 21 14:24:34 2002
From: skullone at servuhome.net (Brent Jones)
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 14:24:34 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Firewall Suggestions?
References: <005401c2195f$07848cb0$0200a8c0@robxp>
Message-ID: <002601c2196a$0a6fc4c0$0200000a@skullone>

What I just recently did, I bought the new OpenBSD 3.1 release originaly as a secondary DNS box.
But later on, I setup packet forwarding and packet filtering.
Its working just awesome, far better then any other firewall Ive used. The rules are a little different then IPTables, but pretty easy to pick up.
The main openbsd networking FAQ is here: http://www.openbsd.org/faq/faq6.html#PF
And I also found this usefull: http://real.ath.cx/BSDinstall.html

Only drawback, theres no public CD images of OpenBSD 3.1, but you can find 3.0 on planetmirror.com

Brent Jones
brentj at servuhome.net

Thanks Sandy  :-)

I'm actually using inetd... but I have set up some very basic fules with
hosts.allow and hosts.deny.  I could be missing something totally here...
but I don't think tcpwrappers will keep users logged on via VNC on the
internal network from opening up servers which are open to the external
network (the Internet)... will they?

The basic iptables rules I set up from the IPMasq FAQ, in addition to my
tcpwrappers setup should keep inetd-started servers well behaved... but my
concern is what those logged on via VNC might accidentally do.  My Linux
networking understanding isn't that great... but I seem to recall users are
able to open up and listen to high port numbers (over 1024, was it?).  I
want to disable that, except specific ports I say are ok... for instance, I
want to allow a friend to open a tightvnc connection after he logs in with
SSH.

Thanks for the input and directions... I'm off to do more reading... getting
Squid-Cache and SquidGuard up and running at the time.  :-)

From dealy at deatech.com  Fri Jun 21 14:49:03 2002
From: dealy at deatech.com (Shannon C. Dealy)
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 14:49:03 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Firewall Suggestions?
In-Reply-To: <20020621140144.F29133@kippered.herring.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206211429010.10504-100000@critter.deatech.com>

On Fri, 21 Jun 2002, Sandy Herring wrote:

> On Fri, 21 Jun 2002, AthlonRob wrote:
> > Hi-
> >
> > I'm trying to set up a firewall. [...]
> >
> > I don't want to mess with connections originating from inside the LAN...
> > but I don't want anybody to be able to set up a LISTENING service which
> > people could access from the Internet... unless I, root, say they can.
> >
> > Any suggestions as to an iptables-based firewall configuration program or
> > script or something?  :-)
>
> You may have a shorter learning curve with TCP Wrappers than with iptables
> or ipchains. Just edit /etc/hosts.allow and /etc/hosts.deny and restart
> xinetd. See `man 5 hosts_access' and `man host_options'. You can easily
> allow outbound traffic and limit inbound connections.

TCP Wrappers won't prevent anyone from setting up an insecure listening
service, it only applies to programs specifically coded to support it, or
those programs which have been "wrapped" by it through running it within
the wrapper script (usually done from within inetd or one of it's
variants).  Any program without TCP wrappers support, or launched from
outside the wrapper is completely unprotected.

Setting up a firewall to meet the above requirements can be a little
complicated, since you are trying to protect it from both internal
mistakes/abuse and external attacks, generally, the simplest approach is
to not let the users do anything "through" the firewall, and instead setup
a proxy server for them to use and configure your firewall to block
everything but the proxy.  Then as new services are needed, add different
proxies and/or open up the firewall for just the desired service,
preferably with limiting the use of the service to as few internal
computers as is practical.

Unfortunately, since I have always done my firewalls by hand, I don't know
how good any of the firewall programs are.  I have heard some good things
about bastille, but have no first hand knowledge.  One little warning,
from the configuration programs/scripts I have seen in the past, I think
in most cases, you really need to take the time to understand firewalls to
use these scripts safely and effectively, otherwise most of them will
allow you to configure a firewall which is wide open.

Shannon C. Dealy      |               DeaTech Research Inc.
dealy at deatech.com     |          - Custom Software Development -
                      |    Embedded Systems, Real-time, Device Drivers
Phone: (800) 467-5820 | Networking, Scientific & Engineering Applications
   or: (541) 451-5177 |                  www.deatech.com

Brian,

Thanks, but I already tried that.  Says "command not found".  Our admin
assures me that we don't actually have vi on the box and vi is, in fact,
vim.  Since it identifies itself as vim and all of its documentation is for
vim, I assume that this is, in fact, the case.  Typing "man vi":

  VIM(1)
  ...blah, blah, blah...

Since it's behaving like vi, I assume that this is why it's using
vi-emulation mode.

From raanders at acm.org  Fri Jun 21 14:54:58 2002
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 14:54:58 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Firewall Suggestions?
In-Reply-To: <005401c2195f$07848cb0$0200a8c0@robxp>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206211443330.19965-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Fri, 21 Jun 2002, AthlonRob wrote:

> Hi-
> 
> I'm trying to set up a firewall.  I've just been following the IPMasq
> Howto for the most part, and do have a basic firewall set up.  
> However, I want something a little bit more secure.  Folks inside my
> LAN will be able to open VNC sessions and have SSH access (including
> X11 forwarding) to the server... I don't want them to be able to (for
> instance) open up a SOCKS proxy on a high port which folks could
> tunnel through to get inside the LAN.
> 
> Any suggestions as to an iptables-based firewall configuration program
> or script or something?  :-)

Having set up several router/firewall systems I'd suggest going with
dedicated router/firewall hardware.  Then (hopefully) regardless of the
status of security updates on any of the computers you're pretty darn sure
your network is protected.
   Where I worked before we had a hard time convincing the customers to
spend the money to keep their systems up to date and I saw several get
broken into even through dial up lines.  Of course the bill to recover was 
a touch more than the updating would have been.

Heck I just put an Asante router/firewall on my home network.  I went for
the FriendlyNet FR3004C with a serial port that I'm using right now with a
56K modem until I sort out a broadband solution. 8-( About 600 feet to far 
for DSL.)


Rod
-- 
         Please don't tell my mother I'm a System Administrator.
                  She thinks I play piano in a bordello.

Try "vi -N";  This run vim non-compatible mode. Vi 
compatible mode which doesn't do syntax. You may need to 
muck about with your .vimrc

From kaile at centerspan.com  Fri Jun 21 17:39:35 2002
From: kaile at centerspan.com (Kaile Riser)
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 17:39:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Votes for linux needed
Message-ID: <3219EF1240D4D311A5920050041F2780020C24A4@mail.centerspan.com>

What if we don't think that's the one? :)

I actually happen to use MacOS / OSX for all my 'standard' computing needs
at home... with FreeBSD, Irix, and Solaris intermingled for all my other
machines. I think I have a Win2K box somewhere, but I never use it. At work,
I have a huge amount of linux servers setup and running (as well as Win2K,
WinXP, FreeBSD and Solaris). Basically, I have a very diverse experience
with different operating systems.

I happen to somewhat agree with David Coursey. For those who are not
computer literate (i.e. most windows only users I have met) getting an Xfree
desktop system working is close to impossible. I don't personally think it's
that great of a challenge, but I'm a system administrator. Most of these
people want to sit down and go. They don't want to know anything except what
button to click to "make it work".

In these situations, based on my experiences with XP, I would have to say
OSX is the best choice of the three for an easy and usable desktop with the
least amount of effort.

Whee!

Kaile

	As far as i'm concerned, Apple did it right with MacOS X.  I voted
for it because i've used it extensively for all sorts of development and
it's _nice_.  A big reason I was able to do different kinds of development
(gtk apps, web stuff, mod_perl, HTML::Mason, etc.) was the ultra-awesome
app from sourceforge called Fink.  After I installed it I tried "fink
install enlightentment"  as sort of a test to see how quickly it would
break.  It installed X and everything that I needed to run elightenment.
On top of that, I could choose to have X apps on the Aqua desktop or set a
hotkey to switch from X to Aqua.  So Lopster, Galeon, Evolution running on
one side.  Hit <cmd>-<opt>-A to switch back to Aqua for Photoshop, Flash,
etc.  IMO, that's about ten different kinds of cool.

If it had been a poll about what I trust more for a server I would have
voted Linux.  For the desktop though MacOS X has won me over.

-cm

From aj at haightmail.org  Fri Jun 21 19:29:06 2002
From: aj at haightmail.org (Aj Lavin)
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 19:29:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: News Gateway
In-Reply-To: <3D133D70.4000008@sun.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206202038420.19690-100000@shaft.bitmine.net> <3D133D70.4000008@sun.com>
Message-ID: <20020622022906.GA7913@zappa>

On Fri, Jun 21, 2002 at 07:51:28AM -0700, Richard Langis Jr. wrote:
> Like I mentioned earlier, Wil and AJ figured this out on the plug-mmtest 
> list (try it out, subscribe to mmtest, then post a message to it from a 
> non-subscribed address, or use the news gateway).  I *believe* that they 
> were going to 'fix' the main list in the same manner.  

I do not have root access to the list server. In any case, changing
the policy of the PLUG lists is the list administrator's
responsibility.

> I'm looking into the options they've set right now.

The only change that Wilco made was to the MailMan test list,
"plug-mmtest". He just converted it to a closed list. As previously
documented, this has the effect of:

1. allowing subscribers only to post to plug-mmtest via email. Posts
from non-subscribers are held for moderator approval.

2. forwarding to the plug-mmtest mailing list of plug.mmtest newsgroup
posts that have a From: header equal to a list subscriber's address.

3. dis-allowing posts to the plug-mmtest mailing list From
non-subscribed email addresses.

Anyone can verify this policy by posting to plug-mmtest.

> Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> >
> >I've seen the idea tossed around, but I haven't seen a rebuttal yet:
> >
> >What is preventing the news gateway from properly working when the list is
> >set to subscriber-only?

Good question. What is the answer, Karl?

- Aj

From mike at computer-arts.net  Fri Jun 21 20:33:05 2002
From: mike at computer-arts.net (Mike Witt)
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 20:33:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] /var/spool/mail/.forward
References: <3D0E0CB8.39B494BD@computer-arts.net> <mailman.1024415538.12097.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <3D11592F.6F6E9809@computer-arts.net> <mailman.1024623981.12680.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <3D13EFF1.A07519E0@computer-arts.net>

> It's extremely unlikely that apache, squid, et al. would be sending email.
> Here are some things to investigate...
> 
> Do any of your users have a .forward file?

No, they don't.  However, one user (me) has a fairly elaborate
.procmail (primarily for spam control)

> 
>         If so, what are the permissions on the user's home directory?
> 
>         I'll wager this is where your problem is. See...
>         http://www.ii.com/internet/robots/procmail/qs/#setPermissions
> 
> Failing that...

> You don't have a user with /var/spool/mail for a home directory, do you?!

Well, yes. The user "mail":

% grep mail /etc/passwd
mail:x:8:12:mail:/var/spool/mail:/sbin/nologin

Also, /var/spool/mail is owned by the group mail and is group
writable (see below) - Is that anything out of the ordinary?

> Have you checked to make sure that $USER is getting set correctly for each
> of the 4 users on your system?

It is

> What are the permissions on /var, /var/spool and /var/spool/mail?

%ls -ld /var /var/spool /var/spool/mail
drwxr-xr-x   26 root     root         4096 Mar 18 18:14 /var
drwxr-xr-x   20 root     root         4096 Jun 12 15:20 /var/spool
drwxrwxr-x    2 root     mail         4096 Jun 21 19:39 /var/spool/mail

/var/spool/mail itself is writeable by the group mail. Is this
unusual? AFAIK it came that way default in the Red Hat install

% grep mail /etc/group
mail:x:12:mail

> What MTA are you using?
> 
>     If it's sendmail, what is ForwardPath set to in sendmail.cf?

Sendmail it is... To be honest, I can't figure out what $z and
$w are. This does appear to match the "example" in the sendmail
documentation. I once had a copy of the whole documentation on
the sendmail config file, but I can't find it at the moment.

# Forward file search path
O ForwardPath=$z/.forward.$w:$z/.forward

-Mike

Mike Witt 
Computer Arts, West Linn Oregon, USA
http://www.computer-arts.net/~mike

> >

> >         I'll wager this is where your problem is. See...

> > Failing that...

> mail:x:8:12:mail:/var/spool/mail:/sbin/nologin

> > Have you checked to make sure that $USER is getting set correctly for each

> 
> It is

> > What are the permissions on /var, /var/spool and /var/spool/mail?

> drwxr-xr-x   26 root     root         4096 Mar 18 18:14 /var

> drwxrwxr-x    2 root     mail         4096 Jun 21 19:39 /var/spool/mail

> unusual? AFAIK it came that way default in the Red Hat install

All of that is correct, as well.

> > What MTA are you using?
> > 
> >     If it's sendmail, what is ForwardPath set to in sendmail.cf?
> 
> Sendmail it is... To be honest, I can't figure out what $z and
> $w are. This does appear to match the "example" in the sendmail
> documentation. I once had a copy of the whole documentation on
> the sendmail config file, but I can't find it at the moment.
> 
> # Forward file search path
> O ForwardPath=$z/.forward.$w:$z/.forward

That's also correct. Excerpted from...

http://www.sendmail.org/~ca/email/doc8.9/op-sh-5.html

    $w The hostname of this site. This is the root name of this host 

    $z The home directory of the recipient.

I'm plum outta ideas on your problem, Mike. Any sendmail gurus wanna take an
at bat on this? You may try turning off your procmail recipes for a day or
two and see if the problem still exists.

From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Jun 21 21:50:07 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 21:50:07 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Network failure, different kernels of the same revision.
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206212143210.619-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

I have a Dell PowerEdge 4400 dual Xeon 800 with a pile of RAM.

It has an onboard eepro100 and a PCI rtl8139.

I installed with the Debian 3.0 bf2.4 CD.  I built the system running the
kernel from that release.

I realized that this was a single-proc kernel and figured I should
definitely go SMP on this little thing.

So, first I downloaded the kernel-source-2.4.18 package and configured and
built the kernel using make-kpkg.  That seemed to work smoothly.  Then I
did a dpkg -i to install my new kernel.

Odd thing is, when I rebooted the system, the network was unavailable.  I
double-checked that the drivers had picked up the two interfaces and that
the scripts had configured them properly.  Sure thing... there they
were.  I checked the physical connections and the routing table.  All
good.  No different than before.

Yet, I get no connectivity out.

Then I back-reved to the bf2.4 kernel (which wasn't a backrev at all
because it's still a 2.4.18 kernel) and everything worked again.

So then I tried apt-get install kernel-image-2.4.18-686-smp.  The install
went fine and I set up the initrd thingie in lilo and we were all ready to
go.

Rebooted to find I was in the same situation as my custom kernel:  Network
devices are present and configured, the routes are accurate, but I have no
network connectivity.

Again, back to bf2.4 kernel and everything works.

I'm at the end of my rope.  What am I forgetting?

Thanks.
J.

From mark at mjbynum.org  Fri Jun 21 21:51:25 2002
From: mark at mjbynum.org (Mark Bynum)
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 21:51:25 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Firewall Suggestions?
In-Reply-To: <20020622040126.7C6D72F2A2@einstein.seansdomain.org>
References: <005401c2195f$07848cb0$0200a8c0@robxp> <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206211443330.19965-100000@main.cyber-office.net> <20020621154921.B30106@kippered.herring.org> <20020622040126.7C6D72F2A2@einstein.seansdomain.org>
Message-ID: <20020621215125.A83187@agora.rdrop.com>

I bought an old Pentium 75 (for $50) and using a floppy based 
firewall. It's done using a distro from the linux router project 
(http://www.linuxrouter.org) or more specifically from
http://lrp.steinkuehler.net/.

It took a while to configure (a couple of days the first time, 
minutes each other time), and I've had to download new images 
every time they change my access (new provider, provider 
upgraded to new dhcp software, etc).  But I've been pretty
happy. I just wished I hadn't thrown my old 486 because it 
could've been used for the same thing.

Mark

From athlonrobnf at cs.com  Fri Jun 21 22:45:52 2002
From: athlonrobnf at cs.com (AthlonRob)
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 22:45:52 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Firewall Suggestions?
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206211429010.10504-100000@critter.deatech.com>
Message-ID: <012d01c219b0$14334cc0$0200a8c0@robxp>

>Unfortunately, since I have always done my firewalls by hand, I don't know
>how good any of the firewall programs are.  I have heard some good things
>about bastille, but have no first hand knowledge.  One little warning,
>from the configuration programs/scripts I have seen in the past, I think
>in most cases, you really need to take the time to understand firewalls to
>use these scripts safely and effectively, otherwise most of them will
>allow you to configure a firewall which is wide open.

Well, I've spent the day dinkin' around with this derned thing.  I must
say... I'm getting a little bit scared.  A few things have actually made
sense!  =O

I'm using the script from the IPMasq Howto document... 'Hard Firewall' ...
I've been able to modify it so I can open ports at will, but cannot close
them without running the whole script again.  To open the ports, I just run:

iptables -A INPUT -i eth1 -p tcp --dport <port> -j ACCEPT

...but had to disable logging (removed all references to drop-and-log-it)...
so am not totally sure what that does to me security-wise.  Just testing
from the laptop it seemed to have no effect but to disable logging.

I cut out all the useless comments in the interests of bandwidth saving.  I
appreciate all the links people have provided... but after looking through
them all, I think doing it myself is better, at least for me.  :-)

What do you guys think?  Will it be relatively secure from people logged on
to the server opening up servers to the Internet?  I'm still looking in to
how I might log any attack attempts, if I ever see any... if it's impossible
to do with what I have here, please hollar.  <g>  (the drop-and-log-it
things have all been commented out.  If I uncomment them, I get logging but
cannot open ports manually after the scrtipt has been run)

IPTABLES=/usr/sbin/iptables
LSMOD=/sbin/lsmod
DEPMOD=/sbin/depmod
INSMOD=/sbin/insmod
GREP=/bin/grep
AWK=/usr/bin/awk
SED=/usr/bin/sed
IFCONFIG=/sbin/ifconfig
EXTIF="eth1"
INTIF="eth0"
EXTIP="192.168.4.1"
INTNET="192.168.1.0/24"
INTIP="192.168.1.2/24"
UNIVERSE="0.0.0.0/0"
$DEPMOD -a
$INSMOD ip_tables
$INSMOD ip_conntrack
$INSMOD ip_conntrack_ftp
$INSMOD ip_conntrack_irc
$INSMOD iptable_nat
$INSMOD ip_nat_ftp
echo "1" > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_forward
$IPTABLES -P INPUT DROP
$IPTABLES -F INPUT
$IPTABLES -P OUTPUT DROP
$IPTABLES -F OUTPUT
$IPTABLES -P FORWARD DROP
$IPTABLES -F FORWARD
$IPTABLES -F -t nat
#$IPTABLES -F drop-and-log-it
$IPTABLES -X
$IPTABLES -Z
#$IPTABLES -N drop-and-log-it
#$IPTABLES -A drop-and-log-it -j LOG --log-level info
#$IPTABLES -A drop-and-log-it -j DROP
$IPTABLES -A INPUT -i lo -s $UNIVERSE -d $UNIVERSE -j ACCEPT
$IPTABLES -A INPUT -i $INTIF -s $INTNET -d $UNIVERSE -j ACCEPT
#$IPTABLES -A INPUT -i $EXTIF -s $INTNET -d $UNIVERSE -j drop-and-log-it
$IPTABLES -A INPUT -i $EXTIF -s $UNIVERSE -d $EXTIP -m state --state \
ESTABLISHED,RELATED -j ACCEPT
#$IPTABLES -A INPUT -s $UNIVERSE -d $UNIVERSE -j drop-and-log-it
$IPTABLES -A OUTPUT -o lo -s $UNIVERSE -d $UNIVERSE -j ACCEPT
$IPTABLES -A OUTPUT -o $INTIF -s $EXTIP -d $INTNET -j ACCEPT
$IPTABLES -A OUTPUT -o $INTIF -s $INTIP -d $INTNET -j ACCEPT
#$IPTABLES -A OUTPUT -o $EXTIF -s $UNIVERSE -d $INTNET -j drop-and-log-it
$IPTABLES -A OUTPUT -o $EXTIF -s $EXTIP -d $UNIVERSE -j ACCEPT
#$IPTABLES -A OUTPUT -s $UNIVERSE -d $UNIVERSE -j drop-and-log-it
$IPTABLES -A FORWARD -i $EXTIF -o $INTIF -m state --state
ESTABLISHED,RELATED \
-j ACCEPT
$IPTABLES -A FORWARD -i $INTIF -o $EXTIF -j ACCEPT
#$IPTABLES -A FORWARD -j drop-and-log-it
$IPTABLES -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o $EXTIF -j SNAT --to $EXTIP


Any input from y'all would be appreciated.  :-)

--
Rob
Running Slackware 8.1

>>>>> "Rob" == AthlonRob  <athlonrobnf at cs.com> writes:

Rob> I don't want to mess with connections originating from inside the
Rob> LAN... but I don't want anybody to be able to set up a LISTENING
Rob> service which people could access from the Internet... unless I,
Rob> root, say they can.

I don't think this is a problem.  Since an incoming connection
wouldn't know how to tell the firewall how to translate to a
particular internal IP number, inbound connections aren't possible to
machines inside unless you specifically map an external port to an
internal address/port.

Your iptables would look something like this:

  IPTABLES=/sbin/iptables
  EXTERNAL_IF=eth0

  $IPTABLES -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o $EXTERNAL_IF -j MASQUERADE

and if you wanted to do a specific mapping, add something like this:

  $IPTABLES -t nat -A PREROUTING -i $EXTERNAL_IF -p tcp --dport $EXTERNAL_PORT -j DNAT --to $INTERNAL_IP:22

which would map connections to the firewall on tcp port $EXTERNAL_PORT
to an internal box at $INTERNAL_IP address on its normal secure shell port.

So, as far as I know, your internal users can open LISTENING ports all
day long, but no one outside will be able to get to them unless the
firewall tells them how (with an $IPTABLES command like the second one).

If I am wrong on that, please tell me!  ;-)

-- 
Russell Senior         ``The two chiefs turned to each other.        
seniorr at aracnet.com      Bellison uncorked a flood of horrible       
                         profanity, which, translated meant, `This is
                         extremely unusual.' ''                      



From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Jun 21 23:55:08 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 21 Jun 2002 23:55:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Network failure, different kernels of the same revision.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206212143210.619-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206212143210.619-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <86ofe3pzub.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

Jeme> So, first I downloaded the kernel-source-2.4.18 package and
Jeme> configured and built the kernel using make-kpkg.  That seemed to
Jeme> work smoothly.  Then I did a dpkg -i to install my new kernel.

[...]

Jeme> I'm at the end of my rope.  What am I forgetting?

Just go to kernel.org and get the linux tarball and compile it:  

  cd /src
  tar xzvf /src_archive/kernel/v2.4/linux-2.4.18.tar.gz
  cd linux
  make xconfig (or whatever)
  make dep ; make bzImage ; make modules ; su -c 'make install ; make modules_install'

or words to that effect.  I've been using Debian since before it
existed but I've never stooped to using their kernel packaging.  The
manual way works just fine and involves less convolution (though you
may need to move the vmlinuz and System.map from / to /boot and/or
tweek the LILO or Grub configuration ... I've come to like Grub a lot
better recently, since it makes experimenting with different kernels a
bit easier).

                         extremely unusual.' ''

From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Jun 22 03:09:58 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat, 22 Jun 2002 03:09:58 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Network failure, different kernels of the same revision.
In-Reply-To: <86fzzfpwmm.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206220304270.4101-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 22 Jun 2002, Russell Senior wrote:
> Hmm.  Okay, in that case I'll start flailing.  In no particular order:

That's what I'm doing.

>   > Blinky lights?  

Link lights on both ends.  Blinky lights on either network interface, but
not on the remote end.

>   > When you try to ping something external, what message do you see?  

100% packet loss.  As though the network is unreachable, it just sits and
waits until I kill the ping, then reports that it got no responses.

>   > Can you ping localhost?  

I can ping the address associated with each of the interfaces.

>   > Is there a network debugging option in the kernel configuration?

Guh... I dunno.

>   > You might try pulling the PCI NIC and see if that helps.

I'm still wondering what's so special about the kernel that works.

>   > What compiler version are you using?  

gcc version 2.95.4 20011002 (Debian prerelease)

>   > Are you certain eth0 and eth1 didn't get reversed (i.e., check MAC
>     addresses or just try swapping cables)?

Oh, golly.  I knew it would be something simple.

I'll try that first thing in the morning.

You know what's so special about the kernel that works?  It has the driver
for one interface in the kernel and loads the other as a module, whereas
the other kernels have them both compiled in... and probably load them in
reverse order.

Damn.  I'll bet that's it.  It's something simple and I didn't try
swapping the cables.

>   > You could try a 2.5.x kernel.  I've got one (for x=21) running on
>     my home desktop.

Oh, I think we got it.  I'll let y'all know tomorrow.

J.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sat Jun 22 07:27:33 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat, 22 Jun 2002 07:27:33 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] rpm question
In-Reply-To: <20020622045454.6E13E10E055@pons.enet.sharplabs.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206220723220.1438-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On Fri, 21 Jun 2002, Dean S. Messing wrote:

> 
> How do I get a .rpm package to build from a .src.rpm
> using a particular "arhitechture".

See '--target' in the rpm man page. The syntax changed a bit somewhere 
in the 4.0.x release series. Depending on how 4.0.3 behaves, it's 
either

  rpm --rebuild --target=athlon whatever.src.rpm

or

  rpm --rebuild --target athlon whatever.src.rpm

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>





From jason at vancleve.com  Sat Jun 22 07:33:05 2002
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Sat, 22 Jun 2002 07:33:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] More Scripting Fun!
Message-ID: <20020622073305.77e80f0b.jason@vancleve.com>

Hi ho,

Me again, with a subtle bash befuddlement.  I want to allow a variable
to control how a command's output is redirected, so I figure I'll just
append the variable to the command, right?  If the variable is empty, no
problem; and if it contains ">& /dev/null", it should redirect all the
output into the Great Unknown, right?  Alas, it is not so.

I'm working with bash 2.05a, for your info, and I'm inside a function in
a script file, where I have this line:

	$COMMAND $* ${COMMAND_SUFFIX}

$COMMAND contains the path to apachectl, $* contains simply "start", and
$COMMAND_SUFFIX is defined thus:

	COMMAND_SUFFIX='>& /dev/null'

And the unexpected result is that apachectl spews out it's "usage:"
message twice in a row, apparently once for ">&" and once for
"/dev/null".  If, on the other hand, I substitute the presumably
equivalent line:

	$COMMAND $* >& /dev/null

then the command executes silently, as desired.  So I'm missing some
subtlety of variable expansion, because I'm at a complete loss with this
one.  What's going on here, and more importantly, is there a clean way
around this problem?  All I can think to do is to split $COMMAND_SUFFIX
into multiple variables.

What do you fellows make of this?

--Jason Van Cleve



From jason at vancleve.com  Sat Jun 22 08:43:00 2002
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Sat, 22 Jun 2002 08:43:00 -0700
Subject: Resolved: [PLUG] More Scripting Fun!
In-Reply-To: <20020622073305.77e80f0b.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20020622073305.77e80f0b.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <20020622084300.5581c024.jason@vancleve.com>

On Sat, 22 Jun 2002 07:33:05 -0700
Jason Van Cleve <jason at vancleve.com> wrote:

> Hi ho,

I think I've found my solution in the evil command--I mean, the eval
command (or built-in function or whatever it is):

	eval $COMMAND $* $COMMAND_SUFFIX

seems to do the trick.  I thought I had tried that already, but I must
have botched it the first time.  I still don't quite understand this
solution, but I suppose it must be an order of precedence thing.  Any
explanations are still welcome.

--Jason V. C.

gcc compatibility, compile/executable speed, flexibility, useful libs- 
anything at all. Is it worthy? If the cost did not matter, would you choose 
it over gcc? A developer working strictly on IA32/64 might find it to be the 
better tool for the job, as gcc is like one of those eleventy-nine thousand 
piece Sears toolkits. It's nice to have all those pieces, even though you'll 
never use them.

Intel makes much of optimizing for their instruction sets- how big a deal is 
this in the real world? One example: gcc supports pretty much all IA 
instruction sets, except SIMD, which Intel thinks is pretty important.

From dh at mda.huntbros.net  Sat Jun 22 18:30:35 2002
From: dh at mda.huntbros.net (dh at mda.huntbros.net)
Date: Sat, 22 Jun 2002 18:30:35 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Resolved: [PLUG] More Scripting Fun!
In-Reply-To: <20020622084300.5581c024.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0206221810270.16209-100000@mda.huntbros.net>

On Sat, 22 Jun 2002, Jason Van Cleve wrote:

>Date: Sat, 22 Jun 2002 08:43:00 -0700
>have botched it the first time.  I still don't quite understand this
>solution, but I suppose it must be an order of precedence thing.  Any
>explanations are still welcome.

Jason,

Your're right. It is because metacharacters are parsed before variable
expansion. Eval is a valid way to handle this, but only if you are quite
certain of the possible values of your variables. Eval on a var containing
"`rm -rf /`" could be devasting. Man bash and search for terms like
metacharacters, operators, pipelines, expansion, and eval.

-- 
David Hunt <dh at mda.huntbros.net>

> Unfortunately it looks like one of those stupid "buy millions of email
> addresses on cdrom" spam campaigns started this morning, and my email
> address (dgc at easystreet.com) is being forged as the from address. The only
> reason I know about it from a bounce message.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Jun 22 18:33:54 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat, 22 Jun 2002 18:33:54 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] OT Cell Phone and PDA
In-Reply-To: <B937B17E.3547%verso@mac.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206221829290.6203-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 20 Jun 2002, Kelly Guimont wrote:

> There are a number of products that have tried to do just such a thing. By
> and large these products fail primarily because you either get a gizzy that
> is a bit bigger than a comfy cell phone, and a bit smaller than a comfy PDA.
> It's one of the first gen of crossbreeding devices, and opinions on it are
> varied. For the most part people are content to carry two devices to get the
> full functionality out of each of them. Even now, items such as the Treo and
> a few other PhoneDAs are making some sort of sacrifice, and the trick is to
> find something that makes the sacrifice that you're willing to make.

Kelly,

  The convenience of carrying only one device, and having all phone numbers
instantly available for dialing, makes the slight size difference quite
tolerable.

  I've been using the Kyocera QPC-6035 (on Verizon Wireless) since last
December and I wouldn't consider going back to carrying two separate
devices. Yes, there are a couple of firmware bugs they're working on, and
I've still not figure out why I can't hold the ppp connection to my ISP from
my notebook using the Kyocera as a wireless modem, but all these issues will
be resolved in time.

  If you've sat there and entered a bunch of phone numbers and names, by
hand, into your cell phone, you'll appreciate sycing the unit to jpilot (or
whatever you use) and being able to call anyone in your addressbook,
regardless of which number you want to call.

  Yes, it's bleeding edge technology, but extremely useful and better than
the former method of carrying both. I'd almost always have the cell phone
with me, but not the Palm. Now I do.

Rich

> That would be preferable, but there are no windows systems around here,
> none of the addresses it bounced from I've ever sent mail to, etc.
> The big thing that makes me somewhat unsure is the subject line.  The
> headers from the original bounced message follows, with the first few lines
> of the body.
 
> > Received: from pool-63.49.204.158.troy.grid.net ([63.49.204.158] helo=helo)
> > 	by goose.mail.pas.earthlink.net with smtp (Exim 3.33 #2)
> > 	id 17LofV-0006MD-00; Sat, 22 Jun 2002 10:27:26 -0700

Dave,

  A couple of things.

  First, write to abuse at uu.net and tell them of the problem; that's where
the message originated:

[rshepard at salmo ~]$ whois 63.49.204.158 at whois.arin.net
[whois.arin.net]
UUNET Technologies, Inc. (NETBLK-NETBLK-UUNET97DU)
   3060 Williams Drive, Suite 601
   Fairfax, va 22031
   US

   Netname: NETBLK-UUNET97DU
   Netblock: 63.0.0.0 - 63.63.255.255
   Maintainer: UUDA

   Coordinator:
      UUNET, Technical Support  (OA12-ARIN)  help at uu.net
      800-900-0241

  Second, just because you've never sent someone an e-mail message doesn't
mean that your address isn't all over the 'Net. I get Klez virus messages
from folks I've never heard of. There are also a host of spam factories that
send my crap, er, UCE, claiming that I've 'opted in' to be spammed. They
share lists, by the way.

  I'd forward the message, with full headers of course, to uu.net with a
polite note asking them to take the appropriate actions to prevent you from
being spoofed by their customer in the future.

Rich

It also depends on how you've configured php at compile time (if you
compiled it yourself).  A phpinfo() will tell you where the active
php.ini file is located if you don't remember or it's in an odd
location.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sat Jun 22 21:02:51 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat, 22 Jun 2002 21:02:51 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] PHP question (fwd)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206221740220.5705-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206222057110.1438-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On Sat, 22 Jun 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> I don't use PHP myself -- never inhaled, so to speak. Could someone
> here please respond to Bill with the information he needs?

Bill,

In your httpd.conf file, you'll want to add something like

  php_flag expose_php on

If you're running a virtual-host setup, you can turn php boolean stuff 
on and off on a per-host basis. See section 3.2 of the online 
configuration document:

  http://www.php.net/manual/en/configuration.php

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

[snip] 

If by that you mean automatically making your 2nd hard drive available at boot, look to /etc/fstab. 

Your computer looks to /etc/fstab to determine what mounts where at boot time.

From CurtisE at CurtisE.net  Sun Jun 23 00:29:24 2002
From: CurtisE at CurtisE.net (CurtisE)
Date: Sun, 23 Jun 2002 00:29:24 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] SSH authentication problem
Message-ID: <GJELJBAKILGBFNJHBMKGIEOHCEAA.CurtisE@CurtisE.net>

Greetings,

I just installed OpenSSH on a RH6.2 box.  I can connect to it with a SSH
client, but can't login.  I get "Permission denied, please try again."  I'm
trying to use the password method of authentication and yes, I've tried many
times and I know I'm using the correct password.  I have even created
another test account with a much more simple password, just in case there is
some issue with special characters or some such nonsense.  The RH box is
using a shadow password file.

Any ideas?  Here is my sshd_config file:

Thanks,
CurtisE


#	$OpenBSD: sshd_config,v 1.53 2002/05/15 21:02:53 markus Exp $

# This is the sshd server system-wide configuration file.  See sshd(8)
# for more information.

# This sshd was compiled with
PATH=/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin:/usr/local/ssh/bin

# The strategy used for options in the default sshd_config shipped with
# OpenSSH is to specify options with their default value where
# possible, but leave them commented.  Uncommented options change a
# default value.

Port 22
Protocol 2,1
#ListenAddress 0.0.0.0
#ListenAddress ::

# HostKey for protocol version 1
# HostKey /usr/local/ssh/etc/ssh_host_key
# HostKeys for protocol version 2
# HostKey /usr/local/ssh/etc/ssh_host_rsa_key
# HostKey /usr/local/ssh/etc/ssh_host_dsa_key

# Lifetime and size of ephemeral version 1 server key
# KeyRegenerationInterval 3600
# ServerKeyBits 768

# Logging
# obsoletes QuietMode and FascistLogging
# SyslogFacility AUTH
# LogLevel INFO

# Authentication:

LoginGraceTime 600
PermitRootLogin no
# StrictModes yes

RSAAuthentication yes
# PubkeyAuthentication yes
# AuthorizedKeysFile	.ssh/authorized_keys

# rhosts authentication should not be used
# RhostsAuthentication no
# Don't read the user's ~/.rhosts and ~/.shosts files
# IgnoreRhosts yes
# For this to work you will also need host keys in
/usr/local/ssh/etc/ssh_known_hosts
# RhostsRSAAuthentication no
# similar for protocol version 2
# HostbasedAuthentication no
# Change to yes if you don't trust ~/.ssh/known_hosts for
# RhostsRSAAuthentication and HostbasedAuthentication
# IgnoreUserKnownHosts no

# To disable tunneled clear text passwords, change to no here!
PasswordAuthentication yes
# PermitEmptyPasswords no

# Change to no to disable s/key passwords
ChallengeResponseAuthentication yes

# Kerberos options
# KerberosAuthentication no
# KerberosOrLocalPasswd yes
# KerberosTicketCleanup yes

# AFSTokenPassing no

# Kerberos TGT Passing only works with the AFS kaserver
# KerberosTgtPassing no

# Set this to 'yes' to enable PAM keyboard-interactive authentication
# Warning: enabling this may bypass the setting of 'PasswordAuthentication'
PAMAuthenticationViaKbdInt yes

X11Forwarding yes
# X11DisplayOffset 10
# X11UseLocalhost yes
# PrintMotd yes
# PrintLastLog yes
# KeepAlive yes
# UseLogin no
# UsePrivilegeSeparation no

# MaxStartups 10
# no default banner path
# Banner /some/path
VerifyReverseMapping no

# override default of no subsystems
Subsystem	sftp	/usr/local/ssh/libexec/sftp-server




From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Jun 23 00:31:22 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun, 23 Jun 2002 00:31:22 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Adding hdd
In-Reply-To: <1024797038.3696.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206230004270.13765-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 22 Jun 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> Hello all. Would someone kindly step me through the automounting of my
> 2nd hdd at boot? Is it put in lilo.conf?

Cooper gave the quick and dirty answer, here, but I'm going to give you a
little more information because, if I'm reading you correctly, you could
use it.  If I confuse you, pretend I was trying to confuse you and making
things up and try to forget everything I wrote, then ask someone else.

lilo.conf is the configuration file for Lilo, the boot loader.  This
utility is used to choose a boot record for loading an operating system at
boot time.  Even DOS has a boot loader, it's just a really simple-minded
and arrogant one that assumes you couldn't possibly have another operating
system or would dream of deviating from the prescribed system
configuration, so it isn't configurable at all.

If you have access to all the operating systems you have installed and
each can be booted with relatively little pain and don't intend to move
any of the drives the main installation of those operating systems, you
don't have to touch lilo.conf.

It sounds like you have a second drive attached to your system already and
are manually mounting a partition from it when you need access, but want
it mounted automatically at boot time.

There is, as you probably guessed, a configuration file that defines which
disk partitions are mounted where in your filesystem.  The configuration
file is called fstab (on GNU/Linux systems) and it's usually located in
/etc.  It's often just parsed by a script that calls mount from the
(usually read-only) filesystem the kernel set up at boot time (based on
options in the boot loader).

If you want the straight-up shiznit on this file, you can probably just
run the following command: man fstab

If you don't care for that sort of thing and want to read my rambling, it
follows.

The standard /etc/fstab is a tab-delimited file of single-row records that
contain the following information in the following order:
<file system>	<mount point>	<type>	<options>	<dump><pass>

The "file system" is usually the device name where the filesystem to be
mounted resides.  This might be /dev/cdrom, /dev/md2, /dev/sda4,
/dev/hdc1, and so on.  It could also be a special keyword for a virtual
filesystem generated by another process or the kernel.  This might be proc
or devfs.

The "mount point" is the place where the root of the mounted filesystem
will join the rest of the filesystem.  Remember that in unix, drives are
fairly transparent to the user and the filesystem (and tools that access
it) doesn't really care how many drives of what type make up its
structure.  So if you want the path to the stuff on that particular disk
to be /usr/local, then that's your mount point.  Remember to make sure
that the mount point is on a filesystem that's already mounted.  That
means both makinig sure that the filesystem containing /usr is defined
previously in fstab and that local exists in that filesystem as a
directory.

"type" is the filesystem type.  That could be ext2, ext3, reiserfs, msdos,
vfat, or whatever.  It's how the partition was formatted.

The "options" vary from type to type and mount script to mount script.  
Probably you want "defaults".  One of the defaults is to automount at boot
time.  Overriding this option requires the "noauto" option.  That's most
often used for removable media that may not be present at boot time, but
has a specific, pre-defined mount point when it is present.

The "dump" field contains a 1 or a 0 to determine whether the filesystem
should be dumped by the dump(8) command.  0 will probably do.  Don't worry
about it.

"pass" is used by fsck at boot time to see when that particular filesystem
should be fscked.  The root filesystem (mounted at /) should be set to 1,
but that's the only hard, fast rule.  Other filesystems on the same
physical disk as the root should have sequential numbers, but filesystems
on different disks can have the same number because the fscks can happen
at the same time.  You probably shouldn't give any filesystem a pass
number of 1 other than the root partition, though, regardless of physical
location... just as a good practice.

Anyway, that's lots of information you don't need.

If any of it's wrong, somebody should tell me because that would mean I am
a big dummy who claims to know things he doesn't really know.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org




From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Jun 23 00:35:15 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun, 23 Jun 2002 00:35:15 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] SSH authentication problem
In-Reply-To: <GJELJBAKILGBFNJHBMKGIEOHCEAA.CurtisE@CurtisE.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206230032250.13765-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sun, 23 Jun 2002, CurtisE wrote:
> I just installed OpenSSH on a RH6.2 box.  I can connect to it with a
> SSH client, but can't login.  I get "Permission denied, please try
> again."

Can we see the output of a verbose session attempt?

Use your usual command line, but with the -v flag first.  Paste us the
output (with any sensitive information modified, of course).

And while I know diddly about Red Hat, I think I know that 6.2 is kind of
old and I wonder if the OpenSSH package you installed uses SSH v1 while
many servers are configured to respond only to v2 connections favorably.

This could also be a PAM configuration issue, so if you use PAM, you might
want to share that information as well.

Politely unhelpful,
J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------

 http://www.openlaw.org




From verso at mac.com  Sun Jun 23 01:10:26 2002
From: verso at mac.com (Kelly Guimont)
Date: Sun, 23 Jun 2002 01:10:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OT Cell Phone and PDA
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206221829290.6203-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <B93AD082.3649%verso@mac.com>

On 6/22/02 6:33 PM, "Rich Shepard" <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> wrote:

> On Thu, 20 Jun 2002, Kelly Guimont wrote:
> 
>> There are a number of products that have tried to do just such a thing. By
>> and large these products fail primarily because you either get a gizzy that
>> is a bit bigger than a comfy cell phone, and a bit smaller than a comfy PDA.
>> It's one of the first gen of crossbreeding devices, and opinions on it are
>> varied. For the most part people are content to carry two devices to get the
>> full functionality out of each of them. Even now, items such as the Treo and
>> a few other PhoneDAs are making some sort of sacrifice, and the trick is to
>> find something that makes the sacrifice that you're willing to make.
> 
> Kelly,
> 
> The convenience of carrying only one device, and having all phone numbers
> instantly available for dialing, makes the slight size difference quite
> tolerable.
> 
> I've been using the Kyocera QPC-6035 (on Verizon Wireless) since last
> December and I wouldn't consider going back to carrying two separate
> devices. Yes, there are a couple of firmware bugs they're working on, and
> I've still not figure out why I can't hold the ppp connection to my ISP from
> my notebook using the Kyocera as a wireless modem, but all these issues will
> be resolved in time.
> 
> If you've sat there and entered a bunch of phone numbers and names, by
> hand, into your cell phone, you'll appreciate sycing the unit to jpilot (or
> whatever you use) and being able to call anyone in your addressbook,
> regardless of which number you want to call.
> 
> Yes, it's bleeding edge technology, but extremely useful and better than
> the former method of carrying both. I'd almost always have the cell phone
> with me, but not the Palm. Now I do.
> 
> Rich


Rich, I fully appreciate the entry process, having to redo my phone more
than once when they went gunnysack on me. I know of what you speak. To quote
a public figure, I feel your pain. (:

I recognize that there are a faction like you out there, but an awful lot of
people out there aren't. In my pre-unemployed SIG days, I was working in an
area where wireless was being watched very closely. During this time there
was a survey done of people who carry such devices, and most said they'd
rather carry two great ones than one that was just ok. Even non-geeks saw
that the tech just wasn't there at the time. I think the Treo and the new
(very pretty) Nokia might be changing that. I'd be thrilled if they did. Now
if I could just convince Handspring to put out the Treo in translucent
colors and make it the teensiest bit curvier....<cough>macuser<cough>...

I also agree with you on the power button of your phone. I have a silent
ring option, which allows me to see who called without having to deal with
the phone, and if I do happen to have it on and it rings, I have two
choices: answer and ignore. Caller ID makes the decision very easy. Plus
even when my phone does ring, it's always on vibrate so I don't bother other
people.

I once overheard a call in a public restroom. That was the point at which I
realized not everyone can draw a line quite as clearly as I can.

I'm still excited that someone asked a question on the list that I had an
answer for! It's the little things, really...

-Kelly

I think it's the greatest tragedy committed on film since Greedo shot first.
-Chasing Amy




From bthoen at gisnet.com  Sun Jun 23 07:33:40 2002

Bingo! You got it in one, Brian (and thanks to Rich too.) I moved
php.ini up one directory to /usr/local/php (from
/usr/local/php/lib), restarted httpd, and everything worked as
advertised.

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Sun Jun 23 08:08:28 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 23 Jun 2002 08:08:28 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Resolved: [PLUG] More Scripting Fun!
References: <20020622073305.77e80f0b.jason@vancleve.com> <mailman.1024760600.11430.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86660avxqr.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Jason" == Jason Van Cleve <jason at vancleve.com> writes:

Jason> I think I've found my solution in the evil command--I mean, the eval
Jason> command (or built-in function or whatever it is):

Jason> 	eval $COMMAND $* $COMMAND_SUFFIX

No, this is dangerous.  If $* should expand to something with whitespace,
then you get two or more parameters where you had one before.

eval \$COMMAND \$* $COMMAND_SUFFIX

please.

-- 
Randal L. Schwartz - Stonehenge Consulting Services, Inc. - +1 503 777 0095
<merlyn at stonehenge.com> <URL:http://www.stonehenge.com/merlyn/>
Perl/Unix/security consulting, Technical writing, Comedy, etc. etc.
See PerlTraining.Stonehenge.com for onsite and open-enrollment Perl training!


From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Sun Jun 23 08:09:37 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 23 Jun 2002 08:09:37 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Resolved: [PLUG] More Scripting Fun!
References: <mailman.1024795881.21290.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <861yayvxou.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "dh" == dh  <dh at mda.huntbros.net> writes:

dh> Your're right. It is because metacharacters are parsed before variable
dh> expansion. Eval is a valid way to handle this, but only if you are quite
dh> certain of the possible values of your variables. Eval on a var containing
dh> "`rm -rf /`" could be devasting. Man bash and search for terms like
dh> metacharacters, operators, pipelines, expansion, and eval.

And my updates would protect Jason from that.

-- 
Randal L. Schwartz - Stonehenge Consulting Services, Inc. - +1 503 777 0095
<merlyn at stonehenge.com> <URL:http://www.stonehenge.com/merlyn/>
Perl/Unix/security consulting, Technical writing, Comedy, etc. etc.
See PerlTraining.Stonehenge.com for onsite and open-enrollment Perl training!


From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Sun Jun 23 08:07:30 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 23 Jun 2002 08:07:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] More Scripting Fun!
References: <mailman.1024756401.10334.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86adpmvxsd.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Jason" == Jason Van Cleve <jason at vancleve.com> writes:

Jason> 	$COMMAND $* ${COMMAND_SUFFIX}

Change that to:

    eval \$COMMAND \$* ${COMMAND_SUFFIX}

And all will be well.  Redirection operators are noticed before
variable substitution, so you can't *interpolate* one without backing
up a level with eval.

--

See PerlTraining.Stonehenge.com for onsite and open-enrollment Perl training!


From rseymour at spamcop.net  Sun Jun 23 08:32:16 2002
From: rseymour at spamcop.net (Richard Seymour)
Date: Sun, 23 Jun 2002 08:32:16 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Adding hdd
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206230004270.13765-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <3D15EA00.9050103@spamcop.net>

Good explanation Jeme. I'm going to quote it in FREE GEEK's computer 
building docs. Thanks.

A couple of minor additions / corrections:

Jeme A Brelin wrote:

 > lilo.conf is the configuration file for Lilo, the boot loader.  This
 > utility is used to choose a boot record for loading an operating
 > system at boot time.  Even DOS has a boot loader, it's just a really

Just for clarification, lilo is not the only boot loader you can use 
with linux. Another boot loader that is being used by several distros is 
called grub. The main configuration file you'd look for in grub is 
called menu.lst.

 > The standard /etc/fstab is a tab-delimited file of single-row records
 > that contain the following information in the following order:
 > <file system>	<mount point>	<type>	<options>	<dump><pass>

/etc/fstab is actually whitespace delimited. Tabs or spaces work equally 
well.

 > If any of it's wrong, somebody should tell me because that would mean
 > I am a big dummy who claims to know things he doesn't really know.


-- 
Are you hinting my apples aren't what they ought to be?

CHEEP GEEKS      Anarchy Software       FREE GEEK

From m at netpro.to  Sun Jun 23 10:12:24 2002

On Sun, 23 Jun 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

>
> On Sun, 23 Jun 2002, CurtisE wrote:
> > I just installed OpenSSH on a RH6.2 box.  I can connect to it with a
> > SSH client, but can't login.  I get "Permission denied, please try
> > again."
>
> This could also be a PAM configuration issue, so if you use PAM, you might
> want to share that information as well.

This would be my guess.  Did you use --with-pam when you ran the configure
script?  After compiling and installing, copy contrib/sshd.pam.generic to
/etc/pam.d/sshd.

Installing /usr/local/lib/perl/5.6.1/Term/ReadKey.pm
Installing /usr/local/man/man3/Term::ReadKey.3pm
Writing /usr/local/lib/perl/5.6.1/auto/Term/ReadKey/.packlist
Appending installation info to /usr/local/lib/perl/5.6.1/perllocal.pod





From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Sun Jun 23 17:46:42 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Sun, 23 Jun 2002 17:46:42 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Win98 -- overwrite?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206231355370.7823-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.31.0206231735000.1829-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Hi Pluggers -

I have a simple (but vital) question: Can I reinstall Windows 98 without
overwriting my other partitions using the win98 cd?

Specifically, I have a small vfat partition on my linux system, on which
Windows 98 is installed. I want to wipe the slate clean and
reinstall Windows 98, but I'm worried I'll overwrite my linux partitions
by doing so.

Anyway, if someone could give me the thumbs up for this I'd appreciate it.
I'm fairly certain the answer is 'yes' but I want to make sure...

Thanks,

Tyler

# /etc/fstab: static file system information.
#
# <file system> <mount point>   <type>  <options>                       <dump>  <pass>
/dev/hda5       /               ext3    defaults,errors=remount-ro      0
1
/dev/hda7       none            swap    sw                      0       0
/dev/hda1       /win            vfat    defaults                0 0
proc            /proc           proc    defaults                        0       0
/dev/fd0        /floppy         auto    defaults,user,noauto            0       0
/dev/cdrom      /cdrom          iso9660 defaults,ro,user,noauto         0       0
/dev/hda6       /home   ext2    defaults                        0       2




From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Sun Jun 23 17:57:08 2002
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Sun, 23 Jun 2002 17:57:08 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Win98 -- overwrite?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.31.0206231735000.1829-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206231355370.7823-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
        <Pine.GSO.4.31.0206231735000.1829-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <64672.12.231.181.15.1024880228.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>

> I have a simple (but vital) question: Can I reinstall Windows 98
> without overwriting my other partitions using the win98 cd?

As long as you don't do any fdisk-ing... The DOS format command should
only  make sense of a FAT16/FAT32 partition. The one gotcha might be Win98
stomping your bootloader. Heck, why would you want to use another OS,
anyways? ;-)
You might want to study up on your bootloader of choice and make a boot
floppy. Here's how to do it w/ GRUB.
http://www.gnu.org/manual/grub/html_mono/grub.html#Creating%20a%20GRUB%20boot%20floppy
-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District





From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Sun Jun 23 18:02:49 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Sun, 23 Jun 2002 18:02:49 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Win98 -- overwrite?
Message-ID: <1259720787.1024880558331.JavaMail.root@monkey>

Win98 does not always play well with others.

When I do this I create and test a linux boot disk, then record my
partition table info, and finally change the partition type on all the
linux partitions to something wierd.

This usually keeps Win98 from screwing things up.

You may also want to format the Win98 partition prior to the install so if
it asks about formatting during install you'll know something is wrong.

  -- Steve

From revans at e-z.net  Sun Jun 23 23:25:05 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Sun, 23 Jun 2002 23:25:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] directory diff/compare utility?
In-Reply-To: <20020623191255.V29056@kudzuforest.com>
References: <20020623184855.U29056@kudzuforest.com>
    <20020624020829.GA16108@zappa> <20020623191255.V29056@kudzuforest.com>
Message-ID: <20020624062250.RYPH11659.rwcrmhc53.attbi.com@downtown>

I don't understand what you are doing, so this may be a waste of your time and
I apologize if I lead you to a dead end.  

Worker is a two panel file manager, much like Gentoo, xtree from dos, and, I
think, midnight commander. On the third button panel there are a number for
diff buttons and one that is labeled dir-diff.	The way it works, I think,  is
you open a directory in the left panel and select all the files; in the right
panel, select another directory and select all the files there .  Click on the
clockbar to get to the third button panel and then click on the dir_diff
button. A xterm pops up and I believe a diff of the two is generated. If this
is saved or if you have to copy the output to a buffer, I don't know. 

There isn't anything on the Worker web site that explains what these buttons do
so the only way for you to know will be to install it and see if it works.
There are three buttons configured for diffs. Looking at the button commands in
the button configuration mode will probably tell you if this will work for you
if you don't want to run the command blindly. The variables passed to the diff
command are worker specific or I would post them here. Sorry again for not
knowing enough to tell you for sure, this what you are looking for.

I suggested Worker before and someone replied they were not able to compile it
on their box.  I didn't have a problem on a SuSE 8.0 install. When I came cross
it it was 2.4, it is now at 2.5., both compiled fine for me. There is a link
off of the Worker web site to a list of rpms at rpmfind. I included that link
below the Worker home page. 

http://www.boomerangsworld.de/worker/woverview.php3
http://www.rpmfind.net/linux/rpm2html/search.php?query=worker&submit=Search+...

Thank you
Russell

Permission denied, please try again.

debug1: authentications that can continue:
publickey,password,keyboard-interacti
ve
Permission denied, please try again.
curtise at elvis.home.curtise.net's password:
debug1: authentications that can continue:
publickey,password,keyboard-interacti
ve
debug1: no more auth methods to try
Permission denied (publickey,password,keyboard-interactive).
debug1: Calling cleanup 0x8061ad4(0x0)
[curtise at elvis curtise]$

--------------------------------------------------------------------------

Jeme and Matt may be onto something with PAM.  I did not use the
"--with-pam" option with the configure script.  I don't really know what PAM
is, but I noticed I do have a pam.d in /etc.  So I blew away SSH and
reconfigured with the "--with-pam" option and copied
contrib/sshd.pam.generic to /etc/pam.d/sshd.  Then I had some other issues
many of which I resolved by reconfiguring with the "--with-ipv4-default"
option also.  I've also reverted to the stock sshd_config file with the
exception of the "PAMAuthenticationViaKbdInt yes" line which I uncommented
and changed to yes.

Now I cannot connect, but at least I'm getting some clues as to why.  I'm
not sure what to make of the clues though.  Here's what I get when I run
sshd in diagnostic mode:

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

[root at elvis openssh-3.3p1]# sshd -d
debug1: sshd version OpenSSH_3.3
debug1: private host key: #0 type 0 RSA1
debug1: read PEM private key done: type RSA
debug1: private host key: #1 type 1 RSA
debug1: read PEM private key done: type DSA
debug1: private host key: #2 type 2 DSA
debug1: Bind to port 22 on 0.0.0.0.
Server listening on 0.0.0.0 port 22.
Generating 768 bit RSA key.
RSA key generation complete.
debug1: Server will not fork when running in debugging mode.
Connection from 127.0.0.1 port 1098
debug1: Client protocol version 2.0; client software version OpenSSH_3.3
debug1: match: OpenSSH_3.3 pat OpenSSH*
Enabling compatibility mode for protocol 2.0
debug1: Local version string SSH-1.99-OpenSSH_3.3
mmap(65536): Invalid argument
debug1: Calling cleanup 0x8069218(0x0)

------------------------------------------------------------------------

Notice the "mmap(65536): Invalid argument" message in the second to the last
line.
>From what I can gather from the mmap man page, it's trying to grab some
memory and failing for some mysterious reason.

Here is what I get on the client side when attempting to connect in verbose
mode now:

------------------------------------------------------------------------

[curtise at elvis curtise]$ ssh -v -l curtise elvis
OpenSSH_3.3, SSH protocols 1.5/2.0, OpenSSL 0x0090604f
debug1: Reading configuration data /usr/local/ssh/etc/ssh_config
debug1: Rhosts Authentication disabled, originating port will not be
trusted.
debug1: ssh_connect: needpriv 0
debug1: Connecting to elvis [127.0.0.1] port 22.
debug1: Connection established.
debug1: identity file /home/curtise/.ssh/identity type -1
debug1: identity file /home/curtise/.ssh/id_rsa type -1
debug1: identity file /home/curtise/.ssh/id_dsa type -1
debug1: Remote protocol version 1.99, remote software version OpenSSH_3.3
debug1: match: OpenSSH_3.3 pat OpenSSH*
Enabling compatibility mode for protocol 2.0
debug1: Local version string SSH-2.0-OpenSSH_3.3
debug1: SSH2_MSG_KEXINIT sent
Read from socket failed: Broken pipe
debug1: Calling cleanup 0x80619b8(0x0)

--------------------------------------------------------------------------

Notice the "Read from socket failed: Broken pipe" message in the second to
the last line.

The messages log just gripes about the same mmap issue:
"Jun 24 01:39:33 elvis sshd[32261]: fatal: mmap(65536): Invalid argument"

So, it would appear (to my untrained eyes) that this mmap issue is the
source of my current problem.  Does this ring any bells with you folks.
This is well above my level of Linux knowledge.

The only thing I can think of at this point is so go back to OpenSSH version
3.2.3p1 which is the version I originally used.  The one I have now is from
a fresh download and it looks like it's a newer version (3.3).  Perhaps 3.3
has some sort of memory bug...

I would sure appreciate any additional ideas.

Thanks,
CurtisE




>Can we see the output of a verbose session attempt?

>Use your usual command line, but with the -v flag first.  Paste us the
>output (with any sensitive information modified, of course).

>And while I know diddly about Red Hat, I think I know that 6.2 is kind of
>old and I wonder if the OpenSSH package you installed uses SSH v1 while
>many servers are configured to respond only to v2 connections favorably.

>This could also be a PAM configuration issue, so if you use PAM, you might
>want to share that information as well.
