From n6jpa at attbi.com  Sat Jun 29 21:11:27 2002
From: n6jpa at attbi.com (Keith)
Date: Sat, 29 Jun 2002 21:11:27 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] What's the deal with the unsigned site?
In-Reply-To: <JEVUOLF051V4MIOK829706NH1T0886.3d1e7b1e@miked>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206292104490.24138-100000@Computer>

On Sat, 29 Jun 2002, Mike De La Mater wrote:

> When I click on the "Mailing Lists" link on the http://pdxlinux.org  site I get an
> error about a bad certificate. It doesn't matter which browser I use.
>
> Why does it do that, and is there a way to make it easier to trust the link for the
> uninitiate? None of the other links require you to accept the certificate.
>

 The way it works if you want the big guys to sign your certificate for "web
security" they want you to pay a few thousand dollars. If you have your own
certificate then you can sign that certificate. The traffic is still
encrypted and is just as safe as if the big guys signed the certificate.
 Of course, most web security is a joke since many of these web sites
let that secure data they receive sit on their HD unencrypted and that
is why you always hear about stolen credit cards from web sites in the news.

 I don't think you have to worry about people stealing your email address
from the plug mail list since we already have it when you sent this email.

;)
YMMV


-- 
Best Regards,  Keith
NW Oregon Radio http://n6jpa.home.attbi.com/ Church of the Bourne Again
Shell. Tux, Save us from the evil Gates of Hell! http://linux.com
http://freebsd.org http://apple.com





From gherteg at herteg.net  Sat Jun 29 21:18:55 2002
From: gherteg at herteg.net (Geoffrey Herteg)
Date: Sat, 29 Jun 2002 21:18:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Thinkpad, Linux
In-Reply-To: <3d1e77d2.2d16.0@pcez.com>
References: <3d1e77d2.2d16.0@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <20020630041854.GA29740@valinux.com>

Hey Stuart.

I'm running two Thinkpads (a 570E and a T20) dual-booted using Lilo on
the T20 and Grub on the 570E.  Both worked fine out of the box though
the Savage IX in the T20s on up seem to need XFree86 4.1+ to work right.

The sound chips in them are CS46xx.  I think Alan Cox has support in the
latest 2.2.x kernel but I use 2.4.18, which has the drivers.  ALSA also
works well with these chips.

The latest models also appear to use the Intel EtherExpress Pro 100.  I
think the ones with 802.11b look pretty tasty, but haven't used one.
But the Prism based cards (Orinoco, etc) work great with both so far.

There's a binary only driver for their modems out there.  It's a Lucent
something or other.  Works fine, dialed up several times with it without
problems.

Open/StarOffice has one issue: you need to set an environment variable
(SAL_DO_NOT_USE_INVERT50="true") before you can run it or the installer
(something to do with the X server).  If you don't, the framebuffer
locks up and only a cold reboot will let you use it again.  Took me
forever to find that little gem (but it's in the O/SOffice README.  Go
figure).

As for the windows side, you can fdisk the drive into two or more
partitions and install Windows again with IBM's recovery disk without a
hitch.  Drivers and apps restored, none the wiser.  Lilo and Grub both
get you into Windows fine.

Hope this brain dump helps a little in the decision.  Drop a line if you
need something specific clarified.

- Geoffrey

From cmoore at hellyeah.org  Sat Jun 29 22:23:44 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Free Hardware Update
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206292207350.3237-100000@lunchbox.hellyeah.org>

	Ok.  Now that Jeme and I have moved all of the stuff that I want
to keep out of the apartment, here is a list of the hardware that's
left.  If no one wants it it will be donated to portland waste managment
as I will no longer have the use of a truck after tonight.

9 HP Vectra workstations.  Most have no hard drive.  They make really good
floppyfw boxes.  I'm actually using one for my firewall.  Ok, that's not
exactly true.  Now that i'm on Jemes network (god help me) I dont need
one.

Two mac quadra 605's.  I _think_ netbsd will run on them.  I'm not sure
though.

One stock mac monitor. 14"

1 486 dx with an unknown ammount of ram and drive space.  Currently loaded
with NetBSD 1.4.

3 mac IIx machines again with unknown ammounts of disk and ram.

1 14" Mag monitor.  I used it for a portable head for servers.  It's a
little fuzzy.

Lots of older scsi cards, i think the video capture card (not sure which
chipset) is around here.  There's a voodoo 1 card for a pci mac here as
well.

This is all stuff that I used to use and I would really like to see it go
to a good home.  I just flat refuse to move it all again.

Leave a message at 236-3930 if you want to check the stuff out.  Deadline
is Sunday night.

-cm

From joncoulsey at attbi.com  Sat Jun 29 23:29:08 2002
From: joncoulsey at attbi.com (Jon Coulsey)
Date: 29 Jun 2002 23:29:08 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Thinkpad, Linux
In-Reply-To: <E17OVVL-0005CJ-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <E17OVVL-0005CJ-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <1025418549.2342.11.camel@madison_b>

On Sat, 2002-06-29 at 20:35, plug-request at lists.pdxlinux.org wrote:

> 
> Now that I have a job again, I am going to buy a new Thinkpad and dual-boot it
> with RH Linux. 

Nice!!

> 
> Wanted to check with the Linux community to see what pitfalls this newbie needs
> to be mindful of regarding Linux on laptops and dual-booting. I've installed
> RH & Mandrake on my 2 home systems with no glitches.
>
> But the Thinkpad -- and I'm not certain which model yet -- it's got all these
> optional components and things like the "Ultrabay."  I wonder if installing
> Linux is going to be painful as a result.
> 
> Their budget machine runs an Intel Celeron -- is there any downside to that
> as far as Linux goes?  Does any particular distro have an advantage over the
> others in terms of running on Thinkpads?

I run RH 7.3 on a 600E and the only thing that was even a little tricky
was getting the sound working. Other than that, everything pretty much
just works. I am still having a little trouble suspending to disk, but
that is mostly for lack of a real try on my part. I have also heard of
modem issues with the mwave modems IBM uses, but I haven't tried making
it work and there is documentation out there on the issue. 

As for the Ultrabay, I use it with a cd drive, floppy drive, and second
battery; all with no problems.

I use http://www.linux-laptop.net quite a bit if I get in trouble
anywhere, there is some great documentation there. It is nice that there
is plenty of documentation out there on running linux on thinkpads.

Good luck.

Jon
joncoulsey at attbi.com

> 
> I'm be using the system for business stuff.
> 
> Thanks!
> 
> -------------------
> http://www.pcez.com
> 
>

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sun Jun 30 06:19:34 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sun, 30 Jun 2002 06:19:34 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Free Hardware Update
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0206300300410.394-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206300608090.1441-100000@billings.heinlein.net>

On Sun, 30 Jun 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> > It's just a desktop PC.  Vectra is what HP called their desktops
> > for a while.  Vectra is the model name.  Now they call their
> > desktops "Pavilion".
> 
> Actually, I'm pretty sure the Pavillions are the home models and the
> Vectras are still the corporate boxes.

*nod*

I've got a small-footprint Vectra on my desk at work. It's a basic
putty-colored box, approx. 13" (w) x 16" (d) x 4" (h).  
Performance-wise, it's indistinguishable from all the other x86 boxes
put out by Dell, etc.

Its prime virtue is that it's really, really quiet. Man, I love not
being able to hear my PC.

I hear that, with the merger, the Vectra is being phased out in favor 
of the Compaq Evo.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

disable Red Hat's kudzu hardware detection during boot up. It
wanted to go through the whole remove-this-add-that scenario
every  time I booted with a different Ultrabay device.

From rseymour at spamcop.net  Sun Jun 30 06:51:17 2002

Message-ID: <3D1F0CD5.4000603@spamcop.net>

Clint Moore wrote:
 > 9 HP Vectra workstations.  Most have no hard drive.  They make really
 > good floppyfw boxes.  I'm actually using one for my firewall.  Ok,
 > that's not exactly true.  Now that i'm on Jemes network (god help me)
 > I dont need one.

 > This is all stuff that I used to use and I would really like to see it
 > go to a good home.  I just flat refuse to move it all again.

 > Leave a message at 236-3930 if you want to check the stuff out.
 > Deadline is Sunday night.

If anyone can get the 9 vectras to FREE GEEK, we'd love them. It looks 
like version 2 of the FreekBox will first go out on the Vectras.

We have about 80 or so of them (of varying CPU speeds) ready for 
evaluation in our storage. This makes them nice for mass rebuilding, and 
when we can solve the rail problem (need to put CD ROMs in practically 
all of them), we'll probably be testing them, cleaning them, loading 
them with a woody based FreekBox distro and giving them out to our members.

Nine more would be great.


By the way, we'd take all the stuff (need to collect $10 per monitor) 
and all would either be reused or recycled.




From john at cryptowave.com  Sun Jun 30 09:10:24 2002

Subject: [PLUG] What's the deal with the unsigned site?
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0206292104490.24138-100000@Computer>
Message-ID: <3D1F2D70.5090306@cryptowave.com>

Keith wrote:

>On Sat, 29 Jun 2002, Mike De La Mater wrote:
>
>>When I click on the "Mailing Lists" link on the http://pdxlinux.org  site I get an
>>error about a bad certificate. It doesn't matter which browser I use.
>>
>>Why does it do that, and is there a way to make it easier to trust the link for the
>>uninitiate? None of the other links require you to accept the certificate.
>>
>
> The way it works if you want the big guys to sign your certificate for "web
>security" they want you to pay a few thousand dollars. If you have your own
>certificate then you can sign that certificate. The traffic is still
>encrypted and is just as safe as if the big guys signed the certificate.
> Of course, most web security is a joke since many of these web sites
>let that secure data they receive sit on their HD unencrypted and that
>is why you always hear about stolen credit cards from web sites in the news.
>
> I don't think you have to worry about people stealing your email address
>from the plug mail list since we already have it when you sent this email.
>
>;)
>YMMV
>
>

A few thousand dollars?! Geotrust has them for $50...
It's typically around $100/year

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sun Jun 30 19:55:10 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)

Message-ID: <86d6u8cg35.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "John" == John H <john at cryptowave.com> writes:

John> try doing an strace ex: strace ./setup

Or, perhaps more usefully: strace -f -o /tmp/strace-oo-setup setup

Then look at the resulting log in /tmp/strace-oo-setup, the name of
which is, of course, completely arbitrary.

I sit corrected.  Good catch.  Having not seen any Vectras in many moons,
and having seen many Pavilions (in retail outlets), I assumed HP changed the
model name of their desktops.  It did not occur to me that one is their
commercial line and one is their residential line.

It's been many cycles since I worked someplace that used HP desktops, other
than the Kyak Workstations - even that's been a couple of years now.  Come
to think of it, the last time I worked much with Vectra PCs was about the
time of the P75-P90 - the same vintage as the ones Clint is getting rid of.
Having not seen any Vectras in many moons, and having seen many Pavilions
(in retail outlets), I assumed HP changed the model name of their desktops.
It did not occur to me that one was their commercial line and one their
residential line.

CurtisE
